HEADLINE: Thomas H. Jacobsen, 62, St. Louis Banker 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, July 23 

 BODY:
Thomas H. Jacobsen, who led the Mercantile Bancorporation as it became one of the Midwest's largest banking companies before merging with Firstar, died on Saturday. He was 62. 
 The cause was leukemia, according to U.S. Bancorp, which merged with Firstar in 2000. 
 When it joined the Firstar Corporation in 1999, Mercantile, based in St. Louis, had $36 billion in assets and operated banks in nearly 500 places in Missouri, Iowa, Kansas, Illinois, Arkansas and Kentucky.
Born in Chicago, Mr. Jacobsen graduated from Lake Forest University and received an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago.
Before coming to St. Louis in 1989, he was vice president of First National Bank of Chicago and vice chairman of the board of Barnett Banks Inc. of Florida.
He joined Mercantile as chief executive in March 1989 and led the corporation to record earnings, with profits increasing from $500,000 in 1989 to more than $500 million in 1998. 
He led Mercantile into the merger with Firstar in 1999.
Mr. Jacobsen was a director of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis and president of the Federal Reserve Advisory Council, which represents the industry in advising Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, on monetary policy.
Survivors include his wife of 17 years, Diane DeMell Jacobsen; and a brother, Robert Jacobsen of Evanston, Ill.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Primedia to name an editorial director of sweeping scope.

BYLINE:  By David Carr 

 BODY:
PRIMEDIA is expected to announce this morning that Elizabeth Crow, a well-traveled magazine executive, has become editorial director of the company's consumer magazine and media group, which includes Seventeen and New York magazine, along with such hobbyist magazines as Kitplanes and Car Craft.
 In the newly created position, Ms. Crow, who most recently served as editorial director of the women's health group at Rodale, will oversee the editorial operations of Primedia's more than 150 consumer magazines, Internet operations and television programs. 
 Tom Rogers, the chief executive of Primedia, said Ms. Crow's comprehensive experience across a broad array of magazines made her an attractive addition.
"We couldn't ask for a person whose skills map any better with what our properties do," Mr. Rogers said. "She brings a track record of editorial excellence that will help make sure our core magazines are well differentiated and well positioned."
Ms. Crow has worked on both the editorial and publishing sides of the magazine business. She is the former chief executive of Gruner & Jahr USA, the owner of YM and Parents, and a former editor of Mademoiselle, which was published by Conde Nast Publications and has since ceased publication.
Ms. Crow, who took 2000 off to paint and write fiction before joining Rodale, said she took the Primedia job because of scale.
"When I was offered this job, I said, 'This is huge,' " she said. "I think I can exponentially leverage the experience I have. It is just a gigantic, wonderful job."
She will report to David Ferm, who recently became president of the consumer division after running the business-to-business group, a division of the company that has suffered mightily in a punishing ad market.
"It is our first editorial consumer director," Mr. Ferm said. "It presents a pretty significant opportunity for refreshing, repositioning and renovating these titles." Both Mr. Rogers and Mr. Ferm said Craig Reiss, an executive hired in a similar role at the business-to-business division, had been successful in improving editorial results there.
Ms. Crow said she was going to become involved in the day-to-day operations of magazine-making by intensely studying each of the company's products.
"I am a magazine doctor," she said. "And as a magazine doctor, what I do is become the best reader you ever had."
Ms. Crow joins a company that is in need of some rehabilitation. Primedia has been battered by the stock market.
Investors, concerned about its long-term debt load of about $2 billion and some questionable Internet-related acquisitions, including About.com, bid the company's stock down to a 52-week low of 95 cents during intraday trading yesterday. The stock closed at $1.01.
Primedia is hoping the overlay of a comprehensive editorial strategy will help draw readers and by extension create a more attractive environment for advertisers. While many of the company's special-interest publications are performing decently during this ad recession, some of the company's larger magazines, like Seventeen, are losing market share to their competitors. 
The hiring of Ms. Crow, however, may not be universally popular with people on the editorial side of the company who may resent another layer of management above them. Experienced editors who run some of the bigger magazines -- Caroline Miller at New York and Annemarie Iverson at Seventeen -- may not feel like they need additional oversight. 
But Ms. Crow said: "I love editors and art directors. I think that they should thank their lucky stars that I am between them and the purse strings."

HEADLINE: Retreat From Stocks Lifts Bond Prices 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury prices increased yesterday, driving two-year yields to record lows as more stock market losses sent investors into government bonds. 
 A late swoon in equities pushed bond prices higher and their yields, which move in the opposite direction, mostly lower. 
 The yield on the Treasury's two-year note dropped yesterday to 2.24 percent, down from 2.34 percent, on Monday and surpassing the low of 2.31 percent in November.
"As long as the equity market continues its free fall," said James Caron, fixed-income strategist at Merrill Lynch Government Securities, "people are going to price in the fact that the Federal Reserve may have to cut interest rates to help boost the equity market."
The yield on the 10-year note dropped yesterday to 4.42 percent from 4.45 percent on Monday, as the price rose 6/32, to 103 17/32.
Yield on the 30-year note was unchanged at 5.28 percent, as the price rose 1/32, to 101 13/32.

HEADLINE: Out of Stocks and Into What? Land, Cashand Bonds, That's What 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT and JENNIFER BAYOT 

 BODY:
Some people have temporarily turned to cash as a safe haven. Others are hoping that real estate or bonds will be the coming decade's version of a can't-miss investment.
 Though most investors seem to be nervously holding to their belief that shares in American companies remain the best long-term investment, many others are looking for alternatives as the worst bear market in a generation deepens almost every day. 
 Deposits in money market funds and savings accounts have soared. Mutual funds made up of bonds, after years of being viewed as inherently inferior to stock funds, are stealing money from their rivals. Housing sales remain brisk, and people have begun increasing their spending on remodeling after a lull late last year. 
"I don't want to try to pick the market's bottom," said Adam Slone, 37, the president of a small executive search firm in Washington, who recently bought a bigger house than he had planned rather than investing money in the stock market. "I decided to be a little more conservative with my money."
From the start of June through July 17, investors sold about $46 billion more of mutual funds filled with stocks than they bought, according to Banc of America Securities. The $46 billion represents almost 1.5 percent of all stock mutual funds held in the United States. Barring a turnaround in the final week of this month, the redemption will be the largest over a two-month period since 1990. 
Whenever stocks declined during the long bull market of the 1990's, investors confidently bought shares, helping to create one of the biggest bubbles of the last century. The fall of the broad market by almost half since early 2000 has left many people questioning stocks, at least over the short term, for the first time in their lives.
So far, however, most are not abandoning them, turning instead to cash, in the form of money market funds and savings accounts, probably until they think the turmoil has ended. Money market funds captured more than three-quarters of the money that flowed out of stock mutual funds during the week ended July 17, Banc of America said.
Over the last year, the value of savings accounts has grown 22 percent, to $2.5 trillion, according to the Federal Reserve. The recent increases appear to be the largest since at least 1959, said Mark Zandi, the chief economist of Economy .com, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa.
Many of these investments offer a return of about 1 percent a year, roughly equal to the current level of inflation.
"That's earning peanuts, absolute peanuts," said David Cole, 53, a film producer in Morro Bay, Calif., who stopped buying stocks last year and moved some money into cash. "But that's better than getting losses."
Many people are able to remain sanguine about the market's drop because their homes are worth far more than their market investments, and housing prices have continued to rise smartly nationwide. A typical middle-class family has about 60 percent of its wealth tied up in its house and about 20 percent in pensions, 401(k) plans and other stocks, according to Edward Wolff, an economist at New York University.
Now, some people are increasing their real estate holdings. 
In the second quarter of this year, as the S.& P. 500-stock index was reversing its gains of last winter, the amount of money people spent on remodeling their homes -- from fixing roofs to renovating kitchens -- began rising. In the 12 months ended June 30, Americans spent $113.8 billion on such projects, up from $106.7 billion in the 12 months ended March 31, according to the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard.
Only a small part of that money probably came directly from stock sales, said Kermit Baker, director of the center's remodeling studies program, but the falling market made people more willing to improve their houses, hoping they would be increasing their value at the same time. With housing prices rising, "you don't need to spend much time justifying the expenditures on your home," Mr. Baker said.
Housing prices -- and the amount of real estate investing -- have also been helped by mortgage rates that have dropped in the last three months. Last week, the average 30-year fixed mortgage rate was 6.54 percent a year, close to the three-decade low of 6.42 percent that it reached in November before rising early this year, according to Bankrate.com.
Most housing statistics are more than a month old and therefore offer little evidence of the effect that the recent market downturn has had on home buying. But investment advisers and real estate agents say that some affluent people selling stocks have used the proceeds to buy second homes in vacation centers.
"Over the last three months, we've seen a huge increase in the second-home market," said Ken Brunt, who tracks the market for EscapeHomes in Orinda, Calif. Mr. Brunt said traffic on his company's Web site and requests for referrals had each doubled since last year, with most of that growth in the last five months. He attributes people's interest to "a much greater awareness of the option to move directly out of the stock market" and into second-home investments. 
The unquestioning belief in housing prices has also raised some fears, however, that the real estate market could be following the path of once-celebrated technology stocks. 
"It scares me that it might be in a bubble," said Harold Evensky, the chairman of Evensky, Brown & Katz, a financial planning company in Coral Gables, Fla. "We've had a lot of clients buying property in Colorado."
Relatively few investors seem to share Mr. Evensky's concern, however. 
Philip Sheinbein, a venture capitalist in Phoenix, and his three younger siblings recently bought a vacation home in Park City, Utah, for $345,000, and they have reduced the part of their portfolio in stocks to less than 10 percent, from about 50 percent in 2000. 
"We're taking a fourth look and fifth look at everything," Mr. Sheinbein said, "whereas before we would have just taken a second look."
Mr. Sheinbein said he had also bought more bonds recently, and he has a great deal of company. 
Investors bought about $110 billion more of bond mutual funds than they sold from July 2001 to June 2002, bringing their total holdings to more than $1 trillion. In the previous two years -- when many investors liked to recite statistics about bonds always trailing stocks over the long term -- they sold a net $45 billion in such funds, according to the Investment Company Institute, a trade group for mutual fund companies.
As a group, however, investors do not appear to be making large transfers of money from one type of stock mutual fund to another. 
Investment in mutual funds made up of overseas stocks, which have fallen about as much as United States equities this year but remain less dearly priced relative to their earnings, has fallen marginally recently, for example. And in the two weeks that ended July 17, people took money out of all the major categories of mutual funds followed by Banc of America except one: gold and natural resources.
But the declines have not been nearly as drastic as the fall in stock prices, suggesting that the bull market of 1982 to 2000 remains as much a part of people's outlook as the recent bear market. 
"We haven't seen a lot taken out," said James P. Gorman, president of Merrill Lynch's retail business. "People have become used to the fact that this is a difficult market environment."
Above all, people seem to have adjusted the time frame over which they expect to make money in the stock market and shed the cockiness of the late 90's.
"I realized that single stocks are gambling; it's like going to the casino," said Mario Ruiz, 46, a consultant to the music industry who lives in Miramar, Fla., and lost about half of the $250,000 he had invested in Cisco Systems, Philip Morris, WorldCom and other companies two years ago.
"But do I believe in mutual funds for the long run? Absolutely," Mr. Ruiz said. "They've taken a drop, I know that. But I don't need that money now. In another 20 years, I think it will come back."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
MARKETS CONTINUE DOWNWARD TREND; BANKS LEAD WAY

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS and JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks fell again yesterday as concerns grew about the fate of telecommunications and energy trading companies and as Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill traveled to Wall Street to discuss the markets and economy with senior brokerage executives.
 On a day when news from Washington dominated the market, banks and energy stocks were hurt by the latest revelations regarding the Enron investigation, with officials of Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase defending their banks at a Senate hearing against accusations they had helped Enron cover up the extent of its debt. Those two stocks accounted for most of the 1.1 percent decline in the Dow Jones industrial average. Page C1. 
 By the end of the day, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index had fallen 2.7 percent, to a five-year low. And the Nasdaq composite index was off 4.2 percent, leaving it down more than 75 percent from the peak it reached less than two and a half years ago. 
"The investor is simply becoming more risk averse," said Frederick B. Taylor, chief investment officer at the United States Trust Company. "You are no longer playing with the house's money; this is real money, so preserve what you have."
Mr. O'Neill, who had faced criticism for his international travels while the stock market was plunging, had little to say publicly after he met with a few senior Wall Street executives in the morning and then had lunch with a larger group of investment strategists and economists at the New York Federal Reserve Bank.
"We had a wonderful lunch," he told reporters.
In the morning, according to people briefed on the meeting, Mr. O'Neill sat down with Philip J. Purcell, the chairman and chief executive of Morgan Stanley; David H. Komansky, chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch; John Thain, co-president of the Goldman Sachs Group; and Stephen R. Volk, chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston.
They discussed the state of the economy, markets and investor confidence, these people said. One of them said that after hearing Mr. O'Neill's views, one Wall Street executive recommended that the Bush administration tone down its language on corporate misconduct because it clearly had not helped the markets. He did not disclose what Mr. O'Neill had said.
The Senate hearing also damaged shares of many energy companies, whose accounting is again being challenged. The Dow Jones utility average, which is dominated by electric utilities and includes some of the energy trading companies, fell 17.81 points, to 191.85, a drop of 8.5 percent. That was the steepest one-day decline for that index since the 1987 crash and left it at a seven-year low. That index has fallen 30 percent this month.
Reliant Energy, a member of the utility index, fell $5.77, to $7.90, after Senate investigators said it was among the companies that Citigroup's Salomon Smith Barney unit had suggested use transactions similar to ones used by Enron.
Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the subcommittee that held a hearing on the role of banks in the Enron debacle, said he wanted to know the extent to which major financial institutions "knew of and aided Enron's accounting deceptions." Citigroup fell $5.04, or almost 16 percent, to $27, while J. P. Morgan Chase dropped $4.44, or 18 percent, to $20.08, trading at its lowest value since 1996.
Telephone stocks also dropped, with AT&T falling 72 cents, to $8.80, and trading at its lowest levels since the 1987 crash after it reported a record loss. Disappointing earnings news also came from SBC Communications, which dropped 66 cents, to $23.30, and Lucent Technologies, which fell 45 cents, to $1.65.
Early in the day, it appeared that Wall Street's string of losing days might be coming to an end. Stock index futures, which trade overnight while the stock market is closed, were up sharply, and the Dow managed to shoot up almost 110 points in early trading. But that gain soon faded, and the index ended down 82.24 points, at 7,702.34, its lowest close since September 1998.
The performance of the futures -- a market that is dominated by professional traders -- reflected the inability of many on Wall Street to believe that prices can keep going down and down. Ever since the market recovered from the 1987 crash, investors have been willing to step in and buy when prices fall, but that willingness seems to have vanished.
Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, rarely ventures into discussing stock prices. But in an interview with Bloomberg News yesterday, he noted that the S.& P. 500 was approaching the decline of 48.2 percent in the 1973-74 bear market, which was the worst decline since the Depression.
"We've just about matched that," Mr. Grasso said. "So I'm very optimistic that we're either at the bottom or very, very close to it." At yesterday's close, the S.& P. was off 47.8 percent from its peak in early 2000.
The failure of the Dow to finish the day up, leaving it with 11 losses over the last 12 trading sessions, could leave investors more worried about the outlook, even though the day's loss of 82 points was far less than the 234-point decline Monday and the 390-point plunge Friday. The fact that foreign stock markets also continued to fall yesterday is making more investors worry about the possibility that the American and other economies are slowing down or even falling back into a recession.
"Investors are beginning to think that the stock market will lead the economy into a slowdown," Mr. Taylor said.
Similarly, Donald Straszheim, an economist who runs his own advisory firm, warned that "the most serious risk at present" was that the stock market decline would begin to hurt spending by both consumers and businesses, as well as housing prices.
Cyclical stocks, which had been very weak in recent days as economic worries seemed to grow, rallied in the morning but gave up all their gains by the end of the day.
Henry Herrmann, the chief investment officer of Waddell & Reed, a money management firm in Overland Park, Kan., said even though there were some bargains, investors were not interested. "Things are a lot cheaper now, and there is a lot more to buy," he said. "But catching a falling knife is a bit of a problem. The market is still uncertain."
The stocks of big technology companies were also weak, with Microsoft, Cisco Systems, Applied Materials, Intel and Dell Computer dragging the Nasdaq lower. Microsoft, which fell $3.28, to $43.01, reached an 18-month low.
That helped push the Nasdaq down 53.60 points, or 4.2 percent, to 1,229.05, its lowest close since April 1997. The broader S.& P. 500 lost 22.15 points, or 2.7 percent, to 797.70, its first close below 800 since May 1, 1997, and its lowest close since April 29, 1997. 
Stock markets in Europe were up before New York trading began but fell when it became clear that the American market was not going to rally. The worst performance was turned in by the main German index, which fell nearly 5 percent.
The dollar, which had been weak most of the period when American stocks were falling in recent weeks, rallied, and the euro fell below $1, settling at 98.65 cents in New York trading. That could reflect a bit more optimism among foreign investors about American investments.

HEADLINE: Latin Companies Are Bargain Hunting in A rgentina 

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 23 

 BODY:
Many North American and European companies in Argentina are still licking the wounds they suffered as the country's economy, South America's second largest, collapsed around them. But some Brazilian and Mexican companies have been waiting for the dust to settle and have slowly begun to seek out bargains that could increase their regional presence.
 That was the case Monday, as the Brazilian oil giant Petroleo Brasileiro S.A., or Petrobras, announced that it would buy a 58.6 percent stake in Perez Companc S.A., Argentina's top energy concern and one of the country's best-run companies, from the family owners for about $1.1 billion in cash and bonds. 
 "It was a slam-dunk for Petrobras," said Walter Molano at BCP Securities in Greenwich, Conn. "It used the market downturn as an opportunity to pick up cheap assets." 
"The sale of Perez Companc," he added, "could shine a light on the excellent opportunities that are strewn throughout the region."
The deal was also the second major one in recession-wracked Argentina this year. In May, another Brazilian company, the brewer Bebidas das Americas, or AmBev, announced the first major deal since Argentina defaulted on its $141 billion debt and sharply devalued its peso five months earlier. AmBev agreed to acquire about 38 percent of Quilmes Industrial, Argentina's main beer producer, in a deal valued around $600 million, with plans to take control of the company eventually.
No one is expecting a sudden rush of mergers and acquisitions in Argentina. Though there is considerable wishful thinking, the continuing economic and political instability will scare off most investors.
But large companies in Brazil and Mexico with enough money and influence to play hardball with the Argentine government have started checking out the wares.
As President Vicente Fox of Mexico stepped off the plane in Buenos Aires early this month with a high-powered business delegation in tow, shares of Telecom Argentina shot up 20 percent when rumors spread that Carlos Slim Helu, the chairman of Telefonos de Mexico, was interested in buying the company, but was balking at its $3.2 billion of debt.
Although Telmex has repeatedly denied the rumors, analysts say that Mr. Slim is probably interested.
"Telmex and other big Mexican companies have enormous amounts of cash; they've had a good run; they have access to credit," Mr. Molano said.
That is not the case for their Argentine counterparts. Before the devaluation, the peso was pegged at parity to the dollar for a decade, tempting much of corporate Argentina to run up huge dollar-denominated debts because interest rates were lower.
Now, with their revenues dwindling and denominated in a peso worth about 30 cents, most cannot afford to pay those debts. Perez Companc's debt is $1.9 billion, for instance, and a spokesman for the family said that the prolonged economic crisis was a major factor in the decision to sell.
There are few signs of an end to the gloom. The economy shrank another 16 percent in the first quarter, and inflation could end up at more than 50 percent by the end of the year. Argentines are to vote in March to elect their sixth president since last December.
Petrobras's chief executive, Francisco Gros, acknowledged that the company was "concerned with the current macroeconomic scenario in Argentina, but in the long term we believe this will be a very good investment considering the good price we are paying for these assets."
"We didn't buy a dead chicken," Mr. Gros told reporters after a news conference here. "The chicken is very much alive, and it's laying eggs."
He said he expected to close a deal on another Argentine oil company, Santa Fe, soon.
According to Mr. Molano, as long as the Argentine government fails to rebuild a solid legal framework for business, it is easier for a state-owned company like Petrobras to risk investing than for other companies to do so.
"The bargains become more notable if you can enforce your property rights," Mr. Molano said. "A state-owned Petrobras from neighboring Brazil carries more clout than a private company from Spain. It's a government-to-government relationship."
Since the crisis began, Brazilian companies invested in Argentina have largely stayed put. And Brazil's president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, has been a vocal supporter of international assistance for Argentina.
By contrast, many European and North American companies have pulled up their stakes altogether, or have reduced or at least frozen their investments in Argentina. Several banks, which have written off billions of dollars in losses since the government froze Argentines' savings accounts last December, have decamped, including the Bank of Nova Scotia, Credit Agricole and Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale.
Eloi Rodrigues de Almeida, who heads Grupo Brasil, a business lobby group based in Buenos Aires, said that had burnished the image of corporate Brazil, once spurned by the more urbane Argentines.
Much public anger at the banking freeze has been vented on branches of two Spanish banks with big Argentine operations, Banco Santander Hispano Central and Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, and two American giants, Citibank and BankBoston Argentina, now part of FleetBoston Financial.
According to a recent poll in Argentina, residents of Buenos Aires and other major cities said they would still prefer that United States companies invest in Argentina, but Brazil came next, ahead of Spain.
Mr. Almeida said that Brazilian corporate raiders, no strangers to economic volatility at home, were ideally positioned to expand in Argentina, Brazil's main partner in the Mercosur trade bloc.
"It's not just a question of shares being cheap," he said. "For Brazilian companies wanting to expand abroad, the natural first stop should be Argentina."
Future acquisitions, he predicted, would be in industries like auto parts, processed foods and dairy production.

HEADLINE: Wearied by Reality, Television Returns To a 1980's Mind-Set 

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif., July 23 

 BODY:
David Morse, a television star of the 1980's, is returning to prime time this fall. In CBS's "Hack," he will play an ex-corrupt cop turned cabdriver who atones by helping strangers. The show is a moody drama that closely resembles "The Equalizer," an 80's series on CBS about a disillusioned ex-secret agent who atones by helping strangers.
 John Ritter is also returning. Nearly 20 years after his hit comedy, ABC's "Three's Company," went off the air in 1984, he's back with two sexy roommates in ABC's "8 Simple Rules." This time, however, they are his teenage daughters. 
 Fox's popular summer talent show, "American Idol," echoes the 80's "Star Search," with the poisonous Simon Cowell stepping in for the pleasant Ed McMahon. 
Television is no more immune to the pull of cyclical tides than fashion, music or the economy. When "The Cosby Show," "Family Ties" and the police drama "Hill Street Blues" were hits in the 80's, it was at a time when insider-trading scandals and the collapse of the junk bond market were souring the public's giddy embrace of Wall Street.
Once again economic jitters: the collapse of the dot-com bubble, the shakiness of mega-media conglomerates, the corporate accounting fraud scandal and insider-trading charges. And series being shown to critics and reporters here this week indicate that either by coincidence or unconscious design, the sensibility that molded 1980's television is saturating the new season.
Media scholars, who sift through torrents of programming seeking patterns, find a link even between the reality shows that defined the television of the late 90's and the prime-time soap operas that marked the early Reagan years. Sitcoms are comforting. Dramas are gritty and disturbing but offer some hope.
"Audiences are looking for normal families -- they found 'Everybody Loves Raymond' on CBS and 'Reba' on WB, and grabbed onto them," Bruce Helford, an executive producer whose own sitcom for ABC, "The George Lopez Show," is centered around a Cosby-ish Hispanic family. "People don't want to be alienated. They are looking for something safer."
Many dramas, on the other hand, mirror public disenchantment with institutions, including the Roman Catholic Church. On "Miracles," a drama that ABC is marketing as a "spiritual X-Files," the hero parts company with the church hierarchy because he feels its leaders do not really believe in miracles.
Shows that aim to provide mindless thrills, like "Fastlane," a new Fox drama showcasing two buddy cops -- one white, the other black -- flashy cars and MTV-style music in an homage to "Miami Vice," also carries a trace of that 80's show's world-weariness.
Dana Delany, whose greatest television success was as a Vietnam nurse in the late 80's show "China Beach," is back in scrubs this fall as a doctor on "Presidio Med," a CBS show that echoes "E.R." and also the 80's show "St. Elsewhere," which gave Mr. Morse his prime-time start. Blythe Danner, who starred in a short-lived 80's prime-time soap called "Tattingers," is a co-star.
Even "Grubbs," a barbed Fox sitcom about a steelworker father, Randy Quaid, who supports his wife and children by faking disability claims, is a paler shade of "Roseanne."
Like ordinary investors, television executives seem to be feeling bruised and less bold. They may envy HBO its 93 Emmy nominations this year for more avant-garde shows like "Six Feet Under," but these days they are as risk averse as portfolio managers. "Network executives are always asking, 'Will it be depressing?' " Mr. Helford said.
Plenty of other signposts of the era of Reagan, Milkin and Madonna are back, perhaps under the spell of what Simon Reynolds, a music critic who is writing a book about 80's post-punk music, called "the charm of remoteness." 
Designer jeans are once again a huge industry, and the revival of 80's techno-pop on MTV and youth radio has now drifted onto network television. On "Keen Eddie," a Fox show about a New York detective transplanted to London, much of the background music is from the 80's.
There is even another crocodile hunter in the movie theaters.
The 1980's are suddenly so compelling that two different shows, one on WB and another on ABC, have heroes who travel back in time to their Reagan-era high school years. NBC's nostalgia is centered on "American Bandstand" in the early 60's with its family drama "American Dreams," but even NBC is developing a made-for-television movie "Hunter: Return to Justice," reviving the exploits of the 1980's television detective Rick Hunter.
" 'Millionaire" and 'Survivor' are like such prime-time soaps as 'Dallas,' 'Dynasty' and 'Falcon Crest,' shows that celebrate people locked in Darwinian competition," said Ron Simon, the curator of the Museum of Television and Radio in New York.
All television shows of course are derivative. Almost any medical show can be traced back to "Ben Casey," just as "I Love Lucy," is at the root of countless comedies. At different times, however, different genres regain their resonance with audiences: screwball comedies that distracted moviegoers during hard economic times or dark satires like the film "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" that matched the country's disaffection after Vietnam and Watergate.
These days, after Sept. 11 and the bursting of the economic bubble, television executives say that television audiences remain skeptical about authority, but that they also seem to hunger for signs of stability.
"It's not like 'Baretta' in the 70's, a tough guy fighting the system, it's people in the system who can assert order over chaos," said Gil Schwartz, CBS's executive vice president in charge of communications. The CBS forensic science drama, "C.S.I.: Crime Scene Investigation," was so successful last year that the network is spinning off "C.S.I.: Miami," this fall, starring David Caruso, who was a star of "N.Y.P.D. Blue" in 1993.
One other explanation of 80's retro of course is that many of the people who are now in charge of making television shows came of age in the 1980's and find their youth fascinating.
Jeremy Miller, a creator and executive producer of "That Was Then," the ABC show about a 29-year-old who travels back to his 1988 high school traumas, said he set his show in 1988 because it was the year he graduated from high school. His show is noticeably bleaker in tone than "Do Over," the WB version which is set in 1980, a more optimistic period. 
One other explanation for the retro programming is that many of the people now making television shows came of age in the 1980's. They are hoping that people in the key demographic groups will find the 80's revival fascinating.
"I think right now we are at a time in our country of fear and economic pain, and we yearn for a simpler time," said Warren Littlefield, the executive producer of "Do Over," explaining the 1980's nostalgia. Mr. Littlefield, who as a top executive at NBC oversaw hits like "The Cosby Show" and "Cheers," has rosy memories. "For me, those years at NBC were a magical ride," he said. "I think of the 1980's as a time of infinite possibility."

HEADLINE: Bloomberg Talks of Layoffs, but Some Hear Negotiation Tactic 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg raised the specter of layoffs this week just as his administration enters a crucial new phase with the city's labor unions.
 The city must negotiate a new contract with its largest union, District Council 37, whose contract expired June 30. A police contract is being decided for the first time by a state panel, which the main police union has long believed would yield generous raises. And the city still hopes to win $250 million more in union concessions on pensions and other fringe benefits to help balance the budget that took effect this month. 
 Some fiscal experts said they believed that the mayor, in hinting at layoffs, was seeking leverage to use in the many labor negotiations that his administration faces.
"We've seen six months of the carrot, and now we're seeing the stick," said Edmund J. McMahon Jr., a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, who has previously criticized the administration for failing to make enough budget cuts. "If he's going to get anywhere in contract talks, and he's going to get anything in terms of meaningful concessions, he needs leverage."
Mr. Bloomberg has said he is simply exploring options to cut a billion dollars out of this year's $42.3 billion budget. He has begun to talk about the need to cut the size of the city's work force -- preferably, but not necessarily, by offering early retirement and severance packages.
The city's budget director, Mark Page, sent a letter to city commissioners on Friday directing them to come up with plans to reduce their spending by 7.5 percent, and telling them that they were free to consider layoffs.
Asked yesterday if he would be open to laying off workers if that was what his commissioners were to recommend, Mr. Bloomberg left the door open. "Nobody is in favor of layoffs," he said. "You want to write the story that somebody is in favor of firing people. Nobody wants to do that. We have no choice. We must cut our expenses, and each commissioner will come back with their ideas as to how they can do that, what the impact would be, first and foremost on the public, and second, on the work force." 
Union officials, City Council members and advocates for social service programs denounced the talk of layoffs, and used the opportunity to renew their calls for tax increases. The mayor has mostly ruled them out this year, explaining that it is an election year in Albany and the city would be unlikely to get legislative support.
"When you start talking about layoffs, you're talking about service reductions to New Yorkers, and before one considers service reductions that go to the heart and soul of what New York is about, you have to think about revenue enhancements," said Randi Weingarten, the chairwoman of the Municipal Labor Committee and the president of the United Federation of Teachers, which settled its contract with the city this year. 
Lillian Roberts, the executive director of District Council 37, said that her union still supports reinstating the commuter tax, which netted the city $300 million to $500 million a year but was repealed by the State Legislature in 1999.
Bonnie Brower, the executive director of the City Project, a budget watchdog group that has criticized the mayor for making too many budget cuts and not supporting tax increases, said: "I think the mayor's refusal to consider smart, targeted, modest tax increases makes the talk of layoffs almost inevitable. I think that the only thing surprising is that it's happening so quickly, while the ink is still drying on the budget."
And Dan Cantor, the executive director of the Working Families Party, which held numerous protests against budget cuts throughout the spring, said he was planning another one at City Hall today -- months before he thought he would need to.
Mr. Bloomberg was clearly sensitive to the concern that the word layoff arouses in a city where many people still remember the troubles caused by layoffs during the fiscal crisis in the 1970's.
He stressed that it was still too early to say if he would need them this year. But he noted again that the deficits that the city faces next year and the year after are "dismal." And, he added, he needs to act soon in a way that closes the gaps without harming the city and endangering its economic future.
"If you balance the budget today in such a way that you damage your long-term growth, you will always have a problem," he said. "We're trying to find that balance between making this still a place where people want to come, live and bring their business, at the same time finding a ways to balance the budget."

HEADLINE: Missing the 90's Bubble Looks Prescientin 2002 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
At the time, they must have felt left out at cocktail parties and dismissed as slightly crazy by many of their neighbors. But those who ignored stocks in the mid- and late-1990's -- and all the hype that was swirling around them at the time -- are now significantly better off than those who put their money to work on Wall Street.
 The decline in the stock market has been so steep in the last two and a half years -- including a 19 percent plunge in the Standard & Poor's 500 index since the end of June -- that anyone who put money in bonds between the mid-1990's and now is doing better today than those who trusted in stocks. On a total return basis, the starting date has to be pushed back to July 1995 before money invested in a broad portfolio of major stocks would have outperformed an investment made at the same time in Treasury notes and bonds. 
 The realization that bonds are not so bad is nothing new in a down stock market. But since the belief in stocks as the only investment has been in vogue so long, bonds have not been on the alternatives list of many investors.
Now they are, and those rushing into the bond market -- while too late to head off big losses in their stock portfolios -- could help buoy the economy and eventually contribute to a stock market recovery as well.
Rising bond prices push interest rates down, and that is fueling not only a housing and refinancing boom but also increased consumer borrowing at relatively low cost. Those actions seem to be what Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is counting on to carry the economy through a rough spot until the stock market settles down and businesses start spending again.
In the last four months, the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note, which has a big influence on home mortgage rates but also affects equity loans and even other borrowing rates on everything from cars to college tuition, has dropped a percentage point to 4.42 percent.
This has brought mortgage rates near their lowest levels in decades, with the average national rate on a 30-year mortgage now at 6.49 percent. Falling mortgage rates prompt homeowners to refinance their home loans. In turn, homeowners can lower their monthly payments and borrow additional money. Both activities can free money for anything from home improvements to vacations.
As a result, the decline in interest rates serves as a stabilizer for the economy, offsetting the blow to consumer spending expected by some economists from the stock market decline.
"Greenspan is betting that the tail wind of a stronger property market will offset the headwind of the stock market," said Paul A. McCulley, portfolio manager and economist at the Pacific Investment Management Company in Newport Beach, Calif.
While Mr. Greenspan has plenty of supporters among economists, skeptics abound as well. Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company, for one, has his doubts.
"If you go half a percentage point below where we are now on mortgage rates, then everybody in the United States will refinance their mortgage and that is a pretty potent force," he said. "Unfortunately, the driver on the other side, stocks, is also a potent force -- negatively."
Since stocks began their latest plunge four months ago, Merrill Lynch's index of Treasury notes and bonds has had a total return of 6.6 percent through Monday. The gains, though modest by the outsize standards of the 1990's, are far superior to bank deposits and a counterpoint to the total-return decline of 29 percent in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in the same period.
With investors putting more money into bonds, bond traders are dealing with an onslaught of new money.
The positive impact from falling interest rates and the negative consequence of falling stock prices work through the economy in many ways, but one of the most important comes from the so-called wealth effect. Under this theory, consumers are more willing to increase their spending when they feel richer because of the rise in the value of their stocks or their homes. The wealth effect, of course, can also move in the opposite direction. While estimates vary, economists think that many people might spend anywhere from 2 cents to 5 cents more for every dollar of increased personal wealth and cut their spending by a somewhat smaller amount when their wealth declines.
Mr. Greenspan indicated last week that he thought the housing wealth effect has the upper hand, for now. "Fixed mortgage rates remain at historically low levels and thus should continue to fuel reasonably strong housing demand and, through equity extraction, to support consumer spending as well," Mr. Greenspan said in his semiannual economic analysis for Congress.
It certainly was not Mr. Greenspan's intention, but there is one other consequence of the end of the stock boom, the fall in interest rates and the better performance of bonds. Mr. Greenspan's own portfolio -- invested in the Treasury market and money market funds to avoid any conflicts of interest -- now looks a whole lot better than when he was being celebrated for helping bring about an economic miracle.

HEADLINE: TRACES OF TERROR: APPROPRIATIONS; 
House Passes Recovery Bill, Including New York Payment

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23 

 BODY:
The House approved a $28.5 billion emergency spending bill today to pay for military operations, domestic security and New York's recovery effort from the Sept. 11 attacks.
 The money for New York, totaling $5.5 billion, represents the final installment of the roughly $21.5 billion aid package that President Bush promised to provide New York to assist in its recovery. 
 The bipartisan House vote, 397 to 32, also includes $14.5 billion for the Pentagon to pay for the war in Afghanistan, as well as $6.7 billion for antiterrorism and other domestic security measures. The Senate is expected to approve the spending bill as early as Wednesday. 
Though it had widespread support, the bill had been held up for weeks in a clash between the White House and lawmakers from both parties. Mindful of the fall elections, lawmakers sought significantly more money than President Bush had requested for a host of initiatives, including bolstering port security, combating bioterrorism and assisting local law enforcement authorities.
Alarmed about the mounting federal budget deficit, the Bush administration balked. In the end, lawmakers cut $1.5 billion from the aid package, concerned that the momentum for a spending bill would fade and that no extra money would be approved before the fiscal year ends on Sept. 30.
The spending package, hammered out last week by House and Senate negotiators, was approved with little fanfare and with nothing approaching the bitterness of the last few weeks, when Republicans and Democrats complained that the White House was shortchanging national security by penny-pinching.
"We simply need to get on with it, and we need to get this down to the president," said Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the ranking Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee and a main author of the spending package.
Last night, a White House spokeswoman, Claire Buchan, said, "the emergency spending bill is important for the Congress to act on, and we're pleased that it is doing so."
The $5.5 billion of aid to New York includes $2.66 billion for emergency response and debris removal at the World Trade Center site, $750 million to help utilities rebuild equipment destroyed in the attacks, $1.8 billion to build a transportation hub connecting PATH trains and subway lines running through Lower Manhattan, and $167 million to repair the West Side Highway and other roads.
The bill also expands the number of New Yorkers eligible for emergency housing aid as a result of the attacks. The provision was included in response to reports that the Federal Emergency Management Agency had denied thousands of people the aid they needed to avoid eviction or foreclosure.
While FEMA officials have said that they are moving to address the problem, the provision's supporters, including Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, argue that action by Congress takes the decision out of the agency's hands and ensures that the aid is distributed to the people who need it.
The spending package includes $522 million more than the president requested for the Pentagon and $2.4 billion more than he sought for domestic security measures.
House and Senate negotiators offset those increases by calling for cuts in other areas, including providing $550 million less than the $4.4 billion that the Transportation Security Administration requested. 
The $6.7 billion that the bill sets aside for national security includes $175 million for the Federal Bureau of Investigation's counterterrorism efforts, as well as $201 million to provide grants to local police, firefighters and emergency workers.
The bill also provides $2.1 billion in foreign aid. That includes $200 million to assist Israel in combating international terrorism, $50 million in humanitarian aid for the West Bank and Gaza and $211 million for enhanced embassy security.
Despite the White House's insistence on adhering to the bottom line, the spending bill also included items that, on the surface, at least, had little to do with national security: $1 billion in Pell grants for low-income students, $417 million to provide medical care for veterans, $400 million to help states upgrade voting systems, $205 million for Amtrak, $200 million for fighting AIDS and other diseases abroad, and $100 million for combating wildfires and floods out West.

HEADLINE: The Benefits of English 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Divided by a Call for a Common Language" (news article, July 19): 
 The cause of immigrants and old-timers alike suffers when pro-English ordinances are viewed as part of a xenophobic "backlash." Resolutions like the one passed in Green Bay, Wis., could greatly increase the social and economic opportunities of immigrants who are not yet fluent in English. 
Furthermore, immigrants and non-immigrants who have a language in common may be able to channel their conflict into constructive debate and discourse, building trust and even friendship across both communities. 

DANIEL SCHIFF
New York, July 20, 2002

HEADLINE: Trying to Elude The Google Grasp 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE

 BODY:
THE Internet has reminded Camberley Crick that there are disadvantages to having a distinctive name. 
 In June, Ms. Crick, 24, who works part time as a computer tutor, went to a Manhattan apartment to help a 40-something man learn Windows XP. 
 After their session, the man pulled out a half-inch stack of printouts of Web pages he said he had found by typing Ms. Crick's name into Google, the popular search engine. 
"You've been a busy bee," she says he joked. Among the things he had found were her family Web site, a computer game she had designed for a freshman college class, a program from a concert she had performed in and a short story she wrote in elementary school called "Timmy the Turtle."
"He seemed to know an awful lot about me," Ms. Crick said, including the names of her siblings. "In the back of my mind, I was thinking I should leave soon."
When she got home, she immediately removed some information from the family Web site, including the turtle story, which her father had posted in 1995, "when the Web was more innocent," she said. But then she discovered that a copy of the story remains available through Google's database of archived Web pages. "You can't remove pieces of yourself from the Web," Ms. Crick said.
The gradual erosion of personal privacy is hardly a new trend. For years, privacy advocates have been spinning cautionary tales about the perils of living in the electronic age.
But it used to be that only government agencies and businesses had the resources and manpower to track personal information. Today, the combined power of the Internet, search engines and archival databases can enable almost anyone to find information about almost anyone else, possibly to satiate a passing curiosity. 
As a result, people like Ms. Crick are trying to reduce their electronic presence -- and discovering that it is not as simple as it would seem. The Internet, which was supposed to usher in an era of limitless information, is leading some people to restrict the information that they make available about themselves.
"Now it's much more common to look up people's personal information on the Web," Ms. Crick said. "You have to think what you want people to know about you and not know about you."
These days, people are seeing their privacy punctured in intimate ways as their personal, professional and online identities become transparent to one another. Twenty-somethings are going to search engines to check out people they meet at parties. Neighbors are profiling neighbors. Amateur genealogists are researching distant family members. Workers are screening co-workers. 
In other words, it is becoming more difficult to keep one's past hidden, or even to reinvent oneself in the American tradition. "The net result is going to be a return to the village, where everyone knew everyone else," said David Brin, author of a book called "The Transparent Society" (Perseus, 1998). "The anonymity of urban life will be seen as a temporary and rather weird thing."
Some believe that this loss of anonymity could be dangerous for those who prefer to remain hidden, like victims of domestic violence.
"If you are living in a new town trying to be hidden, it's pretty easy to find you now between Google and online government records," said Cindy Southworth, who develops technology education programs for victims of domestic violence. "Many public entities are putting everything on the Web without thinking through the ramifications of those actions." 
Of course, a lot of personal information that can be found on the Internet is already in the open, having been printed in newspapers, school newsletters, yearbooks and the like. In addition, the government records that are moving online -- tax assessments, court documents, voter registration -- are already public.
But much of that kind of information used to be protected by "practical obscurity": barriers arising from the time and inconvenience involved in collecting the information. Now those barriers are falling as old online-discussion postings, wedding registries and photos from school performances are becoming centralized in a searchable form on the Internet. 
"Google and its siblings are creating a whole that is much greater than the sum of the parts," said Jonathan Zittrain, director of the Berkman Center for Internet and Society at Harvard Law School. "Many people assume they are a needle in a haystack, simply a face in the crowd. But the minute someone takes an interest in you, the search tool is what allows the rest of the crowd to dissolve." 
As a result, people are considering how to live their lives knowing that the details might be captured by a big magnifying glass in the sky.
"Anonymity used to give us a cushion against small mistakes," Mr. Brin said. "Now we'll have to live our lives as if any one thing might appear on page 27 in two years' time."
Waqaas Fahmawi, 25, used to sign petitions freely when he was in college. "In the past you would physically sign a petition and could confidently know that it would disappear into oblivion," said Mr. Fahmawi, a Palestinian-American who works as an economist for the Commerce Department. 
But after he discovered that his signatures from his college years had been archived on the Internet, he became reluctant to sign petitions for fear that potential employers would hold his political views again him.
He feels stifled in his political expression. "The fact I have to think about this," he said, "really does show we live in a system of thought control."
David Holtzman, editor in chief of GlobalPOV, a privacy Web site, said that the notion of privacy was "undergoing a generational shift." Those in their late 20's and 30's are going to feel the brunt of the transition, he said, because they grew up with more traditional concepts of privacy even as the details of their lives were being captured electronically.
"It almost gives you a good reason to name your kid something bland," Mr. Holtzman said. "You are doing them a good favor by doing that."
Indeed, a generic name is what Beth Roberts, 29, was seeking when she changed back from her married name, Werbick, after a divorce. A Google search on "Beth Werbick" returns results only about her. But a search for "Beth Roberts" returns thousands upon thousands of Web pages. "I would have plausible deniability if someone wanted to attribute something to me," said Ms. Roberts, who lives in Austin, Tex. 
Mr. Fahmawi, the economist, said he envied the ability to be a name in the crowd. "If I had a more generic name, I'd sign petitions with impunity," he said.
But those who have become more conscious of their Internet presence can find that it is almost impossible to assert control over the medium -- something that copyright holders discovered long ago. 
The debate over privacy is particularly fervent in the field of online genealogy, where databases and family trees are copied freely, with or without the consent of the living individuals. 
Jerome Smith, who runs a genealogical Web site, recently removed some names at the request of a man who did not want his children's information on the Web. But Mr. Smith noted the information itself had been copied from a larger public database. "Once you put it out there, it's out there," said Mr. Smith, who lives in Lake Junaluska, N.C.
Google says its search engine reflects whatever is on the Internet. To remove information about themselves, people have to contact Web site administrators.
A disadvantage of instant Internet profiling is that there is no quality control -- and little protection against misinterpretation. The fragments of people's lives that emerge on the Internet are somewhat haphazard. They can be incomplete, out of context, misleading or simply wrong.
John Doffing, the chief executive of an Internet talent agency called StartUpAgent, is surprised by how many job applicants ask him what it is like to be a gay chief executive in Silicon Valley. He says that even though he is heterosexual, some people assume he is gay because his name turns up on the Internet in association with his philanthropic work relating to AIDS and an online gallery devoted to gay and lesbian art. 
While this has been more amusing than troubling, he says, such information could be misused. "What happens if I were a job seeker and someone decides not to give me a job because of the same assumption?" he asked.
There are also cases of mistaken Google-identity. Sam Waltz Jr., a business consultant in Wilmington, Del., met a woman through an online dating service. Before they met in person, she sent him an e-mail message saying that she did not think they were compatible. She had found his name on a Web site called SincereLust.com, which appeared to her to be run by a Delaware-based transvestite group. 
"I'm sitting here, reading her e-mail and thinking, 'What is this?' " Mr. Waltz said.
He discovered that the site was a drama group dedicated to "The Rocky Horror Picture Show." His son, Sam Waltz III, had been a member while he was at the University of Delaware. 
Mr. Waltz quickly explained the situation to the woman, and they have been dating for 18 months. "Now I periodically do a self-Google to make sure there is nothing else that needs to be challenged or checked," Mr. Waltz said.
Some say that the phenomenon of instant unchecked background searches could be manipulated to sabotage others' reputations.
Jeanne Achille, the chief executive of a public relations firm called the Devon Group, was horrified that someone had used her name and e-mail address to post racist slurs in a French online discussion group. She has repeatedly had to explain the situation to potential clients who have asked her about the posting.
"Whoever did this had to put some thought into it," Ms. Achille said. "Is it perhaps one of our competitors? Is it someone who felt we did something to them and wanted to get back at us? Is it a personal thing? Is it a disgruntled former employee?"
The posting has been impossible to remove. "There is no cyberpatrol that you can go to and make all of this go away," Ms. Achille said. "You just have to live with it." 

Defensive Strategies
How to Limit Search Exposure
A lot of online information about you and your family may be out of your immediate control, but there are ways to limit what others can find. 
* Periodically do Internet searches on your name to see what turns up. If there is information that you prefer not to have publicly available, contact the site's owner or Webmaster. Google says its database will typically reflect the changes within six to eight weeks.
* When making postings to the Internet, Usenet discussion groups or e-mail lists that archive messages, consider using a nickname or an "online handle" rather than your full formal name. 
* Take steps to prevent a personal Web site or Weblog from being noted by the robotic programs that "crawl" and index the Web (for example, a family Web page that you want only friends and family members to see). Information on how to do that is available at www.robotstxt.org.
* If you sign a petition or make a donation to a political group, understand that the information could become public and searchable on the Internet.
* If you want to put personal photos on the Internet, consider using an online photo service that can "share" photos with families and friends using a password but are not indexed for search engines. 
* If you do online genealogy, consider whether or not you have -- or need -- permission to put information about living people online, including their mothers' maiden names, which can be used in identity theft.
* Remember that e-mail sent in confidence can be forwarded, intentionally or inadvertently, and even wind up on the Web.

They ended up dating, after he explained that she had confused him with his son. (Timothy M. Shaffer for The New York Times) Drawing (Tom Bloom)(pg. G6)

HEADLINE: American Capitalism's Other Side 

BYLINE:  By Fred P. Hochberg; Fred P. Hochberg was deputy administrator and acting administrator of the Small Business Administration from 1998 to 2001.

 BODY:
Andy Grove, a founder of Intel, summed up the mood of recent weeks when he said he is "embarrassed and ashamed" to be a corporate executive in America today.
 Like so many other great successes, Intel was, in its early years, nurtured by an economic system that encourages innovation and entrepreneurship -- and helped by institutions like the Small Business Administration. In return, the company grew into an example of American ingenuity. 
 Historically, America's small- business owners have always focused on fundamentals: they concentrate on creating something of value, generating jobs and profits in the process. At the heart of the current corporate quagmire is a departure from these principles.
Driven by the perceived imperatives of the stock market, many corporations have skewed their priorities. Meeting quarterly earnings projections has become more important for them than building long-term shareholder value. The result can be seen in the implosion of giant corporations, thousands of layoffs and evaporating retirement savings. This spectacle has cast a pall not just over corporate America but over the American brand of free-market capitalism.
Despite the pessimism here and abroad, most American corporations are aboveboard in running their businesses and recording their bottom lines.
But more important, it's just not true that as big corporations go, so goes the American economy.
During the 1990's, more than 80 percent of the net gain in new jobs was not from corporate giants, but from small companies involved in a range of businesses (far broader than the dot-coms). By the end of the decade, nearly half the work force was employed in small businesses. Their efforts powered the record economic growth of the 1990's.
Government and business leaders from around the world come to our country to learn how we nurture and sustain small entrepreneurs. But we are not doing nearly enough to show the world this side of American capitalism. The Bush administration removed the Small Business Administration from the cabinet and proposed cutting the agency's funding by over 20 percent. Worse, it aims to reduce the agency's lending capacity by 50 percent. This year, there is $9.4 billion available for small-business loans guaranteed by the agency. For next year, the administration is proposing less than $5 billion. At a minimum, the administration should restore or even increase the agency's lending capacity, especially since access to capital may now be sharply curtailed.
At a time of shaken confidence in American business, the administration should also work to put the small-business model at the heart of our global economic message. It should invest more resources to encourage the growth of small businesses in the developing world through microlending institutions. Microloans give people the opportunity to improve their lives and become stakeholders in their societies. Microlending nurtures the fundamental values of democracy and helps them take root.
Businesses based on jobs and profit, not the gambles of the stock market, are the real foundation of American capitalism. I have never heard small-business owners say they were embarrassed by what they do; they are rightfully proud of the enterprises they have built.

HEADLINE: In a Surprise, ABB Reports Quarterly Loss 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 24 

 BODY:
ABB surprised investors and analysts today by posting a loss for the second quarter, which it attributed to operational troubles and the costs of asbestos-related litigation. Coming on a day full of sour corporate news in Switzerland, ABB's loss prompted a 23 percent fall in its stock price.
 The Zurich-based company, a Swiss-Swedish builder of power plants and other heavy machinery, narrowly averted a financial crisis earlier this year and has suffered a series of embarrassments surrounding current and former top executives and their pay. It said today that it lost $13 million in the latest quarter, in part because of cost overruns at two projects in its oil, gas and petrochemicals division that it did not identify. 
 Revenue for the second quarter was $5.78 billion, little changed from the comparable period last year. The company's debt rose sharply, to $5.2 billion on June 30, from $4.1 billion at the beginning of the year.
Much of the problem in the second quarter was traceable to asbestos-related litigation in the United States, stemming from industrial boilers made in the 1970's by Combustion Engineering, a business ABB later bought and then sold again, retaining responsibility for the liabilities. Asbestos claims against the company rose 10 percent in the quarter, raising concerns that ABB will have to add to its reserves.
"We had a loss in the second quarter as a result of some charges to put us on a better footing," said Jorgen Centerman, ABB's chief executive, who has been struggling to restore confidence in the company. Referring to the stock price, he said in a telephone interview: "I don't understand what happened today. If you look at the underlying performance of the company, nearly every single parameter started to move in the right direction."
The positive signs he cited included a 10 percent rise in new orders, many from its biggest and most important customers, and an 8 percent rebound in sales from the depressed levels of the first quarter. Mr. Centerman said the second half of the year was looking stronger; earlier this week, it landed a $1 billion Russian order for oil field equipment.
Asset sales will help ABB meet its target for reducing debt, he said, adding that he expects the company's structured-finance unit to find a buyer after September.
Over the last year, ABB has responded to rapidly weakening demand by eliminating 10,900 jobs, partly through attrition, at a cost of $106 million.
Other Swiss stocks taking a beating today over profit weakness included Serono International, the biggest biotechnology company in Europe, and Adecco, a major worldwide temporary-employment agency. Word that Adecco's first-half profits were lower than expected chopped 14 percent off its share price; Serono shares fell 19 percent after the company lowered its forecast of earnings growth to 10 percent from the mid- to high teens.

PERSON: Arnold Weinstock 

HEADLINE: Arnold Weinstock, Top British Industrialist, Is Dead at 77 

BYLINE:  By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Arnold Weinstock, who for 30 years dominated Britain's electrical and electronics industries with his giant General Electric Company, only to be ousted by critics who then virtually bankrupted the company, died on Tuesday at his home in Wiltshire. He was 77.
 The cause was cancer, The Times of London reported. 
As managing director of General Electric from 1963 to 1996, the famously penny-pinching and autocratic Lord Weinstock led the company as it grew into Britain's largest industrial conglomerate, with products ranging from household appliances to weapons systems, sales of $16 billion a year, profits of $1.5 billion and nearly $5 billion in cash reserves.
But despite the support of British governments on the left and the right, all eager to see General Electric become a technological leader, the cautious Lord Weinstock failed to give Britain much of a stake in emerging industries like semiconductors, computers and cellphones. (The company was not related to the company of the same name based in the United States.)
In 1996, Lord Weinstock, then 72, was persuaded to step down after the death of his son, Simon, who he had hoped would succeed him. He was succeeded by George Simpson, later Lord Simpson, who promised fast growth. But five years later, in September 2001, Lord Simpson was ousted after the company, now renamed Marconi, forecast a substantial loss and acknowledged $6 billion in debt and after the company's stock price had tumbled to 30 cents a share from $18 the previous year.
Lord Weinstock's wealth, once estimated at $750 million and largely invested in the company, shrank to a fraction of its former size.
The decline of the company was attributed to Lord Simpson's reversal of Lord Weinstock's business methods. Instead of building on its traditional strengths, he sought to transform Marconi into a glamorous, fast-growing communications giant, as reflected in the change of name.
Core assets were sold, and the proceeds, together with the cash reserves put away by Lord Weinstock, were augmented by additional borrowing and used to buy into telecommunication equipment plants. When the telecommunications bubble burst, Marconi found itself in trouble. 
Arnold Weinstock was born on July 29, 1924, in the London suburb of Stoke Newington, the last of six children of Polish immigrants.
Orphaned at the age of 10, he was brought up by an elder brother who was a hairdresser. He received a degree from the London School of Economics and began his business career in real estate. 
In 1949 he married Netta Sobell, whose father took him into his radio and television manufacturing company, Radio and Allied. He quickly came to dominate the company, taking it public in 1958 and making him and his father-in-law millionaires.
In 1961 he acquired the much bigger but poorly managed General Electric Company and moved to improve profitability. In 1967, he bought Associated Electrical Industries. The next year, Lord Weinstock took control of English Electric, another electrical engineering company. At 44, he was running Britain's biggest industrial company, with nearly a quarter of a million employees.
Lord Weinstock gave his managers considerable autonomy while monitoring their performance closely. A ferocious cost-cutter, he worked from a modest office. He also kept to the businesses he knew and was cautious about diversifying; a result was a strong company rich in cash but never a world leader in any field.
He is survived by his wife and a daughter, Susan.

HEADLINE: In Budget Crises, State Leaders Call for U.S. Aid 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: DENVER, July 24 

 BODY:
States have used up two-thirds of their available cash and their rainy-day funds trying to cope with budget crises, legislative leaders from across the country said today as they called for federal aid.
 By June 30, the end of the fiscal year for 46 states, the gap between revenues and spending was at $36 billion, leaders said at the annual meeting of the National Conference of State Legislatures. The difference is expected to be $58 billion in the next fiscal year, leaving many states scrambling to pay for continuing programs and federally mandated ones. 
 "The rainy-day funds are there for a rainy day," said the president of the conference, State Senator Stephen M. Saland of New York. "This is somewhere between a rain storm and a hurricane." 
Senator Saland, a Republican, said many states were forced to cut reserve balances and programs this past year, while others raised taxes.
At least 26 states collected less revenue in the last fiscal year than they did the year before, and 19 tapped cash reserves, a June survey by the association found. States also raised taxes by $6.7 billion, breaking a trend of tax cuts that began in 1994. Only one state, Hawaii, cut taxes by more than 1 percent while 16 raised taxes by more than 1 percent.
Four states -- California, Kentucky, Massachusetts and North Carolina -- had not passed budgets when the survey was compiled.
The executive director of the conference, William Pound, said the next fiscal year, which began on July 1 for many states, would be a bigger challenge now that reserves were dwindling.
Legislators attributed the lower revenues to a declining economy, the Sept. 11 attacks and recent business scandals.
Senator Saland also said the federal government had contributed to the problem by increasing state obligations in programs like Medicaid and asking states to assume a bigger role in protecting the nation from terrorism.
Officials here said the federal government needed to meet its commitment to disabled children under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, increase the federal share for Medicaid, help states pay for bioterrorism defense and training, and reauthorize welfare block grants.
State Representative Rich Stanek, Republican of Minnesota, said many voters were turning to government for solutions after the Sept. 11 attacks.

HEADLINE: Levy Says Higher Pay Is Helping to Lure Teachers to New York 

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
More than 2,000 certified teachers from all over the country flocked to a job fair in Brooklyn yesterday, leading Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy to suggest that the sharp salary increase in the new teachers' contract has made New York City schools a more attractive place to work.
 Mr. Levy said that the school system had hired 4,300 of the 8,000 new teachers it needs for the fall, and that 90 percent of those were fully certified and the rest were within "a stone's throw" of being certified. 
 He said the number of certified teachers applying in all license areas was up sharply over last year, though he provided no exact statistics, and he said the Board of Education should have no trouble filling the rest of the positions. 
In a change of policy, Mr. Levy has ordered that teachers hired this year be certified or within a year of being certified, as a way of meeting a State Board of Regents requirement that by September 2003 all teachers in the system be certified. At present, 17 percent of the city's 80,000 teachers lack certification.
"We are on track to get there," Mr. Levy said, adding that he spoke yesterday to teachers who had come to the hiring fair from Minneapolis and San Francisco.
Mr. Levy has also suspended a policy that required certified teachers to accept jobs at the city's most troubled schools last year before any other schools were allowed to hire. That policy was said to have inhibited many qualified teachers from even applying for fear of being assigned to neighborhoods they considered dangerous or classes where students would be hard to teach.
It was unclear yesterday whether that change affected the gain in certified teaching candidates. In any case, the increase in applicants comes as unemployment in the region has been rising.
In fact, both Mr. Levy and Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, credited the new contract's raises of 16 to 22 percent over 30 months for the increase in applicants. The contract raises starting pay to $39,000 from $31,900, and top pay to $81,231 from $70,000.
"We're seeing a whole different kind of buzz about coming to New York City and teaching in New York City than we've seen before," Ms. Weingarten said. 
Many of the teachers who attended yesterday's job fair at the Brooklyn Marriott Hotel came from outside New York City. Another provision of the new contract increases the maximum salary the city can pay teachers hired from other school districts to $61,000 from $43,370.
Ms. Weingarten said she believed the higher pay had done more to attract new teachers than the $8 million advertising campaign the Board of Education began last year.
