HEADLINE: Up, Down and All Around 

 BODY:
The Bush administration was angry about cable TV news networks' displaying stock market movements at the bottom of the screen while President Bush was giving a speech. There were no complaints yesterday, however, that the arrows were being shown as Mr. Bush commented on the arrest of a C.E.O. charged with treating his company's treasury as a personal piggy bank. The Dow industrial average rose nearly 500 points, and although any politician would have given an arm to take credit for finally giving Wall Street a day of good news, most were wise enough to realize that the market's current wild ride is too scary for anyone to try to claim he's in control. 
 It's unlikely, for instance, that the White House will really try to press the idea that the markets rallied on the news that the peripatetic Treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill, had decided to postpone his trip to South America. The House majority whip, Tom DeLay, was at minimum unfortunate in his timing when he called a news conference yesterday to blame the Democrats for the fall of the Dow. 
 Other members of Congress were nodding in the direction of their pending corporate-governance legislation, which was the subject of a House-Senate deal yesterday. If nothing else, the timing of the market rise suggested that no matter what the most absolutist of free-marketeers claim, investors are not scared by stiffer penalties for rogue C.E.O.'s and tougher accounting rules. Indeed, most still fear the government won't do enough to protect them, according to a recent Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll.
The sight of John Rigas, the founder and former chief executive of Adelphia Communications, being led away in handcuffs after being charged with securities fraud was soothing for individual investors eager to see executives held accountable for their misdeeds. Yet late news that AOL Time Warner's accounting practices are being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission was a sobering reminder that the market may be in for far more volatility, as the widespread excesses of the recent bubble get flushed out and addressed.
Americans have come a long way from the simple days of the Beardstown Ladies -- although the ladies turned out to be ahead of their time in achieving their big market gains through errors in bookkeeping. The time when truck drivers wondered if they shouldn't chuck it all for a career in day-trading are long gone. Now we pride ourselves on our nerves of steel -- or at least on an extraordinary ability to block out bad news. We have gotten used to triple-digit moves in the Dow and have perfected the art of filing away financial statements without really looking at them.

HEADLINE: CORPORATE CONDUCT: WASHINGTON MEMO; 
White House Moves to Limit Corporate Scandals' Fallout

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER and DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24 

 BODY:
Responding to criticism from Republicans in Congress and nationwide that President Bush has not acted aggressively enough against corporate corruption, White House officials moved on several fronts today to demonstrate the administration's efforts.
 First, they took credit for today's arrest of executives charged with looting one of the nation's largest cable television companies. They told Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill to cancel another trip out of the country and focus on the domestic economy. And while they insisted that Mr. Bush was not changing any of his plans to visit 12 American cities in August from his Texas ranch, White House officials said they expected him to stress economic security as frequently as national security and said they were still examining what themes he would strike. 
 Taken together, the White House moves are part of a strategy, albeit a defensive one, to contain fallout from the accounting scandals and the volatile stock market they have helped produce. The maneuvering appears to reflect a deepening anxiety within the White House and the Republican Party that candidates seeking election in November could be in peril in the wake of accusations that the party is too close to big business. 
Some Republican incumbents are accusing the White House of reacting too slowly and too tepidly. And they complain that Mr. O'Neill has been missing in action as a public voice to reassure investors.
"There is a strain, no question about it, between House Republicans and the White House," said a Republican campaign consultant. "The strain is caused by a sneaking suspicion that he's worried about '04 and they're worried about '02."
Not surprisingly, White House officials argued vigorously today that they have been intently focused on economic issues. Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, cited polls showing that voters do not blame Mr. Bush or other politicians for the market sell-off. 
"People are in the mood right now to cover only one side of the story," Mr. Fleischer said, blaming the media for suggesting that Mr. Bush was in political peril.
But it was telling that White House officials said that they, not the Treasury, strongly suggested to Mr. O'Neill on Tuesday night that he delay his trip to Latin America, which was to begin on Friday. 
The ostensible explanation was that Mr. Bush wanted Mr. O'Neill, who traveled to Africa in late May and to former Soviet republics last week, to work on assuring Congressional passage of the president's economic initiatives, including expanded authority for the president to negotiate trade agreements. But several Republican officials with ties to the White House said today that Mr. O'Neill's absence from the economic podium was becoming a political embarrassment -- and by the end of the day, Mr. O'Neill was on television, talking up the administration's strategy.
Mr. Bush rarely comments on arrests except when the charges relate to terrorism, but he used a meeting with Democrats to tell reporters this afternoon that "this government will investigate, will arrest and will prosecute corporate executives who break the law, and the Justice Department took action today." Lawyers close to the Adelphia Communications case, in which the founder and two of his sons were arrested and charged with fraud, said the White House has been extensively briefed on the details of white-collar criminal cases now under investigation.
Mr. Bush also praised an agreement in Congress on legislation that would stiffen penalties for corporate fraud. The White House noted that it incorporated some ideas Mr. Bush put forward in a speech on Wall Street early this month, but made no mention of the inclusion of other ideas the White House had argued against. 
In Arkansas, Mr. Bush's predecessor, Bill Clinton, broke a long public silence on Washington's response to the corporate scandals, arguing that his Securities and Exchange Commission attempted a crackdown on loose accounting rules and "Republicans stopped it."
Several Republicans running for Congress said in interviews that they were especially worried about polls showing that the public believed that the party was more concerned about giant corporations than ordinary voters.
Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, a Republican in his 13th term who is in a tough race for re-election, said the issue could cost his party control of the House. 
"The Republican Party must be against white-collar crime as well as street crime," Mr. Leach said. "If it is seen as the party of law and order only at the level of street crime, it will misserve the public."
A trade association executive here who is influential in Republican circles said the "administration tends to do the right thing, but sometimes they do it two months late."
In this case, the executive said, the president and his advisers made a serious mistake by treating the Enron debacle as "a few bad apples" and not as a damaging blow to American capitalism.
The strongest suit the Republican Party has, the executive said, is the belief that it is the party that made capitalism available to ordinary Americans in the form of retirement accounts like 401(k) plans. "The slice of the pie is worthless if the little guy loses trust in the system," the executive said.
But many other Republicans defended the president and said Republican candidates were in a strong position. 
"I'm not in a panic mode," said Representative Thomas M. Davis III of Virginia, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee. "If by Labor Day the market's not on the way up, we can start worrying. But not now."
Mr. Davis said the new regulation imposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission requiring corporate chief executives to certify that their companies' books are accurate would "shake things out and stop the drip, drip, drip" of new disclosures of wrongdoing.
To calm the troops, the White House circulated on Capitol Hill this week a memo, containing reassuring numbers, written by a prominent Republican pollster -- making the point that the party is in better shape than it was before Sept. 11. 
"The American people are rightly directing their anger at corporate America," one senior White House strategist said today. "But it's an election year, and its not surprising there is general nervousness."
Such nervousness has also seeped into the White House, however, where many officials recall how Mr. Bush's father seemed ill attuned to economic conditions as he ran for re-election in 1992.
So today both the Justice Department and Mr. Fleischer argued that the arrests of the former Adelphia executives were the first fruits of Mr. Bush's new corporate fraud task force. While they conceded that the investigation that led to the arrests was under way well before Mr. Bush created the group earlier this month, they insisted the task force had sped communication among various agencies involved in the investigation, making a quicker arrest possible.
Despite the change in climate since the stock market began to plunge, the White House has made few changes in its economic agenda, emphasizing trade, privatization of Social Security and oil and gas drilling in Alaska.
But today, there were signs that White House policy makers were thinking about further economic proposals if the bear market worsens -- or the general economy deteriorates. "This president will always want to be in motion to make sure the economy is growing," Mitchell Daniels, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, told reporters after delivering a speech on the White House's budget agenda.
Other officials said that Lawrence Lindsey, the president's economic adviser, had briefly raised the possibility of encouraging investors to buy stocks by enacting a lower capital gains tax for stocks purchased in coming months or years. But the idea was quickly rejected because it favored one kind of investment over others -- and a kind most attractive to the wealthy.
"I heard it around here, but it never amounted to much," one official said.

HEADLINE: CORPORATE CONDUCT: THE EX-PRESIDENT; 
Clinton Says Republicans Blocked His Audit Reforms

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 24 

 BODY:
Former President Bill Clinton today hailed his own efforts to increase the oversight of corporate governance and criticized Republicans and Harvey L. Pitt, currently the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, saying they had frustrated Mr. Clinton's efforts at reform.
 He said Republicans thus deserved some of the blame for the current flight of foreign capital from United States markets. 
 Asked about President Bush's handling of the economy and his attempts to rally investor confidence, Mr. Clinton, who was touring the construction site of his presidential library here, avoided criticizing his successor directly. Instead, he chided Republicans, who he said had blocked his administration's efforts to, among other things, bar accounting firms from working as auditors and consultants for the same companies.
"I'm sure that some of the people in Congress that stopped a lot of the reforms I tried to put through are probably rethinking that now," Mr. Clinton told reporters.
"Arthur Levitt, my Securities and Exchange commissioner, tried to stop the Enron accounting issues -- using the same accounting company being consultant and accountant -- and the Republicans stopped it." Later, Mr. Clinton added that Republicans had fought Mr. Levitt's effort, "and Harvey Pitt was the leader trying to stop us from ending those kind of abuses. That is a matter of record." Mr. Pitt, who was a securities lawyer before being appointed by President Bush to head the S.E.C., counted accounting firms, including Arthur Andersen, among his clients.
When asked if he agreed with senators and representatives who have called for Mr. Pitt's resignation, Mr. Clinton demurred. "I don't have to make those decisions anymore," he said.
Mr. Clinton also said he had been overridden by Republicans when he vetoed a securities-industry bill he said would have "basically cut off investors from being able to sue if they were getting the shaft." And he recalled that his Treasury secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, had tried to crack down on the use of offshore accounts to conceal corporate financial information, but that Senator Phil Gramm of Texas "and other Republicans stopped that."
"And that is one of the things that has caused all the European money to leave the markets, because they see that the government is in the hands of the party that stopped all of this stuff," Mr. Clinton said. "And so I think they've got a burden on their hands, and they seem to be trying to turn it around. We'll see."
Mr. Clinton again criticized Republicans in the White House and Congress when he was asked about investor confidence, suggesting that they ask the opinions of market-moving investors like George Soros and Warren E. Buffett. Those investors, Mr. Clinton said, disapproved of last year's tax cut and "knew it was a mistake to start running deficits again, that it would run long-term interest rates up and again undermine confidence."
But Mr. Clinton said the underlying American economy would "reassert itself sooner or later."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
From a Broken Laser Pointer to an Online Auction Giant

BYLINE:  By DAVID GELERNTER; David Gelernter is professor of computer science at Yale University and chief scientist at Mirror Worlds Technologies.

 BODY:
THE PERFECT STORE
Inside eBay
By Adam Cohen
332 pages. Little, Brown. $25.95.
 "Jerry Marcus, a tall, soft-spoken accountant from Queens, New York, already had 1,500 clothing irons, but he was hunched over his computer at home, bidding on one more." 
 This suspenseful moment comes in Paragraph 1, Chapter 10 of "The Perfect Store: Inside eBay," Adam Cohen's new book about the most successful company in Internet history, the world's leading sponsor of electronic auctions. Will the tall, soft-spoken accountant from Queens succeed in acquiring clothing iron 1501? I won't spoil it for you by telling. Suffice it to say that eBay has made it big by letting the Jerry Marcuses of the world peddle antique clothing irons to other Jerry Marcuses.
EBay's story is amazing, and Mr. Cohen's enthusiasm carries you along even if (like me) you are unsure, to start out, why exactly you should care. His prose is brisk and cheerful as the blue-red-gold-etc. of the famous eBay logo, and considerably less grating. And although his pro-eBay sympathies are plain, Mr. Cohen, an editorial writer for The New York Times, always supplies enough information to let an uncooperative reader draw a contrary conclusion.
EBay was conceived by Pierre Omidyar, who was born in 1967 to French-Iranian parents in Paris and studied computing in the United States. Mr. Omidyar has no grand vision of what technology should be; he is no Alan Kay, no Bill Joy. He has no drive to remold the technology industry; he is no Bill Gates, no Larry Ellison. He didn't invent the Internet or the World Wide Web or the Internet-mediated auction. "There had been auctions on the Internet for years," Mr. Cohen writes, "long before Omidyar even thought of starting an auction Web site."
But he did build a well-conceived Web site, did make a string of brilliant business moves that seem common-sensical only in retrospect, did become one of the richest people in the world, and does seem like a humane and decent man. Mr. Cohen struggles diligently to make him interesting, too, but here the results are mixed.
Mr. Omidyar is a little short of lovable quirks. Evidently Ebola is one of his hobbies. It was tough to persuade him to remove his "offbeat tribute to the Ebola virus" from the Web page on which he'd also put his brand new "AuctionWeb" service -- eventually to be renamed eBay. Before long it came time to tour the country, hyping eBay and the approaching public offering of its stock.
When it emerged that the eBay team was expected to do the tour in the gross luxury that is customary on such occasions, Mr. Omidyar put his foot down. Not that he turned down the private jets and fancy hotels, but "he refused to capitulate completely." His "rebellion" against "extravagance" took the form of insisting that Goldman, Sachs -- the firm that sponsored the road show -- pick up the tab. With rebels like him, who needs reactionaries?
So who is Pierre Omidyar -- an idealist who wants to change the world, or just an ordinary Ebola enthusiast who hit it big? Mr. Cohen presents evidence on both sides.
In the book's closing scene, eBay executives trek to Guatemala; via eBay, poor Guatemalans will sell their handicrafts directly to collectors everywhere. Bringing eBay to Guatemala "was Omidyar's dream," Mr. Cohen writes. "EBay could help transform San Pedro La Laguna -- and the lives of the people who live there."
Here, Mr. Cohen sounds uncannily like Humphrey Bogart in "Sabrina," explaining to Audrey Hepburn why poor people need billionaires.
But earlier he tells another revealing story. In the early days of his online auction business, Mr. Omidyar decided to sell a broken laser pointer. He started the bidding at a dollar; two weeks later, the high bid had reached $14. Then and there "it occurred to him," Mr. Cohen notes, "that AuctionWeb had a bright future ahead of it."
Mr. Omidyar had grasped what millions more would see eventually, to their profit: that a global electronic auction is perfect for flushing out the one person in the world who will pay the absolute most for any random piece of junk.
Mr. Cohen believes that "the implications of the eBay model -- of Mr. Omidyar's original conception of a perfect, global marketplace that everyone comes to on an equal basis -- are revolutionary." Maybe, but eBay is a strange business where Beanie Babies and recycled Barbie dolls were major milestones on the road to commercial greatness and "a lucky Elvis fan beat out 46 other bidders to pay $811 for the pest control agreement from Elvis's home on Hillcrest Road." The eBay story isn't so much about markets or economics as shopping.
EBay has no inventory, doesn't actually sell anything itself, but collects a commission on every sale. Obviously, this company is important. Some 75,000 Americans now run businesses entirely on eBay's sites. EBay strides through the world economy like a movie star, surrounded by its horde of dependent businesses, its buyers, sellers, critics and rapturous fans.
But the story leaves you pondering. The Web supposedly began a new information age, but eBay brings nothing of its own to the table; it simply connects people. It uses cyberspace not as a library but as a giant switchboard. And this era of the Great Switchboard in the Sky has barely begun. When I said in a 1991 book that global electronic auctions were inevitable (one prophetic claim plus 75 cents will get you today's newspaper), I meant four related activities: buyers bidding to get goods or services from a seller; sellers bidding to supply goods or services to a buyer. So far, eBay concentrates only on buyers bidding for goods, but the rest will follow. And it won't stop there. People will consult the great cyberswitchboard to get a job or a mate or a life. (It's already happening.)
EBay makes money by brokering deals. But what happens when buyers and sellers cut out the middleman and deal direct? At eBay you search for the item you want. But you can also search the Web as a whole. In the long run, we won't need two separate levels of search. Eventually we will use the fabric of cyberspace itself, not eBay, as our switchboard.
But chances are eBay will somehow still be making money off the deal.

HEADLINE: INSIDE ART 

BYLINE:  By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:
A Portrait With a Pedigree
 The cover of the May 10 issue of The Gazette de Drouot, a weekly publication about art and antiques sales in France, had an unusual image from a small country auction in the Loire Valley: a portrait of Washington as commander in chief of the American Revolutionary forces, painted in 1782 by Charles Willson Peale. Also strange was the low estimate, just under $300,000. 
 "The minute I saw it I assumed it would go for a high price," said Thomas Coville, a private American art dealer in New Haven and New York. "Its provenance and history make it extremely important." 
Mr. Coville teamed up with Stewart Feld of Hirschl & Adler and Vance Jordan, both of Manhattan, to buy the portrait. Bidding was fierce, and the three ended up paying $5.3 million, a record for a traditional American painting sold in Europe.
Peale painted many versions of this picture. One is in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, another in the Princeton University Art Museum, a third at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts and a fourth at Versailles, where it once belonged to Louis XVI. Mr. Coville said his recent purchase was "the only one we know of that was still in private hands."
In 1781 after the Battle of Yorktown, the Executive Supreme Council in Philadelphia decided to commission a portrait of Washington and engaged Peale, the leading portraitist of the time, who was living in Philadelphia. He had known Washington for 10 years, having joined the Revolutionary Army and having fought in the Battle of Princeton. So Peale's were the first official portraits of Washington by someone who had fought in the Revolution.
This painting, a three-quarter-length image, shows a youthful, charismatic Washington, a very different image from the elderly Washington in the portrait by Gilbert Stuart. It is thought to have been executed after the Battle of Yorktown, in which Washington's army along with the French forces under the command of Jean B. Donatien de Vimeur, Marechal de Rochambeau, defeated the British in the final major battle of the war. This work, in which the battle is seen in the background, was taken to France in 1783 by the marechal to his chateau, near Vendome. It remained there until the sale in June.
The fact that it came from a descendant of the commander of the French forces at Yorktown and had only one owner makes it particularly important. It had been exhibited only once, in 1975, at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington. Adding to its rarity is that it hangs in its original Louis XVI frame.
Mr. Coville said he, Mr. Feld and Mr. Jordan have not decided on a price for the painting. It arrived in New York just last week, and they were not sure who would show it first.
Is the rocky economy a concern to the dealers? 
"This is probably one of the few pictures one should buy in this economy because its value has nothing to do with the state of the stock market," Mr. Jordan said, adding that the dealers hope it will end up in a museum. 

A Cutback at Phillips
Last week Thierry Millerand resigned as director of French and Continental furniture for Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg. This week the auction house announced that it was closing the department. It does, however, plan to go ahead with an auction of the London dealer John Hobbs's furniture and decorative objects on Oct. 22.
"Our strategy is to focus like a boutique on just a few categories in areas we know best," said Louise T. Blouin MacBain, Phillips's chief executive. She added that Simon de Pury and Daniella Luxembourg had no intention of holding French furniture sales when they joined the company in January 2001. But since Mr. Millerand, considered one of world's leading experts in French and Continental furniture, was already working there, it made sense to keep a schedule of furniture sales.
While Phillips is shutting down one department, Mrs. MacBain stressed that it would be expanding others, bringing in more experts in areas like watches, 20th- and 21st-century design, and photography.
Meanwhile, she dispelled rumors that the auction house would move out of its West 57th Street headquarters. "We have a five-year lease," she said. "Nothing is going to change. But we might rent out one or two floors if there is a demand for them."

Educating the Public
The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art wants to make education more than simply comprehensive labels, gallery talks and regularly scheduled programs. On Oct. 12 it will open the Koret Visitor Education Center, a public drop-in center. The new 7,000-square-foot center, on the museum's second floor, more than triple the size of its current education center, will feature seating areas so the public can peruse exhibition catalogs and art books. It will also have activity bins for children, multimedia kiosks, video and DVD viewing stations and online information. A trained staff member will be on hand to answer questions.
"The traditional education programs reach only a small percentage of visitors," said John S. Weber, curator of education and public programs. "We've invested in our collection. Now we need to invest in ways people can better understand it." Mr. Weber also stressed that the museum intended to continue its scheduled educational programs.

Comings and Goings
David Gordon, secretary of the Royal Academy of Arts in London, has been named director of the Milwaukee Art Museum. He replaces Russell Bowman, who is starting an art-consulting business in Chicago. Mr. Gordon will start his new job in October.
"I've lived in London for 60 years," Mr. Gordon said. "I thought it was time for a change." He said he was "entranced by the museum's incredible building and collection."
An American investment banker is filling Mr. Gordon's place at the Royal Academy. Lawton Fitt, a managing director at Goldman, Sachs, will be the firstwoman to occupy the post in the 234-year history of the academy.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 30, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A brief report in the Inside Art column of Weekend on Friday about the sale of a Charles Willson Peale portrait of George Washington for $5.3 million in June in Cheverny, France, misspelled the names of two of the three purchasers. The buyers were Thomas Colville (not Coville), Stuart Feld (not Stewart) and Vance Jordan.

HEADLINE: People Who Can Rebuild A City 

BYLINE:  By Richard Florida; Richard Florida is a professor of economic development at Carnegie Mellon University and author of "The Rise of the Creative Class."

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH 

 BODY:
As planning for the former World Trade Center site enters a pivotal stage, it's clear that more is at stake than designing a memorial. The future of a region is being shaped. While the recently released plans and the reaction to them have sparked much discussion of architectural vision, the real issue is economic. We can't assess whether the plans are sufficiently visionary, or say whether the vision is the right one, until we have a clear sense of how Lower Manhattan is to function in the greater New York economy.
 That economy is fundamentally a creative economy. Growth derives from the endless creation of new firms, new industries and new ways of doing things. The directions these may take in a free-market system are unpredictable. Thus the most sensible overall planning approach is to help Lower Manhattan become what it is becoming anyway -- a multifaceted creative hub -- rather than to indulge in economic overplanning or try to micromanage the future. 
 Planners must avoid the temptation of using public land and subsidies to set industrial policy, either by trying to prop up existing industries or to pick winners from among the new ones. The fear that Lower Manhattan is losing its status as a center of the financial industry, for example, is not new and should not be allowed to drive planning. Well before Sept. 11, financial-sector activity was diffusing away from Wall Street, as when Goldman Sachs & Company decided to move many operations to a new building across the Hudson River. But the Street isn't dead. If it were, firms would be moving to Austin or Taipei, not New Jersey. What we're seeing is a natural cycle: all industries cluster and then diffuse over time.
To replace the tax revenue lost by this diffusion, some favor promoting biotechnology in Lower Manhattan. But biotech startups are complex and iffy, burning tons of cash through long development cycles, and even a substantial biotech sector would hardly be able to replace financial services. It's never wise for communities to bet a big chunk of the farm on one industry -- be it biotech or baseball. Even a hot growth industry may cool off or evolve in unexpected ways.
No one knows what the next big thing will be, and it often emerges where two or more fields intersect. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg built his business ventures by mixing finance and information technology; others have built theirs by mixing information technology with retail savvy, graphic arts or music.
It's not surprising that the most successful metropolitan areas are places that attract a range of creative workers -- not just technical and business types but the artists, writers, performers, designers and others who make up the creative class.
San Francisco, Seattle and Boston are prime examples; so is greater New York. Every such region has at its core an urban hub. Typically these hubs have teeming cultural districts like the blend of galleries, music clubs and other small venues long found in Greenwich Village; mixed-use, live-work-play areas like those in the former warehouse districts of SoHo and Tribeca; ethnic neighborhoods like Chinatown; and artists' havens like Williamsburg, Chelsea, Dumbo and Red Hook near Lower Manhattan.
These hubs, in turn, play multiple roles in the economic life of a metropolitan area. They attract talent, are good venues for any business that is creativity-intensive and serve as places for people from many different fields to exchange ideas.
From Seattle to Cambridge, Mass., the coffee house, the bistro and the bikepath serve the functions that the businessmen's club and the golf links always have: they're where the next generation of movers and shakers meet and mingle.
Lower Manhattan is ideal for this role. It lies at the crossroads of the region and adjacent neighborhoods have the diversity and creative culture required today for competitive advantage. Combine this with the financial expertise and capital long available here and you have what could be a natural setting for the growth of new ventures building on existing strengths. 
In practical terms, how can planners best help Lower Manhattan keep evolving in this direction? First, don't muck up what's organic and unique, either by force-feeding certain industries or by building the generic malls that turn off many creative workers.
Instead, integrate with what's already blooming. Think about seeding institutions that draw a diversity of jobs and talents: perhaps multidisciplinary think tanks or university branches. Make room for more housing, and when adding cultural amenities, think beyond tourist attractions and big-ticket high-art venues. Add or encourage participatory features that residents can enjoy regularly: more green space, bikepaths and walkways, and waterfront access.
Above all, work on connectivity. Not just a transit system to shuttle workers from bedroom communities to office towers but vastly upgraded rapid transit by rail, water, you name it -- in and out of the hub and all around the tri-state region. That's expensive and a tall order. But it is vital for an age in which high-growth regions must have a variety of urban subcenters around a creative hub, rather than a few monolithic business or industrial districts.
The real opportunity here is to help Lower Manhattan become the prototypical hub of the 21st century -- by accelerating its natural evolution from a center of global financial innovation to a place that feeds creative growth across the region.

HEADLINE: China Vexed by Glare of U.S. Investigations 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Friday, July 26 

 BODY:
Senior Chinese officials are expressing irritation over a series of American actions in the last two weeks but are keeping their public comments fairly low-key as they seek to put a rosy glow on China's position in the world in preparation for the Communist Party congress this autumn.
 The timing of recent critical reports by the United States appears to have been coincidental, involving investigations that were many months in the making. But the quick succession of criticisms of China has clearly annoyed officials here. 
 The Pentagon released a report on July 12 concluding that China was rapidly modernizing its military with an eye to countering American power in the Pacific and pressing Taiwan over unification. 
A commission created by the Congress nearly two years ago released a separate report on July 15 in which it concluded that China posed a security and economic threat to the United States. 
Finally, the State Department said last Friday that the United States would impose sanctions on eight Chinese companies and a Chinese citizen accused of selling equipment with potential military applications to Iran. The companies were identified on Wednesday and at least two have denied they transferred arms technology or related goods to the Middle East. 
Yan Xuetong, the director of the Institute of International Studies at Qinghua University here, said the drumbeat of criticism had sent a message that the relationship between the United States and China had cooled somewhat in recent months. 
"The timing gives China a clear signal that the improvement after Sept. 11 is a temporary improvement and not a permanent change," he said.
China has supported the American effort to curb terrorism, partly because of concerns about China's own Muslim minority in the western region of Xinjiang.
But in contrast with previous periods when China has taken public offense at statements from Washington, the complaints this time have been relatively muted. With preparations under way for the party congress, held once every five years, Chinese leaders are saying little on many subjects, not just policy toward the United States.
Many decisions are being deferred. For instance, China's central bank announced on Tuesday that it would leave interest rates unchanged instead of cutting them as had been widely expected.
People's Daily and other major newspapers carried a front-page commentary on Tuesday titled "Stress the General Situation, Stress Unity, Stress Stability." 
No date has been set yet for the party congress, and there have been reports of infighting over the extent to which a younger generation of leaders will replace Jiang Zemin, China's president and the party's general secretary, and his closest advisers.
The low-key tone of Chinese objections has been especially true of the response to the sanctions. The Foreign Ministry ended up faxing a cautiously worded three-sentence protest to news agencies on Monday afternoon but did not follow its usual procedure of issuing a statement through the official New China News Agency. 
The news media here have ignored the sanctions so far, which will bar the nine companies from doing business with the American government and limit their ability to trade with the United States. 
The reports from the Pentagon and from the United States-China Security Review Commission, appointed by Congress, have belatedly drawn a somewhat stronger response. 
Zeng Jianhui, chairman of the foreign affairs committee of the National People's Congress, told the official China Daily on July 17 that the reports' discussion of a Chinese threat to the United States was "out of tune with the trend of Sino-U.S. relations."
The Chinese Embassy in Washington criticized the Pentagon report on Monday, especially its assertion that China spends more than three times as much on its military as it publicly acknowledges. But the criticism was issued by a spokesman, Xie Feng, rather than the ambassador.
China Daily published two front-page articles on the reports today, with Mr. Zeng saying that he would like to invite the reports' authors to China and adding, "I'd like to see no confrontation or bickering but, instead, efforts to find more common interests and truth in a matter-of-fact way."
Michael Wessel, a member of the Security Review Commission, said that the commission had been aware that the Pentagon was preparing its own report but that the release of the two reports just three days apart was coincidental. 
"There was no coordination or Machiavellian intrigue here," he said in a phone interview from Washington, adding that he had not been aware of the plan for sanctions either.
The commission's most controversial recommendation was that American businesses should report to Washington on their investments in China and technology transfers to China, along with the effects of their China operations on the number of people they employed in the United States.

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Rise On Economic Data 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Bonds rose for a fifth trading session in six yesterday as stocks fell and the government said that durable goods orders tumbled, adding to evidence the economy's recovery from recession is slowing.
 The report "puts doubt in people's minds about how strong the recovery will be," said Edgar Peters, who helps manage $15 billion at PanAgora Asset Management in Boston. 
"That's what is moderating any euphoria in the stock market and helping to keep bond yields low." 
 Demand for bonds picked up after the Commerce Department said orders fell 3.8 percent, the first drop since March and the largest since November.
The price of the 10-year note rose 25/32 , to 103 27/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.38 percent from 4.47 percent. The 30-year bond rose 23/32 , to 101 4/32 , while its yield fell to 5.30 percent from 5.35 percent.

HEADLINE: Hedging Learned at the Family Farm 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
John Henry is a complicated man.
 He owns a controlling interest in the Boston Red Sox and a small piece of the New York Yankees. 
 For most people, this would be something of an existential crisis. Since the Sox sold Babe Ruth to the Yankees in 1920, Boston stopped winning championships and the Yankees started winning them and have not stopped. 
The rules of baseball prohibit this sort of dual ownership, though there are much bigger issues for Bud Selig, the baseball commissioner, to ponder, like the possibility of a strike. But it seems appropriate for an investor who is often betting in multiple directions. 
Mr. Henry himself, a lifelong baseball fan, learned how to hedge against the weather and price fluctuations when he took over his family's Arkansas farm at age 25. He previously owned the Florida Marlins, which he sold last year to buy the Red Sox. His Yankee stake preceded both those relationships. One of Mr. Henry's minority partners in the purchase of the Red Sox was The New York Times Company.
He said in an interview this week that he had had a deal in place to sell his share of the Yankees to an unnamed party, but then accepted a competing bid from the Yankees' management. 
"We have a deal, we have a price, they just haven't sent me the money," he said. "Maybe they're afraid I might spend some of it." As in, on free agents for the Sox. 
Maybe they should be worried, because Mr. Henry is one of the few major investment managers making money right now. His John W. Henry & Company, an investment fund group, based in Boca Raton, Fla., struggled during the bull market, but is prospering again, with his funds appreciating sharply. 
Mr. Henry, 52, a cerebral man with a head for mathematics, uses complex formulas to trade futures contracts, which promise the delivery of assets like commodities or stock indexes on a future date at a set price. Money managers like Mr. Henry, also known as managed futures investors, follow trends in the global market, looking for price discrepancies to exploit, be it changes in currencies, grain prices or interest rates.
Mr. Henry talks about trading the way Yoda talks about the Force. 
"The nature of markets is to trend," he once said, referring to his style of investing, which he calls trend following. "The nature of life is to trend." 
George Soros, once the world's largest hedge fund manager, exploits some of the same trends Mr. Henry does, but with a more gut-driven approach. Managed futures investing tends to be driven by computer formulas and quantitative analysis. Mr. Henry's fund is also structured differently from a hedge fund and is available to retail investors with as little as $5,000 to allocate, though skeptics contend such funds are overly risky.
Part of Mr. Henry's philosophy is that trends course through the markets and their wake can render what seems like a sure-fire stock pick useless, because nothing operates in a vacuum. 
"I've seen year after year, brilliant men buying low and selling high -- for a while successfully -- and then going broke because they thought they understood why a certain investment instrument had to perform in accordance with their personal logic," he said in a speech in 2000. 
By October of 2000, the fund group's assets had fallen from $2.4 billion to $1 billion in about 12 months, so Mr. Henry cut his fees and consolidated his operations.
But in the last year, his style has returned to favor. His assets are back to $1.4 billion. His largest fund, Strategic Allocation, is up 22 percent in the last year and has gained 13.1 percent annually over the last five years, compared with 3.7 percent for the S.& P. 500. 
His most profitable trend this year has been the change in the direction of the dollar against the euro. Since the euro's inception, American tourists have enjoyed its weakness. But a variety of factors, from the terrorist attacks to the limp United States economy to the bear market, have strengthened the euro against the dollar. Last week, its value surpassed the dollar's for the first time in more than two years. 
"I began believing in March that we were going to have a major move in the dollar, so we had some fairly big positions," Mr. Henry said. "We've been long not just the euro but the British pound and the yen.
"When you're in this kind of situation, this decline in the stock market, you have to hope this fund is working," he added. "That's what you're in it for. This is a way to be diversified."

HEADLINE: China Bank Shares Fall in Initial Offering 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 25 

 BODY:
In one of the biggest stock market debuts anywhere in the world this year, shares of the Hong Kong unit of the Bank of China began trading publicly today. They promptly fell 4.7 percent on heavy selling by Hong Kong residents.
 The initial price for the offering was set last Saturday. Since then, markets around the world have weakened, and the Hang Seng index, the main barometer of Hong Kong stocks, has fallen by 4.3 percent, so today's movement in the bank stock caught up with the broader market. 
 Still, the offering, which raised 19.5 billion Hong Kong dollars ($2.5 billion), was a milestone for China, the first international stock listing by a mainland bank. In it, the state-owned Bank of China sold 22 percent of the shares in its Hong Kong unit, which is the territory's largest lender and its second-largest taker of deposits.
The Chinese government has been actively selling stakes in state-owned enterprises even when stock markets have been weak, in the hope that partial private ownership will improve the business practices at the companies. China Telecom, the near-monopoly provider of fixed-line phone service in southern China, is preparing an even larger initial public offering for later this year.
About a third of the shares in the Bank of China offering were set aside for retail investors living in Hong Kong to buy at a 5 percent discount; the rest were sold to institutions and foreigners at full price. The discount allocation, a common feature in large privatizations around the world, prompted a frenzy of activity over the last three weeks.
Residents filed 385,000 applications for shares, a huge number in a territory of 6.8 million people.
Trading opened today near the full offering price, 8.5 Hong Kong dollars ($1.09) a share, but the price eroded during the day, to close at 8.10 Hong Kong dollars, barely above the discount price retail investors paid.
Analysts said the Bank of China and its underwriters had been lucky that financial markets in New York rebounded so strongly on Wednesday. The Hang Seng, which lost heavily before the American rebound on Wednesday, inched down only 0.9 percent today.
"The timing was quite fortunate given what happened in the U.S. markets overnight -- otherwise the results could have been quite a bit worse," said Patrick Vizzone, a director of Commercial Economics Asia, a Hong Kong consulting firm.
Local corporate and institutional investors were not so lucky. More than a dozen companies that are trying to expand in mainland China and want to impress Beijing, led by the Standard Chartered Bank, agreed in advance to buy large blocks of stock in the initial public offering instead of waiting to buy it from retail investors during the early trading. 
Large institutional investors around the world were also buyers -- some through a private placement of the stock today in the United States -- on the expectation that the stock would soon be included in the Hang Seng Index and in a widely followed index published by Morgan Stanley Capital International.
Traders said the stock fell despite heavy buying by the underwriters to support it. The lead underwriters were Goldman, Sachs; UBS Warburg; and Bank of China International Holdings, another arm of the parent bank in Beijing.
Because of strong demand in the days before trading began, the underwriters actually sold 15 percent more shares than the Bank of China initially sold, with all of the extra shares going to institutional investors. They must cover the difference within 30 days, either by buying shares in the open market or by having the Bank of China issue more stock to them at the institutional price.
Despite the first-day drop, investors still valued the Hong Kong unit of the Bank of China higher than American institutions like J. P. Morgan and Citigroup, as measured by the ratio of stock price to book value. Yet 9.5 percent of the unit's loan assets are classified as nonperforming, even after the government took some bad loans off its books. That is nearly twice the average for Hong Kong banks and six times that of American banks.
None of the proceeds of the offer will remain in the Hong Kong unit as fresh capital; it will instead go to the parent bank, whose nonperforming-loan burden is higher still.
Henry Lee, managing director of the Hendale Group, a Hong Kong money management company, said the crucial question now was whether the stock would fall below 8 Hong Kong dollars a share. "If they break that, it may not come back up above that level soon," he said.
If it does fall that far, the Bank of China risks antagonizing Hong Kong residents despite the retail discount. Although trading was fairly heavy today, equal to one-sixth of all the newly issued shares, many people at one Hong Kong brokerage office were holding on to their stakes.
"Wait and see is my approach, and I'll only sell it when it goes up to 8.60," said Chan Yee-ting, 52, who described herself as a housewife. "It's a long-term investment for me."

HEADLINE: Build Plants, Top Energy Regulator Urges 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR

 BODY:
New York's top energy regulator called yesterday for the construction of new power plants and greater participation in conservation programs, saying that the near-record electrical use earlier this month illustrates the need for action.
 The push comes during a month in which the downstate region experienced one major power failure and several smaller ones. The regulator, Maureen O. Helmer, chairwoman of the New York Public Service Commission, told government officials this week that while she was confident the state would be able to make it through the summer without any more major failures, more long-term solutions were needed, including the building of new plants. 
 State regulators have approved several new generation projects, although many have been stalled by the inability of power companies to attract investments because of the Enron scandal and the weakening economy. 
This month's power problems came as a surprise to many energy experts, who thought that the softening economy, the loss of the World Trade Center and other factors would reduce demand for power this summer. But utilities still found themselves struggling to meet demand in many areas.
"Our experience early this month reinforces the fact that the demand for electricity is growing and that we must continue our efforts," Ms. Helmer said in a statement released late Wednesday.
On Saturday, an explosion at a Consolidated Edison substation on the East River knocked out electrical power for roughly 63,000 people in Manhattan. It is still unclear exactly what caused the short circuit that led to the explosion, officials said yesterday.
Two years ago, state officials, including Ms. Helmer, warned that a power crisis was rapidly developing. As a result, the New York Power Authority installed 10 minigenerators in the city. The timing proved crucial, because in August 2001 the Con Ed network reached record levels of use.
At a City Council hearing on Tuesday, Ms. Helmer said the minigenerators were not enough. She said the state was prepared to activate several programs that encourage customers to reduce electric consumption to cope with shortages. In emergencies, Con Ed has the authority to demand that some businesses reduce their power usage.
On July 18, the New York Power Authority was able to reduce demand in the city by asking more than 15 businesses and government agencies to cut back as part of a program that provides organizations with $40 for each kilowatt of electrical power that they save, said Michael Saltzman, a power authority spokesman. Gov. George E. Pataki has heavily promoted a program under which people receive $75 for turning in inefficient air-conditioners.
The New York Independent System Operator, which runs the power grid, has said the city will need 2,000 to 3,000 additional megawatts of power generation by 2005. Con Ed has a capacity of about 13,000 megawatts in the city and Westchester County. To address long-term concerns, Ms. Helmer called for the construction of new plants and for importing electricity under the Hudson River and through the New York Harbor from New Jersey and other states.
Ms. Helmer said that she did not anticipate any other serious problems this summer, but stopped short of making any guarantees.

HEADLINE: U.S. Proposes to Cut Global Farm Subsidies 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25 

 BODY:
The Bush administration, criticized overseas for supporting a huge increase in American farm subsidies this year, said today it was prepared to seek reductions worldwide as part of a global trade agreement.
 The proposal was included in a negotiating package the administration unveiled in advance of World Trade Organization farm negotiations to resume next week in Geneva. 
 "This plan is a win for America's farmers, ranchers and consumers and also a win for the global economy," the United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, said at a news conference.
The administration will seek a ban on export subsidies, payments provided to increase foreign sales, and sharp cuts in domestic support provided to farmers to raise production.
The United States proposal would cap this support at 5 percent of a country's total farm output, a figure that the administration said would trim $100 billion from the current level of subsidies provided by the United States, the European Union and other wealthy countries.
Beyond the curbs on trade distorting subsidies, the administration also called for global tariffs on farm products to be cut from a worldwide average of 62 percent to an average of 15 percent in five years.
The administration's proposal has won praise from major American farm groups.

HEADLINE: Data Suggest Weak Spots In Economy 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25 

 BODY:
Factory orders for big-ticket goods, including cars and computers, unexpectedly fell 3.8 percent in June from May, the largest amount in seven months, the Commerce Department reported today.
 The June decline in orders for durable goods -- items expected to last at least three years -- was the first since March and came after a 0.6 percent increase in May. Analysts had expected a 0.6 percent increase. 
 Adding to concerns was a National Association of Realtors report today that sales of existing homes -- the largest part of the housing market -- dropped 11.7 percent in June from May. That left sales at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.1 million, the lowest in nine months. Existing-home sales, however, have been running at brisk levels for much of the year and the association is forecasting record sales for 2002.
The Commerce Department, meanwhile, reported today that new-home sales rose to a record seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1 million in June, a 0.5 percent increase over May. Analysts had expected a 4.7 percent decline.
Many analysts think low mortgage rates will continue to support the housing market, which in turn would help a recovery.
The decline in durable-goods orders along with a 1.4 percent drop in shipments -- a barometer of current demand -- was considered an ominous sign that businesses might be growing even more uncertain about a recovery.
"The report suggests that there is an endemic concern about the state of their own businesses, whether consumers will step up and buy their products, and the prospects for the economy in general," said Mark Zandi, chief economist for Economy.com.
The decline in orders was broad based. Orders for cars, computers, communications equipment, machinery, metals, metal products and electrical equipment all dropped.
"The glass remains half-empty for many manufacturers and the recovery -- while well under way -- has not yet accelerated to a satisfactory pace," David Huether, chief economist for the National Association of Manufacturers, said.
Two Labor Department reports released today offered workers some encouraging news. Wages and benefits increased 1 percent in the quarter from April to June from the previous quarter, the fastest pace in six months. That came after a 0.8 percent advance in the first three months of this year.
In addition, new claims for state unemployment insurance dropped to a 17-month low, suggesting that the pace of layoffs is stabilizing. Claims fell last week by a seasonally adjusted 21,000, to 362,000.

HEADLINE: Kodak's Profit Increases, but Sales FallAgain 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, July 25 

 BODY:
The Eastman Kodak Company reported today that its second-quarter profit increased sharply because of a tax benefit and cost reductions. Sales, however, fell for a seventh consecutive quarter. 
 Net income rose to $284 million, or 97 cents a share, from $36 million, or 12 cents, a year earlier. Revenue fell 7 percent, to $3.34 billion, from $3.59 billion, the company said. Quarterly sales last rose in the third quarter of 2000. 
 Excluding a tax gain related to the closing of a subsidiary and a write-down of assets, profit would have fallen to $248 million, or 85 cents a share, from $325 million, or $1.12, Kodak said. The average profit estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was 83 cents.
Film sales in the United States fell 20 percent in the quarter as consumers cut back travel plans and took fewer photos. Layoffs and other cost-cutting measures helped earnings this quarter and hurt results a year ago. The chief executive, Daniel A. Carp, said Kodak was not seeing signs of an economic improvement.
Operating cash flow in the quarter fell 18 percent, to $410 million from $503 million a year earlier. 
"What we have to do at Kodak is manage for cash, stay tough on costs, manage market share and position for the upturn," Mr. Carp said. "We're just going to have to keep our heads down and grind through this."
Shares of Kodak fell 29 cents, to $28.10. They have fallen 36 percent in the last year amid declining sales and competition from Fuji Photo Film of Japan.

HEADLINE: McCall Faults Nursing Home Investigations 

BYLINE:  By LYDIA POLGREEN

 BODY:
Thousands of complaints about poor care at nursing homes in New York were ignored or not properly investigated by the State Health Department last year, according to an audit released yesterday by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall.
 Mr. McCall said the failures occurred even after the state centralized its system of tracking complaints. In the new system, instituted in May 2001, complaints are entered into a centralized database managed by department officials in Albany and sent to regional offices for investigation. The system includes a toll-free number so people can check the status of their complaints. 
 But the audit, which compared the database records with records kept in regional offices, found serious discrepancies between the records, indicating that many complaints were not properly investigated, Mr. McCall said. 
The audit found that of a random sample of complaints, 43 percent were not investigated promptly or not investigated at all. Nearly 1,000 cases, including 695 in the New York City region, were assigned to investigators who no longer worked for the Health Department, the audit found, and more than 1,200 complaints were assigned to investigators who lacked proper certification.
In some cases, serious complaints of physical abuse or safety concerns were not investigated within two days, even though investigators are required by law to do so within that period, the audit found.
At a news conference in Manhattan yesterday, Mr. McCall, who is running for governor, accused Gov. George E. Pataki's administration of failing to "adequately investigate allegations of abuse, neglect and mistreatment" of nursing home residents across the state. 
A statement released yesterday by the Health Department said that it has more investigators than ever before, 246 to supervise 685 nursing homes, and that it levied record fines in 2001. According to the statement, 95 homes were inspected in 2001, up from 43 the previous year.
John Signor, a spokesman for the Health Department, said Mr. McCall had twisted the audit results to suit his political purposes. "Once again, Carl McCall is unnecessarily scaring seniors and their families in a shameless attempt to further his political ambitions," he said. "Every complaint received by the department is reviewed and investigated."
Health care watchdog groups said the audit confirmed accounts of problems that they had heard about for years. Cynthia Rudder, director of the Nursing Home Community Coalition, said investigations into complaints often ended without family members being informed of the outcome of the inquiries, or were investigated improperly or too slowly. 
"One resident complained about a lack of blankets in the winter, but by the time the investigator showed up it was summer and he found there was no problem with blankets," Ms. Rudder said.
Patricia Sheehan put her father, Oswaldo Esteves, 73, in a nursing home in Jackson Heights, Queens, almost two years ago, when his symptoms of Alzheimer's disease became too much for her mother to handle at home. When her father contracted pneumonia in spring of 2001 and had to be hospitalized, doctors discovered that his body was covered with tiny red insect bites.
Mrs. Sheehan said she got no response when she called the Health Department to complain. She put her father in a different home but tried to follow up to make sure other patients in the first home did not suffer the same problems.
Six months later, an investigator called her to check on her father's status. "They said there was no need to pursue it anymore since he had been moved," Mrs. Sheehan said. "I was totally shocked."

HEADLINE: Protecting Capitalism From Itself 

 BODY:
Back when financial markets were soaring, analysts marveled at the phenomenon of "panic buying" on Wall Street -- the desperate snatching up of any stocks within reach by investors who felt they could not afford to stay on the sidelines. Yesterday's nearly unanimous passage by both houses of Congress of sweeping corporate governance reform legislation was the political equivalent of panic buying. We are in a bull market for reform, and even the most adamant foes of regulation realized they could not afford to stay on the sidelines.
 However, the bill itself, unlike some of the stocks snatched up by investors in the late 1990's bubble, has real underlying value. It is essentially the legislation introduced in the Senate by Paul Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat. Until a few weeks ago it seemed to have little chance of being approved by the Senate Banking Committee, let alone by the Republican-controlled House of Representatives, which initially passed a far weaker reform bill. Now, within days, President Bush is expected to sign into law a reform he could not quite bring himself to endorse explicitly as recently as July 9, when he came to Wall Street. 
 The legislation creates an independent oversight board with strong disciplinary powers for the accounting industry. It was in the 1930's that private accounting firms were formally entrusted with certifying corporations' financial statements on behalf of the public, but the profession has proved incapable of policing and disciplining those of its members who betray that trust. 
The new measure rightly forbids auditors to provide many kinds of lucrative consulting services to companies whose numbers they are checking on the public's behalf. It also requires firms to rotate their lead partners involved with a client, and directs the Securities and Exchange Commission, which will oversee the new accounting board, to review a greater number of financial statements.
Top corporate executives will become more liable for any misleading information provided by their companies, although an opportunity was missed to make them liable not only for misstatements they know to be such, but also for those they should reasonably be expected to know are untrue. This leaves open the door for continued plausible deniability in the boardroom, and may be an issue for Congress to revisit soon. 
The self-congratulatory rhetoric in Washington cannot hide the fact that much of what this legislation ostensibly does accomplish -- both in terms of policing accountants and cracking down on companies' own malfeasance -- will be undone in the absence of vigorous and effective enforcement by the S.E.C. The current commission chairman, Harvey Pitt, has proved to be the wrong man at the wrong time for the job. News of his absurd quest to obtain cabinet status and a salary increase has further undermined confidence in the judgment of Mr. Pitt, a former lawyer for the accounting industry who took office last year ominously pledging to preside over a gentler, friendlier S.E.C. The bill proposes a needed boost in funding for a commission long hobbled by insufficient resources as well as by delays on the part of the White House and the Senate in seating the four other commissioners. 
The American economy is still trying to get past the damage done by greedy executives -- and their facilitators in the accounting and other professions -- who believed that making a company's performance look good was more important than actually performing. If President Bush and Congress produce a law empowering the S.E.C. to crack down on false accounting and corporate malfeasance without ensuring that the commission has the will and resources to do so, this seemingly ambitious bill will turn out to be just another illusion, a short-lived reform bubble on Capitol Hill.

PERSON: Alain E. Kaloyeros 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
Behind a Research Center, a Geek With Great Cars

BYLINE:  By ROBIN FINN

DATELINE: ALBANY 

 BODY:
AT the technology-obsessed State University of New York here, the big man on campus this season does not play football. To be blunt, at 5-foot-7 -- on his tiptoes or in his dreams -- he's nowhere near big enough, and at age 46, this grizzled physics professor is past prime time for rough-housing on athletic fields. Instead, he plays around with atoms, invents chip technology, and was point man in the project that is to bring a $400 million computer chip research center, and potentially thousands of new jobs, to Albany later this year.
 "I don't believe in computer intelligence, only human intelligence," says Alain E. Kaloyeros, a dapper dervish of a scientist. "After all, we're the ones who make them. Though I think in some ways, by swamping us with information, they're training us to be smarter and faster." 
 But being on science's cutting edge does not make Mr. Kaloyeros a one-dimensional man. Perish the thought. His nostrils flare, as does his Continental accent (part Greek, part French, part Lebanese). Check out that trophy key hanging from his belt loop: it ignites a 390-horsepower Maserati. He has a sports car fetish, a sushi habit, and an addiction to Starbucks; his favorite movie is "Ocean's Eleven," the George Clooney version. He loves its sarcasm, especially when insomnia strikes. His favorite invention, even though it's not one of his, is the radar detector. 
In these parts, Mr. Kaloyeros, dean of the School of Nanosciences and Nanoengineering, the future-is-now branch of physics that traffics in individual atom management, is most definitely the player of the moment. Something of a computer chip wizard -- he holds 10 patents for thin film technology and last year received SUNY's Outstanding Inventor Award -- Mr. Kaloyeros is also a veritable Chamber of Commerce in disguise. 
It turns out he's the guy who, along with Gov. George E. Pataki, can take credit for bringing an infusion of Silicon Valley to the Hudson Valley. When the industry-epitomizing consortium, International Sematech, which Mr. Kaloyeros and the university has done business with since 1994, let slip last year that it needed a state-of-the-art research center that could open by October 2002, Mr. Kaloyeros didn't think twice: "I said, 'Why not New York?' and we took it from there." 
He wooed the Sematech executives like a suitor: first the trip to Lake George for a scenic powwow with the Semiconductor Industry Association, then the campus tour (nice coincidence that a construction project -- tenants wanted -- was under way adjacent to his Nanosciences building), then lots of quality time with the governor. That last thing, he says, was a pivotal psychological component because "it implies that the state is interested in a long-term relationship." In short, he did everything but send flowers; not that he didn't think of it. A single pink rose was how he roped in his wife, Paula, in the late 80's.
THE secret negotiations lasted from September until last week, when Sematech announced its plans to move onto campus, right next door to the Center for Environmental Science and Technology Management, the futuristic ship-shaped building where Mr. Kaloyeros has an office, appropriately, in the glassy prow. Earnest old Albany not only bested a bid by Belgium, but according to him, it fended off a pair of after-the-fact counteroffers from other states. He isn't sure if he should name them, but what the heck: sorry, Oregon and Florida. 
"They're the darling of the industry," he says of Sematech, whose 12-member constituency includes I.B.M., Intel, Motorola and Royal Philips Electronics. "Everybody would like to get Sematech in their backyard; this whole new high-tech field is driven by university research, and building critical mass at the state university level is something that's going to end up helping to drive the state's economy. You know, we're at the point now where 90 percent of your life is run by computer chips," he adds. Clearly, he thinks this is a swell thing. Money in his pocket, too: he or she who invents the littlest, fastest, multi-tasking chip will never hurt for work. 
Not for nothing does the vanity plate on his metallic black Porsche Boxster -- his alternate ride is that brand-new Maserati Spyder crouched in the parking lot -- shout out his tongue-in-cheek take on his sense of self: GEEK. As in, the strata of geekdom where Bill Gates, whom Mr. Kaloyeros describes as a transcendent nerd, is club president. Mr. Kaloyeros purchased his last two Porsches courtesy of royalties from his patents and is already lusting after the Ferrari 360 Spider. He's in line for a black model; all his convertibles are black, and all his cars are convertibles, the better to tan in while driving to work from suburban Slingerlands, where he lives with his wife and two sons. 
Mr. Kaloyeros earned a doctorate in physics from the University of Illinois in 1987. Raised to be career-minded in East Beirut, Lebanon, where his father was a banker and his mother worked in marketing for Sony and Sanyo, he recalls that the in crowd at his Lebanese high school was composed of the smart kids, not the jocks or beauty queens. "Better be nice to geeks," he jokes, "because the way the world is going, chances are you're going to end up working for one."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Day Is Freneti c As Investors Start Looking For Bargains

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
In another day of stock market sound and fury, the Nasdaq composite index took a pounding, but the broader market averages closed with only modest losses.
 Portfolio managers, encouraged by the action, said investors seemed to shift out of a sell-everything mode and were beginning once again to differentiate between stocks that are cheap and those that are not. 
 At the close of trading, the Nasdaq composite index had fallen 50.15 points, or 3.9 percent, while the Dow Jones industrial average ended the day flat, at 8,186.31. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 4.75 points, or about a half of 1 percent. With about 2.5 billion shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange, trading was frenetic. 
"I was sort of encouraged by what happened in the market because it's giving us the first indication that we're beginning to see differentiation," said Charles I. Clough, of Clough Capital Partners in Boston. "Until now, it's been massive liquidation, week after week. The Nasdaq gave out, but that's where the economy is most weak and where there is still some washout to occur."
Stocks were in free fall by midafternoon, with the Dow industrials down 245 points and the Nasdaq hitting a new intraday low of 1,220.93, a loss of 70 points. Both indexes recovered, but the Nasdaq could not struggle back to its previous closing level. 
Investors in technology were alarmed by a report from the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company that it was cutting capital expenditures because of weak demand for chips. Since many technology stock bulls were counting on a pickup in chip orders ahead of the crucial back-to-school season, the company's announcement took the wind out of technology stocks.
Semiconductor stocks have been one of a few safe Nasdaq havens in recent weeks, hanging in while other sectors were battered. Yesterday, the Philadelphia semiconductor index of 17 chip stocks lost 10 percent of its value. Intel fell 6.5 percent, to $17.48.
The carnage in technology stocks is now beginning to approach the losses endured in the Dow industrials after the crash of 1929, said David Dreman, head of Dreman Value Management. From its high in September 1929, the Dow fell 89 percent by July 8, 1932, he said. "The high on the Nasdaq 100 was 4,825 in March 2000," he said, "and the low yesterday was 873, a drop of 82 percent." The Nasdaq 100 closed at 894.54.
Investors seem to be taking the view, with reason, that technology stocks are still overpriced, Mr. Dreman said. "Even though we're down this much, these companies were so enormously overvalued that there could be a lot more downside ahead. There was so much overexpansion in capacity in telecom and computers, it's going to take a long time for these companies to come back, if ever."
Genuity Inc., an Internet service provider, fell $2.30, to 29 cents as it defaulted on $3 billion in loans. Verizon Communications said it would not buy back a controlling stake in the company. Genuity shares were spun off to the public in June 2000 by the GTE Corporation at $11 each.
Eroding confidence in corporate practices continued to hammer some of the biggest companies yesterday. AOL Time Warner shares fell $1.75, or about 15 percent, to $9.64 on news that the company's accounting was under scrutiny by the Securities and Exchange Commission. J. P. Morgan Chase lost 95 cents, or about 4 percent, to close at $22.35, as securities regulators look into the bank's role in the Enron fiasco. The bank says it did nothing wrong.
Investors are continuing to flee mutual funds, according to Robert Adler at AMG Data Services. For the week that ended yesterday, a record $12.2 billion exited stock funds, bringing total outflows for July to $30.6 billion, the most since the company began compiling fund data 10 years ago. Corporate bond funds and money market funds both drew in money. 
"There is no indication of panic or full-scale flight from the market," Mr. Adler said. "But every buyer who disappears is not just disappearing, he is becoming a seller. That puts a different picture on the market." Outflows are also escalating at index funds. 
Anthony M. Maramarco, portfolio manager at Babson Value Fund in Cambridge, Mass., said that he had started to see the traditionally defensive stocks, like food companies, come back a bit. It may be a harbinger of more stability. "Even though we haven't had that blow-off that everybody was looking for, we may have gotten to the point where we will just bounce along at the bottom here," he said. "There's certainly a lot of bad blood that has been let."
