HEADLINE: Russian Tea Room to Close After Tomorrow's Dinner 

BYLINE:  By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
The Russian Tea Room, that storied preserve of infused vodka, glinting caviar and buttery blini that was for decades a clubby watering hole for the city's bolderati, announced its closing yesterday, less than three years after its spectacular but ill-fated $30 million renovation.
 The flamboyant restaurateur Warner LeRoy, who hoped to reinvent the Tea Room as a variant on his hugely successful Tavern on the Green, died a little more than a year after reopening the restaurant at 150 West 57th Street, a six-story Italianate brownstone squeezed between two large buildings. It will close after dinner tomorrow. 
 LeRoy's daughter Jennifer, whom he had handpicked to become the restaurant's chief executive, was in the end unable to summon the requisite dazzle and ballyhoo to keep the high-maintenance property afloat as a theme restaurant and tourist draw.
"Only Warner could make it something old and something new," said Clark Wolf, a New York-based restaurant consultant. "I guess he was the only one who had that kind of life force." 
Some may suggest that the closing marks the passing of a restaurant age that was rich in history and character, but the Tea Room era actually passed with the shuttering of the original restaurant in 1996 for a nearly four-year, Perils-of-Pauline, down-to-the-studs reconstruction, according to Tim Zagat, chairman of Zagat Survey.
"A large part of its greatness came before Warner took it over," Mr. Zagat said. "In those days, it was a place of wonderful spirit and ambiance. It was a home away from home for many people in the theater, show business and the arts."
He added, "I hope that someone, somehow will find a way to revive it soon and operate it in a matter of months."
But although there had been rumors of potential buyers in the Tea Room's waning weeks, yesterday's announcement "was very serious and very sad," said Shelley Clark, a Tea Room spokeswoman. After giving the news to the 17 managers after lunch, Ms. LeRoy, 23 and the chief executive of the restaurant's parent company, LeRoy Adventures, gathered much of the staff of 170 late in the afternoon and told them.
"My family and I inherited our father's ambitious dream for the Russian Tea Room, and we did everything in our power to realize his vision," she said in a statement afterward. "Unfortunately, like so many other restaurants, the Russian Tea Room suffered from the slowing national economy and the tragic events of 9/11."
Ms. Clark said that the company's other dazzle palace, Tavern on the Green, the highest-grossing restaurant in the United States according to Nation's Restaurant News, "will not be affected in any way by the closing, and will look forward to seeing Tea Room patrons there."
The Tea Room lost its principal financing in the third quarter of last year, when Vornado Realty Trust, which had been a 50-50 investor, wrote off its nonmanagerial investment of $7.374 million as a loss, according to Howard J. Rubenstein, Vornado's spokesman. 
"Vornado invested in the Russian Tea Room and it turned out to be a failed investment as a result of Warner LeRoy's untimely death last year," Mr. Rubenstein said.
Neither LeRoy nor the managers who succeeded him were able to summon the ghost of the Tea Room past. "For many years it functioned as a semiprivate club," said Malcolm M. Knapp, a restaurant analyst in Manhattan. "But it took so long for Warner to reopen it that it broke the rhythm of the whole club idea, and Warner couldn't capture the original spirit."
"It became a tourist and event place for corporations," he said, then became a victim of economic cutbacks in private parties, and the decline in overseas tourism. It had high overhead costs, and they weren't making their sales numbers."
The restaurant began as, literally, a tea room in the 1920's. In reputation, RTR, as addicts called the place, was on a par with the Stork Club and the Algonquin Round Table. Flaunting a stage-Russian flair that appealed to its fiercely loyal patrons, the original Tea Room was dominated by red-red banquettes, shimmery samovars and year-round Christmas ornaments whose wacky ubiquity announced an ambiance of festive eccentricity.
Many of the legendary goings-on there may actually have happened: Leonard Bernstein writing the opening refrain of "Fancy Free"; Madonna in the coat-check room (she was fired); the timely escape from a back door of the Shah of Iran's sister to duck an irate crowd; and Zero Mostel swathing himself in an apron to take orders from diners for, as he put it, "peasant under glass." 
It was, of course, the place where Elizabeth Taylor had to show off her new bauble from Richard Burton: a diamond as big as the Ritz. Then there was the time that a weeping Sol Hurok entered the Tea Room, announcing that he had just emerged from the most touching film he'd ever seen: "The Sol Hurok Story. 
From its initial clientele of musicians and dancers warped from the vortex of Carnegie Hall next door, it became the place for agents, writers, actors, stars and celebrity-gazers to, well, be. Sitting within listening range of agent Sam Cohn's booth -- Table 1 -- was to attain nirvana.
"Now where is Tootsie going to have lunch?" asked Mr. Clark, referring the character played by Dustin Hoffman in the 1982 movie about an obnoxious actor who dresses as a woman for lunch at the Tea Room and fools his agent.
Warner LeRoy bought the restaurant in 1995 from its longtime owner, Faith Stewart-Gordon, who chronicled its zenith years in a 1999 memoir, "The Russian Tea Room: A Love Story."
LeRoy, the son of Hollywood pioneers, was the kind of showman who, leaving a $48 million estate at his death in February 2001, also left orders to spend some of it on "a great fun memorial party." If anyone could make the Tea Room a competitor for Tavern on the Green, foodies said, it was Warner LeRoy.
But he may have miscalculated from the beginning. "Tavern is unique in its look, location and the size of the large-scale parties it can handle," said Mr. Knapp, adding: "Tea Room just wasn't the same."
Nevertheless, LeRoy embarked on a War-and-Peace of a renovation that was fraught with delay, rumor and controversy, not the least of which was a failed development partnership with the four-star chef David Bouley.
After the new Tea Room opened, for a time there was stretch-limo-lock on West 57th Street, and there were some generous restaurant reviews. But many critics found the upgrade long on visual spectacle and short on menu appeal. "From Russia, with kitsch," was the pronouncement of Gourmet magazine. And William Grimes in The New York Times termed the redo "appalling," noting the giant acrylic bear that dominated the upstairs dining hall and terming much of the menu "a dreary slog."
But if there are many who will forever regret the demise of the old Tea Room, there are some who will miss aspects of the new Tea Room as well. "After he died," Mr. Zagat said, "I could still feel Warner's spirit whenever I was there."

HEADLINE: The State of Puerto Rico 

 BODY:
More than three million Americans -- some 800,000 of them New Yorkers -- have roots in Puerto Rico, but to many other Americans the island is an enigma, a place where they are likely to take their passports, which are not needed, but not a knowledge of Spanish, which often is. So it comes as little surprise that as Puerto Rico marked a milestone this week with official fanfare attended by Mayor Michael Bloomberg and a New York City contingent, there was little notice of the event on the mainland.
 It was the 50th anniversary of the commonwealth, a status conferred on Puerto Rico to allow self-government and end its days as a colonial prize won by the United States in the Spanish-American War. And while cannons boomed and music and dance made for a festive party, the relationship being marked is showing signs of strain. 
 With its mix of limited benefits and obligations of United States citizenship, the commonwealth status has endured by default. Several nonbinding plebiscites the island has held over the years have failed to produce an acceptable alternative.
The ambivalence is significant in Puerto Rico, where political and civic involvement permeate the lives of its 3.8 million people. A thundering drum roll of rallies, car-mounted loudspeakers and personal canvassing regularly result in voter turnouts of about 80 percent. On an island of strong opinions, the status debate generates much shaking, sometimes even violence, but not much movement.
Puerto Ricans born on the island -- like those born on the mainland -- are United States citizens. Island residents pay Social Security taxes, but no federal income tax. They cannot vote in presidential elections and they have no vote on the floor of Congress. While the island has a Constitution and self-government, Washington controls matters involving defense, transportation, communication, immigration and foreign trade.
As a commonwealth, Puerto Rico retains its Spanish language and culture, even as it blends in American life. But the limits of the status quo -- in which Puerto Rico does not get the full benefits of statehood nor the advantages of fuller sovereignty -- have been blamed for creating a situation where the per capita income is lower than that of any state in the Union. Tax breaks given to American companies that set up shop overseas are being phased out for Puerto Rico, many companies have left and unemployment is in double digits. Anger at the United States found a flashpoint in recent years on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques, used for target practice by the Navy. Tempers barely cooled when President Bush announced last year that the Navy would withdraw in May 2003.
Now Puerto Rico is looking for a new deal. Its governor, Sila Calderon, wants more sovereignty and economic opportunity, including control over foreign trade, but statehood advocates refuse to join her efforts to reach consensus on a proposal for change. So she is showing Puerto Rican political muscle elsewhere, heading a drive to register all eligible voters among Puerto Ricans living on the mainland, many of them in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Florida. All that will help to get the attention of members of Congress, who must approve any change for the commonwealth. But the first step, a re-examination of what is best for Puerto Rico, must begin there. And so far, that kind of introspection has been limited, tortured and inconclusive.

HEADLINE: Jobs for New York, Performed in Ghana 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "In New York Tickets, Ghana Sees Orderly City" (front page, July 22) implies that outsourcing suppliers who have offshore service centers are hurting New York City and America. I say, "Au contraire." 
 Outsourcing allows companies to get non-core jobs done a lot more cheaply and as well as or better than if they did it themselves. The outsourcing supplier can charge less because the women in Ghana are doing the data input. 
Today, most outsourcing suppliers rely on this labor arbitrage; they can employ well-trained workers who are thrilled to work at the top of their country's pay scale, which happens to be far lower than ours. 
Judging from the article, this work is having a wonderful impact on Ghana's economy. If patriotism is important, native Americans have formed outsourcing companies to provide the same labor arbitrage on our shores.

BETH ELLYN ROSENTHAL
Editor, Outsourcing Journal
Dallas, July 24, 2002

HEADLINE: Jobs for New York, Performed in Ghana

To the Editor:
 It is outrageous that, in these times, New York City is outsourcing jobs to Ghana, more than 5,000 miles away (front page, July 22). 
 In the aftermath of Sept. 11, New York City has a 7 percent unemployment rate. Thousands of New Yorkers are looking for jobs, and the city is giving away jobs to other states and countries.

HEADLINE: Pressure on Companies Using Tax Dodge 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Pressure on companies that acquire a Bermuda mailbox as part of a strategy to earn tax-free profits in the United States increased yesterday with the California state treasurer and the president of the top labor organization attacking the moves.
 In a surprise move last night, the House approved an amendment to the bill that would create a Department of Homeland Security. The change would forbid the department to contract with companies that establish an offshore headquarters to evade American taxes. Page A8. 
 Union leaders plan a rally Tuesday outside the New York Stock Exchange to denounce the Bermuda deals as unpatriotic, damaging to employees and shareholders and a central issue in corporate corruption. State treasurers will gather in New York on Aug. 12, where H. Carl McCall, the New York comptroller, will ask them to consider actions against companies that use or plan to use an offshore mailbox to escape taxes on their American profits.
The first state treasurer to do so, Philip Angelides of California, issued an order Thursday banning 19 companies that use the tax dodge, including Ingersoll-Rand, from state contracts that are under his control and from selling their commercial paper to the state's $45 billion pooled fund for state and local governments.
Mr. Angelides said he would also ask trustees at the California Public Employees Retirement System, or Calpers, and the California State Teachers Retirement System, or Calstrs, the largest and third-largest pension funds in the country, respectively, to sell all $752 million of stock in the 19 companies.
"A company that would deliberately do a sham relocation offshore to escape taxes," Mr. Angelides said, "would also look to bend environmental rules, shortchange workers or even stick it to their shareholders.
Mr. Angelides, a former real estate developer, added: "The danger in their thinking is that if everyone does it, then it undermines the economy as a whole. The issue is how do you change the culture of thinking that you do not have to play fair? You have to start with the most odious of practices, those that on their face strike most Americans as wrong, and the Bermuda business certainly does that."
Ingersoll-Rand will seek a meeting with Mr. Angelides in hopes of persuading him to change his policy, said Paul Dickard, a spokesman.
Last night, John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., wrote Stanley Works directors asking them to stop trying to acquire a Bermuda mail drop "before you inflict serious harm on Stanley Works, its shareholders and employees."
Escaping taxes through a Bermuda deal is "particularly inflammatory at a time when American workers and domestic companies are being asked to finance the war on terrorism with their tax dollars," Mr. Sweeney wrote.
On Monday, Mr. Sweeney and Thomas Buffenbarger, president of the International Association of Machinists, and union members plan to gather outside a Stanley Works factory in New Britain, Conn., to protest the Bermuda plan.
The two also plan to deliver a letter to John M. Trani, the chief executive. Mr. Trani will not be in town, but Peter Duda, a spokesman, said that Mr. Trani would be delighted to meet with the union leaders. Mr. Sweeney will speak outside the stock exchange on Tuesday.
Following are the 19 companies and their working headquarters on Mr. Angelides's list, as well as 3 companies that plan to use a Bermuda offshore address:
Accenture (Chicago); APW (Waukesha, Wis.); Cooper Industries (Houston); the Everest Reinsurance Group (Liberty Corner, N.J.); Foster Wheeler (Clinton, N.J); Global SantaFe (Dallas); Gold Reserve (Spokane, Wash.); Helen of Troy Cosmetics (El Paso); Ingersoll-Rand (Woodcliff Lake, N.J.); Leucadia National (New York, pending); McDermott International (New Orleans); Monday Ltd. (New York); Nabors Industries (Houston); Noble Drilling (Sugar Land, Tex.); PXRE Group (Edison, N.J.); Stanley Works (New Britain, Conn., pending); Treansocean Offshore (Houston); Tyco International (Exeter, N.H.); Veritas DGC (Houston, pending); Weatherford International (Houston); White Mountains Insurance (White River Junction, Vt.); and Xoma (Berkeley, Calif.). 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 30, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Saturday about pressure on companies that have acquired offshore addresses to reduce taxes misspelled the name of an oil drilling contractor that is among 19 companies barred by the California state treasurer from receiving contracts that he controls. It is Transocean, not Treansocean. Because of an editing error, a list of companies that use offshore addresses or plan to do so misstated the locations for five. Transocean, Global SantaFe and Noble Drilling use the Cayman Islands; Gold Reserve uses Canada; and McDermott International uses Panama. None use Bermuda.

HEADLINE: Russia to Go On Building Nuclear Reactors in Iran 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 26 

 BODY:
The Russian government, brushing aside the Bush administration's concerns, indicated today that it planned to continue building new nuclear reactors in Iran like one that American officials have repeatedly warned could be used to develop nuclear weapons.
 Russia's assistance in building a nuclear plant in the Iranian city of Bushehr, near the Persian Gulf, has been a nagging irritant in relations with the United States for years. It produced the sourest note in otherwise friendly meetings between President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin here in May. 
 While administration officials have pressed Russia to break its contract to complete a 1,000-megawatt reactor at Bushehr, a document approved this week by Prime Minister Mikhail M. Kasyanov and announced today outlined plans to build three more reactors at the site.
The document also indicated that Russia would offer to build two more reactors at a new nuclear power station at Ahwaz, a city about 60 miles from Iran's border with Iraq. 
That appeared to contradict remarks earlier this month by Russia's atomic energy minister, Aleksandr Y. Rumyantsev, who said the cooperation with Iran in developing its nuclear-power industry would end with the project at Bushehr.
Russia, like Iran, has repeatedly dismissed the American concerns about the project, insisting that it was a purely civilian effort to develop new energy sources. But the Bush administration, which has labeled Iran part of an "axis of evil" along with Iraq and North Korea, fears that the Iranians will use Russian equipment and expertise to pursue a secret program to produce nuclear weapons that could threaten Europe and the United States.
Russia's plans were released on the government's official Web site today, without public comment, as part of a draft outlining potential areas of economic, industrial and scientific cooperation with Iran over the next 10 years.
The prospect of more Russian assistance is certain to provoke new warnings from the United States and may undercut the close relationship that has developed between Mr. Putin and Mr. Bush, especially since the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States.
In recent months Russian officials have sought to defuse the Bush administration's complaints, saying Russia would insist that Iran return the plutonium produced as a byproduct of nuclear power generation to prevent it from being used in weapons. After their meetings in May, Mr. Bush said Mr. Putin had assured him that Russia would press Iran to allow extensive international inspections of the plant.
Iran has signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and has previously said it will cooperate fully with the International Atomic Energy Agency, which oversees the world's civilian nuclear power programs.
In Washington, administration officials said Russian cooperation with Iran's nuclear energy program would be on the agenda next week when Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham leads an American delegation to Russia to discuss energy and nuclear proliferation issues.
"Our concerns with regards to Russian cooperation with Iran on the issue of Bushehr are well known," said Sean McCormack, a spokesman for the National Security Council. "We have expressed them in public as well as in private directly to Russian President Putin. And we will continue to work with Russia on proliferation issues of concern."
After today's announcement, the chairman of Parliament's foreign affairs committee, Dmitri O. Rogozin, said Russia's plans should not hurt relations with the United States since Moscow shared Washington's worries. "Neither Russia nor the United States is interested in other countries' use of peaceful nuclear technologies for military purposes," he told the Interfax news agency.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Both Dow and S.& P. Gain, Ending the Week Positive
The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose, finishing the week higher. It was the first positive week in three for the Dow and the first in four for the S.& P. The Nasdaq composite index also rallied, but it finished the week down, its fourth consecutive weekly dip.
 The Dow rose 78.08 points, or 1 percent, to close at 8,264.39, while the S.& P. 500 was up 14.16 points, or 1.7 percent, to 852.84. The Nasdaq climbed 22.04 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,262.12. For the week, the Dow was up 3.1 percent and the S.& P. 500 up 0.6 percent. The Nasdaq was off 4.3 percent. Page C4. 

Criticism of AOL Chairman Widens
Analysts and investors are criticizing Stephen M. Case, the chairman of AOL Time Warner, saying the company's management would be better off purged of executives from the former America Online. The discontent accelerated this week after the company disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an investigation into accounting practices at AOL. A1.

Bush Goes to the Hill for Trade Bill
Hours after House and Senate negotiators reached a surprise break-through on a broad trade bill, President Bush made a rare visit to Capitol Hill to rally House Republicans behind the measure, which he said was essential for economic growth. Mr. Bush huddled with fellow party members in a closed-door caucus, trying to ensure the success of a package that had been deadlocked for years and remains tough to push through the House. A1.

Consumer Confidence Fell in July
Consumer confidence dropped to 88.1 in July, compared with a preliminary report of 86.5 and a June reading of 92.4, according to a University of Michigan survey that shows Americans may not let tumbling stock prices completely dim their view of the economy. C4.

A Delay Is Granted in ImClone Case
A federal judge gave prosecutors and lawyers for Samuel D. Waksal two more weeks to try to reach a plea agreement that would resolve insider trading charges against Dr. Waksal, the former chief executive of ImClone. C2.

Official's Departure Hurts Motorola
Shares of Motorola plunged nearly 11 percent after the No. 2 executive, Edward D. Breen, left, was named chief executive of Tyco. Investors showed skepticism that Motorola's chief executive, Christopher B. Galvin, and Mr. Breen's successor as president and chief operating officer, Mike S. Zafirovski, could carry out a viable restructuring plan and return Motorola to profitability. C2.

Criticism of Offshore Mailboxes
Pressure on companies that have a Bermuda mailbox as part of a strategy to earn profits in the United States tax-free increased with the California state treasurer and the head of a labor organization attacking the moves. C3.

Budget Deficit Rose in Portugal
Portugal disclosed that its budget deficit had soared above the limit set by the European Union, causing the European Commission to begin a sanctions procedure against Portugal. Under the union's rules, Portugal could be assessed heavy fines if it fails to get its deficit back below 3 percent of its gross domestic product. It was was 4.1 percent last year. C3.

Some Americans Are Spending Less
With the recent flurry of corporate scandals and the declines in the stock market, many people around Davenport, Iowa, are paying off debts, putting off vacations, spending less for meals and postponing big purchases. A7.

Disarray at Canadian Concern
Hydro One, Ontario's dominant power transmission company, has been shaken by a public furor over how it is run, and by whom. C3.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A2-5

Bush Promotes Trade Bill In Rare Visit to Capitol
President Bush went to Capitol Hill to rally House Republicans behind a broad international trade bill, which he said was essential for economic growth. Earlier, House and Senate negotiators agreed to give the president power to make trade deals that Congress cannot change, only ratify or reject. HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PUSHES TRADE LEGISLATION IN VISIT TO CAPITOL 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26 

 BODY:
Hours after House and Senate negotiators reached a surprise breakthrough on a broad trade bill, President Bush made a rare visit to the Capitol today to rally House Republicans behind the measure, which he said was essential for economic growth.
 Mr. Bush huddled with fellow party members in a closed-door caucus, trying to ensure the success of a package that had been deadlocked for years and still faces resistance in the House. House and Senate negotiators agreed late Thursday night to give the president the right to make trade deals that Congress could not change but only ratify or reject, which would amount to a major victory for the president. 
 "We're going to get a free trade agreement," Mr. Bush told reporters as he left the Capitol late this afternoon trailed by an entourage of his senior staff. "We're going to get a free trade agreement, which is very important for jobs and workers, very important for our farmers and ranchers, and it's very important for our economy."
But it was a sign of how contentious trade issues are in the politically polarized House that by late tonight, even the president's direct plea had not sealed the deal. With the House pushing to go into an August recess, Republican leaders were still trying to quell several rebellions and turf wars and had not yet brought the measure up for debate. 
The negotiating power Mr. Bush seeks was held by five earlier presidents but expired in 1994. President Clinton never succeeded in convincing Congress that the negotiation authority should be renewed, in part because of concern among Democrats that trade deals cost American jobs and lower environmental standards.
Mr. Bush has always put expanding international trade near the top of his economic agenda. In recent weeks, he has stepped up pressure on Congress to pass the trade bill on the grounds that it would help the economy recover from last year's recession and restore confidence at a time when the stock market is sinking -- even though the fruits of any trade deals are years away.
Besides granting broader trade negotiating authority to the president, the agreement, reached just before midnight Thursday, breaks significant new ground for American workers. It creates a program of subsidized health insurance, in addition to other benefits for Americans who are displaced by foreign competition. The measure calls for the government to pay 65 percent of the health insurance costs for such workers in the form of refundable tax credits.
Passage of the trade package is considered assured in the Senate, which plans to take it up it next week. But trade is always a difficult issue in the House, which passed its own version of the bill by just one vote last year. While House and Senate negotiators were able to reconcile their different versions on Thursday night, Republican leaders in the House were wary that the compromise could lose support during the August recess; they spent the day furiously trying to round up votes and pass the measure tonight. 
Senior administration officials -- including Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans and Robert B. Zoelleck, Mr. Bush's chief trade negotiator --worked by the side of Republican officials in the Capitol twisting arms of wavering Republican and trying to solve problems. Representative William M. Thomas, a California Republican who as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee was instrumental in negotiating the accord, said Mr. Bush himself had made a brief but direct pitch to party members. "He basically said, I want it because the American people need it," Mr. Thomas said.
But despite the president's direct intervention, internecine Republican battles went on well into the evening as Republican members of the Appropriations Committee threatened to vote against the bill because it usurped some of their powers to control spending.
The pact also caused a sharp split among Democrats, which could have repercussions in the party's presidential primary in 2004. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, called the legislation "a very strong bill for workers adversely affected by trade."
But Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, was critical of it and said House Democrats would work to defeat it. The two Democratic leaders rarely disagree on major issues. 
Organized labor, already running ads against such trade legislation in eight major states, promptly began lobbying against it. John Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said, "Working people have watched unfair trade deals and growing trade deficits send millions of family-supporting jobs overseas to nations where corporations can abuse workers' rights, child labor and the environment."
Democrats who were disappointed by the agreement argued that the health care tax credits would not ensure that displaced workers would be able to afford coverage in the private health market.
Democratic aides were working hard to keep most of their party voting against the bill as a tactic to force Republicans from vulnerable textile and steel areas to cast a vote for the bill that could be used against them in the election.
For years Congress has been unable to pass trade negotiating authority because of discontent among many lawmakers with the North American Free Trade Agreement and deepening concern, particularly among House Democrats, about the costs of free trade.
Lawmakers attributed the surprise agreement, in part, to the concerns about the stock market and the economy -- and the desire of Republicans to support the president on economic matters. In past years, Republicans had resisted tying a trade bill to a worker assistance package, but they moved toward the position of the Democrats in the last two years. The final agreement split the difference between the 70 percent tax credit for health insurance offered by the Senate, and a 60 percent tax credit offered by the House. 
In fact, both parties were already putting forward new economic measures with an eye toward the fall elections at back-to-back news conferences. Democratic leaders promoted their ideas for retirement security, including tough penalties on senior executives who mismanage corporate pension funds.
Republicans countered with their proposals, including the forfeiture of assets of corrupt executives.

HEADLINE: Seeking Soul Mate: Must Like DeLillo 

BYLINE:  By Valerie Sayers; Valerie Sayers, director of the creative writing program at the University of Notre Dame, is the author of five novels.

 BODY:
 A THING (OR TWO) ABOUT CURTIS AND CAMILLA
By Nick Fowler.
398 pp. New York:
Pantheon Books. $24.95.
 NICK FOWLER'S rueful, funny first novel is the latest in a long American line of Wounded (White) Man fiction. Curtis Birnbaum, a balding Manhattan rock musician, recovering from drug addiction and fantasizing about a record contract, woos the beautiful Camilla Fell, then loses and pines for her. As in any decent Wounded Man story, Birnbaum must come to terms with a weak and withholding father (actually, two weak fathers, his own and Camilla's) and a punishing mother (a minor, extravagant, satisfying character).
"A Thing (or Two) About Curtis and Camilla" is pretty current in its social observations, and holds the promise of news from the world of Contemporary Wounded Men. So what has changed since Hemingway and Fitzgerald and Cheever recorded the pressures and repression weighing down a sensitive middle-class man trying to make it in a capitalist world? As Fowler tells it, the pressures haven't changed much -- a man's still simultaneously worried about performing, dodging gold diggers and scraping together enough money to start a family -- but as for repression, there isn't any anymore. By now we're all used to anything going, sexually speaking; even children know the score. In beautifully economical flashbacks, we learn that Birnbaum, who wasn't shielded from the sexual bitterness his parents flung at each other, was already a Wounded Boy. Now, in this age of It's O.K. for a man to cry, anything goes emotionally too, so Curtis spews and spills. His insecurities make him a good comic character -- one mark of the New Wounded Man is how he revels in his own humiliations -- but sometimes his gooey excesses (especially in the early lovey-dovey pages with Camilla) can be downright embarrassing. A reader gets through the pap, though, since the story in general is informed by a pretty irresistible delight in its own telling.
Fowler's playfulness encompasses a (by now familiar) range of visual and narrative tricks: mini-chapters, footnotes (any veteran of fiction workshops will attest that footnotes are certainly popular nowadays), song lyrics, photos (including a tiny one of -- no kidding -- Don DeLillo). The book designer, Justin Salvas, has a deft, light touch, but Fowler's not in it just for the graphic pleasures. His invocation of his literary heroes is a joy: he calls on William Blake (who flashes the twin themes of innocence and experience), T. S. Eliot (who signals the bleak moments), and that mini-poster boy DeLillo (for whom Curtis and Camilla share a passion that's something of an aesthetic mystery, given Birnbaum's own narrative predilections). 
J. D. Salinger is another of his heroes, which makes sense, given Curtis's tender and protective impulses. Those impulses tend to arise most often around a 9-year-old girl named Little Green ("after that Joni Mitchell song"), Curtis's Salingeresque neighbor. Sophisticated, charming, smart, dangerously close to too cute, Little is also a vulnerable child, one Curtis would certainly be happy to catch in the rye. Her trust enables him to extend the story of his own wounding into a meditation on childhood in "these graceless days." Little also allows Curtis more opportunity to report the news from New York's funny pages, his satiric chronicle of life in Lower Manhattan sharpening as it takes on an increasingly absurd tone. My favorite scenes involve the locker room at Crunch, the Lafayette Street gym; an overheard cellphone conversation Curtis follows through the streets; and sidewalk table-gazing at Time Cafe (Time with a capital T is a central motif ).
Camilla is a classic tragic love object: gorgeous, mysterious, tortured by some elusive secret. As she is a blue-eyed black woman, her first appearance signals, perhaps, some concern with race. (Curtis asks, "What's it like going through life so beautiful?" She replies, "It's like if I asked you what it's like to be white.") But the subject does not come up between them again. On a questionnaire Curtis sends, Camilla lists favorite movies by white male directors, books by white male writers (O.K., I admit there's one on the list by a woman -- Annie Proulx -- and obviously plenty of black women admire music and art by white men. But the mirror-imaging of Curtis's white-guy tastes and the absence of any competing sensibility is just a little suspicious). When Curtis asks if she's taken a class in feminist studies, Camilla says she "found the 'subject' boring and despotic." A lot of young women are scared off by the word "feminist" these days, but given Camilla's horrific sexual history, that quick exchange seems (if I may use an unfeminist term) too easy.
Birnbaum's fictional world, however, appears to have miraculously got past the point where feminism or ethnicity or race matters. (Curtis doesn't make a huge thing of his Jewishness, and he describes a woman as "half Asian or something, so hard to tell in these mongrel days.") Then, near story's end, he notices a poster of Mike Tyson, "our modern Grendel." The reader is about to meet Camilla's father, another black man who's something of a monster. Equal opportunity for bad guys? Or is this novel finally about to rush headlong into tricky old questions of race and sexual power? It's just the moment when you want a novelist to face what he's created head-on, but Fowler ducks even as he's pushing into dangerous territory.
Camilla's father is an outrageous, pathetic, bizarre character who brings the novel to a gonzo finish but doesn't make all that much sense as father of the woman we've seen throughout the book, or even as the ending to Curtis's story. Fowler is switching tracks from Wounded White Man to Wounded Black Woman, which leaves a lot of serious ground to cover -- but at this point, structurally speaking, the novel's about to arrive at its final destination. So the big serious psychosexual issues have to be compressed into a couple of (pretty weird) dramatic scenes. This funny novel, most successful in Curtis's absurd and playful moments, ends on a disturbing, off-key note. Yet Fowler attacks the conclusion of his story with a kind of crazy courage, and you can see in his straining how he might be exploring what he'll take on next time out.
Nick Fowler is an expansive, lyrical, inventive writer. Given the ambitions of this novel, I imagine he'll end up thrashing around again with tricky and troubling characters -- not to mention ideas about the ways men and women wound each other and their children. At the risk of sounding like Curtis's demanding mom (or a despotic feminist), I hope he takes them on.

HEADLINE: And Bear In Mind

 BODY:
 (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

YOU ARE NOT A STRANGER HERE, by Adam Haslett. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $21.95.) These nine short stories (Haslett's first collection) exhale a desiccated bleakness, a despair mitigated by the characters' continuing desire to be good, to do the right thing despite hopelessness, loss, disease and frequent mental illness.

FRAGRANT HARBOR, by John Lanchester. (Marian Wood/Putnam, $25.95.) A novel of large scope, placed chiefly in Hong Kong in 1935 and after, undertaking big propositions: race, class, love, war and, perhaps most successfully, the transformation of a refugee community into one of the world's richest societies.

THE MONK DOWNSTAIRS, by Tim Farrington. (HarperSanFrancisco, $22.95.) A tender, witty novel in which a former monk, after 20 years in his order, rents an apartment from a 38-year-old single mother; the ensuing relationship grows cautiously, taking account of the prudence required of struggling people who aren't going to get that many more chances.

MUSSOLINI, by R. J. B. Bosworth. (Oxford University, $35.) A historian's judicious examination of the dictator who helped create Fascism from a mix of socialism and nationalism; he ruled Italy for 21 years, losing touch with reality when he became dependent on Hitler and too well acquainted with war.

THE WHORE'S CHILD: And Other Stories, by Richard Russo. (Knopf, $24.) In these short stories the author of "Empire Falls," this year's Pulitzer Prize novel, abandons working-class settings and protagonists in favor of intellectuals caught in late middle age, worried about illness and ambivalent about marriage.

THE WINTER ZOO, by John Beckman. (Holt, $25.) The hero of this first novel, a young man newly arrived in Poland from Iowa, trades his naivete for lessons in youthfulness; Beckman captures the rush of freshly liberated desires in post-Communist Europe, making his climactic scene a pansexual orgy in a Cracow hotel.

PRAGUE, by Arthur Phillips. (Random House, $24.95.) A first novel set in 1990, far beyond the recently fallen Berlin Wall, where young Americans reveal themselves not as travelers but mere tourists, detached from their surroundings, weightless and immaterial among time-battered buildings and people who have survived wars and uprisings.

HALF IN LOVE: Stories, by Maile Meloy. (Scribner, $23.) Fourteen stories, set mostly in the author's native Montana, among small-time racetracks and failed oil wells, where brides choose wedding dresses to hide branding-iron scars; no one expects an easy life here, and even the young feel their choices constrained by economics and losing habits.

IRIS ORIGO: Marchesa of Val d'Orcia, by Caroline Moorehead. (Godine, $35.) A fascinating biography of a remarkable woman, an Anglo-American heiress who became the lady of a big estate in Tuscany, where she knew everybody, worked hard, taught peasants to read, helped people escape Fascism and wrote beautifully on many subjects.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; 
Airline Food Still in Flux

BYLINE:  By SUSAN CATTO; SUSAN CATTO contributes to The Times from Toronto.

 BODY:
WHEN airlines began cutting back on food service last fall, some analysts predicted it would be only a matter of time before competitive pressures forced a return of the foil-wrapped entree, or some approximation of it. The analysts were right -- sort of.
 In recent weeks, several airlines have changed their policies again, restoring or upgrading their food service. Continental has introduced larger portions and better cuts of chicken on its trans-Atlantic flights. United has restored its breakfast service, even on short flights. American Trans Air has introduced hot snacks. First-class and business-class meals are nearly as ubiquitous as they were this time last year. Is this a return to the days of fully catered flying? 
 Not exactly. According to Robert Mann, president of R. W. Mann & Company, an airline analysis and consultation business in Port Washington, N.Y., "We're far more likely to see meals as they have been known and pilloried go away" as airlines continue to cut costs. Last month, The Wall Street Journal reported that American Airlines was considering taking away meals entirely on domestic flights.
Commenting on the report, Todd Burke, a spokesman for the airline, said: "To say that we're evaluating food service is certainly a true statement, but we're absolutely not planning to pull food from our flights." 
What is likely to continue, at American and elsewhere, is a balancing act between the airlines' quest for efficiency and the passengers' need for food.
When the major airlines removed meals from most short domestic flights, airport restaurants and fast-food outlets sprang up to feed passengers. Hotels and services such as Los Angeles-based SkyMeals started offering airplane-ready meals to go, for a price. (A sample SkyMeals entree: flash-seared ahi tuna with wasabi aioli, sesame ginger dressing, jicama, orange and cilantro salad, cucumber, zucchini and avocado. Cost: $32.50, including delivery to your home or office.)
Yet even experienced fliers had problems adjusting. Paul Williams, a travel consultant at Linden Travel in New York, started advising his clients to pack meals after a foodless day of travel last November. He left his house at 4 a.m. to catch a flight to Tucson, Ariz. The flight was late and he had to rush to make his connection in Dallas.
"I didn't pack anything and I was absolutely starving at the end of the trip," Mr. Williams said. Now he tells his clients to bring their own food, even if they have a lengthy layover.

X-Raying the Cheeseburgers
Passengers planning to take their own food, however, have sometimes been stymied by airport security, according to Mr. Mann. "The presumed alternative to having airlines serve you a meal is to buy something to bring along and eat that," he said. "Unfortunately with this unfolding security environment, which is highly random and highly irrational, you don't know whether you're going to be able to bring anything on board."
Packed food and drinks are usually permitted if they can go through X-ray machines without spilling, but Mr. Mann said he had heard of passengers being told to consume or discard beverages before proceeding. More commonly, guards have asked passengers to sip drinks, unwrap sandwiches and open cartons to prove their contents are harmless. Besides that, early-morning departures and closely timed connections can make it impossible for passengers to eat before or between flights.
Nevertheless, more meals per flight are being served now than six months ago, and sympathy for passenger hunger isn't the only reason airlines are re-evaluating the importance of food. They've discovered that a hungry passenger is an irritable one, more likely to complain, drink too much or be dissatisfied with the airline. That's a reason Continental decided not to cut back meals, according to Julie King, a spokeswoman. Instead, she said, the airline has sought savings in areas, like refinancing loans, that have no direct impact on the customer.
That strategy is one thing that has kept Paul Tauger, a lawyer in Costa Mesa, Calif., loyal to Continental. "I refuse to fly American Airlines now because they will not give you a meal domestically on most flights," he says. "I get bored on flights and I can't sleep. The meal breaks it up, so I like to get the meal," he says.
Meals serve the same function as the on-board movie, Mr. Mann, the consultant, said. "They occupy people and keep them in their seats." The meals-as-entertainment theory is borne out at AirlineMeals.net, where flying foodies with digital cameras post photos, analyze entrees with the zealotry of restaurant critics, and vote on the Meal of the Month. (June's favorite: a juicy-looking steak with potatoes and spinach from Austria-based Lauda Air.)

Rundown on Policies
So how can you tell if you'll be fed on your next flight?
For one thing, you'll need to fly during mealtime. You're unlikely to get lunch on a three-hour flight departing at 2 p.m. or dinner on a flight after 9 p.m., but even the definition of mealtime depends on the individual airline. "Mealtime varies from market to market depending on competitive factors and how long the flight is," said Kurt Ebenhoch of Northwest Airlines. The rules are constantly in flux, but here is a general guide to economy-class policies at individual airlines as of early this month.
American: No meal service on main-cabin domestic flights under four hours, with the following exceptions. Meals are served on flights between Chicago or Dallas and the West Coast. Meals are also served on selected routes to and from Northeastern cities, including flights between Dallas and these cities: Hartford, Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Washington.
American Trans Air: Hot snacks (breakfast pastry or pizza pocket, for example) on most flights three hours or longer and on all flights between Chicago and the West Coast.
America West: Main-cabin meals on flights over five hours out of its Phoenix hub.
Continental: A cold breakfast or snacks on flights over an hour and a half; breakfast, lunch or dinner on flights over two hours. Improvements to the trans-Atlantic meal service (better cuts of chicken and bigger portions of vegetables and pasta) have not yet been duplicated on domestic flights.
Delta: No meals on most flights under four hours. Exceptions include some Northeast routes.
Northwest: Meals only on flights from one of the airline's three hubs (Memphis, Detroit and Minneapolis-St. Paul) and the West Coast.
Southwest: Snacks only.
United: Cold breakfast on flights over one hour; hot breakfast on flights over two hours. Lunch or dinner on flights over three and a half hours.
USAirways: Snacks on most mealtime domestic flights over two and a half hours; meals on flights from its three hubs (Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Charlotte, N.C.) to the West Coast.
