HEADLINE: A New Authority On Indian Law 

BYLINE:  By VIRGINIA GROARK 

 BODY:
ON a gothic-style campus that sits about an hour's drive from the state's tribal casinos, the University of Connecticut School of Law is quietly putting together an American Indian law program, with the aim of becoming a leading authority on the subject in the Northeast.
 Nell Jessup Newton, the school's dean, is one of the top Indian law experts in the nation and is nudging the school into the field. She is overseeing the revision of the most important book on the subject, Felix S. Cohen's Handbook of Federal Indian Law, an assignment that lured a professor who had worked with the Hopi and Navajo tribes to accept a job at the school to join the project. Richard D. Pomp, a longtime professor who specializes in tax law, is writing the first textbook ever on the taxation of American Indians, encouraged, he said, by Ms. Newton. And the university is expanding its curriculum to offer another Indian law class, its second, in the coming academic year. Only about two dozen other law schools in the nation offer as many, virtually all of them in the West. (Yale has one.) 
 "This was the only job that I applied to," said Bethany Berger, the professor who came to the school to work with Ms. Newton. "Dean Newton is probably one of the top five Indian law scholars in the country. And so the opportunity to work with her is great." According to state and tribal experts, the Indian law research at the school couldn't happen at a better time. With two of the nation's richest and most powerful tribes located in Connecticut and a handful of others seeking federal recognition, issues involving Indian law are surfacing across the state, making additional and objective expertise in the field a much welcome resource. 
"It's definitely needed here in the Northeast area," said Thomas Acevedo, chief of staff for the Mohegan Indians, who noted that several western universities have strong Indian law programs. "I think UConn is just now discovering that they need that discipline as well in the law school and I think with the hiring of Nell Newton that they will make sure that happens." 
Ms. Newton, who became dean just two years ago, would like to further expand the curriculum to add Indian law courses on topics like jurisdictional issues. The law school has offered an introductory Indian law class since 1998, but is expanding its course offerings in the field. Next year, for example, the law school will offer its first course on American Indian taxation.
The creation of an Indian law clinic that would give students experience working with tribal governments is another one of her goals. And she would like to create an Indian law center that focuses on the unique legal issues of tribes in the 13 original states.
Though Ms. Newton acknowledges that those are long-term plans, she and others said an expansion of Indian law offerings would be useful, especially at a time when Indian issues are consuming the state.
"I am absolutely delighted that more expertise and erudition will be devoted to a subject that is profoundly significant and increasingly so for Connecticut and the whole country," said Attorney General Richard Blumenthal, whose office has some lawyers who spend as much as 90 percent of their time working on Indian law issues.
In fact, Indian law issues have been popping up in Connecticut courtrooms with increasing frequency in recent years as the Mashantucket Pequots and the Mohegan Indians achieved economic power and handfuls of other tribes sought federal recognition and filed land claims. But until now, many lawyers, or judges for that matter, had not delved into that area of law.
"What you are finding is in commercial transactions, for example, or in litigation, you do come across lawyers that just have never experienced it before, so it's a learning process for them," said Jackson T. King, general counsel for the Mashantucket Pequots and a UConn law school alumnus. "And then you also come across judges who have never confronted the issues before either as a judge or in their practice, so it becomes a learning process for them too."
And it's not an easy subject matter. Many lawyers said it is a complicated area of law that involves an interplay of statutes, constitutional law and history that dates backs as far as the 18th century.
As David J. Elliott, a Hartford lawyer representing Kent School in the Schaghticokes Indians' land claim and federal acknowledgment procedures, put it, Indian law involves jurisprudence that is "well off the beaten path of what lawyers usually do." 
The other problem is that many people don't understand the relationships that tribes have with state and federal governments, Mr. Acevedo said.
"People sort of lack the understanding of why do we have Indian tribes as separate governments within the United States and of course people are really never taught that in our school systems," Mr. Acevedo said. "So that understanding sort of exasperates people because they always just think of the federal and state system and they don't understand that there's a federal tribal system within the federal government make up of how the United States is governed."
For that reason, lawyers and judges alike have been very interested in learning more about the subject. Two symposiums that were held by the Mashantucket Pequots in recent years attracted lawyers from around the state as well as state and federal judges, Mr. King said. The General Assembly's judicial committee convened a symposium on sovereignty last year, and in the fall, an Indian law seminar will be held at the Mohegan Sun Casino, said Dale White, general counsel for the Mohegans. 
Likewise, Ms. Newton has given several "Indian Law 101" talks to organizations like the Connecticut Bar Association, covering topics like land claims, Indian gaming and other things. 
"The legal issues are extraordinarily complex and yet we are in a state where most people don't even understand that if you slip and fall on a reservation you have to bring your case in tribal court," Ms. Newton said.
At UConn, the growing amount of activity involving Indian law was not planned. Though Ms. Newton's academic expertise in Indian law made her an attractive candidate, it was not the primary reason why she was hired, said Philip E. Austin, the university's president. Her track record at the University of Denver, where she was dean of the law school, as well as her ability to be an effective fund-raiser also were major factors.
Likewise, Ms. Newton said the presence of two of the nation's richest tribes in the state was not necessarily her sole reason for coming here. 
"I came here because it's just an extraordinary school," she said. "And had there been no tribes in Connecticut, I think I still would have come here."
"I like to think of it as the icing on the cake for me," she added. "I think the same was true for the university."
But Ms. Newton's presence rekindled interest in the subject matter, said Mr. Pomp. A tax scholar who has worked with several third-world countries as well as the Navajo tribe, Mr. Pomp is working on a textbook on taxation of American Indians, which he expects will be published in 2003. 
In addition, Mr. Pomp will teach the taxation course next year with Ms. Berger.
A graduate of Yale University's law school, Ms. Berger said she only applied to UConn because, in addition to teaching Indian law, she wanted to work with Ms. Newton on the revision of the Handbook of Federal Indian Law. Originally written in the 1940's, the handbook has only been updated twice, most recently in 1982. In the current project, Ms. Newton is overseeing more than 30 Indian law experts who are revising the book, which many refer to as the "bible" in Indian law.
"The opportunity to work on that was really tremendous," Ms. Berger said. 
Such a project along with additional course offerings can only benefit law school students, said Mr. King. In addition, they are going to a school in a state where Indian law cases are often raised in courts, which makes it an exciting time to study the subject. 
"The Indian law issues that people think about, a lot of them start in Connecticut," Ms. Berger said. "The questions of tribal recognition, of Indian gaming, things like that, it's all happening here."
And that, Mr. Pomp said, is another reason why the Indian law activity at UConn makes sense.
"I think with the dean's arrival a couple of years ago and with of course our own tribes, this is a perfectly logical development in the history of the law school," he said.

HEADLINE: Strong Demand For Store Space In Manhattan 

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
NEW YORKERS and visitors to the city have kept shopping despite an weakened economy and the events of Sept. 11, and as a result demand for retail space in most locations has been strong even as the office market has sagged, according to real estate executives. 
 The surge in demand in the retailing market has been led by bank branches that stress convenience to customers who need to conduct transactions outside traditional banker's hours, drugstore chains that seem to want to be on every other street corner and a proliferation of wireless stores that sell cellular telephones and the bewildering variety of calling plans attached to them. 
 "It's the latest craze," said Faith H. Consolo, vice chairwoman of Garrick-Aug Associates, a brokerage company specializing in retail space. "We had yogurt stores, then we had coffee stores and now we have wireless stores." 
Although there has been an increase in vacancies in some once-hot locations like SoHo, there are multiple bidders for whatever space becomes available in traditional shopping areas -- and some that were not so traditional, like Times Square. Over all, Ms. Consolo estimated the retail vacancy rate in Manhattan is about 5 percent, with most of those vacancies concentrated below 14th Street, where the proximity to ground zero and transportation difficulties have reduced foot traffic. 
This is in contrast to the office market, where the vacancy rate crept above 10 percent in the second quarter, according to a report by Grubb & Ellis, the real estate brokerage and services company. Asking rents for office space have declined 5.7 percent since the beginning of the year to an average of $47.85 a square foot annually, the lowest level since the first quarter of 2000, the report notes.
Brokers disagree about the flexibility of landlords on retail rents, and the difference may be a matter of location. In prime areas, Ms. Consolo said, building managers are sticking to and getting their asking rents. 
In other areas, there appears to be some room for negotiation. "The asking rents are not being published at a lower number, but for the right tenant there is room to talk to the landlord," said Susan Kurland, a senior director of Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage and services company.
Several real estate executives said the events of Sept. 11 have had an impact on the retail scene in ways obvious and not obvious. The obvious include the destruction of the retail space in the World Trade Center and nearby and the reduction of the number of tourists in places like SoHo.
The less obvious include an apparent increase in the number of stores selling home furnishings and other items for the home. "People have been traveling less since Sept. 11," said Joseph A. Aquino, a managing director at Garrick-Aug. "They are staying home more and, as a result, they are more interested in fixing up their homes."
He noted that a 40,000-square-foot Crate & Barrel store is being built at the northwest corner of Broadway and Houston Street and that Maurice Villency, which had planned to vacate a 30,000-square-foot store on Third Avenue between 56th and 57th Streets in favor of a location on Madison Avenue, will now stay and renovate.
The new Circuit City store at Broadway and 80th Street and the proliferating wireless stores are a part of the stay-at-home trend, he said. "That seems to be what people want now, a big television and a cellular telephone." 
If tourists are fewer in some areas of lower Manhattan, they are still very much in evidence in Times Square, which is attracting retailers as new office buildings in the once-seedy area fill with well-paid workers, as well.
Thomas M. Bow, the director of leasing for the Durst Organization, which owns the Conde Nast building on Broadway between 42nd and 43rd Streets, recently arranged for a Duane Reade store on the first floor and basement, even though there is another Duane Reade a block away at 42nd Street and Eighth Avenue.
He noted that the shoe stores Foot Locker and Skechers are due to move into the area, Foot Locker next to the heavily visited Toys "R" Us store at Broadway and 44th Street, and Skechers to the Reuters building at Seventh Avenue and 42nd Street. The Skechers store will be in what is known as the "town house" section of the building to the west of the subway entrance on the north side of 42nd Street. J. P. Morgan Chase will have automated teller machines on the ground floor and a branch office on the second floor and 3,500 square feet of street level space remains to be leased. Skechers' 4,500-square-foot store will be the New York flagship for the California-based chain, which brokers say is looking for additional stores in the city.
A 7-Eleven convenience store is scheduled to move into 1 Times Square, the triangular building at 42nd Street between Seventh Avenue and Broadway where the ball is dropped on New Year's Eve. The Hershey Food Corporation is planning to open its first major store away from its hometown of Hershey, Pa., at 48th Street and Broadway.
According to Mr. Bow, Times Square may eventually rival New York's traditional shopping mecca of Fifth Avenue for some types of stores because it is becoming a 24-hour-a-day, 7-day-a-week market. "Stores like the N.B.A. would be better off here than on Fifth Avenue, because Times Square does not shut down," he said.
Brokers said asking rents on 42nd Street near Times Square are $325 a square foot while space on Broadway in the area has an asking rent of $500 a square foot.
With Nasdaq at the 43rd Street corner of the Conde Nast building and ESPN Zone on 42nd Street, the remaining midblock space was 3,500 square feet of street level space with a 35,000-square-foot basement attached. Mr. Bow said Duane Reade took the street level and 12,000 square feet of the lower level. The remainder was taken by one of the building's major tenants, the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, for use as a library and conference space, he said.
Retail space in low-rise structures to the east of the Conde Nast building on 42nd Street is being leased only on a short-term basis, Mr. Bow said. The Durst Organization has long had plans to demolish the buildings to erect a 50-story, 1.6-million-square-foot office building to be called One Bryant Park.
Heavily visited areas like Times Square, Union Square and Columbus Circle tend to reward retailers better in slow economic times than such secondary locations as the avenues on the West Side where public transportation is less convenient, said Fred C. Posniak, director of leasing for W&M Properties, an investment and management company. 
He said that leasing had been brisk in the Fisk Building at 250 West 57th Street bacause of its proximity to Columbus Circle, near where the Hearst headquarters is located and where a headquarters is being built for AOL Time Warner. "The good location always holds up better than places like SoHo, which was dependent on tourism," he said.
Mr. Posniak said the retail and office markets are related and retailers located near buildings filled with office workers will naturally do better than those in neighborhoods with many vacancies. "Retailers on Eighth and Ninth Avenues are going to have trouble," he said.
But not all real estate executives agree. Some say population shifts are luring retailers to areas of the city once deemed too poor or unfashionable to attract anything but local mom-and-pop retailers. One developing area is the Lower East Side, where refurbished housing is attracting young adults with rents lower than in many other parts of Manhattan, said Alan Victor, executive vice president of the Lansco Corporation, a brokerage and services company .
He said new restaurants and boutique stores were opening on Clinton, Orchard and Rivington Streets.
"The Lower East Side is attracting a hip, young crowd and restaurants, like 51 Clinton Fresh Food, have opened up," said Katherine Daisley, director of marketing at Lansco. And she said noted that Orchard Street, between Houston and Delancey Streets, had long been noted for stores offering goods at bargain prices.
"The Lower East Side has been developing for the last decade because there is an economic advantage for people to live there," said Gene P. Spiegelman, director of retail services at Cushman & Wakefield. "Services follow people. You can say the same thing about the West Village or TriBeCa."
"It has become a night-time destination for younger people," she said, ignoring the irony that some of the newcomers are moving to an area their forebears struggled mightily to escape.
Of course, some retailers want to be just about everywhere. In addition to the rapidly spreading Commerce, Washington Mutual and North Fork bank branches and the wireless stores -- AT&T, Verizon, Cingular -- a chain of sandwich shops, Pret A Manger, has been popping up mushroomlike around the city, with 12 stores open in Manhattan and has said it plans to open a score more.
The London-based chain, which is 33 percent owned by the McDonald's Corporation, emphasizes company ownership of its shops (as opposed to franchises), fresh foods prepared on the premises and an absence of preservatives -- what its bags describe as "the obscure chemicals, additives and preservatives common to so much of the 'prepared' and 'fast' food on the market today."
It also publicizes its policy of donating any unsold food to charity at the end of the day to assure customers the sandwiches sold the next day will not be holdovers.
ONE of the underlying strengths of the retail market in Manhattan is the eagerness of foreign companies to establish a presence here, if only to be noticed without much expectation of making a profit. "Some of these stores are here mostly as flagships as opposed to true retail," said David A. Green, an executive director with Insignia/ESG, the brokerage and services company. 
According to Robert Futterman of Robert K. Futterman & Associates, a retail oriented brokerage, there are eight or so foreign-based retailers, including organizations bearing the names of the designers Jil Sander, Joseph Abboud and Adrienne Vittadini, that are actively looking to open their first stores in Manhattan despite the uncertain economic times. 
Other high-end stores that already have a presence in the city, like Coach, Armani Exchange and Ann Taylor, are seeking to expand their already successful businesses, brokers say.
Some retailers try to get ahead of the curve, moving into neighborhoods that are converting from an industrial past to a residential and commercial district. One example, Mr. Green said, is Whole Foods Market, which opened a 40,000-square-foot store in Chelsea at Seventh Avenue and 24th Street. Many of the old warehouses in the area have been converted into art galleries and artist's studios, and other buildings have been converted to housing.
"We are seeing the emergence of a neighborhood as the old buildings are converted," Mr. Green said.
Other companies simply need a space big enough to make their retailing concept work, even if the location is not ideal. The Minnesota-based Best Buy, which sells a broad array of electronic devices and major appliances, was one of them. "Best Buy needed a space where they could lay out the store," said David LaPierre, a managing director with Insignia/ESG. "So they took 43,000 square feet at Sixth and 23rd and now they are open for business.
"The quality of the space dictates where some retailers will go," he added. "They will go to the West Side to find quality space even if they would rather be on the East Side."
Even areas like SoHo, which went from being one of the hottest retail areas of the city to one of the coldest, with annual rents dropping from $450 a square foot to under $300, can be seen as an opportunity rather then a disaster, according to some brokers. "Values in SoHo are getting back to reality," said Jeffrey D. Roseman, a broker with Newmark New Spectrum Retail.
Some real estate executives say SoHo's troubles may be temporary, because many of the tourists that once thronged its streets were from the metropolitan area and had been discouraged from coming to the area by the traffic and other restrictions that followed the events of Sept. 11. They said national chains might move into spaces vacated by local retailers, particularly at the lower rents.
"There is more supply there than there has been in eight or nine years," Mr. Green said. "We are starting to see creditable candidates looking there and the landlords are easing off rents," he said.
Madison and Fifth Avenues were unaffected by Sept. 11 and have barely felt the effect of the recession, said Ms. Consolo, who noted that Asprey, the British seller of luxury goods, is expanding from about 10,000 square feet to 25,000 square feet at 56th Street and Fifth Avenue.
"The retail market is doing much better than I would have expected in this economic environment," said Ms. Kurland of Cushman & Wakefield.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.; 
When Publish or Perish Is More Than Just Words

BYLINE:  By LEWIS BEALE 

DATELINE: HOBOKEN 

 BODY:
HOW'S this for a disaster in the making? A writer and artist, living and working out of a third-floor walkup, decide to start their own publishing house. They have limited funds and almost no experience in the book business. To make matters even worse, the first two volumes they plan to issue seem to have almost no commercial potential.
 "What makes us particularly lunatic is that we're starting off with a book of poetry and a book of literary criticism," said Dennis Loy Johnson, who, with his partner, Valerie Merians, is the driving force behind Melville House Publishing, which will release its first offerings in September. "Two big sellers. Absolute sure fire hits." 
 If nothing else. Mr. Johnson and Ms. Merians are realistic. They know what they're up against. 
More than 135,000 new books were published last year, which means the fight for shelf space at the local Barnes & Noble or independent bookstore is more vicious than a championship boxing match. In addition, New Jersey is not exactly a hotbed of the publishing industry; although the state boasts two fine university presses -- Princeton and Rutgers -- and several small, specialized publishing houses, the bulk of the industry is in New York City, where Knopf, Doubleday and Random House reside.
Then there is the issue of what Mr. Johnson and Ms. Merians have chosen to publish. Even though a third of all the new books in 2001 were adult fiction, children's works or in the field of sociology and economics, Melville House will issue "Poetry After 9/11," an anthology of New York poets, and "A Reader's Manifesto," in which the critic B. R. Meyers attacks pretentiousness in the work of such literary luminaries as Don DeLillo and Cormac McCarthy.
Despite all this, the limited nature of their potential readership may be an advantage for the initial Melville House offerings.
"Their market will be very clear to them, very specific," said John Whitman of Turtle Books, a small publisher of illustrated children's books. "The advantage for smaller publishers is when they're filling a small niche. When you do something specific, you find people who will follow you. They will find that they will connect more quickly to their market, and they won't waste advertising dollars, because they can go to outlets and venues that can reach that audience."
Not that the two fledgling publishers were thinking that hard about marketing when they decided to create Melville House. The impetus for the venture came from mobylives.com, a chatty publishing industry Web site run by Mr. Johnson, who also writes short stories and whose weekly book column appears in several newspapers around the country. After Sept. 11, Mr. Johnson's site began getting a lot of poetry, and he noticed that "poetry was everywhere."
"I thought this was a remarkable response," he said. "People who don't normally do poetry were doing it. So we also wondered how the real poets were responding, and would people be interested in that."
Mr. Johnson and Ms. Merians decided to solicit poems from writers they knew and to compile them into a book.
"We thought it would be very modest," said Ms. Merians, who is a photographer and sculptor. "We would hand sell it just to New York area bookstores. You know, an out-of-the-back-of-the-car kind of thing."
About that time, Mr. Johnson got a fan letter from B. R. Meyers, whose attack on literary pretension that appeared in the Atlantic Monthly last July had caused a sensation. Mr. Meyers told Mr. Johnson he was going to self-publish his essay to try to reach a wider audience, which Mr. Johnson saw as a recipe for disaster. So Mr. Johnson talked Mr. Meyers into letting him publish an expanded version of the work.
"Then we thought, 'We've got a serious business now. Meyers has got a following. That book will sell,' " Mr. John said.
Then the real work began. The printing itself was the easiest part, since it simply entailed calling around and finding out how much it would cost. But Mr. Johnson and Ms. Merians had to incorporate, hunt down poets and read manuscripts, plus negotiate royalty contracts with their writers. And there was the toughest nut to crack: persuading someone to distribute their books.
"The biggest problem a new press has is getting a distributor," said Mr. Whitman. "The reason more established distributors hesitate to take on new people is because they don't have a backlist, and they're often undercapitalized.
But Melville House was lucky. After several distributors hung up on them or laughed in their faces, Mr. Johnson and Ms. Merians connected with a Chicago-based company called the Independent Publishers Group, whose president, a former college professor, took a personal interest in the Meyers book.
"It's a real long shot to take on these little guys," said Curt Mathews, the chief executive of IPG, a distributer for small publishing houses. "The way I do it is to think about what they're publishing, and get a reading on them. Are they clever? The people who make it tend to have a sense of what's interesting and what isn't. You have to be able to imagine the audience, what they want, and how they get to know the book exists. Dennis seemed to me to have some relevant background, so he wouldn't be making it up as he went along, and he seemed real sharp."
Melville House was fortunate in another sense. When word got out that a book of post-9/11 poetry was coming out, the media started to pay attention -- so much attention that it had to hire a publicist. CNN called. So did National Public Radio, "Good Morning, America" and any number of local television and radio stations.
Good feelings aside, there are still serious financial and distribution issues. For instance, Mr. Johnson and Ms. Merians have to pay their own printing costs, and given the nature of most book distribution deals, will receive only about 25 percent of the total sale price, out of which they have to cover overhead and pay royalties. Because it usually takes three months from the initial publication date before sales money begins coming in, the neophyte publishers say they do not expect to see money until early next year. In the meantime, they will have spent more than $20,000 -- an enormous amount for them -- borrowed from their families and a bank.
Then there still is the problem of getting the books on the shelves. Although both works are currently listed on the Amazon and Barnes & Noble Web sites, there is no guarantee a reader will be able to find them in a major store.
"The majors like to support the independent publishers and new authors," said William Kohler, a publisher's representative based in Ocean City, "but it involves sifting through the multitude of titles to find what they want to give shelf space to. You're at the mercy of people who have the control, who read the book and say it has a chance."
So it comes down to reviews, personal contacts and marketing and what Mr. Kohler referred to as "sweat equity" -- the simple act of getting out there and flogging the book on their own.
"We will be hitting pavement everywhere we go this summer," said Mr. Johnson. "We will bring books and meet the local store owners."
It certainly will not be easy. Mr. Johnson estimates they will have to sell 25,000 copies of Mr. Meyers's book just to break even, a hefty number for a startup publisher.
But Mr. Johnson and Ms. Merians say they are committed. They already plan to issue two more works, a book of short stories and a volume of poetry, next year. Ultimately, they would like to establish Melville House as a boutique firm that issues no more than six books a year, specializing in highly literary novels and poetry.
"We don't want to be snapping off quickies to make money," Mr. Johnson said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dennis Loy Johnson, left, and his partner, Valerie Merians, formed Melville House Publishing, which in September will release its first offerings, "Poetry After 9/11," an anthology of New York poets, and "A Reader's Manifesto," which attacks pretentiousness in the work of literary luminaries. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Living Tax-Free at the Top Rungs

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
ABOUT one in every thousand Americans who earned more than $200,000 in 1999 paid no income tax, despite a 1969 law intended to prevent tax-free living, new data from the Internal Revenue Service shows.
 In an annual report on high-income people who pay no taxes, the I.R.S. said that almost 2.5 million Americans reported an adjusted gross income of at least $200,000 in 1999, putting them in the top 2 percent of all taxpayers. (Adjusted gross income is the last line on the front page of a Form 1040 tax return.) 
 Within that group, 2,525 individuals and married couples paid no federal income tax. These taxpayers had an average adjusted gross income of $389,000 each, according to the spring 2002 issue of the Statistics of Income Bulletin, which the I.R.S. released this month and where the 1999 annual report appeared.
Of those nontaxpayers, 2,174 paid no tax anywhere in the world. 
Over all, the $200,000-plus income group had an average income of $580,000 each and paid, on average, 26.5 percent of their adjusted gross income in federal and foreign income taxes, the I.R.S. found. Foreign income taxes accounted for less than $1 of every $500 of total taxes paid. 
Congress had ordered the reports after a 1969 Treasury study found that 155 individuals and couples paid no income tax on incomes of $200,000 or more. (Adjusted for inflation, a $200,000 income in 1969 was the equivalent of about $908,000 in 1999.)
The number of high-income people paying no taxes has varied from around 1,800 to 2,800 in recent years. Many of them took deductions for interest, including interest paid on investments, and losses from S corporations, a form of closely held business. 
To prevent people with very high incomes from enjoying the benefits of government without sharing in the costs, Congress passed the individual alternative minimum tax in 1969. But over the years, Congress has not adjusted the law to fully account for inflation; as a result, the alternative minimum tax today applies to very few people who make more than $627,000, but can apply to a single parent making as little as $28,000. 
The Treasury Department estimates that the alternative minimum tax will affect about 80 percent of taxpayers who make $75,000 to $250,000 in 2010, when the tax cuts that President Bush championed in his election campaign are fully effective.
As a result of the alternative minimum tax, some taxpayers will get no relief under the Bush tax cuts and others will have their tax cuts reduced.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER MANHATTAN; 
Parkway's Scenic Views May Soon Be Official

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
As the Henry Hudson Parkway meanders under old stone overpasses in Riverdale, past the green edges of Inwood Hill and Fort Tryon Parks and down the west side of Manhattan, it reveals surprisingly serene views of the Hudson River, the George Washington Bridge and the elegant architecture of Riverside Drive. 
 The vistas fade in and out as the road curves, which is exactly what Robert Moses had in mind when he built the road in the 1930's. This is exactly why Hilary Kitasei, a Riverdale resident, is leading a group that plans to nominate the road as the city's first official scenic byway. 
 Ms. Kitasei and the Riverdale Nature Preservancy Henry Hudson Parkway Task Force also hope to encourage a few improvements in the roadway. To name a few of their complaints: signs are intrusively large and there are too many of them; cement barriers are ugly; rusted chain-link fences spoil the rustic overpasses; the billboards in Harlem ruin the view of Riverside Church; and the State Department of Transportation is considering straightening some of the S-curves to speed up traffic. 
"Parkways are different from typical highways," said Ms. Kitasei, chairwoman of the task force. "And aesthetics are important. The goal of an expressway is to get from Point A to Point B with the maximum safe speed. A parkway is a driving experience."
The state Scenic Byways Program began in 1992, and today includes 14 roads covering more than 2,000 miles, none in the city. Because nominations must come from a community group, the task force has been meeting with community boards, parks groups and government agencies to rally support. Scenic Byway status would not bring any special protection, but it would make it easier to get money and political support for improvements.
Task force members have different particular interests. Nancy Bruning, president of the Friends of Fort Tryon Park, is worried about the proposal to straighten the S-curves, which would likely eliminate some parkland and worsen a local drag-racing problem.
Paul S. Mankiewicz, a task force member and a biologist who runs an ecological engineering firm on City Island, contends that adding soil and terracing and more plants along the roadways would both beautify the parkway and be an economical way to capture rainwater, reduce flooding and perhaps lower the summer temperature a few degrees.
"It's hard to find a reason to object to it," Ms. Kitasei said. "It's taking back the park in parkway." SETH KUGEL

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lovely river views decorate the Henry Hudson Parkway. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FIELD NOTES; 
Bridal Gowns That Draw Oohs A Second (or Fifth) Time Around

BYLINE:  By JAY MOLISHEVER 

 BODY:
IF material objects can carry emotional weight, try to calculate the load-bearing capacity of the gown your mother wore on her wedding day. 
 Laurel Trask of San Carlos, Calif., started looking for her late mother's 1946 rayon brocade gown after she and her fiance, Brian Connor, made plans to marry this fall. "Since my mother had Alzheimer's for many years before her death, she was kind of lost to me," Ms. Trask said. "This is a way of reconnecting with her when she was young and strong." 
 Brides and their mothers say that marrying in a family bridal gown adds emotional depth to the ceremony. It can also be a stylish option. In recent years there has been an upswing in interest in mining attics and closets for wedding dresses -- particularly those from the 1930's, 1950's and 1960's.
This resurgence, said Carolyn Niezgoda, who is a wedding gown restorer in Brooklyn (www.carolynniez.com), "coincides with the fact that their mothers had the beautiful romantic 1950's gowns with the portrait necklines and the full skirts and crinolines that flattered the waist, which were getting away from the those high necks and cover-up gowns that you found in the 40's. Now we're also seeing the beautiful empire-waist sheaths from the 1960s."
For her marriage in June 2001, Marcia Rocker Gardy of Alexandria, Va., decided on her mother's drop-waist gown, a satin and lace confection that had taken on a faded ivory color. When she took the dress to Imperial Gown Restoration in Fairfax, Va. (www.gown.com), Mrs. Gardy requested a light cleaning that wouldn't change its patina, which she said "represents almost 50 years of a wonderful marriage." 
"These dresses give their wearers a greater sense of family connection," said Jonathan Scheer (www.jscheer.com), a fabric restorer on New York's Upper East Side, who reports "a marked increase in brides wanting to wear their mother's, and sometimes, their grandmother's wedding dresses." 
Steven Saidman, Imperial Gown's third-generation owner, said, "There has been a visible, substantial increase in requests to restore antique gowns since 9/11." The revival, he added, began before then; he attributes it to "a culture that has again become more traditional." 
Ms. Niezgoda explained: "People need to create stories, they need the connectedness." For mothers and daughters, she said, the process of preparing an heirloom dress "is almost always an astounding bonding experience." 
Depending on its condition, a family gown can represent a substantial savings -- or a substantial outlay. The cost of restoring a vintage dress can be in line with the price tag on a new designer gown. Even the best-cared-for heirlooms may require careful refitting, not to mention specialized cleaning, repair, color and fabric restoration, even restyling. The process can take several months and can cost from $1,000 to $4,000.
Wedding dresses with a history present certain limitations. Susan Washburne McMichaels Sacher, 28, knew from childhood that she would someday wear the ivory silk brocade gown her great-great-grandmother wore in 1882. Her maternal grandmother and namesake, the late Susan Washburne Reyburn Winship, was married in it in 1941, and her mother, Susan Bishop Winship McMichaels, gave it a spin in 1967. "I'm the fifth Susan in the line to wear this dress." said Mrs. Sacher, who was married in May at Grace Episcopal Church in New York to Robert Sacher, an owner of the Luna Lounge in New York. 
The Susans' gown was a bit discolored in places. "I don't think it had ever been cleaned," Mrs. Sacher said. And she recalled that when she took it to Mr. Scheer, the restorer, "He said to me, 'I could clean it, but I'm worried that the detail and ornamentation could be damaged.' So in the end I opted not to do anything to it."
That meant not letting out the seams. "I'm the same height as my great-great grandmother, so the length was perfect," she said. "But Victorian bodies were quite different than American women's bodies are today. Women wore corsets and such, so while I'm very fit and work out all the time, my shape is not that of a woman from 120 years ago." So the sacrifice Mrs. Sacher faced was caloric, not economic. "I had to find a way to fit myself to the gown," she said.
Some experts recommend that brides avoid emulating every aspect of the look their mothers strived for on their wedding day. 
"This is not a re-enactment, it's a marriage" said Paula Stanton of Elegant Bridal Boutique (www.EverythingVintage.com) in Mount Horeb, Wis., who recommends mixing and matching accessories from other eras. "Having the cap, veil and shoes all from the same period as the dress gives the feeling of a costume, not a bridal gown." 
And reverence for a heirloom gown means different things to different brides. "For some, it's like renovating the old family home; for others, it's a Williamsburg museum restoration," Mr. Saidman said.
When Jennifer Bertsch Dolce and her husband, Jared, of Pelham, N.Y., became engaged two years ago, she decided that she wanted to march down the aisle in the same empire-waisted satin sheath that her mother, Beverly Bertsch, wore in 1965. "I had bought it in Filene's in Boston," Mrs. Bertsch said. "On sale."
Mrs. Dolce, who at 5-foot-8 is three inches taller than her mother, said: "The dress was wrinkled and yellowed. But when I first tried it on, I felt, this is it."
They took it to Ms. Niezgoda, who hand-cleaned and reblocked each panel and restyled it for the bride's taller figure, removing the boxy kimono sleeves and raising the shoulders with spaghetti straps. Then she relined and resewed the entire dress, at a cost of $1,500.
"The dress didn't mean as much to me when I bought it as when she wore it," Mrs. Bertsch said. 
Women who don't have an heirloom dress in the attic can readily find a gown that looks the part. "My mom and dad actually eloped, so there was no wedding dress to be handed down," said Polly Miller Tubbs of Blue Mounds, Wis., who chose a Chantilly lace ball gown from the 1950's from Ms. Stanton's shop when she married Dennis Tubbs in the British Virgin Islands last month. 
Mrs. Tubbs plans to preserve the gown. "Just in case I have a daughter," she said.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MOTT HAVEN; 
With Lofts Scarce, the Bronx Beckons and Artists Notice

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
A few years ago, the murmurs started. Artists were discovering the attractions of the South Bronx: cheap rent, good subway access and, especially, vacant industrial space.
 A few dozen artists arrived, but the expected explosion never occurred. But that may change. Carnegie Management Corporation, a Brooklyn developer, is putting the finishing touches on the conversion of the Estey Piano Company factory into 155 live-in artists' studios, renting for $950 to $1,700 a month. The first 18 units in the long-vacant factory should be available next month. 
 There is no lack of interest. Last month, when Carnegie ran an ad in The Village Voice, calls flooded in.
Mark Hohlstein, a 38 year-old sculptor and collage artist, is one person interested in the area. He tried out the neighborhood once before, but is now living upstate and trying to move back into the city. Most areas, however, are unaffordable to him.
"I'm an artist and to pay the rent in Williamsburg, you have to work," he said. "I have to not make art."
He scoured the map for alternatives. Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and Long Island City, Queens, were filled up, he decided.
"So I just went up, and there's the Bronx," he said.
Carnegie originally bought the piano factory for $4.75 million from Touro College, whose plans to convert it into student housing had fallen through. Renovations, which include installing high-speed Internet service and restoring the ancient clock tower, will cost another $4 million. 
"We decided this is the next frontier," said Berl Jacobs, who, with son Isaac, runs Carnegie. "This is going to be the new Williamsburg." 
Carnegie, which converted six industrial buildings in Williamsburg to lofts, has been working with the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, which has helped them obtain necessary zoning changes.
"From our perspective, this is a logical development for the area," said Neil Pariser, senior vice president of the development corporation. "It has come back from the ravages of the 1970's."
The factory building is a block from the spot where the crucial scene in "Bonfire of the Vanities" was filmed, but it is also near the South Bronx's increasingly popular antiques district.
Workers are preserving the uneven parquet floors, the crisscrossed wooden joists and the industrial window frames while installing modern kitchens and bathrooms.
"The artists have discovered the area for the last four or five years, and it's ripe," Mr. Jacobs said. "When they put in the seeds, we developers come in and let the trees grow." SETH KUGEL

HEADLINE: Business; 
Venture Capitalists Are Taking the Gloves Off

BYLINE:  By LYNNLEY BROWNING 

 BODY:
THE venture capital world is looking less like a genteel club and more like a brawling barroom.
 Venture capitalists are offering the companies they bankroll increasingly hard-knuckled deals that leave little wealth for a start-up's managers or original backers. The moves are leading some entrepreneurs, desperate for money, to decry today's investors as bullies. Some venture capitalists are even suing rival venture firms, asserting that the tough new terms are wiping out the value of their previous investments. 
 "People are playing hardball," said Ted Dintersmith, a general partner at Charles River Ventures, based in Waltham, Mass. 
The bursting of the Internet stock bubble more than two years ago wiped out many venture investments in dot-coms. Now, amid the bear market in stocks and limited prospects for investors or young companies to make money soon, venture capitalists are looking for novel ways to make money. As a result, "private companies are facing the most onerous terms from venture capitalists that we have seen in 20 years," said Steven E. Bochner, a securities lawyer at Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati in Palo Alto, Calif., who represents venture firms. 
In the boom of the late 1990's, venture capitalists chose one of two options. They could be paid back their invested capital, share in profits and receive dividends. Or they could convert their preferred shares into common stock when the private company held an initial public offering or was sold. During that time of huge payouts for newly public and acquired companies, they usually chose No. 2.
But with markets now all but dead for initial public offerings and mergers and acquisitions, venture capitalists from Silicon Valley to the East Coast are increasingly demanding -- and getting -- both options. This "double dip," known as "participating preferred," leaves far less potential wealth for a company's founders and previous investors. Venture capitalists are also negotiating more deals with heightened "liquidation preferences," in which start-ups agree to pay back the initial investment at least two or three times over. 
Previously, venture capitalists handed over money to a start-up in a lump sum. But more are now parceling out funds in tranches, and then only when the new companies reach certain milestones -- a sales target, for example, or the hiring of a particular chief executive. 
They are even trying to protect their investments through veto rights that permit them to block future investments from other venture capitalists who might dilute their stakes, said Mark G. Borden, chairman of the corporate department at Hale & Dorr, a law firm based in Boston. As a result, Mr. Borden said, a start-up company that casts its lot with a particular venture capitalist or group of investors may find itself tethered to those backers and unable to raise new money elsewhere.
ENTREPRENEURS particularly dislike one recent trend: venture capitalists have been pushing young companies to agree, retroactively, to lower the prices that investors now pay for shares should the start-up be worth less when it tries to raise more money later. Such a move, known as a "full ratchet," is intended to prevent an investor's stake from being diluted. But it can significantly reduce or even wipe out the stakes of a company's original investors and managers, giving the new investors most of the company for a song.
"If you were in the first round of investors, you generally now get crushed" when a start-up raises more money later, said J. Edmund Colloton, general partner and chief operating officer of Bessemer Venture Partners, based in Wellesley Hills, Mass.
Consider Mahi Networks, a private optical networking start-up. In three rounds of financing, from September 1999 to November 2001, Mahi raised $110 million from blue-chip venture firms like Benchmark Capital, Sequoia Capital, the GE Capital unit of General Electric and the venture arm of Goldman Sachs. At one point during the Internet boom, Mahi was valued at more than $180 million.
Last month, though, a new group of smaller-name investors, led by St. Paul Venture Capital of Minneapolis, acquired about three-quarters of the company for $75 million in financing. Before that, Mahi was valued at only $25 million, said Chris Rust, Mahi's president and chief executive. But most of that was tied up in employee incentives, including stock options, leaving almost no value for existing investors.
Despite having nurtured Mahi with money and advice, the early investors chose not to back the company further. With the new, lower valuation, "there was effectively no value attributed to all of our previous investments," said one venture capitalist whose firm was an early backer. "We were all completely washed out" in the last round, said the investor, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
There is no hard data on the prevalence of the newer, tougher terms. Venture capitalists are famously secretive about their deals, which are private and largely unregulated. But ask venture capitalists or securities lawyers who work with start-ups, and tales of onerous terms will abound. "At the end of the day, the money is coming with strings attached," said Mark G. Heesen, president of the National Venture Capital Association, a trade group based in Arlington, Va.
The shift has turned the conventional wisdom on its head. Venture capitalists once loved risk, but no more. The Internet bust and Wall Street's slump have left them scrambling to make money to repay their own investors and to justify their management fees.
Venture capitalists once clamored to be first in the door of a hot new company. Now they can usually make money only by being the most recent investor. "We're certainly looking for later-stage deals, where you get the benefit of the previous investors having taken the risk," said Todd Dagres, a general partner at Battery Ventures in Wellesley, Mass.
Some entrepreneurs agree to the harsh new terms simply because they have no other way to raise cash to survive. But other managers now shun the investors, whom they call "vulture capitalists," bent on picking the meat off a young or struggling start-up. Today's venture capitalists "want to take advantage of you," said George R. Waller, chief executive of Strike Force Technologies, an employee-financed software maker in West Orange, N.J. Mr. Waller said he had turned away 30 venture firms in recent months because they had demanded, among other things, hard-to-reach sales milestones.
George J. Nassef, chief executive of ValetNoir, a start-up based in New York that makes marketing software for casinos, said several venture firms had even asked in recent months to have their potential investments secured with receivables, or money owed to ValetNoir by its customers. He turned them all down.
NOT surprisingly, the shift in financing terms is upsetting some venture firms that were early investors in start-ups but are now suffering as the companies seek to raise additional money at bargain-basement prices.
In one high-profile case, Benchmark Capital, a blue-chip Silicon Valley firm, sued the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and Juniper Financial this month. Benchmark was an early investor in Juniper, an online financial services concern, having put $20 million into it in early 2000, just before the Internet bubble burst. It also contributed to a second, $94 million round that September. Juniper, based in Wilmington, Del., is seeking to raise $50 million from Canadian Imperial, which already owns around half the company, but on terms that would sharply dilute Benchmark's original, unspecified stake. Benchmark sued to prevent the start-up from raising the money. All the parties declined to comment on the case, which a Delaware judge threw out last week. 
Such friction was rare during the boom, when venture capitalists operated like a competitive but tight-knit fraternity, channeling deals to one another. Start-ups and their backers saw their interests as allied. But in tighter markets, "there's a lot of ugly behavior coming out," said Mr. Bochner, the Wilson Sonsini lawyer. "There's going to be much more litigation like this."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 4, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about disputes in the venture capital industry misstated a ruling in a lawsuit brought last month by Benchmark Capital against the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and Juniper Financial, a start-up company that Benchmark helped finance. A Delaware judge denied Benchmark's request for a preliminary injunction to stop Juniper from getting new financing from the Canadian bank, a move that would dilute Benchmark's stake. The judge did not throw out Benchmark's suit.

HEADLINE: Health Care's Logic 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "More May Not Mean Better in Health Care, Studies Find" (front page, July 21): At the very least, the research provides evidence that the health care sector is not driven by common market forces. This is especially interesting given the Bush administration's propensity for eliminating central oversight and promoting simple remedies like increased competition. 
 A lack of careful public planning would introduce the same opportunities for abuse into health care that we have seen with Enron. Also, studies like these indicate that abiding by traditional laissez-faire would cause wasteful disparities. Though health care constitutes a major portion of the economy, it is not governed by the conventional principles of economics.

RAJ GUPTA
Washington, July 23, 2002

LENGTH: 2395 words

HEADLINE: Not Quite Sex and the City 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
CLUB KIRA guards its secrets well. Waiters in tuxedos admit the male customers to this unmarked Japanese haven, tucked into a residential building on East 49th Street in Midtown, only after studying them through a hidden camera. A red awning signals the club's presence with just two stars: "kira, kira" means sparkle in Japanese. The businessmen who retreat here to unwind know that the shining stars are emblems of the club's young hostesses.
 In a cracker box of a lounge, Ryoko Karasawa and her customer huddled shoulder to shoulder on low leather seats. Around them, other couples leaned into one another. The women wore tight cocktail dresses. The men had arrived straight from work in dark business suits. 
 Ms. Karasawa refreshed her customer's whiskey for what seemed the hundredth time. She poured delicately, cradling the bottle in both her manicured hands. He was drunk, but the married executive did not let his tongue, or his hands, slip much. Not as much as other customers. And Ms. Karasawa was relieved. That night, at least, the $80 she would earn for five hours of work would come a bit easier. 
 Manhattan harbors some 15 Japanese hostess clubs, secretive bars that employ young women to serve as companions for the almost exclusively Japanese and male clientele. Most of the clubs are clustered on the East Side between 45th and 53rd Street.
Common in Japan, hostess clubs offer a hint of the illicit, a chance for ritualistic flirtation but no sex. In a city known for its libido, they represent not quite sex and the city. The small number of hostesses who sleep with their customers do so outside the clubs' auspices. For the men, these sanctuaries mostly provide, for a few hours at least, the illusion of back home.
 Even so, business has declined since Sept. 11, as the terrorist attacks dampened the city's night life. According to the Japanese Consulate, four Japanese companies have abandoned the city since September. In addition, the still-struggling Japanese economy means shrinking company expense accounts and limits on corporate entertaining. At least two expensive clubs have closed in recent months, and more customers are paying their own cover charges. 
 So, another layer of fragility has been added to a sometimes fragile world where half the hostesses don't use their own names, and where emotional sleight-of-hand is the order of the night.
 Club Kira's decor is tasteful but impersonal, as in an expensive hotel. Gleaming coffee tables are cluttered with bottles of Scotch, bowls of rice crackers and heart-shaped ashtrays. A murmur of jazz leavens the talk and laughter within the gray-blue walls.
There are no windows, no clocks, nothing to intrude on the club's mission to offer a timeless sense of refuge and relaxation to men who pay the $150 cover charge simply to sit and talk with the hostesses. Usually, the customers' employers pick up the tab.
 Diversion for the men comes at a high price. For the women who serve them, this means hard work. 
"When I was young, I didn't understand this as much, but a hostess's job is to help people have a good time," said Ms. Karasawa, 31, who was a hostess in Tokyo for 10 years. "Why else would they pay?" 
Ryoko Karasawa was the pseudonym she used on the job in Japan, and she did not want her real name revealed for this article. Other women interviewed also declined to give their full names.
 For the hostesses, most of whom are here on student visas, the clubs represent one of the few job options readily available to them. Some clubs pay the hostesses in cash, off the books. Many of the women hide their night jobs because they violate visa restrictions. Being a hostess also carries a social stigma in the Japanese middle class.
"Most young Japanese women have aspirations," said Ichiro Suganuma, a former manager of an expensive club who now works in the film industry. "They want to be a singer, be rich, see America. But when you come here, it's hard. There are a lot of other women like you."

Outside the Mainstream
In the last two decades, it has become fairly common for Japanese women to study and even work overseas. Still, a Japanese woman's decision to live abroad sets her outside a mainstream culture that guarantees her security as a homemaker, but is not concerned with her professional fulfillment.
"It's very striking that a lot of Japanese women don't have a long-term plan when they go abroad," said Karen Kelsky, a professor of anthropology at the University of Oregon and the author of "Women on the Verge: Japanese Women, Western Dreams" (Duke, 2001). "They have vague notions that they want a career, but they have no societal support for their career goals. It's a poignant situation."
Most New York hostesses fell into the job when they encountered the city's high cost of living. The entertainment at the hostess clubs has its roots in the geisha tradition, which dates to 18th-century Japan. Like the geisha, a hostess indulges her customer's every conversational whim, creating a space where he can escape routine and shed his workaday persona.
For this privilege, patrons pay cover charges of up to $150 at places like Club Kira and $30 an hour at the less expensive clubs. A few of the top New York clubs have sister clubs in Tokyo owned by the same people. But most clubs here are owned by Japanese men who have relocated permanently to New York. At the clubs, customers buy bottles of liquor at about three times the retail price. A bottle of Johnnie Walker Black for $120 is a popular choice.
Titillation is one of the top attractions; hostesses flirt and flatter. Officially, touching is prohibited, but it happens anyway. Sexual banter abounds, but actual sex is rare, and never on the premises. At the hostess clubs, it's men's egos that receive the most caressing.
 Club Kira sometimes gives its customers an extra chance to assert their masculinity. On holidays and other special occasions, a game of darts allows them to win savings off their bill if they strike close to the bull's-eye. One night, Ms. Karasawa, wearing a lipstick-red blazer and a long black skirt slit to the thigh, stood behind her customer and rooted as he took aim at the target, an easy seven feet away.
When her customer's sure throw shaved $100 off his bill, she clapped and smiled, perky as any high school cheerleader. When her turn came, her dart nicked an outer ring. Throughout the night, the women's darts always wobbled short of the mark.
 Insincere? Of course. But in the hostess clubs, it's a man's world.
When men pay for sex, "it's not sincere, it's really cold," Mr. Suganuma said. "The clubs are different. They're not sincere, but they're warm. Let's say you're a lonely guy in New York City. Everyone at the clubs tells you you're the greatest. If you want to smoke, they'll light your cigarette. If you want to drink, they'll pour your drink. Those little things really count."

The Hostesses' Shadow World
Each hostess's approach to negotiating this shadow world, and integrating it into her life, is different.
Ms. Karasawa is unusual among New York's Japanese hostesses because she doesn't hide her job from her friends and family. She said she was not ashamed to be a hostess. She decided she needed the flexibility of the clubs, because she can take the night off when she has an English-language class or another conflict. She said her parents know about her job, and offer moral support.
But Ms. Karasawa receives financial help from no one. She squeezes her tuition and other expenses from the $1,500 to $1,800 she takes home each month from Club Kira. Ms. Karasawa has to manage her money carefully. She buys her cocktail dresses on the outskirts of the garment district for $20 each.
 Though money is tight, Ms. Karasawa does not let her job take up more time than necessary. She already works five hours a night, five nights a week, at $15 to $18 an hour. Most clubs pay hostesses a $15 to $20 bonus if they bring a customer in with them by 9:30 p.m. A hostess will typically call her customer at work or e-mail him to arrange a dinner date, and then accompany him to the club. 
But Ms. Karasawa refuses to do that. "Customers are customers, not friends. I would have a better meal at McDonald's with a friend than an expensive meal with a client."
Ms. Karasawa said she often struggled with her customers' notions that hostesses are young women who spend all their money on recreation and neglect their studies. What bothers her more than sexually suggestive remarks, she said, are comments like, "If you don't have money, you shouldn't study abroad."
"It really sets me off when they say that," she added. "But I can't show my anger."
Unlike Ms. Karasawa, Noriko, 28, a former hostess at Club Gold, an expensive club on East 52nd Street, kept her hostess work a secret, even from her parents, who help her meet expenses. After Sept. 11, Noriko's hours were cut from four days a week to two or three, but she said she didn't mind, because her reduced schedule meant that her new boyfriend had less reason to be suspicious.
Even in jeans and a simple top, Noriko exuded femininity with her careful makeup and red-highlighted hair that fell in soft layers around her face. On the nights she worked, she told her boyfriend that she was out with friends or studying late at the library. About misleading her boyfriend, who is Japanese, Noriko said, "I didn't feel guilty, because I didn't have feelings for the clients." 
Recently, she discovered that her boyfriend had taken some of his business clients to an expensive hostess club. "I was kind of surprised," she said, "because he's not the type to go to clubs. But in his case, he has to go sometimes."
Noriko echoed Ms. Karasawa's frustrations about customers who wouldn't take her seriously. Last year, she earned a graduate degree from a top New York university, but her customers refused to acknowledge her achievement. "A typical customer I didn't like would say things like: 'Where do you live? You live in Queens. What do you do? You go to language school,' " she said, voicing a typical hostess stereotype. "They didn't give me a chance to answer for myself."

Relaxation Without Shop Talk
 Like most clubs, Club Gold is a dusky, timeless vault, its walls closer to saffron than gold. For those who keep track, closing time is 1:30 a.m. Noriko spent many nights at the club, restless and impatient for her guests to leave, eager to switch from her clingy dress to jeans and a sweater. But it's the manager's job, not the hostess's, to hint that the night has come to an end.
"I always told my hostesses that customers work hard for their companies," said Mr. Suganuma, the former club owner. "They need to be treated right, sent back to their companies refreshed. Whatever they say is right."
Men visit the clubs as a release from stress. Even among groups of co-workers, talk of the office or of serious issues rarely surfaces. "Usually the hostesses are very young, new in New York," said Y. N., a frequent club customer who asked to be identified only by his initials. "I'm more experienced. I give them advice, and they like it."
In New York and Japan, a hostess takes her conversational cues from her customer. If he wants to talk, she will listen with puppyish attention or laugh when he cracks a joke. A good hostess can also engage the most awkward man in banter. Most clubs offer karaoke, so singing can help move the night along. Food is never a diversion. Clubs offer snacks like cheese, fruit and crackers, but no meals.
Some men go to the clubs just to socialize with co-workers and enjoy a few hours in the company of attractive young women. Y. N. puts himself in this category. Married with two young children, he said he liked talking with the young women at any number of East Side clubs. But he restricts his visits to work-related socializing, paid for by his employer. He said his wife knows that he goes to the clubs. "What's the big deal?" he asked.
Others nurture hopes of having a relationship with a hostess. With these men, especially, a hostess must negotiate a narrow bridge in offering the illusion of sexual availability without suggesting the possibility of actual sex. Most of the customers are married. Most of the hostesses are single.

'They Want a Girlfriend'
"Even if they're married, they want a girlfriend," said Kanako, a former hostess at Club Gold. Kanako, 22, looks like an Asian kewpie doll, with big eyes and a round face framed by bright red hair. Petite and hip, she was able to wrap herself in the latest designer fashions by treating her clients like so many open wallets.
As is customary in Japan's service sector, men don't tip the hostesses, but some men give them gifts on special occasions, like birthdays or holidays. For Kanako, accepting gifts was part of maximizing her earnings.
 One married customer took Kanako out to buy a Chanel bag and to dinner at a nice restaurant. Then he told her that he had made a hotel reservation for the two of them. 
"His wife was due to deliver their baby in a week," she said. "Can you believe this guy, going on dates with girls while his wife is pregnant and has to stay home? I got mad, and asked him, 'Is that why you bought me these things, because you want to sleep with me?' He said, 'No, that wasn't the case,' and apologized. I got in a taxi and went home to Queens."
This spring, Kanako stopped working as a hostess. She had begun seeing a young Japanese man who said he would leave her if she didn't quit. "I preferred being poor with him to being rich without him," she said.
Hostesses who live in Manhattan find it harder to dodge customers' advances. The more aggressive men find out where they live and then drop by their apartments on the pretext of walking a dog or doing an errand. Some even note whether a hostess appears to be home. If her light is on but she doesn't pick up the phone, he will confront her the next time he comes to the club.
Ms. Karasawa, however, never entertains after-hours invitations. More experienced than the younger hostesses, she simply tells her customers that she does not want to see them outside the club.
Still, she understands the paradox of being a hostess in New York: it's her job to soothe away the tensions of life in a foreign land for men whose safety net is much wider than her own.
But, she said, "When it comes right down to it, we've got to look out for ourselves."

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM; 
Wholesale Name-Dropping

BYLINE:  By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IF we baby boomers have been criticized for anything, it is our tendency to live the high life. If we can afford nice things, we buy them. Why stay at a hotel when a resort is nearby? Why watch television on a little screen? We traded our sedans for sport utility vehicles, then got rid of the first models when the luxury carmakers jumped in. Now BMW, Mercedes and even Porsche, for goodness' sake, are putting such powerful engines into their sport utility vehicles that drivers can have it all -- an S.U.V. that is also a sports car. Did they do that just for us?
 So it is surprising that in other ways, we are edging in a direction that seems appropriate for our more practical parents. Even before the stock market began its plunge, we were becoming a generation of warehouse-club shoppers. Suddenly, price does matter, and, more surprising, we're bragging about it. 
 "It is a relatively new societal phenomenon," said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Trend Report in Upper Montclair, N.J. "People used to wow you about how much they paid for something. Today they impress you by telling you how much money they saved."
When I was a kid, my parents shopped at a warehouse-type store called Railroad Salvage, where, as I remember, the merchandise had that fell-out-of-a-boxcar look. Now the wholesale clubs are luring us not only with lower prices, but also with more high-end products. At dinner parties, I used to see shopping bags from Fresh Fields and Hay Day, the luxury grocers, in the hosts' kitchens. Now the food is coming from warehouse chains like BJ's Wholesale Club and Sam's Club, where customers buy in bulk at lower prices. "Before, I'd hire a caterer when I'd have a party," one woman told me. "Now, I go to Costco."
When retail sales rose in June, the gain was led by discounters like Wal-Mart Stores, which runs Sam's Club, and by Costco Wholesale.
Mr. Barnard, who has seen Rolls-Royces in parking lots of warehouse stores ("It wasn't the chauffeurs who were shopping"), said boomers are the majority of customers.
Jim Hebert, president of Hebert Research in Bellevue, Wash., said the average Costco member is 48 and has a median annual income of about $74,000. Slightly more than half the members are baby boomers, he added. One explanation, beyond the quest for name-brand goods at low prices, is that boomers are raising families and have homes with enough room to store all the purchases.
"Costco is pretty typical baby-boomer demographics," Mr. Hebert said. "With the concept of buying in bulk, you have to have a house big enough to hold the bulk. It's sort of good for good-size families who have an extra freezer so they can buy things and store them. Baby boomers are the ones with the bigger families and living in the suburbs."
Greg F. Young, 46, a certified financial planner in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., who has two teenagers, said it was easy to get carried away at these places. "I've gone there to return something and spent $150," he said. "You see everything you need and it's in large quantities. You just know you're getting a better deal than at the supermarket, so you end up eating the same cereal for three months."
Two other Costco shoppers are Homa Sabet Tavangar, 36, an international business consultant, and her husband, Alex, 45, an engineer, of Berwyn, Pa. They also have two children.
"It used to be embarrassing saying you got something from there, but it's not embarrassing anymore," she said. "Now you show off what you bought."
Mr. Hebert called the trend the "Costco delight."
Richard A. Galanti, chief financial officer of Costco, said it was the "bragging rights" of finding good deals.
"Not only did they find it at Costco," he said, referring to products like Prada handbags and fancy wines, "but they're saying, 'Look at the price of this thing.' "
Mr. Barnard said that even the wealthiest people now think that it is stylish to save. "Regardless of what your economic status may be, you are forced to recognize that if you pay more, you're a bloody fool," he said. "That is essentially the secret that is driving such companies as Wal-Mart, Target and dollar-type stores.
"The discount store is something you would creep into in the middle of the night," he added. "But now it is wholeheartedly embraced. Nobody likes to be taken for a ride, especially the boomers."
MY wife, Christine, regularly chides me about filling up the basement with my warehouse purchases. "Do we really need 20 bottles of apple juice?" she asks. She has given me one wall of the basement to stack my hoard and dares me to step beyond that.
One morning, I was able to fight back after I caught her staring at me.
"What?" I said.
"You look very handsome today," she said, as if that were a rare event. She continued to study me. "Oh, it's the shirt. It's new. It looks great on you. Where did you get it?"
This was going to be fun. "Costco," I said, giving her my best Brad Pitt smile. "$14.99."
I should have told her that I had two more cases of them in the basement.
