HEADLINE: A Summary of the Major Actions of the Legislature's 225th Session 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. and RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY 

 BODY:
The 225th annual session of the New York State Legislature dragged quietly to a tentative close on July 2, after six months of partisan posturing and wrangling and very little real action.
 Time and again, Gov. George E. Pataki, the Republicans who control the Senate and the Democratic leaders of the Assembly appeared to make progress toward major deals, only to see them fall apart in waves of recrimination. It was, by all accounts, one of the most gridlocked years in memory, a sharp departure from the axiom that Albany finds a way to do business in even-numbered years, when officials must stand for re-election. 
 Even the end of the session was not agreed on, having become, like so many things about state government, something of a fiction. The session was scheduled to end on June 20, but trickled on, as each house found reasons to return a few times -- the last a session of the Senate on July 2 to pass a handful of bills -- and each has signaled that it might come back this year, if deals can be reached on major legislation. 
The biggest agreements of the year included giving Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg far greater control of New York City's schools, a big increase in health care spending despite a looming fiscal crisis, and, after two years of bitter conflict, a package of women's health care measures, including requiring insurers to cover contraceptives.
Chief among the long list of failures was the inability of lawmakers to agree on revamping the state's system of long mandatory sentences for drug crimes, enacted three decades ago under Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller.
High hopes were also dashed for legislation to reduce rising auto-insurance premiums and insurance fraud, a package of antiterrorism bills championed by the governor, a bill to raise the minimum wage, an overhaul of the state's toxic-waste-cleanup program, a statewide ban on smoking in restaurants and a law to prevent discrimination against gays. A requirement that clergy members report abuse of children to the authorities, agreed on in principle by all sides, appeared to run aground on what seemed like a simple language problem.
The session began with a deal between Mr. Pataki, a Republican who is running for a third term, and Dennis Rivera, a high-ranking Democrat and the leader of the largest health workers' union in the state, for $1.8 billion in new health care spending over the next three years. About half of that money will go toward pay raises for members of Mr. Rivera's union, 1199/S.E.I.U.
Despite questions about the fiscal soundness of the deal, it sailed through the Legislature in January, and the union repaid Mr. Pataki by endorsing him for re-election.
There were 745 bills that passed in both the Assembly and the Senate, most of them addressing narrow local issues like property transfers. Of those, Mr. Pataki has signed 198 into law and vetoed 2, but most have not yet been delivered to his desk.

Budget
LEGISLATION ENACTED
Lawmakers passed an $89.6 billion election-year budget on May 17, relatively early, given the recent history of late budgets and legislative gridlock in Albany.
While other states around the country were cutting spending, New York managed to avoid deep cuts to services and even provided a $420 million increase in education aid, about 3 percent.
The budget includes $3 billion in one-time revenues, however. It also relies heavily on uncertain new federal aid, spends nearly all of the state's reserves, and adds $900 million in debt.
All told, the budget raises spending by about 6 percent, though the portion paid entirely with state taxes and fees will go up only 3 percent. 
The Legislature imposed some new taxes and raised a number of obscure fees on items like hunting licenses to bring in about $85 million more.
The budget also counts on reducing the state work force by at least 5,000, through incentives for early retirement and a hiring freeze. 
The governor and lawmakers also agreed to shift many costs now borne by the state to the federal government through some unorthodox accounting. College scholarships, for instance, will be financed with $380 million from a surplus of federal welfare money, while special funds for the environment and health care were used to provide $400 million to help balance the budget.
New York City's schools got a one-time infusion of about $200 million -- actually money the state had owed the city for years for school construction -- to help Mr. Bloomberg pay for a new contract with city teachers.

Crime and Justice
AWAITING SIGNATURE OR VETO
Would make it a felony to commit identity theft -- the unauthorized use of someone else's name, address, driver's license number, Social Security number, credit card numbers or A.T.M. codes. 
Would require fingerprinting of employees of the financial exchanges.
Would require people designated as violent sexual predators to provide the addresses of their workplaces to the State Division of Criminal Justice Services.

LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have eased the Rockefeller-era drug law penalties, and made drug treatment available more often as an alternative to prison.
Would have abolished discretionary parole for all felons.
Would have prohibited public access to any state documents compiled as part of an investigation into terrorism.
Would have made it a felony, punishable by life in prison, to possess chemical or biological weapons.
Would have allowed wiretaps on individuals, regardless of the phones they used, rather than wiretaps only on particular phone lines.
Would have required that a member of the clergy who becomes aware of the sexual abuse of a minor report it to law enforcement officials.
Would have given the state attorney general power to investigate and prosecute abuses in homes for the mentally ill.
Would have prohibited any district attorney from prosecuting a case unless at least a part of the crime took place in that district attorney's county.

Business and Labor
AWAITING SIGNATURE OR VETO
Would prohibit employers who receive state money from spending that money to combat union organizing of their workers.
Would require employers to accommodate workers' observances of religious holidays, when practical.
Would allow domestic partners and other dependents to collect on life insurance policies provided by employers.
Would make medical residents and interns at hospitals eligible for unemployment insurance if dismissed.
Would enact the presumption that any lung diseases resulting in the disability or death of paid firefighters were incurred in the line of duty.
Would lower to 65 from 70 the age at which retirees can re-enter public employment without any earnings limit and without losing retirement benefits.

Would impose liability on employers who fire or discriminate against employees for displaying the American flag.

LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have banned smoking in restaurants, except in restaurant bars that are physically separated from the dining room or in separately ventilated smoking rooms.
Would have raised the minimum wage to $6.75 an hour, from $5.15, by January 2004.

Taxes

HEADLINE: Business Ethics Issue Contrasts Candidates' Styles: Aggressive, Measured and Steadfast 

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
Last week, as corporate chieftains were arrested and the stock market churned, Andrew M. Cuomo invited reporters to a Midtown Manhattan hotel ballroom stocked with his supporters and delivered a formal half-hour speech based on a four-page proposal on corporate ethics. It was a kickoff to a four-city tour by Mr. Cuomo with appearances by laid-off employees whose savings have evaporated. 
 His opponent in the race to become the Democratic nominee for governor, H. Carl McCall, responded with an e-mail message touting his record as a "national leader protecting shareholders." 
 And Gov. George E. Pataki, the Republican who is seeking a third term, ate sausage and peppers at country fairs.
The different approaches to the topic, arguably the most compelling of the week, illustrate the very different personal styles and campaign strategies of the top contenders in the governor's race. There is Mr. Cuomo, the former United States housing secretary whose try-anything aggressiveness has sometimes been viewed as arrogant; Mr. McCall, the state comptroller whose measured movements have been taken for complacency; and Governor Pataki, an incumbent whose popularity and fund-raising success have allowed him to float above the fray.
While national politicians are busy devising ways to approach the Wall Street scandals as a campaign issue, it is in some ways odd for candidates in local races to weigh in. But New York is home to the stock market and many corporate headquarters, and candidates routinely travel to Ireland or Israel to expound upon issues way beyond their influence and day-to-day concern.
Mr. Cuomo's tour came as Congress agreed to toughen federal law. But he has vociferously argued that it is well within the scope of the governor to ensure the credibility of corporate books, if only because the issue affects jobs in the state. He released a report that concluded that 1,795 jobs in the state were lost as a result of scandals at six companies. If nothing else, the governor could use his bully pulpit to endorse change, said a spokesman for Mr. Cuomo, Peter Ragone, just as Mr. Pataki has spoken out against the Navy bombing in Vieques, P.R., and a recent court decision barring the Pledge of Allegiance from schools.
On Friday, asked what he had done to rein in corporate misdeeds, Mr. Pataki responded by praising federal prosecutors and Congress. "I think it's important that we have a strong federal law," he said.
On the other hand, Mr. McCall can, unlike his opponents, point to concrete steps he has taken to rein in abuse. He has led several shareholder suits against major companies accused of fraud, and early this month, he announced that money managers and accounting firms that do business with the state pension fund would have to adhere to stricter standards.
A spokesman for Mr. McCall, Steven Greenberg, seemed confident that voters were familiar with that record. "Corporate accountability is part of our economic message, and it's part of who Carl McCall is," Mr. Greenberg said. "His whole life is based on accountability and responsibility -- that's what his mother taught him." 
But Mr. McCall's record did not deter Mr. Cuomo. "Cuomo's nature is to seize the initiative, sometimes to his own disadvantage, and McCall's nature is to measure the situation and produce what he feels is a reasoned response," said Philip Friedman, a Democratic political and corporate consultant who is not involved with any candidate in this race. But, he added, "The odds are that neither strategy would be enough to unseat Pataki."
Mr. Cuomo's offensive is one of a string of attempts to find something he or Mr. McCall could sorely use: an issue that ignites voter enthusiasm or, better yet, pulls the governor off his cloud. 
So far, the candidates have tried to raise alarms about government spending, campaign finance, nursing homes, a possible subway fare increase and prescription drug prices. But voters are paying little attention, political analysts say, possibly because they are preoccupied with national issues like terrorism and economic security. And the salvo that drew the biggest reaction, Mr. Cuomo's attack on the governor for failing to lead after the Sept. 11 attack, backfired.
But Mr. Cuomo might have the advantage when it comes to the Wall Street scandals, said Jefrey Pollock, the president of Global Strategy Group, a Democratic polling firm. "You've got, clearly, a Republican governor who has benefited tremendously from the increase in the stock market and the boom economy, who also wants to play footsie with the folks in the White House. You've got Carl McCall boxed in, because he invested in a lot of these things. Andrew is the one who's probably boxed in the least." 
As state comptroller, Mr. McCall invests the $112 billion state pension fund, which has lost millions on stocks like WorldCom and Global Crossing. But Mr. McCall has said that it has still outperformed similar funds, and some analysts said they doubted the public would fault him for investing in some of the country's biggest companies. 
Norman Adler, a longtime political consultant, said it was not unwise for Mr. McCall to stick to issues that appeal to his core constituency, like education, as he did on Wednesday in front of a Manhattan school, while Mr. Cuomo pushed his corporate reform message upstate. 
But if Mr. Cuomo did not dominate the debate, then at least he nudged it. When Mr. McCall finished a speech on the inequity of state education funding, he was met with an awkward silence. Reporters had no questions about education. 
"You see," Mr. McCall crowed. "We've gotten our message across." 
Then someone asked about corporate accountability.

PERSON: Pete Seibert 

HEADLINE: Pete Seibert, Soldier Skier Who Built Vail, Is Dead at 77 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Pete Seibert, who transformed a sheep pasture in the Colorado Rockies into the Vail ski resort, died July 15 at his home in Edwards, Colo. He was 77.
 The cause was cancer, said Jennifer Brown, a spokeswoman for Vail Resorts. 
 In 2000, Ski magazine placed Mr. Seibert third on its list of history's 100 most influential skiers for building one of the first and largest of the new breed of postwar American ski resorts, with all the amenities of European skiing villages. 
Mr. Seibert's early inspiration came from pictures he saw of an idyllic Austrian ski resort when he was 10, Skiing magazine reported in 1999. He had already been skiing for three years on a pair of his mother's wooden skis.
Mr. Seibert served as a combat soldier on skis in World War II and was wounded so badly that doctors said he might never walk again, let alone ski. Three years later, he placed third in the giant slalom at the United States Nationals.
On March 19, 1957, he saw a skier's promised land when Earl Eaton, a sometime uranium prospector, took him on a seven-hour climb through deep snow to the summit of a mountain whose bulk had not been visible from the valley below.
Mr. Seibert was awed. It was an almost perfect hill, with slopes all around that permitted skiing in all directions, at different degrees of steepness; skiers of almost any level would be able to get down safely. The peak was 3,000 feet above a valley that seemed perfect for a ski village. At an elevation of 8,000 feet above sea level, the valley was just below the timberline, so the trees minimized the problem of high winds.
"My God, Earl, we've climbed all the way to heaven," Mr. Seibert said, according to articles in Denver newspapers over the years.
Mr. Seibert gave Mr. Eaton credit for finding Vail, which Mr. Seibert named for Charles Vail, chief engineer of the Colorado highway department from 1930 to 1945.
But most people give Mr. Seibert credit for the next critical steps. He secretly bought the land, telling anyone who asked that he was building a rod and gun club. He found people willing to invest in the still-unproven postwar ski industry. He organized construction and found a gondola lift in the Alps. 
Scant snow was on the ground when the resort opened in December 1962, so he hired Ute Indians to perform a snow dance. A blizzard materialized.
"Everybody else thought we were crazy, but we thought we could do any damned thing we decided to do," Mr. Seibert said in an interview with Sports Illustrated in 1989.
The result, with bed, board and bars close at hand, established a style that has since become familiar at American ski resorts.
It happened fast. In 1964, Sports Illustrated reported that "never in the history of U.S. skiing has a bare mountain leaped in such a short time into the four-star category of ski resorts."
Peter Werner Seibert was born on Aug. 7, 1924, in Sharon, Mass. He spent much of his youth in the White Mountains of New Hampshire, where he practiced with Austrian instructors who had left Europe as war seemed imminent. By 15, he was winning races.
In 1943, Mr. Seibert, then 18, joined the Army and volunteered for the 10th Mountain Division. In 1945, he saw combat in the Apennine Mountains of northern Italy, where he was hit by small-arms fire and two mortar shells, one of which blew off his right kneecap. He spent 17 months undergoing surgery and convalescing.
With the dream of starting a ski resort, Mr. Seibert headed for Colorado. Other members of the 10th Mountain Division did the same thing, forming the nucleus of the postwar skiing industry.
Though Mr. Seibert had to tape himself from his hip to his ankle and strap on a homemade leg brace, his skiing progressed to the point that he qualified for the 1950 United States Alpine ski team. But he wanted to get into the resort business, and he used the G.I. Bill to study hotel management at a school in Switzerland from 1951 to 1954.
He returned to Colorado to take a job with the Aspen Ski School and in 1955 became manager of the Loveland Ski Area. After three years, he moved back to Aspen as assistant manager of the Aspen Highlands resort. After discovering what would become Vail Mountain in 1957, he devoted himself to his dream. With the help of a small group of partners, he paid $55,000 for 520 acres.
The land was in the White River National Forest, and the Forest Service required him to come up with $1.8 million by December 1961 to cover construction costs. He decided that each investor of $10,000 would get four free lifetime lift passes. For $500 more, investors would get land for a home site.
The lots are now worth millions.
Mr. Seibert never realized a fortune from Vail. In March 1976, a frayed cable caused two gondolas carrying skiers up the mountain to plunge 125 feet to the ground. Four were killed and eight injured. Fearing lawsuits, Mr. Seibert sold his stake in Vail.
He later put together the group that developed Snow Basin, a ski resort in Utah. A cash squeeze resulting from a recession forced him to sell again. After working on several other ski developments, he returned to Vail as a consultant.
Mr. Seibert was president of the American Ski Federation and the National Ski Areas Association, and was inducted into the United States National Ski Hall of Fame. 
He is survived by his sons, Peter Werner Seibert Jr. of Edwards, Brant Albert Seibert of Boulder, Colo., and Calvin Pardee of Manhattan.
As recently as last March, Mr. Seibert was poking around Colorado, looking for another mountain to develop.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pete Seibert in Vail, Colo., in 1962, the year the ski resort opened. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Wall Street Waves Are a Riptide to Some, a Ripple to Others 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS and SUSAN SACHS 

 BODY:
They winced in affluent Westchester, they shrugged on 125th Street in Harlem, and in suburban New Jersey they headed for the mall, though with a slight buzz of unease and a keen eye for bargains.
 As the stock market whipsawed through a week of numbing losses, followed by a roaring one-day gain after two months of prolonged bleeding, the pain emanating from Wall Street has hit people in the New York City region in varying but distinct ways. 
 In Katonah, N.Y., a hamlet in northern Westchester County, investors bemoaned their losses and continued shifting their money into real estate. The well-to-do, however, kept on spending. On the streets of Harlem, there was mostly cynicism and ambivalence toward the turbulence of a distant world. And in Wayne, N.J., a citadel of middle-class comfort, many people said they had been bruised by the market but were more fearful that the continuing slump would choke the prosperity of recent years. 
Many of the more than three dozen people who were interviewed in three very different communities last week said they were largely removed from the Dow's wild ride and expected few immediate changes in their spending or style of living. But from the streets of upper Manhattan to the boutiques of Katonah, nearly everyone expressed a growing unease, even outright panic, about what lay ahead. Even those without stock portfolios said they worried about what the market's ugly gyrations could mean for their lives.
The pain is not just on paper for those approaching retirement, no matter what their financial status. Many people in their 50's and 60's said they no longer open their 401 (k) statements; others have decided to keep working for a year or two longer than they had expected. "I know things could change, but if they keep going this way, we'll be eating cat food in our golden years," said Jane Perkinson, 61, a production manager at Business Week, as she strolled along Katonah Avenue, a street lined with designer gift shops and real estate companies with pictures in their windows of the million-dollar homes they are selling.
Across the region, there was little optimism that the markets or the economy would improve anytime soon. For many, like Susan Broer, 46, the mad plunges of July became too much to bear. Last week, said Ms. Broer, an administrator at Manhattanville College, she moved her entire savings out of stocks and into bonds. "It might be too little too late," said Ms. Broer, who lives in Somers, near Katonah, "but I just didn't have the guts to sit there and watch anymore." 
While outsiders might imagine the village unruffled by the recent tumult on Wall Street, Katonah is not a solid bloc of extravagant wealth. Plenty of teachers, therapists and artists moved here before the boom of the 1980's, when quaint Katonah, an hour from Midtown, began drawing a more upscale crowd. There are old-timers, too, like Margaret Van Geldern, 43, a stay-at-home mother whose family occupies the Victorian house built by her great-grandfather. By most measures, the family has experienced little financial strain: they never played the stock market, their mortgage is nearly paid off, and Mr. Van Geldern, a construction manager, is still busy building $2 million homes throughout the county. But Ms. Van Geldern, whose teenage daughter is starting to look at colleges, knows how fickle the housing market is, and next year, she plans to go back to work. "My daughter wants to go to a good school," she said. "If people stop buying luxury homes, we're going to be in trouble."
That trouble has already arrived for many. Peter Vadnai, a freelance photographer who moved to Katonah three decades ago, discovered the lure of online stock trading in 1997. Most of his savings vanished with the pop of the dot-com bubble, and these days, Mr. Vadnai, 58, rarely turns on CNBC. "I guess as long as you don't bail out, you have a chance," he said hopefully, sitting at the Katonah Restaurant. "I just don't know if they'll come back in my lifetime."
It's not just the ailing stock market that plagues him. His livelihood, the commercial photography business, is sputtering, and he openly frets about the effect of terrorism on an already fragile economy. "All it takes is one person to blow himself up at a mall in Dubuque," he said, "and everyone will stop shopping at malls." 
Still, neither terrorism nor the dropping Dow seems likely to stop the rich from spending. The Saab dealership on Bedford Road continues to thrive, and Bob Menin, a veteran real estate agent, said home sales remained brisk, though prices have begun leveling off after tripling in the 1990's. He said many clients were planning to invest in multifamily homes or condominiums.
A few doors down at the Katonah General Store, June Goldfinger has had no trouble selling the $3,800 cashmere bathrobes and $5,000 silk dresses she designs. Like many of her customers and friends, she puts her extra cash into property, not stocks. Besides extensive holdings in Katonah, she said, she and her husband own real estate in Santa Fe, N.M., Manhattan and the Caribbean island of Anguilla. "I cater to the rich and the filthy rich," she said, showing off a $600 leather handbag. "They feel badly about what's happening to other people, but they're not feeling the pinch themselves."
The same might be said of Harlem, where declining blue chips are of little concern to many residents. People there are worried about getting a job, getting by and getting a good education for their children. A question about the market, in fact, usually brings a wry laugh. "On this side of 110th Street, we don't think of these things affecting us," said Kimathi Arnold, 32, as he walked home from work with a friend. "Our net worth is based on what we make. We don't have assets in the stock market, and the cynicism we have is learned through experience."
Mr. Arnold has an online trading account, but he said he had never used it. "I don't see the market as being a friendly place," he said, "especially if the money you lose means you don't put food on the table or have a place to live."
His friend, Jamal Goodridge, 28, said he kept his savings in bank certificates of deposit.
Both men work at Global Business Institutes, a private technical school where they counsel students. Many people they see have been struggling since Sept. 11, either because they lost jobs or family members did.
"After 9/11, no one has money to lose." Mr. Goodridge said.
Both men worry about the trickle-down effect from the difficulties on Wall Street. "The stock market is an indicator of how different sectors of the economy are doing, and if there's no confidence in the economy and corporations are going bankrupt at an alarming rate, then it makes a difference," Mr. Arnold said. "Honest hardworking Americans were told those 401 (k)s were going to be a revolution in how your money can grow. To us regular people, the stock market is something we are affected by but have no control over."
At Benjamin Optical, on 125th Street, business has been steady and good for the last few months. A stock market shiver, said a co-owner, Joel Minsky, does not show up right away and maybe not at all. "It hasn't affected the way anybody here behaves," said Dr. Minsky, 53, an optometrist who is carrying on a business his father founded 50 years ago. "It hasn't changed my thinking or planning for the future, either. I'm expecting it to turn around." He said he stayed away from stocks, and when it comes time to retire, he and his wife will draw on an I.R.A. and his wife's pension. "I'm 53 and I figure I'll work another 20 years," he said. "My father is still working and he's 84."
Across the Hudson River, in a middle-class swath of northeast New Jersey where many people try to live within their means, the last decade seemed to lift everyone's boat more or less equally. Jobs were plentiful and even blue-collar workers learned to embrace the market.
A soaring Nasdaq helped Allan Thiel buy a Harley-Davidson, but last Thursday, he and his wife, Rosemary, were prowling the Willowbrook Mall in Wayne trying to avoid pricier enticements like Abercrombie & Fitch and Banana Republic. 
Mr. Thiel said he had been an avid stock trader but now curses high-tech names like Lucent and Cisco, which make up the bulk of his portfolio. "I've been so depressed about the market," said Mr. Thiel, 54, who installs heating systems. "I don't watch TV anymore. I'm sick of those red arrows pointing down." 
Ms. Thiel lost her job recently with Omnipoint, but Mr. Thiel's business remains strong. Still, for now, the couple said they would stick to shopping at Sears and avoid using their credit cards. "We'll probably be fine if we're careful," Ms. Thiel said. "But what about our children's future? That's what I worry about."
Joan Danner, too, once enjoyed the fruits of a thriving stock market, which helped pay for her daughter's wedding and a big-screen TV. With the market gone bad, Ms. Danner, a receptionist, has given up the extras. She is increasingly anxious that the shrinking pot in her I.R.A. account will stall her retirement. "At this rate, we'll have nothing in a few months," said Ms. Danner, 54, as she scanned the aisles at Sears for summer clearance sales. 
Her husband recently lost his job as an insurance underwriter but found another one, although at a lower salary. Her own job, she added, is far from ironclad. Beyond an early retirement, other dreams, like a renovated bathroom in their home in Fairfield, will have to be deferred. "It's been harvest gold since the 70's," she said with a laugh. "But that will have to wait. For now, we're going to live day to day."

"I cater to the rich and the filthy rich," she said. (James Estrin/The New York Times); (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)(pg. 26)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Minor Leagues Hit the Mark

BYLINE:  By BILL PENNINGTON 

DATELINE: BROCKTON, Mass. 

 BODY:
It is Saturday night in this hardscrabble city of idle shoemaking factories, and the place is jumping.
 Just past empty storefronts in Brockton's downtown 15 miles south of Boston, a crowd of nearly 5,000 has packed a new $17 million minor league baseball stadium to watch the Rocks, the home team named after the former heavyweight champion and Brockton native Rocky Marciano. 
 The upper grandstand, where seats cost $4, is jammed with families giggling at festivities that include a fan race against a large rock deposited in the basepaths (the rock has not won this season), a water balloon-tossing contest and a shirtless boxer who jukes and jabs his way through the stands, pausing only to deliver bouquets of flowers to women. Fans clutch commemorative Marciano bobblehead dolls, a promotional handout, and children's groups abound. Just the night before, local Girl Scout troops had camped in the outfield after the game. 
There was also a minor league baseball game going on, but like the drive-in, the mall or the bowling alley before it, the stadium and its game were only the pretext for a community gathering. On the field, the Rocks, also known as the Rox, were losing. In the stands, the score was registered in smiles. And the home team was winning in a rout.
This summer, it is likely that more people than ever before -- perhaps as many as 40 million -- will flock to small ballparks to watch minor league baseball games in North America. That's more than half the number that will attend major league games this season.
Affordable, family-friendly and a spiritual touchstone to small-town America, minor league baseball is enjoying an unprecedented boom. Not only has attendance approached record highs established in pretelevision days, but an astonishing number of new ballparks -- frequently publicly financed -- have also sprouted in every region of the country. Since 1995, 78 minor league parks have been completed in the United States, and 2 in Canada.
As Major League Baseball grapples with economic problems, a deteriorating image and a possible players' strike, minor league baseball is a phenomenon of fun where a family of four can attend a game for less than $40, food, drinks and parking included, and the children will probably come away with a player's autograph, too.
"People never gave up on a night at the ballpark; they were just starving to feel the connection," said Dave Echols, general manager of the Brockton franchise. "We give them a game they can almost touch, and a good time, too."
Expansion and unparalleled growth have come with consequential change. Minor league baseball has become big business, with franchises selling for as much as $25 million. The mom-and-pop operators once typical in the minor leagues, whose job it was to rake the pitcher's mound and flip the burgers in the concession stand, have increasingly given way to corporate ownership groups with sophisticated financing schemes and multimillion-dollar budgets.
Debt among minor league owners has doubled in the last five years, according to industry officials, and has led to questions about the long-term financial health of some franchises even as more cities continue to pursue minor league fields of dreams. It is estimated that as many as a third of the roughly 200 minor league teams are not profitable. Last year, the Portland Beavers in Oregon, whose stadium got a $38 million face-lift, had about $10 million in operating losses.
It is also possible that financially troubled Major League Baseball, which pays for the salaries, health insurance and equipment for all the players and coaches on the 160 minor league teams affiliated with big-league franchises, may decide to reduce that subsidy when its contract with those teams comes up for renewal in two years. That could have a devastating effect on the budgets of many minor league teams.
For now, though, there is no stopping minor league baseball's booming place in North America's sports culture. From Aberdeen, Md., to Edmonton, Alberta, teams are playing in bustling parks. The core appeal? Minor league baseball is successfully marketing fun.
And while that is a nostalgic notion, it is revealing that the selling is being done in an altogether different, and modern, way. Because going to a minor league game is anything but an old-fashioned trip to that dusty old ballpark downtown.

Tradition Takes a Back Seat
Nowhere is the shifting face of the minor league baseball industry more evident than 150 miles west of Brockton in the Berkshire Mountains of western Massachusetts, where the city of Pittsfield has had a minor league baseball team off and on for a century. Since 1919, Pittsfield's Wahconah Park has played host to those games, making it one of a handful of ballparks, including Wrigley Field and Fenway Park, dating from that era.
Lou Gehrig and others of his era played at Wahconah and they would recognize it still, from the wooden grandstand to the wooden rafters from which hang wooden owls, whose presence discourages pigeons from nesting and eventually soiling the clothes of patrons seated in the wooden benches below. With tiny locker rooms, dugouts and concession stands, Wahconah is ancient and charming, almost museum-like.
Built before baseball was played at night, Wahconah was laid out so that the batter faces west, not east, as is customary in most modern parks. This can lead to a blazing sun shining directly into batters' eyes from beyond the center-field fence, and yields the most peculiar Wahconah feature: games interrupted by a sun delay.
For years, players in Pittsfield tried to embrace the Wahconah charm and endure the lack of amenities. Along the way, Pittsfield's civic leaders declined to replace the stadium. As recently as the 2000 season, the Mets' Class A farm team in the New York-Penn League called Wahconah Park home. Then the Mets decided they would be better off in the $39 million KeySpan Park in Coney Island.
A Class A affiliate of the Houston Astros took the Mets' place in Pittsfield, but the team announced last year that it was leaving for a $14 million, state-financed ballpark in Troy, N.Y.
When the Astros' departure was made final, an offer was made to move another New York-Penn League team, the Utica Blue Sox, to Pittsfield -- provided a plan for a new stadium was approved. But voters in Pittsfield overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to create a civic authority that would have built a new park; the Blue Sox headed to Aberdeen, Md., where they moved into the $22 million Ripken Stadium.
"Pittsfield has so many other fish to fry," said the city's first-year mayor, Sara Hathaway, who campaigned against a new stadium. The city had an $8 million deficit last year. "There are some morale issues in Pittsfield and some of that is because there isn't a new stadium," she said. "But I don't spend a lot of time worrying about it."
Pittsfield's Astros team is averaging more than 3,000 fans this summer in Troy's Joseph L. Bruno Stadium, named for the majority leader of the New York State Senate, who was instrumental in securing the state construction money. It has wide concourses, picnic grounds, rows of concession booths, a year-round merchandise store, major league-quality dugouts and locker rooms, a state-of-the-art underground hitting and pitching tunnel, and a video scoreboard capable of showing replays.
The stadium, known as the Joe, also has 10 mezzanine-level luxury boxes, which are sold out for the next three years, at $15,000 annually for 38 home games.
Meanwhile, an unaffiliated independent league team -- the same league Brockton plays in -- has taken up residence in Pittsfield, but attendance for the team, the Berkshire Black Bears, is roughly a third of what the Astros draw in Troy. At Wahconah, there have been minor renovations, including a luxury box of sorts: two wicker chairs, a wicker table and an area rug off the main aisle behind home plate.
"We still have a great baseball tradition here," Hathaway said. "There's still nothing wrong with an afternoon at Wahconah Park with the family."
Which is undoubtedly true, but increasingly, cities like Pittsfield, which were staples of minor league baseball for decades, are falling out of the loop. A trend toward newer, more profitable stadiums -- and frequently more affluent markets -- that began in the mid-1980's has become a gold rush.
Whether it is Lexington, Ky., Lansing, Mich., or Lowell, Mass., minor league baseball has moved to places where families with the most disposable income reside within easy driving distance. Success has been written in teeming grandstands. Lexington, a Class A team, set a South Atlantic League record by operating 4 percent above the stadium's 6,033-seat capacity. Lansing established a national Class A attendance record. At Lowell, where every game has been a sellout since 1999, standing-room-only tickets go on sale 10 hours before game time, and there is frequently a line.
In 1983, the city of New Britain, Conn., built a new stadium to lure a minor league team from nearby Bristol. In 1996, a bigger and more plush stadium -- with luxury boxes, souvenir store, picnic grounds and a rooftop sports bar -- rose next to the existing stadium, which was only 13 years old.
So New Britain, which has lost most of the manufacturing plants that built its reputation as the Hardware City, now has two minor league ballparks. The older stadium is used primarily for amateur tournaments. The new stadium is setting attendance records.

A Quality-of-Life Issue
The notion that a new stadium can act as an engine for economic development has been debunked by a paper trail of academic research longer than 73 Barry Bonds home runs measured end to end. Economists studying the effect of new major league and minor league ballparks have almost universally concluded that such projects -- with some exceptions -- offer very little tangible economic return for the taxpayers' dollar.
"They don't feed any positive economic growth or impact," said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College, who has written extensively on the subject. "It won't produce a huge per capita increase or mean many more jobs. People don't travel great distances to see these teams. It is revenue recirculated in the community. They spent it at the minor league ballpark instead of the cineplex."
Zimbalist and other economists agree on the likely exceptions: cities where the ballpark is but one piece of an extensive urban-renewal effort with goals more far-reaching than providing sporting entertainment.
"If it's part of a long-term project, a stadium might improve the gestalt of a downtown," Zimbalist said.
To those in the minor league baseball industry, that is precisely the point -- it is all about the feel-good effects. In Brockton, city leaders point to the brightly lighted, packed baseball stadium as proof of what's new in a city once viewed as drab and aging. Waterfront development, much of it initiated by a new minor league ballpark, has transformed the aura of the downtowns in Trenton and in Bridgeport, Conn.
Marvin Goldklang, who heads a group that owns five minor league teams and is a consultant to two others, conceded that the economic benefit of a baseball franchise is hard to quantify.
"But it is real," Goldklang said. "Just open the local chamber of commerce's pitch book. We're on the first few pages. For a small- or medium-sized city or region, a minor league team is more central to attracting new industries to the area than at the major league level."
In Troy, Bruno justifies the $14 million spent on the Joe in similar terms. "It's a place where people come together and enjoy themselves," he said. "We've directed a lot of money into the arts in the capital region over the years. Why? For the same reasons. It's a quality-of-life issue."
This is a message not lost on economists, at least when discussing minor league baseball.
"If you believe in the power of minor league baseball," Zimbalist said, "it doesn't matter if it raises income levels and creates jobs. The American culture does love baseball; it's good, wholesome entertainment. That's how it should be evaluated."
At the River Dogs' games in Charleston, S.C., there is a concierge booth, where fans can make their postgame dinner reservations. The River Dogs have also held a women's night at the ballpark, when men were turned away at the gate. The game sold out. The River Dogs also played host to something called Nobody Night.
Before their July 7 game with the Columbus (Ga.) Red Stixx at Joseph P. Riley Jr. Park -- another place nicknamed the Joe -- the River Dogs padlocked the gates so that the official attendance would be zero. That broke the previous record for the smallest crowd at a professional baseball game, which had been 12 people for an 1881 game between Chicago and Troy.
Several thousand River Dogs fans congregated outside the ballpark July 7, some watching from the picnic grounds beyond the center-field wall. After the fifth inning, when the game became official, the gates were opened and fans streamed in to find candy and T-shirts (not to mention unclaimed foul balls) awaiting them in the empty seats.
The River Dogs' president is Mike Veeck, son of the legendary baseball owner and promotional wizard Bill Veeck. The father sent a midget, Eddie Gaedel, up to bat as a way to draw attention to his lowly St. Louis Browns in 1951; the son came up with Nobody Night, as well Lawyer Appreciation Night, when each attending lawyer was charged twice the ticket price and billed again every half inning. Proceeds went to Legal Aid.

'Homespun Family Entertainment'
At the River Dogs' games, as at nearly every minor league park these days, there is continual between-inning entertainment: sumo wrestlers, dance contests, mascot races, pie-eating contests. 
"We're selling homespun family entertainment," said Bill Gladstone, who took his Astros' farm team from Pittsfield to Troy, where it became the Tri-City Valley Cats. "It's still about the game, but it's a game where the fans talk to the players and sit close enough to hear the dugout chatter."
Bill Dowling, president and principal owner of the New Britain Rock Cats, was once executive vice president of the Yankees.
"Everything about the major leagues costs so much now, and the players are perceived as greedy or unconcerned," Dowling said. "We appreciate that we have to entertain you for the $7 you paid to get in.
"So we entertain. We sell joy."
The actor Bill Murray is a part owner of a handful of minor league teams nationwide, including Brockton, where a comic's touch is evident throughout the ballpark. While most of the signs over the food service areas read "Concessions," one reads "Confessions" and another "Contentions."
Among the standard fare on the menu board is this prominently displayed item: pan-seared tuna steak, which is permanently listed as "Tomorrow's Special." 
Even the stadium public-address announcer, John Dolan, gets into the act. When a batter from the visiting Elmira Pioneers hit a home run, the buzz that had filled the ballpark came to a halt. The batter circled the bases in complete silence until he finally touched home plate, when Dolan paused and said into his microphone, "Whatever."
In minor league baseball, it is all in the program. Literally. Inside the cover of a Brockton Rox game program, there is Murray's picture and his official title with the team: director of fun.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
A Troubled Game, An Informal Poll

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM C. RHODEN 

 BODY:
THE New York Times had its baseball poll; Lou Harris has his. Late Thursday night, I decided that I would have mine: the William C. Rhoden Anonymous Informal Impromptu Attitude Survey. My survey consisted of 17 questions designed to get at an elusive, gnawing truth about why we continue to put up with baseball and its labor problems. 
 Why do we in the United States continue to maintain baseball as part of the big three bread-and-butter sports -- along with football and basketball -- when soceer is clearly a better game? I'm not a huge fan of soccer, but the game certainly points us toward our global future more than baseball, a provincial relic that becomes less relevant with each new season. Soccer's World Cup, with its concentration of internecine rivalries and strong community identification, gives truer meaning to the concept of a World Series than does baseball. 
 Still, we put up with this nonsense to feed a psychological need that has less to do with the game than with a need to cling to a rapidly fading past and hold off a menacing future. 
The game of baseball deals in nostalgia; the business of baseball counts on collective public amnesia to keep the shell game going. Most of us remember when we watched our first baseball game; few remember the vows we made only eight years ago never to watch another baseball game.
In an effort to get at the why of all this, I came up with my own poll. I distributed 50 questionnaires, most of them at Shea Stadium on Friday evening. The ages of respondents ranged from 17 to 66, and their professions ran the gamut: auto mechanics, homemakers (their word, not mine), financial analysts, investment bankers, retired schoolteachers, carpenter, community activist. Lawyers, of course. Most began watching the game around 8 years old.
My overriding interest was to see how many of these fans viewed baseball players as fellow workers. Eighty percent said they did not identify with players as fellow workers, 16 percent said they did and 4 percent had no answer. On the bottom-line issue of a strike, 90 percent of those polled said that the players should not strike, the remaining 10 percent said they should. 
Twenty-six percent of the respondents said there was no rationale for a strike. The rest were divided. Most said the players had a short athletic life and were entitled to maximize their earnings. Some said players were underpaid. Still others said workers should get what they could get.
I didn't ask for names, but Ann Cotty did not want to be anonymous. A 24-year-old graduate student from Kingston, N.Y., Cotty sat behind home plate Friday at Shea. She wrote that she had been watching baseball since she was an infant, and that her love for the game would not be affected by a strike. "But for major league baseball, respect will be lost to a large degree," she wrote.
Cotty wrote that she would come back to the ballpark if the players went on strike, adding, "But I know I will be in the minority and the tremendous salaries of the players will cost me a great deal in tickets and other parts of the ballpark."
Finally, Cotty wrote: "A strike will hurt everyone. Fans will lose the entertainment and excitement of the ball games, owners will be unable to pay even the league minimum salary when very few seats are filled in their ballparks. And don't forget the workers who make minimum wage who will be unemployed when their millionaire co-workers decide to strike." 
Cotty was the only one to sign a name, but almost everyone had additional comments.
A 52-year-old administrator, who is rarely contented on the job, was unmoved by the great amount of money players make. The administrator said that the players should strike, that they were underpaid and that pro baseball players were entitled to whatever then could extract from management.
A 49-year-old bell captain, who thought that the players should strike, saw the battle between players and owners as a classic battle between labor and management. "The management's job is to get the maximum labor from workers at the lowest cost," the bell captain wrote. "The workers must strike for maximum benefits."
A 65-year-old retiree, who said the players should strike, thought the Attitude Survey was unfair.
"This is slanted against the players," the retiree wrote. "The owners need to share revenue or keep to their budgets. Player salaries will fall in line if owners are rational."
A 24-year-old who works in the sports information department at Army said the strike was "all about greed; the owners the players, all they want is more."
What makes players different from the average worker? "They work 200 days less than the average Joe," the 24-year-old wrote.
A 44-year-old who is self-employed said that the only rationale for a strike was pride on the part of players, who, the 44-year-old wrote, were "unable to concede defeat in any way to their owners." He resents the amount of money the players make, sides with management in all labor situations and does not see players as typical workers. At the same time, he said he fantasized about being a player and had watched the game since he was 6.
Every poll has a couple of key points. Mine were: Is baseball still our national pastime? If the players strike, will you come back to the park? 
Seventy-two percent said that baseball is still the national game, and 28 percent disagreed. The person from Army wrote: "Baseball is not the national pastime. It's just a nickname."
As for returning after a strike, 56 percent said they would be back. Sixteen percent said they would not, but with qualifications like "probably," "likely not," "not for a long time" and "to a lesser degree."
Then there were those who stayed above the fray. Jean-Paul Bellin watched Friday's Mets game with his wife and their two sons. Asked about the American pastime and whether he would he return to baseball, Bellin answered: "No. I am French. It's too far!"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Baseball fans in Milwaukee, Commissioner Bud Selig's hometown, making their sentiments about a strike clear during a game in May. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: UP FRONT: WORTH NOTING; 
Garbage In, Garbage Out. A Princeton Success Story.

BYLINE:  By Jo Piazza 

 BODY:
Bookworms may no longer be Princeton's only larval export.
 By October Thomas Szaky, a sophomore from Canadia who is majoring in economics, hopes to have his worm-based waste management business, Terracycle International Inc., meet a goal of disposing of 15 tons to 30 tons of organic waste a day in Princeton Township. 
 The venture began with Mr. Szaky's simple curiosity over a friend's composting bin. It took Mr. Szaky about 10 months to raise $20,000 to build what he said he recently discovered was the world's largest continuous flow reactor -- or in a non-Princetonian's parlance, a conveyor belt where garbage goes in, worms digest it and soil comes out.
With the help of university students, including a team of three undergraduate engineers, Terracycle is currently disposing of most of the organic waste produced by Princeton's dining halls as well as local summer camps.
By October the company, which has offices in Princeton and Toronto, hopes to raise another $500,000 in private capital to expand the system and promote it to the rest of Princeton Township's waste producers -- restaurants, supermarkets and landscaping companies.
No bookstores? Jo Piazza

HEADLINE: BackTalk; 
I.O.C. Chief Keeps Links To Nations Balanced

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY 

 BODY:
The International Olympic Committee president is essentially a roving ambassador, and Dr. Jacques Rogge did plenty of roving in his first year in the position, visiting 30 countries and meeting with Olympic athletes and world leaders, including President Bush, Jiang Zemin of China, Gerhard Schroder of Germany and Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
 His most important journey was to Salt Lake City in February for the Winter Olympics, which were successful but rocked by a figure-skating judging scandal and the subsequent awarding of double gold medals. 
 Rogge, a 60-year-old orthopedic surgeon and former Olympic sailor from Belgium, continues to espouse probity, transparency and the need to rein in the cost and size of the Olympic Games. On July 16, the one-year anniversary of his election, he spoke about the road traveled and the road that stretches ahead.
Q. How has your perspective changed in the last year after all the meetings with the primary actors in the Olympic movement?
A. I've been even more convinced by the need to have a very close and positive relationship with governments, while at the same time keeping your independence. You might know that I was one who fought on the front line for the independence of the national Olympic Committees during the American boycott in 1980 with Jimmy Carter and the same in 1984. So we need to be independent, but at the same time you cannot build anything without the great support of governments. And even when speaking about the Salt Lake City Games, government support, which was very welcomed and absolutely needed, was far higher than it has been in the past in the United States. So, government support and the links with government are really essential.
Q. After one year, what would be your primary agenda items for the Olympic movement?
A. Definitely the No. 1 issue is doping, and everything we have to do to reduce this evil. And we are working very hard. We have tripled the number of tests. We caught seven positive cases in Salt Lake City, whereas in the 18 previous Winter Games, from Chamonix in 1924 until Nagano in 1998, we only caught 5. That does not mean there is more doping but definitely that we catch more cheats. We wholeheartedly support WADA (the World Anti-Doping Agency). We created WADA, so we put a great emphasis on that. We've done so already. 
And definitely the second thing is that I'm keen on reducing the scale and complexity of the Games. The commission is now in the study phase to examine where we can make cuts without affecting the quality. The third thing is the Olympic program, which I think we have to adapt. That is always a very sensitive and emotional issue. But we need to make the program a little bit more modern and to adapt to the changing needs of young people and sports fans.
From 1948 in London until Sydney, we've had a constant increase of number of sports events and disciplines and we then decided that for Athens we would freeze the program to 10,500 athletes, 28 sports and 301 events. So that's the first time in 50 years there was no increase in the program. The next phase is to fine-tune within those limits.
Q. Would you be in favor of increased professionalization of refereeing?
A. Absolutely. You need it at the top level. Of course whatever you introduce at the very top level could have repercussions on the grass-roots level and in the small clubs and in the minor leagues and in all the hundreds of thousands of little clubs in the countryside. They can't afford to have video replay and so on. So you have to draw a line. Where do we begin with professional referees? But definitely at the very top, yes.
Q. Looking back at Salt Lake City, how do you feel about the way you handled the skating controversy? Are you concerned that the decision to award a second gold medal to the Canadian pair was made too expeditiously?
A. The second medal for me is a matter of fundamental justice. We took the right decision in agreeing to the proposal of I.S.U., and they worked well with us. Where I failed definitely, and I admit that frankly, is that I failed in understanding that this would create a lot of criticism in Russia. And I was not proactive in addressing that. Neither at the level of Russian public opinion, which is never easy when you are in a place like Salt Lake City and there is a time difference of not less than nine hours. And I also have not been proactive at the level of the government, who faced hostile public opinion. So I should have done more on that, and it's a good lesson for the future. Everything has been talked out now. The Russians understand why we did it. But again, the lack of communication has not been good, and I take the blame for that. 
Q. And you have no concern about the legal procedure being pursued through the Court of Arbitration for Sport and its eventually coming back and rebounding on the decision to award the second gold?
A. Listen. If C.A.S. makes a decision, we will abide by it, of course. That's normal. We've done our duty. In both cases, both in the doping cases and in the case of the judge. In the judging case, we had a written confession admitting that there was manipulation, and in the case of the Russian cross-country skiers, we had a positive doping test. So we've acted on that.
Q. Do you view what happened with the United States Olympic Committee president, Sandra Baldwin, who resigned after admitting to falsifying her resume, as a step back for the Olympic movement?
A. From a personal point of view, this is tragic for Sandy, and I really felt bad for her. But you have to put this into perspective. This was an act; call it an act of pride or vanity, from which she never made one dollar. She never used it for applying for a professional position. She's a volunteer. She made an error, yes; she paid dearly. But I think there are other issues in the United States of a far graver nature. You are a country now living in a totally new era of security in general, the threat of terrorism, major economic shock, crash of Wall Street, ethics in the reporting of major companies. But here you have a woman who has devoted her life to sport. It's sad, but it's not substantial.
Q. We seem to be in a period of shrinkage with concerns about economic viability. What's your feeling from sponsors and television about the future for sports?
A. We recently had meetings with broadcasters and experts. The I.O.C. is being protected by the fact we had long-term agreements, and all the sponsors have clearly said: "Don't worry. We'll continue with you." The size of the sponsors we have, as multinational world leaders in their fields, means they can absorb the economic shock and they see the long term. Without revealing names, you will hear about the signing of sponsors in the coming weeks and months for the period after Beijing in 2008. 
Q. You don't envisage any deflation in the price of rights for the Olympic movement?
A. No. What we hear is that the value of the brand -- I don't like that word -- but the value of the brand is still intact. When people negotiate for 2010 or 2012, they don't negotiate with the present economic crisis in mind. 
Q. There is continuing interest in Athens and how things are unfolding. Given the success of Sydney and Salt Lake City, is it as important that Athens get it 100 percent right in 2004?
A. It's not going to be the Sydney Games. The city is different. The size of the population is different. In Sydney, you had no problem, no shortage of land. It's a continent on its own. You could build Homebush Bay from scratch. You can't do that in Athens. Everywhere you dig, you find archaeological remains. There are delays. Environmental rules are far stricter and so on. But I think the human factor will be extremely good. I have no concerns for media and broadcasters. They will be very well served. The athletes will have good venues, good competitions. We might experience more difficulties in terms of transportation. We will experience more difficulties for accommodation.
For the general public and spectators, it will be a bit more difficult. However, the athletes will not suffer. The Olympic family, selfishly, will not suffer either. The 50 billion audience we generate in 16 days will see very good Games. 
Q. Anything you see on the doping front that has come across your desk that concerns you?
A. WADA is investigating into genetic transfer, which is needed. From what I hear, and I read a lot, I am still not as pessimistic as public opinion. Because for the public, it's Frankenstein. We know that's not going to be the case. We know that testing will be possible.
There is an ongoing and improving collaboration with pharmaceutical companies. The fact we found so fast darbepoetin at the Olympics was really the effort of working closely with the pharmaceutical companies and also with the man who actually masterminded the drug. To discuss with the pharmaceutical companies to find a good test in due time. That's really important.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Jacques Rogge, the International Olympic Committee president, says the value of the Olympic brand has remained intact. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF; 
A $70 Million Gap Seen in Suffolk Budget

BYLINE:  By John Rather 

 BODY:
Lower-than-expected sales tax revenues and higher social service costs are threatening Suffolk County with a projected budget gap of more than $70 million next year unless action is taken, Robert J. Gaffney, the county executive, warned last week.
 Mr. 
Gaffney said the county would have to consider cutting services, promoting early retirement and raising fees to address the problem. He said he might also revive an effort to sell future tobacco settlement revenues. County legislators rejected such a sale last year. 
 Mr. Gaffney's approach to averting a deficit will be reflected in the proposed 2003 budget he will send to the county legislature on Sept. 20, and which is now being drafted.
Kenneth Weiss, the county budget director, said sales tax revenues were not expected to meet the 4.6 percent increase projected in the current budget. He said that if the trend continued, revenues would be $33 million below estimates for 2002 and 2003. Add a projected deficit of nearly $44 million in the social services budget through 2003, and the overall deficit would rise to nearly $77 million.
Mr. Weiss said that other counties and New York City were experiencing lower-than-projected sales tax revenues. "Everybody is having the same problem," he said. "The sales tax is driven by the economy."
He said the recent stock market slump would "affect consumer confidence, and consumer confidence is the driving force behind retail sales."
Revenues from the 8.5 percent sales tax in Suffolk account for a major portion of total county revenues. Suffolk keeps 4.25 percent of the total. The state keeps 4 percent and the remainder goes to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. John Rather

HEADLINE: Relief Workers, Our Better Selves 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Anthony Lake is right in calling for a memorial at the United Nations honoring those who die doing their duty ("Honoring Relief Workers," Op-Ed, July 22). 
 Humanitarian workers represent the better nature in us all. 
Their safety should be of concern to us all, as well.
The United States government supports the Office of the United Nations Security Coordinator through our assessed obligation as well as through contributions to specific operations.
International organizations need to keep better data on acts of violence against humanitarian workers, including rape. A greater understanding of the extent of such violence will help us plan better for their safety.
The United States government supports a resolution before the United Nations Economic and Social Council acknowledging the need for aid workers to have safe and unhindered access to the civilians they are helping. This fall, the General Assembly should continue to make the safety of humanitarian workers a priority.

ARTHUR E. DEWEY
Asst. Secy., Bureau of Population,
Refugees, Migration, State. Dept.
Washington, July 25, 2002

HEADLINE: Home Front; 
On Wall Street, Present Is Prologue

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
Wall Street continues in feverish, nervous malaise. Its pulse keeps going up to 120 under hourly rumors of defalcation int his or that great corporation, railroad, or others. Faith in financial agents is gone. Every treasurer and cashier is "suspect," and no wonder after the recent epidemic of fraud.

George Templeton Strong, Oct. 27, 1873
 THE language is stuffy - defalcation is just a fancy word for embezzlement, which itself is a genteel way to say "stealing." But otherwise, this entry from Mr. Strong's New York diary sounds like it could have been written yesterday.
 And while the current parade of corporate scandals, the insider-trading allegations and the overall stock-market smash-up has shocked many New Yorkers, there are a few for whom this is all old hat.
 "For historians, it's unbelievably boring and repetitious," said Mike Wallace, a professor of history at the city University of New York and co-author of the Pulitzer-Prize winning "Gotham: A History of New York City to 1898."
 Financial fiascos have been a feature of New York life for centuries; in 1854, Mr. Wallace said, "the railroads were the dot-com boom, and there was wild speculation." Leading, of course, to insider trading, fraud and, ultimately, financial catastrophe.
 The good news, for New York, is that the city has survived countless such episodes. The bad news is that the consequences have often been severe and long-lasting.
 The panic of 1857 left tens of thousands of jobless people on the streets. After the panic of 1873, hundreds of New Yorkers starved to death. The panic of 1893 resulted in economic depression. After the crash of 1929, "New York suffered badly," said Charles R. Geisst, a professor at Manhattan College and a historian of Wall Street. "There were more Hoovervilles here than anywhere else."
 The grinding stock market declines of 1973 and 1974 helped land the city in fiscal hot water; the crash of 1987, some economists aver, helps explain why New York went into recession well before the rest of the country and emerged far later.
 If anything, finance has taken on a greater role in the city in recent years. "It's not entirely true but New York is a one-horse town, but we've lost manufacturing and lost the port," Mr. Wallace said. "Washington is a one-horse town, and so is Hollywood, but they don't have these huge swings."
 But Wall Street is built on boom and bust. During the boom years, New York profits more than anywhere else. During the bust years, the city suffers more.
 It's not only because stockbrokers are out of work; so are all the lawyers and advisers and accountants and clerks and building cleaners and, these days, computer experts who flock around the financial business. Restaurant owners, bauble sellers, opera singers and cigar vendors lose valuable clients; so do housekeepers, golf pros and manicurists. Heck, so do newspapers.
 New York's image also suffers when the stock market swoons, exposing financial shenanigans. "As early as the 1830's, people in Ohio were enraged," Mr. Wallace said. "They were ralling about the people living in Sybaritic luxury in New York while we virtuous farmers live in penruy."
 After the stock market melted down in the 1970's, the rest of the nation generally approved of Gerald Ford's "Drop Dead" attitude about New York. The spectacle of a Wall Street bigwig being hauled off in hand-cuffs did not do much to burnish New York's image in 1987.
 So you have to wonder how the rest of the country will feel about New York now that more Americans than ever have staked their financial futures on the stock market. True, Enron isn't based in New York. But the banks that profited from it and the brokerage firms that flogged it (and all those other now-worthless stocks) are.
 It may turn out to be too bad that the Rigas family were accused of using ill-gotten gains from looting Adelphia Communications to buy a place on the Upper East Side. Couldn't the Rigases have gone back to Coudersport, Pa., to get arrested?
 So while there's no guarantee that times will get together, the outlook isn't exactly rosy. "I think New York's in for it this time," Mr. Geisst said. Or, as George Templeton Strong put it more than a century ago, "There is a prospect of a hard, blue winter."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The panic on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange more than a century ago shows that corporate scandal and financial fiascos are not new to New York City. (Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper, 1884)

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Once UponA Time, A Restless C.E.O. . . .

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
WELCOME to story time in corporate America.
 The old story went like this: chief executives were in such demand that they were apt to jump ship at any moment. 
 The new story says that the scrutiny of large companies has caused some C.E.O.'s to consider resigning and others to balk at a promotion to the corner office.
The next story is already emerging. It says executives will begin quitting in droves if boards force them to hold on to their company stock in an effort to tie the executives' pay to their company's long-term health. 
The storytellers have most often been the executives and the recruiters and pay consultants they hire. By suggesting that the job market for chief executives is fluid, the tales of executive wanderlust have conveniently offered an economic rationale for enormous executive pay. The evidence, however, is about as impressive as the wardrobe of the emperor in that other fairy tale.
The job of C.E.O. is fabulously attractive, allowing somebody to lead thousands of people, often in an organization where they have spent years. Few people leave voluntarily before they are ready to retire. Surprisingly few have even been willing to leave one corner office for another elsewhere.
This is a crucial point at a time when policy makers and corporate leaders are both struggling to stop the bleeding on Wall Street and to help the fitful economic recovery. It means that reforming executive pay -- a central part of re-establishing corporate America's credibility -- may not be nearly as hard as some people think.
Set that aside for a moment, though, and return to the first story, the one about jumpy C.E.O.'s ditching one company for another.
Since 2000, a year in which executive turnover spiked, 77 of the 200 biggest companies have hired a new boss, according to Pearl Meyer & Partners, a compensation consulting firm in New York. How many of those companies had to do so because their chief executive took another corporate job? Two.
David M. Cote left TRW for Honeywell, and John H. Dasburg left Northwest Airlines for Burger King. That was the sum total of the wanderlust.
Most departing chiefs retired and remained on their company's board, according to news accounts. A good number were forced out.
Yet many companies, including USX and Verizon, lavished their executives with so-called retention bonuses. Dozens of others cited retention to justify big pay packages, even -- as was the case at Enron recently -- when the executives could hardly expect to be sought-after candidates for other jobs.
The new version of the myth says the recent criticism of corporate America has turned the chief executive's job into an unappealing one. David F. D'Alessandro, the chief executive of John Hancock Financial Services, recently said that he had run into a peer at Yankee Stadium who told him: "I'm thinking of actually getting out, retiring. I didn't sign up for this."
There is no reason to doubt Mr. D'Alessandro, but don't expect the unnamed executive to make good on the threat. In fact, check back six months from now to see if anybody running a healthy company ceded his power and perks.
The idea that executives have little loyalty, however, serves an important political purpose. It allows them to argue against a serious idea for altering executive pay.
Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, has proposed requiring top executives to hold all their company stock as long as they are in their jobs. Congress is unlikely to adopt the plan, but some analysts think that boards of directors might enact milder versions of the policy on their own. Executives have begun to fight the effort, saying that talented leaders would quit after their stock price had risen, sell the stock and find new work.
IF boards are wise, though, they will realize that finding a new company to run is not easy. Bank One and Citigroup already have stock-holding rules for top executives, and neither has suffered an exodus. Boards can also backload pay packages, giving executives an incentive to stay.
The economic theory needed to design such a contract is fairly basic. Boards and investors simply have to decide that they will not bend to executives' wishes as often as they did in the slap-happy 1990's.
The idea is not perfect, of course. Some executives, anticipating a big stock decline, will still decide that quitting and selling makes more sense than sticking around to receive more shares. Should anybody really be worried, however, if a company loses an executive with that mind-set?

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Time for Faith in Brokerage Shares?

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH HARRIS 

 BODY:
AS investors have grown disenchanted with Wall Street, the stock prices of major brokerage firms have tumbled sharply. While the stocks may well fall further, some analysts say they may be a good value.
 The weak economy and the depressed stock market have cooled activity in investment banking, whether mergers and acquisitions or initial public offerings -- all major sources of revenue for many companies in the group. Though trading volume has surged during the market turmoil this month, it declined in the second quarter, reducing brokerage income. Moreover, the firms earn fees from assets under management, which have also fallen. On top of that, corporate scandals and questions about analyst bias have dogged the group. 
 These pressures have led to declines of more than 30 percent this year in the share prices of companies like Merrill Lynch and Charles Schwab.
Questions are arising about when the industry's stocks will reverse course, but "I can't say a rally is imminent," said Guy Moszkowski, an analyst at the Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup.
Still, he said, on a valuation basis, the companies have begun to look attractive. Earnings remain positive, attributable in part to cost-cutting and diversification.
In addition, the price-to-book values of brokerage firm stocks -- the price divided by the net value of assets -- are approaching levels not found since 1998. Merrill Lynch trades at 1.4 times book value, compared with its former low of 1.5, while Morgan Stanley has hit 1.96, compared with its 1.7 low, Mr. Moszkowski said.
Charlotte A. Chamberlain, an analyst at Jefferies & Company, said, "They're priced like snow shovels in July." 
Still, David H. Ellison, who runs both the FBR Financial Services fund, which was down 4.4 percent this year through Thursday, and the FBR Small Cap Financial fund, up 9.2 percent, says investing in shares of brokerage firms is premature. He prefers to delay until the economy is in a clear upswing. "These are bull-market companies when the market's doing well and capitalism is functioning in an ebullient environment," Mr. Ellison said.
That has hardly been the case recently. Merrill Lynch has come under particular pressure because of an investigation over possible conflicts of interest among its stock analysts; it recently reached a settlement with Eliot L. Spitzer, the New York State attorney general. Merrill is also reorganizing and announced last week that E. Stanley O'Neal would become chief executive in December, a year ahead of schedule, and will replace David H. Komansky as chairman in April.
Strong performance in nonbrokerage areas has been a buffer to stocks of other brokerage firms. Bond trading and underwriting contributed to 46 percent of 2001 revenue at Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers, Mr. Moszkowski said. That has helped to limit stock price declines this year to 1 percent at Bear Stearns and 19 percent at Lehman, he said.
Schwab, however, remains more of a retail brokerage firm despite its diversification into wealth management; its earnings fell 7 percent in the first six months of 2002 from a year earlier. Schwab stock has lost 42 percent this year.
In the past, brokerage stocks have rallied in advance of economic improvement. Merrill Lynch's stock price, for instance, more than doubled in a five-month period beginning at the end of October 1990, when the economy was in recession.
"Long before you have a recovery these stocks will react positively because the market is always one of those things that anticipates," said Anton V. Schutz, portfolio manager of the Burnham Financial Services fund, which was up 3.2 percent this year through Thursday.
WHILE the combined earnings of the 10 largest securities firms declined from the first quarter of 2000 to the first quarter of 2002, the group did not lose money, performing well compared with other recent turbulent periods. From the end of 1987 through the end of 1990, the industry's earnings were in the red for 5 of the 13 quarters, starting with a $700 million loss in the fourth quarter of 1987, when stocks crashed, said David M. Trone, an analyst at Prudential Securities. And in 1994, when the Federal Reserve raised interest rates, the group lost money again in two quarters.
The brokerage firms he covers are "very comfortably in the black and there are no individual firms that have lost money," Mr. Trone said. 
Anna M. Dopkin, an analyst and portfolio manager of the T. Rowe Price Financial Services fund, is also encouraged. "So far, they've proven to be better stores of capital this time around thanks in part to a lower tolerance for risk," she said.
But Ms. Dopkin sees equally attractive investments in other industries, like bank stocks. For now, though, she does not have to choose because few investors are moving money into her fund, which was down 17.6 percent this year through Thursday.
"I wish the money was pouring in, because I could spend it," she said.
