HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Capitalist Tools; 
Police for Hire in Russia's Business Jungle

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW 

 BODY:
IN Russia's morning newspapers these days, a frequent staple is a police raid on corporate wrongdoers. Uniformed men with guns round up anxious office workers. Files are searched. Managers are marched out of their offices.
 In many cases, the policemen wear ski masks to intimidate those under siege, prompting the Russian public to call their raids mask shows, a sardonic reference to a Soviet-era comedy troupe. 
 On the face of it, these are scenes of law enforcement in action, something Americans might actually envy as they think about their corporate scandals. But a closer look shows something entirely different going on. 
In fact, those policemen are acting not for the state but for corporate rivals. Underpaid and underappreciated in their day jobs working for the government, they're moonlighting for the highest bidder. And they're not enforcing the rule of law so much as rules of the business jungle bent by canny operators to their own advantage.
All of this is playing out -- and stirring some protests -- against a debate within Russia about the role of law itself as the country evolves from a brutal form of communism through a Darwinian form of capitalism. At the end of the road, reformers hope, will be a somewhat more rational business atmosphere. Two years ago, when he was a candidate, Vladimir V. Putin, now the president, summed up the quest aptly, if clumsily, when he promised that under him Russia would get a "dictatorship of the law." 
Consider the recent example of Slavneft, a Russian oil company that is emerging from state ownership. After it fired its chief executive earlier this year and its shareholders elected a new one, Yuri Sukhanov, who was better connected politically and who promised to be less autocratic, the former chief executive responded by hiring about 40 police officers and physically taking over the company headquarters in downtown Moscow last month. 
On the surface, it seemed to be the case that the law was on his side. He said he was enforcing a court decision that had ruled his dismissal illegal, and he cited a criminal investigation that had begun against his successor.
But the court ruling had been made in a distant Russian region where the company had neither business nor a base. And the case against the new chief executive was soon dropped, with authorities citing "absence of a crime."
In short, this was a battle between two business groups for control of a state-owned company in anticipation of a planned privatization in the fall. 
The battle highlights a peculiar development in Russian capitalism. Police and prosecutors with crumbs for salaries are being hired, or simply used, as tools in business battles, and the practice has become increasingly prevalent since Mr. Putin became president. 
"Quite simply, you can hire the authorities for money," said Grigory A. Yavlinsky, a deputy in parliament and leader of the liberal Yabloko party. In the last two years, he added, "it has become an institution."
In part, the trend is a side effect of Mr. Putin's emphasis on building a strong state. While Boris N. Yeltsin relied on powerful business executives to help run Russia, Mr. Putin promised to "eliminate them as a class," and turned to police and prosecutors to restore order. As doors to Kremlin offices closed, business, no longer allowed to roam Kremlin corridors, hired law enforcers instead.
As Russia continues to try to sort out who owns what in its newly privatized economy, the practice is giving big businesses a strong edge over smaller, weaker ones, and as a result the development of small businesses has slowed. Though the economy as a whole is now expanding for a fourth year, economists say the growth has been almost exclusively in very large companies.
A recent study by the Center for Economic and Financial Research in Moscow and the World Bank found that a mysterious glass ceiling stops small concerns from growing beyond a certain size. A possible explanation, said Yekaterina Zhuravskaya, director of the study, is that they are blocked by bigger rivals that control local authorities.
In fact, the Slavneft spectacle threw a spotlight on the problem at a crucial moment for legal reform. Government reformers are rewriting laws to block such maneuvering. A new criminal procedural code took effect this month, and a business law code will take effect by the end of July. Under these new rules, the police and prosecutors will have to seek a court order to conduct a search, and other state administrative and enforcement agencies will lose the right to start criminal investigations. Under the new laws, the distant provincial court would not have been allowed to rule on the Slavneft case, the search of the office on the day of the takeover would have required a court order and under next year's rules, it will be more difficult for prosecutors to start criminal investigations of corporate managers. 
Pavel V. Krasheninikov, a deputy in parliament and former minister of justice, who is helping rewrite the laws, said reformers are "rooting out the conditions for abuse," which are "catastrophic for our economy."
On July 17, Russia's interior minister, Boris Gryzlov, issued a warning to moonlighting policemen to stay out of property disputes.
A big problem is that the abuse defies the image of the orderly, reformed Russia that Mr. Putin is projecting to the world. Even so, many say it is a bit too much to expect Russia to fit in just yet to the rest of the capitalist world's notions of a rule of law, and that even the clumsy misuse of the police and courts represents a step forward in this country's economic evolution.
"It is civilized corruption," said Lev M. Timofeyev, author of "Shadow Russia," a book on corruption in the Russian state. "Prices are set. It is clear whom to pay. It's much better than corruption anarchy, when you don't know whom to pay and, any moment, bandits or police could pay you a visit. Business can't develop in those conditions."
Or as Mr. Krasheninikov put it hopefully, "Twenty years from now we'll see this all as very uncivilized."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
Detroit and California Rev Their Engines Over Emissions

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
IF Detroit and California ever made a sitcom together, it would be sort of like "Dharma and Greg."
 Detroit, the strait-laced company town, just can't figure out that wacky California. Is it the nation's biggest car market, or is it the most troublesome? Is it the land of Ronald Reagan and Lee Iacocca, or of tree hugging hippies who want every car to be electric? 
 Yes, Arnold Schwarzenegger lives there, and he drove a Hummer before anybody else. But another resident is Gray Davis, the Democratic governor of California, who signed a controversial bill on Monday to cut greenhouse gas emissions. That, needless to say, could mean fewer Hummers. 
"There's more than a little concern among the car companies about how bad the relationship with California has gotten," one industry executive said, speaking on condition of anonymity. 
"There needs to be a stand-down, but the more we want to talk, the more radical and out of control they get," he added. "You'd almost like to see a white knight come in here and arbitrate."
The state's new legislation, which will almost certainly be challenged in court, would sharply cut emissions of carbon dioxide, mostly by imposing new, yet-to-be-determined regulations on cars and trucks sold in the state by the 2008 model year. It is only the latest challenge the industry faces from California, which has regularly been aggressive in setting air-quality standards. The state has set tougher rules on emissions of smog-forming pollutants than the federal government.
The industry's view of California was summed up last week in an editorial cartoon in The Detroit News. A middle-aged couple stand in their driveway, next to their sedan. They are looking quizzically at their neighbor, Mr. Jones, who is riding a galloping horse out of his garage, briefcase in hand.
The Joneses, the cartoon's caption read, "say their new, state-of-the-art low-emission vehicle meets California's C02 emissions rules."
By signing the bill, Mr. Davis put his state squarely at odds with Washington. The Bush administration has pulled the United States out of the Kyoto Protocol, a global agreement on regulating greenhouse-gas emissions. And in March, the Senate handily defeated a bill that would have significantly raised gasoline mileage requirements for the first time since the 1980's. Tailpipe emissions from cars driven in the United States constitute the world's fifth-leading source of greenhouse gas, according to the Sierra Club. The nation as a whole is the top producer of such emissions. 
REPEATED defeats on Capitol Hill have made California an appealing alternative battleground for frustrated environmental groups and politicians. Senators John McCain and John F. Kerry, who led a failed Senate effort to raise fuel standards, sent a joint letter to California legislators encouraging them to consider the bill. "Big money and the special interests went to the mat to stop us," Mr. Kerry said earlier this month. "I'm just glad to see they weren't able to smother a real dialogue in California."
Republican leaders, and influential Midwestern Democrats like Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, have long prevailed in their opposition to toughening federal gasoline mileage requirements. The industry's expected legal challenge to the new California legislation will likely argue that the state's authority to regulate greenhouse-gas emissions from automobiles is superseded by the federal government's fuel economy regulations, because the two issues are closely correlated.
"We will see if CO2 is something different from fuel economy," Dieter Zetsche, chief executive of the Chrysler Group, said last Thursday. 
"We are clearly aware of our responsibility and that of the industry to increase fuel economy," he added. "We don't think it's the best approach to force the customer into a mix of vehicles that they wouldn't buy on their own."
Companies like Chrysler have argued that California's regulations are already forcing them to produce small cars that consumers don't want and to develop costly and in some cases obsolete technologies. The most immediate threat is California's zero-emission vehicle mandate, which would force the industry to derive 10 percent of its sales from low- and zero-emission vehicles, like battery powered cars. The plan has been delayed by a legal challenge from General Motors and DaimlerChrysler.
Environmental groups counter that California's regulations have been the only real impetus to developing cleaner technologies like hybrid engines that use electricity and gasoline, or hydrogen fuel cells, a technology many automakers see as one day replacing the internal combustion engine.
Detroit, for its part, says it is giving customers what they want. All one has to do is look at the sales figures. Last year, for the first time, sales of passenger cars were overtaken by less fuel-efficient pickup trucks, S.U.V.'s and minivans.
While G.M. phases out Oldsmobile, the Hummer brand, based on the Humvee military transport, is rising in its place. This month, G.M. began selling the Hummer H2, a smaller vehicle that can fit in some garages. Still, at 8,600 pounds, it is so big it is not subject to the same fuel-economy rules that govern other cars. G.M. estimates the H2 gets about 13 miles per gallon, which would put one H2's carbon emissions at 3.4 metric tons in a typical year, compared to 1.9 tons from G.M.'s Chevrolet Malibu sedan. 
A recent magazine advertisement showed the imposing grill of the Hummer looming over an arid, treeless landscape under a pale sun. 
"Hummer," the ads copy reads. "Like nothing else."

HEADLINE: The World: Character-Building; 
The Comic Side of Vicente Fox

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY 

 BODY:
NOT many heads of state would publicly acknowledge that their first years in office were fitted for the funny pages.
 In Mexico, however, where television and radio stations cannot always reach the rural poor, comic books inform as much as they entertain. They have long been powerful messengers, shaping public opinion with hundreds of thousands of copies distributed each month. 
 President Vicente Fox, a former Coca-Cola salesman with a keen sense of marketing, seems stuck in a serious image crisis. On July 2, 2000, he became Mexico's first democratically elected opposition president, ending the 71-year rule of the Institutional Revolutionary Party. Voters since then have expressed increasing disappointment in President Fox because his government has failed to live up to the expectations for change that fueled his rise to power. 
With his popularity ratings continuing a steady decline, Mr. Fox turned for help to Kaboom! Studios, a team of cartoonists whose work for the creators of "The Simpsons" won them international acclaim.
A 24-page comic book titled "July 2: Now No One Can Stop the Change in Mexico!" hit the streets a couple weeks ago. Readers called it a high-gloss version of comic books published in the past by PRI candidates for president and, in recent months, by Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, the mayor of Mexico City. 
The comic is meant to be a superhero's story: a mild-mannered business executive wins the nation's first democratic elections, transforms a system of corruption and impunity into a government that upholds law and order, and shares power with the people. In some frames President Fox is depicted with the same square jaw and stern glare of the Man of Steel.
In a nod to the demands of the masses, there are subliminal hints of sex and violence. Women are curvy and show lots of cleavage. And there are scenes of gun-wielding police officers fighting criminals to the ground. But the main messages, narrated by a group of hip-looking college students, are aimed squarely at readers' political conscience. 
The strategy isn't novel. In 1999, for instance, the Chinese government produced comic books that demonized the outlawed Falun Gong spiritual movement. Government-issue comics and cartoons are not always used for self-serving propaganda, however. They have been published in the United States and Africa to combat AIDS. In Bosnia, they have warned children of the lingering dangers of land mines. In Japan, they help explain the complex economic system. A book of line drawings in Peru was distributed to promote immunization and family planning among peasants. And in Thailand they have been used to teach rural mothers how to breast feed.
The Fox comic, of course, is strictly about image management. It is paid for and published by the office of the president and is heavily slanted, avoiding any criticism of Mr. Fox. The fact that crime rates are still high, the comic says, is a matter for state and local governments. It exaggerates the president's record of achievements, pronouncing, for example, that "all students have quality schools."
And, of course, there is an odious archenemy, Ivan. Everything about him is dark -- his hair, his clothes, his attitude. The comic book opens with Ivan slouched arrogantly in his chair, wearing a long black trench coat, platform boots and a T-shirt with a skull on the front. His ragged black hair hangs down his to his shoulders. And he guzzles from a can like a drunk, with drops dribbling down his chin.
Other students scold Ivan for sleeping through the election that brought President Fox to power. The day marked the start of "a deep democratic change in Mexico," the students said.
Ivan, however, remains unconvinced. He has the fewest lines in the comic book, but his are the words increasingly echoed by people across the country.
"What change are you talking about," Ivan asks, "if everything has stayed the same?"

Powell Begins Asia Tour As Kashmir Dominates

President Bush said the authority, "will open markets, expand opportunity, and create jobs for American workers and farmers." 1

HEADLINE: At Trade Center Site, A Wealth of Ideas; 
Competing Interests Are Fighting To Have a Say in Reviving Downtown

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
A tangle of interests is at work in Lower Manhattan, seeking to influence the rebuilding of the World Trade Center and, more broadly, the structure and methods of the downtown economy. 
 The effort is hardly the most complex attempt at urban planning or public development the city has ever undertaken, in scale, in scope or in infrastructure. 
 But the political, aesthetic and commercial interests that are involved in the effort bring with them such a dizzying array of positions and agendas that it is often quite difficult to keep track of who wants what.
How do the interests of Gov. George E. Pataki, for example, who with the governor of New Jersey controls the agency that owns the World Trade Center site, differ from those of Larry A. Silverstein, who controls the rights to build office space there? 
And how might the interests of the families of the victims of the attack on the World Trade Center diverge from those of, say, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg or the people who live near ground zero?
As the vendor himself might say at Yankee Stadium, "You can't tell the players without a scorecard."
Created in 1921 as a regional planning body to settle disputes over the use of the common harbor and the Hudson River, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is jointly controlled by the governors of each state: New York's appoints its executive director, and New Jersey's, its chairman. The authority built and controls public works linking the two states, including the Holland Tunnel and George Washington Bridge; operates the region's three major airports; and owns several business and industrial parks. But its consuming passion for the last 10 months has been the 16 acres of land where the World Trade Center stood.
The Port Authority's interests in the rebuilding process are several, the simplest being revenue. In 2001, in the largest real estate transaction in New York history, the agency sold control of the site for 99 years to a group of investors led by Mr. Silverstein, a New York developer, in a deal valued at $3.2 billion. To help guarantee that it continued to receive the $120 million annual rent due from the Silverstein group, the authority required that all six design plans for rebuilding the site restore all of its office, retail and hotel space.
How meaningful that annual income is, however, is open to question. After payments in lieu of property taxes to the city, the authority nets about $90 million for other capital projects -- only about 2 percent of its $4.5 billion budget.
More important for the authority's long-term outlook is Mr. Silverstein's lawsuit against his insurers, who before Sept. 11 wrote a $3.5 billion policy on the trade center. 
The $3.5 billion is what the insurers would pay "per occurrence" of some catastrophic event. The question before the court is, was the attack by two hijacked airliners, aimed at bringing down the twin towers, one occurrence or two? The difference means billions for the rebuilding effort.
Finally, the authority is seeking to regain its heart and soul. Most of its executives suffered through the 1993 bombing and rebuilding of the trade center, only to see it vanish in the space of a few hours last fall.
Few public employees represent the "can do" spirit more than the authority's engineers -- one reason it has been difficult for the agency to share the rebuilding work with the rest of the world.

The Governors
Gov. George E. Pataki of New York is pretty much universally thought of as the nexus of power in the rebuilding effort, and he has taken an avid interest in the process -- not surprising given that it is the most visible public project in the state in a year when he is seeking re-election.
In November, as the Port Authority was still reeling from its losses, Mr. Pataki created the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to oversee the rebuilding, in one stroke expanding his influence from the 16-acre site to much of Downtown Manhattan.
The development corporation's board consists of 16 members. Eight are appointed by the governor and eight by the mayor of New York City. (Four mayoral appointees were chosen last year by former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and four this year by Mr. Bloomberg.)
That gives the board some appearance of balance between city and state interests, but Mr. Pataki is first among equals, having appointed the board's chairman, John C. Whitehead, a former Wall Street executive, and its president, Louis R. Tomson, a longtime Pataki aide.
In his book "Divided We Stand: A Biography of New York's World Trade Center," Eric Darton describes an event that captures perfectly the relationship between New York and New Jersey as it affects the World Trade Center.
In early spring 1961, David Rockefeller, the head of Chase Manhattan Bank, and Nelson Rockefeller, the governor of New York, met with Austin J. Tobin, who led the Port Authority, to present plans for the World Trade Center to Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey.
As Mr. Darton describes it, Governor Meyner, peering over the drawings and model for the development, shrugged and turned to Governor Rockefeller.
"What's in it for me?" Mr. Meyner asked.
Since Sept. 11, Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey has had little to say about the fate of the site and its effect on New Jersey.
But that silence should not be mistaken for indifference. Much of the Port Authority's income goes to build transportation projects in New Jersey. 
Most recently, Mr. McGreevey convinced the development corporation to conduct a public hearing about the rebuilding plans, which is scheduled for late August, in New Jersey.

The Mayor and the Council
Mr. Bloomberg, for months, mostly kept quiet about his wishes for the site. But when he did speak, he stirred things up. His comments last month about a memorial -- that essentially, less is more -- upset many relatives of victims of the attack. Then, after being briefed on the initial designs for the 16 acres, but before the plans were released to the public, Mr. Bloomberg gave them a lukewarm review and said that he would be submitting his own ideas.
Mr. Bloomberg's criticism gave added weight to subsequent criticisms of the plans from architecture and design professionals and the general public. Most recently, the mayor began to push for more housing at or near the site.
City Council members have been largely ignored in the redevelopment process, though not for lack of speaking out.
When rebuilding officials testified at a Council hearing early this year, they were peppered with questions about the ethnic makeup of the development corporation's board, which at the time consisted of nine white men and two women, one of whom is African-American. Three of Mr. Bloomberg's four subsequent appointees are members of ethnic minorities.
The Council also has pushed for recognition of problems visited on Chinatown and the Lower East Side after Sept. 11, which led to the expansion of grant programs in those neighborhoods.

Lower Manhattan Development Corporation
The development corporation saw how ephemeral its power really was this spring, when its chief planner, Alexander Garvin, released a request for proposals from architectural firms to help redesign the trade center site. Port Authority officials quickly swatted down the effort; Mr. Garvin withdrew the request, and soon another call for planners was jointly released by the Port Authority and the development corporation. 
A further sign of its relative lack of power came in the Port Authority's insistence that all the site's office and retail space be restored. Given that a major portion of the land had to be reserved for a memorial, planners were left with few options but to produce a very dense arrangement of buildings. 
The agency does have some muscle, though, in the form of money. Congress required that the corporation get at least $2 billion of the $21.7 billion appropriated for rebuilding. That has occasionally left state and city officials asking for money for business recovery programs from an agency appointed by city and state executives. And the development corporation's outreach efforts, including helping to pay for the recent town hall meetings to consider the initial six rebuilding plans, set the stage for the ensuing public revolt.

The Victims' Families
The dust from the collapse of the twin towers had barely settled when people began to talk of how to memorialize the victims of the tragedy. But even 10 months later, many family members cannot bring themselves to visit the site, much less engage in a public debate over its future. The public face of the group -- often referred to simply as the families -- has been represented by a relatively small number of people, but it has become clear that collectively they are not of one voice.
In the early days, some family members vowed to chain themselves to bulldozers if any effort was made to build anything on the site where their loved ones had fallen. Those threats have dissipated, but the momentum behind a "soaring" memorial, as Mr. Giuliani put it, has not. Frustrated with their reception from Mr. Bloomberg, family members have made efforts to re-engage Mr. Giuliani in the public discussion about a memorial. Most recently, Mr. Pataki has emerged as their biggest champion.

The Design Professionals
As commercial life in the city slowed considerably after Sept. 11, designers and architects quickly found their creative juices bubbling over, and they were unable to keep themselves from thinking about what form the rebuilding process would take. They wanted to be involved, if only to rescue the city from the mad rush that so often results in bad design decisions' being justified by short-term economic goals.
Three groups have made repeated contributions to the public dialogue: the Civic Alliance to Rebuild Downtown New York, a coalition of civic groups and community and professional associations; New York New Visions, a group of architects, urban planners, designers and others who laid out a program of development priorities and an array of possible designs for the site and surrounding areas; and Rebuild Downtown Our Town, made up mostly of local residents, many of them also designers or planners, with an interest in community affairs.
These groups have researched and reported on everything from how memorials are conceived and constructed around the world to the history and functions of holes cut in construction site fences to allow the public to peer in. The latter effort helped shape a specially designed "viewing wall" to be built around the site, containing information about the rebuilding effort and the history of the trade center, as well as places to leave small tokens honoring the attack victims. The Civic Alliance also conceived and organized the "Listening to the City" town hall meetings, attended by 4,500 people last weekend.

The Residents
Nearly every constituency involved in the rebuilding thinks it is being ignored, perhaps none more so than the residents in Lower Manhattan, which was the city's fastest-growing neighborhood before Sept. 11. The dust that billowed across the area as the twin towers collapsed settled in thick blankets in their homes, their schools and their offices. (More than half of those who live downtown walk to work.) They lost most of their shopping areas, their streets were torn up, their backyard has been flooded with tourists and they face the prospect of being under a five-year siege from construction companies and developers.
Relatively few of them have opted to move out, however, evidence of the quality of life in a section of the city with unparalleled waterfront access. When Mayor Bloomberg said that many people opposed turning the trade center site into a cemetery, he was voicing this group's frustrations. That has put them into a sort of natural conflict with many victims' relatives, but there are few groups as committed to a poignant and meaningful memorial than those who will be in the closest proximity day in and day out.

Mr. Silverstein
In the days immediately after Sept. 11, Mr. Silverstein brashly declared that he would rebuild the twin towers. And he and his investors have the contractual right to rebuild what was on the site on Sept. 10. The Port Authority has interpreted that literally, saying that Mr. Silverstein's lease gives him the right to build two towers, each more than 100 stories tall. But the authority also says such a plan would be economically unfeasible. Even if a landlord could lease that much space, who would rent the top 20 floors or so? Therefore, the authority says, the lease should be renegotiated.
Westfield America, part of an Australian shopping mall company, had a more complex lease, which allowed it to increase to at least 600,000 square feet its 430,000 or so square feet of retail space at the site, including the building of at least two floors of mall space above ground on the trade center plaza.
The trade center's retail space was among the highest-grossing in the country. With plans developing for a major transportation hub stretching from the World Financial Center eastward under the site to the Fulton Street subway complex, Westfield America is unlikely to want to move from the site, and so far, aesthetic concerns about the juxtaposition of retail sites with the sacred ground around a memorial have gotten little attention.
Squaring off against Mr. Silverstein are developers who have a lot of empty office space on their hands, both downtown and across the city and region. Few of them, particularly those with downtown properties, which tend to be older and of lesser quality, are eager to see 11 million square feet of splashy new office space come on the market.

Downtown Businesses
Public officials say they want the downtown area to diversify so that it does not rely so heavily on financial services. That is happening to some degree, as financial companies move out of Lower Manhattan in search of more hospitable working conditions, better access to the suburbs and fewer problems in general.
If location is everything for a small business, proximity to the World Trade Center went overnight from being a dream to the worst kind of nightmare. Some 100,000 potential customers disappeared after Sept. 11. Businesses were shut down for days or weeks, some were looted, many were left without the support to continue or the wherewithal to conceive how to deal with the new environment. Grant and loan programs helped, but for most small businesses, only nominally so.
As the rebuilding effort proceeds, many shops and stores will come back. And, enlivened by new residents in the area and the continuing growth in businesses that feel safe enough to operate downtown, small businesses and retail stores will begin to flourish again. But if, in several years, a 600,000-square-foot mall opens, it could suck the life back out of those businesses that struggled to make it back. That is what keeps small-business owners awake at night.
Mike Wallace, the historian and author of "Gotham," the history of the city's early development, said that in scale, the current rebuilding of Lower Manhattan "doesn't even begin to approach the efforts of the New Deal era, when vast projects threw up highways, housing, hospitals, schools, docks, etc." Similarly, the regional plans of the 1920's and 1930's were far more sweeping and all-encompassing. The development of the street grid, the subway, the Robert Moses-era projects intended to put the population into their automobiles -- all required a grander effort, with more creative thinking and more political muscle, Mr. Wallace said, calling the current effort small potatoes. 
But for those who have a stake in it, the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan is seen as an effort that will decide how successful New York City is in the 21st century. As they jockey for position, one thought lingers in the back of their minds: Let's not mess it up.

HEADLINE: Talks on Kashmir Urged by Powell 

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, July 27 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived in India today at the start of a weeklong Asian trip to shore up support for the campaign against terrorism, with his first issue the flare-up over Kashmir that has threatened war between India and Pakistan, two nations critical to the campaign. 
 As Secretary Powell landed, for his third visit to India and Pakistan since October, Indian officials promptly raised complaints about what they say is continued cross-border infiltration from Pakistan into Kashmir. 
 Secretary Powell said he would press for talks between India and Pakistan over the disputed Kashmir region, but added that the timing would be up to them and that he did not expect a breakthrough on this visit. Instead, he told reporters traveling on his plane from Washington, "I'm going to be talking to both sides about what we can do to keep the momentum going." 
Six weeks ago, Secretary Powell's deputy, Richard L. Armitage, won a pledge from Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, for a permanent halt to border crossings into Kashmir by militant groups. These incursions into the Indian-controlled part of Kashmir have brought repeated violence and led to a military buildup along the border.
Indian officials, while acknowledging that border crossings are down, maintain that the problem has not stopped altogether and say that they will not open political discussions with Pakistan until the infiltration stops. They also say they will keep their large troop presence along the border through the end of October and scheduled local elections in Kashmir this fall.
"We do not think the necessary conditions exist" for talks, the Indian foreign minister, Yashwant Sinha, said as Secretary Powell arrived for a meeting this evening before conferring with other Indian officials and then heading to Pakistan to meet with General Musharraf on Sunday.
From South Asia, Secretary Powell will travel to Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia and the Philippines, and to an international conference of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations in Brunei next week, where he is expected to win a pledge for shared financial and immigration information in the campaign against terrorism.
"All of those nations have increasingly realized that terrorism is a danger to each and every one of us," Secretary Powell said. "It's not just an American agenda. It has to be an international agenda."
In Indonesia, which is the world's most populous Muslim country and has been a somewhat reluctant partner in the effort, Secretary Powell is expected to discuss renewing American assistance after a nearly decade-long suspension over concerns about human rights abuses.
In the Philippines, where 1,000 American troops have ended a six-month stint training local soldiers in counterterrorism tactics, Secretary Powell said he expected to discuss the next round of efforts.
"But the details of that and the sequencing and the timing of all that, I would leave to Don Rumsfeld and his colleagues to work out," Secretary Powell said, referring to the defense secretary.
Secretary Powell has spent scores of hours in telephone diplomacy trying to keep the two nuclear rivals from going to war at a time when the United States is more involved in the region than it has been in decades and badly wants the cooperation of both countries in the campaign against terrorism. He is the latest in a continuing parade of international officials who have come in rotation in an effort to hold down tensions.
Today in Islamabad, the European Union's foreign policy and security chief, Javier Solana, praised General Musharraf's efforts to curtail the infiltration to date but said he hoped Pakistan would do more. "We would like him to continue taking decisions in that direction with the same courage, with the same energy and with the same determination that he has shown," Mr. Solana said. "I am sure he is going to take that."
But in an interview with CNN that was broadcast here this evening, the Indian foreign minister, Mr. Sinha, expressed disappointment at the pace of progress.
"Although there has been some decline in infiltration, infiltration continues at very significant levels," he said. "What had been promised to us was the complete and permanent stop to infiltration. It's almost six weeks now. That's not in evidence at all."
Indian officials say that infiltration by militants from Kashmir has been creeping up since last month, and that infiltrators are now crossing in smaller groups and seem to be based closer to Pakistani troops for better cover and help in crossing.
Asked en route here about the likelihood of Indian complaints about continued infiltration, Secretary Powell smiled and said: "I think I'll wait to respond until after my ear has been filled. There is constant discussion and debate as to the extent of infiltration across the Line of Control. It's not the most, it's not the easiest thing to measure, and it's hard to measure with any precision.
"I have sources of information that I'll review with the Indians," he added. "Then I will discuss all of that, of course, and receive President Musharraf's judgment when I get to Islamabad."
Secretary Powell said he would encourage both sides to back free elections in Kashmir, "and to permit an international presence, people from outside to travel to Kashmir during that period, widely and openly, to help the Indians show the international community, show the world, that it is a free, open, fair election."
Speaking briefly to reporters before his meeting with Secretary Powell, Mr. Sinha said that outsiders would be welcome on an "individual basis" at the time of the elections. But in the CNN interview, he said: "The elections will be held on time. The elections will be free, fair and hopefully peaceful. There is no reason for anyone to question the democratic credentials of India."
Secretary Powell said a resumption of direct dialogue between India and Pakistan "is going to take some additional work." He added, "We're going to have to see some more additional changes on the ground, and I will just do everything I can to begin the talks to begin the talks." 
Secretary Powell said he would also raise with General Musharraf "the continued need to be vigilant with respect to Al Qaeda activities and Taliban activities drifting over the border into Pakistan."

HEADLINE: BUSH HAILS VOTE IN HOUSE BACKING TRADE LEGISLATION 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27 

 BODY:
The House of Representatives delivered a major victory to President Bush early this morning, narrowly voting to approve a broad trade package that gives him the authority to negotiate trade deals that he has called essential to economic growth.
 The razor-thin 215-to-212 vote came at 3:30 a.m., after a long evening of arm-twisting by Republican leaders and White House aides and hours after Mr. Bush himself made a rare appearance on Capitol Hill to lobby Republicans personally for a package that has been deadlocked for years. 
 Most Democrats supported organized labor's view that free trade is causing the loss of domestic manufacturing jobs. The vote was largely along party lines, with 27 Republicans voting against the measure and 25 Democrats supporting it. 
Representative Robin Hayes, a Republican from North Carolina, a textile state -- who provided the crucial vote last year when the House passed its original bill by just one vote -- voted no this time, with the vote tally showing that the president's victory was assured.
The vote came little more than 24 hours after House and Senate negotiators unexpectedly struck an agreement on compromise legislation late Thursday night to give the president the right to make trade deals that Congress could not change but only ratify or reject. The legislation also breaks significant new ground for workers. It creates a program of subsidized health insurance, in addition to other job training benefits for Americans who lose their jobs because of foreign competition. The measure calls for the government to pay 65 percent of the health insurance costs for such workers in the form of refundable tax credits.
With trade a highly partisan issue and with powerful crosscurrents in the House, Republican leaders refused to begin the August recess without action, fearful that the deal would become ever more difficult to pass as the elections approached and labor stepped up its pressure.
The trade negotiating authority has substantial support in the Senate, where its passage as early as next week seems nearly assured.
Mr. Bush hailed the House vote today, saying the authority would help reach trade agreements that "will open markets, expand opportunity, and create jobs for American workers and farmers."
But while the negotiating authority strengthens the White House's hand in presenting any agreement to Congress, negotiating major trade agreements remains a long and arduous process. The United States, Canada, Mexico and 31 other countries in the Western Hemisphere have been negotiating over a proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas since 1994. While a draft text of such an agreement has been published, it is full of the square brackets that indicate areas of continued dispute. The negotiating parties have declared as their goal the conclusion of an agreement by 2005, after the next presidential election.
The negotiating power Mr. Bush seeks was held by five earlier presidents but expired in 1994. President Bill Clinton never convinced Congress that the authority should be renewed, in part because of concern among Democrats that trade deals cost American jobs and lower environmental standards. Once Mr. Bush took office, the House passed trade authority by just one vote in December. The Senate later approved its version by a heftier margin, leading to negotiations that reached agreement on Thursday.
Passage was particularly sweet for Mr. Bush because he has been trying to shore up confidence in the stock market. He has argued that the trade bill will help the economy recover from last year's recession and the recent market gyrations even though the fruits of any trade deals are years away.
Another major agreement, on bankruptcy legislation, ran into an unexpected problem in the House, when anti-abortion Republicans rebelled against a provision that would prohibit people who attack or block access to abortion clinics from declaring bankruptcy to avoid paying court-ordered fines.
Short of the votes to pass the bill that would make it more difficult for consumers to declare bankruptcy to get out of paying debt, the House left for the summer without taking action, a delay that leaves the agreement's ultimate fact uncertain.
On the trade legislation, Mr. Bush, aware that the House vote would be critical to the pact, came to Capitol Hill on Friday to make his case personally to his party. But trade is always a difficult issue in the House, and even after Mr. Bush's direct intervention the outcome of the vote remained uncertain for hours. 
Senior administration officials including Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans and Robert B. Zoellick, Mr. Bush's chief trade negotiator, worked by the side of Republican officials in the Capitol trying to round up votes. The office of Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip, was the nerve center of the operation, and Mr. DeLay worked the House floor right up to the final outcome.
A series of spats and rebellions from testy lawmakers who were trying to leave for a monthlong August recess added to the uncertainty. "We have what is known in Texas as a running gun fight," Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, said as the outcome was still uncertain this morning.
Full-scale debate began only just before 2 a.m., with Democrats complaining bitterly about the hour. "The best time to bring up a historic bill is at 1 o'clock in the morning, to debate it until 3 in the morning," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, a New York Democrat.
While Democrats spoke out against job losses from trade, most Republicans said the measure would bring more economic growth and lower consumer prices. "We've fallen behind in terms of trade relationships because the president has not had this power," said Representative Bill Thomas of California, who as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee negotiated the deal.
Representative Jennifer Dunn, a Republican from export-dependent Seattle, argued that the bill would "enhance our competitiveness, create jobs and help bolster our economic recovery."
But some Republicans from textile states broke ranks and joined the opposition, fearful that free trade would cost textile jobs in their districts. "You're going to put some of my people out of business," said Representative Lindsey Graham of South Carolina. 
Although the pact was praised by the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, the House Democratic leadership was working to defeat it, side by side with organized labor. Democrats who were disappointed by the agreement argued that the health care tax credits did not ensure that displaced workers would be able to afford coverage in the private health market. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, said the measure failed to "enhance human rights, reaffirm worker rights and promote environmental protection."
Although Democrats knew that some of their moderates would support the measure, they wanted at the least to keep most of their party voting against the bill as a tactic to force Republicans from vulnerable textile and steel areas, where trade is less popular, to cast a "yes" vote that could be used against them in the election. Today labor officials vowed to try to defeat certain Republicans who had rallied around Mr. Bush. John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said, "Working people will hold them accountable for their decision in November." 
Besides providing Mr. Bush with new trade authority and workers with assistance, the trade measure had several other provisions. It would end most tariffs on imports from Colombia and other Andean nations and cut duties on goods from poor nations working to improve human rights.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 8, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on July 28 about the passage of a broad trade package by the House of Representatives referred imprecisely to the timing of the vote cast by Robin Hayes, Republican of North Carolina. Mr. Hayes, who opposed the measure, had told Republican leaders several hours before that he intended to vote no, according to aides. He did not wait until the final seconds to see if the Republicans needed his support in the vote, which was 215 to 212. The congressman's office asked in mid-August for a clarification, but the request was e-mailed to a vacationing reporter.

HEADLINE: Finding a Formula for Medicare Drug Benefits 

BYLINE:  By Marilyn Moon; Marilyn Moon is an economist at The Urban Institute and the author of the forthcoming "Medicare: A Policy Guide."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
The political debate over how to add a prescription drug benefit to Medicare has dragged on now for more than four years. Prescription drugs have become an integral part of health care delivery, but unlike insurance for most working families, the Medicare program for older and disabled people provides almost no drug coverage. Politicians from both parties know they have to do something, but the hurdles are big: money and control.
 The debate in the Senate is still ongoing. But large differences along party lines remain, and the Republican House plan that was passed on a party line vote in June makes hopes for compromise remote given the desires of consumers for broad coverage and of drug companies for minimal government controls. 
 The sums needed are enormous; over the next 10 years, Medicare beneficiaries are expected to spend $1.8 trillion for drugs. Thus, while the Senate Republicans' top offer of $370 billion over eight years is a lot of money, it represents only a bit more than one-fifth of drug spending over that period. The Republican plans contain big gaps in coverage and allow restrictions on what drugs will be covered. Democrats offer more coverage, but at a cost of $500 billion or more.
Since all proposed plans would be voluntary, those who spend relatively little on prescriptions need to be wooed into participating with the promise of receiving some benefits. Otherwise, only high users will enroll and any program will become very expensive over time.
All the competing plans offer generous coverage above a certain level of spending for those with catastrophic expenses. The differences arise in how to treat people who spend below the catastrophic level but still spend several thousand dollars annually on drugs. The Senate Democratic proposal requires beneficiaries to pay a portion of the costs, up to $4,000 a year. Beyond that limit, all drug costs are covered. But under the House Republican plan individuals must pay 100 percent of their drug expenses between $2,000 and $5,300.
Increasingly, many people on Medicare are ending up in this middle spending range, particularly those who take one or more drugs every day for a chronic condition. Drugs for such common ailments as hypertension, high cholesterol and arthritis cost $1,200 to $1,500 a year, creating a substantial financial burden for the chronically ill.
A viable compromise is to offer comprehensive coverage for those with low incomes and catastrophic help for all other beneficiaries, an approach that seems to be gaining favor in the Senate. But this plan would still cost about $400 billion, while providing little help for most Medicare recipients with chronic illnesses.
Money accounts for only part of the differences between the two parties. A big disagreement is over how the benefit is structured -- and the precedent it sets for Medicare's future. The Democratic approach basically would have Medicare pay for drugs the way it now pays for hospital and physician benefits. Republicans want instead to have the benefit offered by private insurers. Compromise on this ideological question is especially difficult.
The Democratic approach is simpler and relies on Medicare's well-tested structure. But drug manufacturers, fearing that Medicare would impose price controls on drugs, are strongly opposed to enlarging Medicare itself to cover drugs.
Supporters of a private insurance structure argue that only competition among plans can achieve substantial control over rising prescription drug costs. But this theory has not been proved in other contexts. The private managed-care option in Medicare, for example, has raised costs to the federal government. Meanwhile, many Medicare recipients have had to suffer with plans that cut benefits or, worse, are withdrawn altogether because the companies offering them have quit the Medicare program entirely for lack of profits.
A privately administered drug benefit would be particularly problematic. If private insurers carry the risk for drug costs, they will probably structure their plans in ways that put high users of drugs at a disadvantage. For example, they can establish a list of preferred drugs (a formulary) and either not cover certain drugs or charge more for drugs that are not on the list. There are, for example, many anti-cholesterol drugs, but a formulary may not include the drug that works best for a particular patient. Consumers who need many drugs are likely to find it hard to decipher which medications the plans will cover and at what cost.
Ultimately, lawmakers and the rest of us must decide whether we trust government to deliver a new drug benefit effectively. What we do know is that the need for drug coverage is too great to let this issue remain unresolved. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
Like Narcissus, executives are smitten, and undone, by their own images.

BYLINE:  By Tim Race 

 BODY:
THERE'S nothing wrong with a little self-esteem. It's grandiose delusion that causes all the trouble.
 How else to understand the case of the 78-year-old founder of Adelphia Communications, John J. Rigas, and his two sons? The three were led away in handcuffs last week by federal authorities, who accused them of "rampant self-dealing" and using Adelphia, a publicly held company, as a "personal piggy bank." If guilty as charged, the Rigases may represent yet another example of the narcissistic entitlement that permeated so many companies in recent years. 
 Few of the nation's executives now accused of fraud may have set out initially to break the law. What's more likely is that they became lost in a narcissistic fog in which they imagined that they were above the law -- that the rules no longer applied to people as grand as themselves. 
And so, if federal investigators are to be believed, we have seen narcissism on parade in a variety of costumes:
*The Rigases, the authorities say, took out loans to themselves using the company as collateral.
*Samuel D. Waksal, the socialite founder of ImClone Systems, is said to have given his friends and family stock guidance not available to hoi polloi.
*L. Dennis Kozlowski, one of the world's highest-paid executives as chief of Tyco International, had the wherewithal to spend $13 million for paintings by Renoir and others, but not the inclination to pay sales tax on them, according to the grand jury indictment.
*Scott D. Sullivan, the financial architect of WorldCom's wondrous ascent, is accused of buffing the books rather than risk tarnishing his image as a corporate wunderkind.
Narcissism isn't meant here as mere metaphor, but in the sense of the psychiatric personality disorder recognized and classified by the American Psychiatric Association. The condition is named for Narcissus, a beautiful youth in Greek mythology who fell in love with his own reflection and then pined away, not realizing the object of his fancy was a mere image. Beyond simple self-regard, the narcissistic disorder refers to a destructive pattern of thought and behavior whose traits include an unrealistic sense of one's importance and power, an excessive need for admiration and a lack of empathy for the feelings or needs of others.
Whether the Rigases or any of the other executives under indictment or investigation would clinically qualify for the narcissistic label, is beside the point: the stock bubble -- in which paper wealth created auras of power and invincibility -- seems to have bred an environment in which the narcissist who may lurk within many of us was able to emerge in feverish full bloom.
"It happens every decade; the proportion of these cases increases during times of market euphoria," observed Jay A. Conger. He is a professor at the London Business School and a widely published author on management behavior, whose 1990 article, "The Dark Side of Leadership," is widely cited in the literature of narcissism in the executive suite. (The article's case studies include the rise and fall of the charismatic entrepreneur John Z. DeLorean, whose DeLorean Motor Company's dubious books -- let the record show -- were audited by Arthur Andersen.)
Professor Conger, in an interview, said the "romance of leadership" that is common in the business world tends to put top executives on a pedestal.
"This can become a liability if the leaders begin to believe they are geniuses," he said, calling Enron a classic example. "They begin to believe they and their organizations are one-of-a-kind, that they're changing the face of industry. They desire entitlements beyond any other C.E.O.'s."
And if problems arise -- the debts mount, the revenues fall short of grandiose forecasts -- "the narcissists want to restore the image, they may do things to protect the image," he said. "And it may not be the C.E.O. who does the unethical things. It may be their subordinates, who want to protect the C.E.O. and themselves, who are in the ecosystem of narcissism."
The destructive nature of narcissism makes it "Malignant Self Love," according to Sam Vaknin, who has written a book by that title (Narcissus Publications, 1999), an overview of psychiatric narcissism. Mr. Vaknin, 41, who was born in Israel, now lives in Skopje, Macedonia, where he runs a Web site about the narcissistic personality disorder (http://samvak.tripod.com/) and is an economics correspondent for United Press International.
Mr. Vaknin's expertise stems in part from his having received a narcissistic personality diagnosis from a prison psychologist in Ramla, Israel, in 1996. Mr. Vaknin served 11 months there for engaging in stock manipulation while he was a well-known and widely celebrated director of an Israeli investment firm, Mikbatz Teshua.
In a lengthy e-mail dialogue, Mr. Vaknin declined to discuss the specifics of his own case, but he did offer his analysis of the narcissistic personality in the context of financial fraud.
"The narcissist lacks empathy -- the ability to put himself in other people's shoes," he wrote. "He does not recognize boundaries -- personal, corporate or legal."
"The narcissist regards himself as one would an expensive present: he is a gift to his company, to his family, to his neighbors, to his colleagues, to his country," Mr. Vaknin wrote, saying that such a person's sense of inflated importance and entitlement "makes him feel immune to mortal laws and somehow divinely protected and insulated from the inevitable consequences of his deeds and misdeeds."
To talk to the experts is to get the sense that narcissism is an occupational hazard of the corporate world. Ask David S. Gerson, a doctoral candidate at the University of Washington's business school, who is finishing his dissertation on narcissism in the workplace. When he first proposed the topic, Mr. Gerson recalls, his dissertation committee worried he would be unable to unearth enough examples of the grandiosely self-deluded. As it turns out, Mr. Gerson said, "it's fairly prevalent in organizations."
And while psychiatrists say that the narcissistic disorder tends to develop before or around age 4, when the afflicted may have trouble maturing beyond the me-centricism of early childhood, Mr. Gerson is among the business management researchers who argue that, in a conducive corporate culture, adults "can learn to be narcissists."
"Rather that thinking that these business people were evil to start with," Mr. Gerson says of the recent parade of rogues, "we should recognize that they were in a system that encouraged that behavior."
He, like Professor Conger, argues that because narcissism is a latent human condition that periodically flourishes, the only business antidote is oversight and accountability -- perhaps the sort of measures provided for in the corporate-conduct legislation Congress passed last week.
Of course, rules are one thing, effective enforcement quite another. It all depends on whether the narcissists are running the asylum.
Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been under fire lately from members of both political parties. But Mr. Pitt, who recently proposed a promotion and pay raise for himself even as his critics called for his resignation, has remained adamant that he is by far the best man for the job.
As Mr. Pitt put it in a recent interview with The New York Times, "it is an enormous advantage to the public to have somebody who knows about the securities business and the securities law as I do, and it would be unthinkable to deprive people of my expertise."
Monitoring this news from Skopje, Mr. Vaknin e-mailed that Mr. Pitt's was "one of the more narcissistic statements I ever came across."

HEADLINE: Technology Climate Is Gloomy, But Its Future Still Seems Bright 

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Given the free fall of technology stocks and the waves of layoffs and bankruptcies lately, now might seem an odd time to say this, but it's true: the digital revolution rolls on, and it may have only just begun.
 Yes, the technology industry appears to be a place of unrelieved gloom these days. Hopes for a modest recovery later this year were probably buried for good last Thursday when the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, the world's largest supplier of computer chips to other companies, delivered a surprisingly bleak outlook of weak demand for the second half of 2002. 
 Announcements come daily of companies cutting back on spending and payrolls, from struggling start-ups to industry stalwarts like Intel and I.B.M. By some measures, the slide in technology stocks since their peak in March 2000 now approaches the magnitude, in percentage terms, of the market collapse in the worst years of the Depression.
Clearly, a lot of the money, glamour and people have left the technology business. And yet, the technology itself continues to spread, in every way. 
That fact does not spell success for any particular company or justify high stock prices. But it does mean that over the long haul, the technology sector will generate more than its share of business opportunity and economic growth -- as it has since the 1960's, when computers appeared in big companies, universities and government agencies. Sure, excess capacity and price-cutting make the current business environment brutal for the producers. But not for the consumers. The numbers for the technology in use worldwide -- personal computers, cellphones, handhelds, digital cameras, DVD players, MP3 music players and households online -- all continue to grow apace.
And the expansion of the technology goes beyond digital devices. Increasingly, computer science has spilled over into other fields. Computing has helped transform everything from the way scientists plumb the mysteries of biology, chemistry and physics to the way Detroit designs cars and Hollywood makes movies. As it moves beyond traditional calculation, computer science is becoming more and more interdisciplinary, introducing the computing arts to a wider circle of people including more women.
And in good times or bad, the scientists, inventors, engineers and entrepreneurs -- the beating heart of the technology industry for decades -- are still in the game. It is such people who push the technology ahead on its uncertain but inexorable journey toward a few, often unanticipated, markets that prove to be lucrative -- despite the many inevitable failures along the way.
Dan Bricklin, 51, the co-inventor of the electronic spreadsheet nearly a quarter-century ago and still an active entrepreneur, observed last week, "The people who really have a love for this stuff -- the technology and what it can do -- never stop." 
Mr. Bricklin and Bob Frankston developed VisiCalc, a spreadsheet program, and began marketing it in 1979. VisiCalc was the first "killer app," or killer application, in the personal computer business -- an industry begun, notably, in the deep economic recession of the mid-1970's. The spreadsheet showed a practical, business use for the desktop machines. 
Over the years, Mr. Bricklin, a programmer and a graduate of the Harvard Business School, has followed his muse through a series of start-ups, mostly modest successes but some disappointments as well. In 1990, he was a founder of the Slate Corporation, which was to make software applications for pen-based computers, like those produced by Go and Apple's Newton. "The whole idea," Mr. Bricklin recalled, "was that pen computers would sell well," which they did not.
His current company, the Trellix Corporation, founded in 1995, produces and sells software that allows small businesses to build and operate their own Web sites. Its customers have included Cnet, Bizland, Terra Lycos and Thomas Register. In the last two months, Mr. Bricklin said, Trellix has seen a strong increase in business. "The Internet is a fantastic success, a force that has entered lives of regular people, and it is not going away," he said.
Venture capital investments, to be sure, are less than in the boom times of 2000. But the financing spigot is far from shut off. In the first two quarters of this year, venture investments -- mostly in information technology start-ups -- were running at a quarterly rate of about $6 billion, according to VentureWire Research, which tracks venture capital.
That level is way below the peak of $27.4 billion invested in the second quarter of 2000. But the recent rate is also 40 percent higher than at any time before the second quarter of 1999, going back more than a decade. 
Today, the fledgling companies that receive financing tend to be ones that sell useful technology that can save corporations money in basic data-processing chores like storage, security and network management. "Those companies are still doing well and getting money," said Richard Shaffer, editor in chief of VentureWire.
Softricity, a software start-up in Boston, has just received an additional $15 million in venture financing -- even though the company has adopted its technology, changed its name and overhauled its business model since it was founded in 1999. The technology grew out of software written for the Computer Museum in Boston, which distributed educational game software for children to many personal computers over a network. At the time, David Greschler, a founder of the company, was the director of exhibits at the museum.
The company retooled its technology into a service for downloading software from big Web portals, like ZD Net, and raised $22 million in the height of the dot-com bubble and called itself SoftwareWow.com. That idea soon looked doubtful, and the founders went back to the drawing board. They fine-tuned their software to make it a tool for running and managing software applications on PC's in corporate networks, and renamed the company Softricity, a utilitarian moniker, combining software and electricity.
For Mr. Greschler, the start-up experience has been an exhilarating education in the patience, persistence and flexibility required to be a technology entrepreneur. The appeal is to "take an idea you've worked on for years and try to get it over the line," he said. "We're not there yet, but we're moving in the right direction." 
The Siggraph convention in San Antonio last week provided a snapshot of both the slump and the long-term trend in technology. Attendance at the show, an annual gathering of the computer graphics community, was estimated at 20,000 to 25,000, down sharply from last year. "But the hard core is here and just as excited as it has always been," said Andy van Dam, a professor at Brown and a computer graphics pioneer.
Mr. van Dam recalled the trouble he had in 1960's when he set up a special interest committee for graphics within the association for computing machinery -- a move that led eventually to the huge Siggraph annual gatherings. Back then, he had a hard time finding 30 people to sign a petition, and the computer association was skeptical about granting committee status to computer graphics.
Today, Mr. van Dam says, a standard desktop PC, with a $200 graphics card, can render images of cinematic quality that five years ago could have been achieved only with a professional work station that might have cost hundreds of thousands of dollars. "We're talking about revolutionary progress, better than Moore's Law," Mr. van Dam said, referring to the observation years ago by Gordon Moore, a co-founder of Intel, that computer processing power doubles every 18 months. "And we're still at the beginning." 
Computer graphics is only one facet of computing, but it has become crucial to fields as diverse as crash-testing in the auto industry, molecular simulations in drug design and special effects in Hollywood. "Even the movies that are not science fiction are half digital," noted Rick Rashid, director of research at Microsoft. "Look at 'Gladiator.' You need the Roman Coliseum? You just build it digitally."
In one field after another, computing has made ever deeper and broader inroads, not just as a tool but as different approach to problem solving. Biology is perhaps the most obvious example, a discipline that moved out of the petri dish and onto the hard disk. The metaphor of human genome research is computational: humans are information processing machines, and DNA is the code that humans execute. "It's not data processing, it's a new view of biology," said Edward Lazowska, a professor at the University of Washington. "And that's happening all over. Computer science is pervading all other disciplines."
That has led to a lot more interdisciplinary work, so that these days much of what people do in various fields involves computer science, even though its practitioners do not think of themselves as computer geeks -- particularly among the generation that takes PC's and the Internet as much for granted as it does light bulbs and telephones.
A case in point is Jennifer Walk, 20, who is entering her junior year as an economics and math major at Yale this fall. Ms. Walk has programmed in C, C++ and some statistical-analysis programming languages. She likes the practical problem-solving of computing -- so different, she says, from the abstract theory of math. In fact, she took a summer job at Microsoft. 
But Ms. Walk says she has no interest in becoming a computer scientist. "I can't picture myself programming 8 or 10 hours a day as a career," Ms. Walk said. "And that's how I think of it."
Some university computer science departments have begun offering interdisciplinary programs. Partly as a result, the number of woman computer science graduates is inching up, although women still represent only 19 percent of those receiving bachelor's degrees in the field.
For many of this generation, computing often shapes the way they see the world and solve problems. "They think about the world in terms of information and information processing," said Seth Lloyd, a professor at M.I.T.
Seema Ramchandani, for example, entered Brown in 1998 and pursued a traditional pre-med program. "I wanted to be a doctor all my life," she explained. But after taking one of Mr. van Dam's courses as a sophomore, she changed her mind. Ms. Ramchandani, 20, will begin a master's program in the fall that combines computer science and neuroscience, which she describes as "more a computational view of what goes on in the brain."
Her research, she explained, is endlessly fascinating. "How can something so random work so well," she observed. "The brain is just a hack."
"You and I are quatranary," Ms. Ramchandani said, referring to the four letters, designated A, G, C and T, after the chemical units in DNA.
Pointing to a notebook computer in the room, she said, "And that's binary," a reference to the 1's and 0's of computer code.

HEADLINE: A National Snapshot 

 BODY:
Every decade, by order of the United States Constitution, America counts its inhabitants and, in the process, takes a valuable snapshot of itself. The 2000 national census instantly told us that the country had grown to almost four times the size it was a century ago. Now, as the Census Bureau reveals the richer details from that counting, we can find clues about exactly how the populace has changed. 
 One out of every nine residents is now foreign-born, and we have already seen some of the responses. On the one hand, politicians from coast to coast are signing up for Spanish lessons. On the other, radio ads in still-homogeneous states somberly warn that if the borders aren't closed, Des Moines will soon look like Los Angeles or New York. While that sort of improbable paranoia is hard to worry about, the extent of the xenophobia now infecting parts of Europe is a reminder of how important it is to stand behind the concept of the United States as a nation of immigrants. 
 The census also sent warnings about a more mundane problem -- traffic. More than three-quarters of Americans drive to work, with the average commute up from 22.4 minutes in 1990 to 25.5 minutes now. Monster traffic jams have spread to monster suburbs around cities like Atlanta. At some point, as the globe warms and the icecaps melt from burning fossil fuels, this nation of commuters will be steaming too long in their cars and will begin transferring their anger where it belongs -- to Congress and the White House.
The census also shows why health care has started to rank high on every poll of voters' concerns -- the nation is growing older as the steadily wrinkling baby boomer group adjusts the nation's median age upward to 35.3 years compared with 32.9 years a decade ago. Some areas of Florida have already begun outfitting ramps and slowing down stoplights for the elderly. The rest of the nation will soon have to follow.
Many Americans reported a dramatic improvement in their income by 2000, although their sense of good fortune may have taken a beating lately. But even at the height of the economic boom, the level of poverty showed little improvement -- a sign that the rising tide had left plenty of boats on shore.
