HEADLINE: With No Party to Call His Home, Golisano Bids for a Ballot Spot 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
In embarking on his third bid for governor, B. Thomas Golisano, a billionaire entrepreneur and founder of the state's Independence Party, has unleashed a campaign of lavish spending, a multipronged strategy to get a spot on the ballot and a goal apparently of frustrating Gov. George E. Pataki at every turn.
 This month the Golisano campaign began broadcasting a barrage of campaign commercials on television stations throughout the state. Despite his high visibility and his intention to spend huge sums -- he said he would put as much as $70 million of his own fortune toward the campaign -- the task remains for Mr. Golisano to find a way to get onto the November ballot. 
 For now Mr. Golisano, a Rochester businessman, appears to be immersed in several efforts to get on the ballot. Most prominently, he is taking on Mr. Pataki in the Sept. 10 primary of a highly fractured Independence Party. At the same time, he is trying to win the nomination of the state's Conservative Party through a write-in campaign. On still another front, he is pushing for an additional ballot line by trying to create yet another political party in the state. 
Although Mr. Golisano's chances of eventually winning the governor's race are widely dismissed by many political strategists, he is taken seriously for the ways in which he can be a nuisance to the two-term incumbent governor, mainly by using his vast resources to undermine Mr. Pataki's attempts to run on minor party lines.
Moreover, Mr. Golisano, a self-made billionaire who started the Rochester-based payroll services company Paychex and has been on Forbes's list of the 400 wealthiest Americans, has the potential to resonate with voters on some issues. His background as a political outsider with business acumen, which he is tirelessly promoting in television ads, allows his campaign to evoke many of the themes that Michael R. Bloomberg used in his bid for New York City mayor last year.
Mr. Golisano's criticisms of the governor may also help him connect with some voters. He has contended that Mr. Pataki failed to reform education and campaign finance and that he has done nothing to stoke the economy upstate. Mr. Golisano is expected to use a good portion of his $70 million in campaign spending on ads with an anti-Pataki theme.
Mr. Golisano did not respond to several requests for an interview. But Roger Stone, his consultant, said that Mr. Golisano's message would resonate particularly well with voters in the western part of the state as well as those upstate, on Long Island and in the suburbs of New York City. He added that Mr. Golisano could easily win the Independence Party primary because of widespread discontent about taxes and the economy upstate.
"The Golisano voters are overwhelmingly middle-income people who are squeezed by the highest income, sales and property taxes in the country," Mr. Stone said.
Although Mr. Golisano has mounted what many political observers describe as an intense effort win the votes of the Independence Party's registered members, many suggest that winning the primary of a party he founded eight years ago remains a challenge for him. 
"It's clearly an uphill battle for him," said Evan Stavisky, a political consultant who works mainly with Democratic candidates. "His allies within the Independence Party have lost control of the grass-roots level, which inherently makes this an uphill battle."
The Golisano camp may face another hurdle. Not only are many registered Independence Party members unaware a a primary is scheduled, Mr. Stavisky said, but many are also not even aware that they are in the party. The number of registered Independence Party members has soared to nearly 220,000 from about 130,000 in the 1998 gubernatorial race. But Mr. Stavisky and other political strategists suggest that many people registered for the party mistakenly, believing that they were identifying themselves as "independent, and thus unaffiliated with any party."
"You have people who don't know they are in a party," Mr. Stavisky said, "and getting them to participate in a party primary is difficult." 
What is clear is that there is a political war between the Golisano and Pataki camps. Mr. Golisano's campaign has taken the unusual step of supporting two different candidates for lieutenant governor, on two different minor party lines. His choice for the Independence Party is Bill Nield. For the Conservative Party line, he is supporting Dan Mahony (no relation to J. Daniel Mahoney, the party's founder). 
Mr. Pataki's main ballot line is that of the Republican Party, where his running mate is Lt. Gov. Mary O. Donohue. Under state law, should Mr. Pataki appear on either the Independence or the Conservative lines with a lieutenant governor candidate other than Ms. Donohue, the votes he got on those lines would not count toward his overall total. So Mr. Golisano could fail in his attempt to get on those two party lines but by supporting his own candidates for lieutenant governor he could still deny Mr. Pataki votes on them.
"It's one of those weird quirks in the state election law that plays brilliantly into the hands of Tom Golisano," Mr. Stavisky said. "It's clearly an attempt to make life difficult for George Pataki."
But Mr. Stone said that his motivation was to allow voters in the Conservative and Independence Parties to choose their own nominees for lieutenant governor. "There is not going to be a coronation of George Pataki," Mr. Stone said. "There will be two primaries. Why does the idea of an open election terrify these Pataki people so much?"
Mr. Pataki's campaign complicated matters for Mr. Golisano last week by filing a lawsuit in State Supreme Court in Rochester, charging that 15 workers hired by the Golisano campaign to collect signatures in his effort to get on a ballot line were residents of Florida, rather than New York, as required. The Pataki campaign has asked that Mr. Golisano's petition forms be invalidated.
"The law is that the signatures have to be collected by citizens of New York, and Tom Golisano didn't do that," said Mollie Fullington, a spokeswoman for the governor. "Nobody should be able to break the law."
Mr. Stone said that the suit is frivolous and is intended to be an annoyance by the Pataki campaign. "It's just a Republican dirty trick that is designed to intimidate voters from signing the petitions." He said that under the law, those who collect signatures need only to "work or have an office" in the area they are canvassing. 
Pataki campaign officials insist that Mr. Golisano does not pose a credible threat in the Independence Party primary nor in the general election, should he prevail in any effort to secure a ballot line. They point to the fact that in his earlier races, in 1994 and 1998, Mr. Golisano never won more than 8 percent of the vote.
"The governor has strong support among the electorate," said Kieran P. Mahoney, a senior adviser to Mr. Pataki. "And he has the same level of support among registered Independents. I think the governor is in strong shape in this primary."
Clearly, the Independence Party primary represents a potent means of gaining a spot on the November ballot, since the party members range across a broad political spectrum, from Mr. Golisano himself, a businessman, to Lenora Fulani, a neo-Marxist and former leader of the New Alliance Party.
But even the campaign for the Independence nomination is highly complicated. Mr. Golisano's support among rank-and-file Independence Party voters has apparently waned, his support at the convention shows, and his supporters have fought bitterly over party rule reform with a party faction that calls itself the "Democracy Coalition." And while he secured enough votes to earn a spot on the party's primary ballot, he got just 30 percent of the votes at the party convention. Even the party's state chairman, Frank MacKay, is supporting Mr. Pataki.
"Golisano eked out 30 percent of the vote that is weighted heavily toward the Rochester area, where Golisano is strong," said Jacqueline Salit, an Independence Party state committee member and the spokeswoman for the party in New York City. "On a one-person, one-vote basis, he would have received 18 percent."
Mr. Golisano faces a deadline in about two weeks for gathering signatures for the Conservative Party nomination. But the most promising step for Mr. Golisano may be forming yet another political party, the same method he used when he established the Independence Party eight years ago. To form a party it is necessary to secure the signatures of 15,000 registered voters in the state by mid-August.
For now, the question is what kind of turnout the Golisano and Pataki camps will achieve in the Sept. 10 primary. An Independence Party primary for attorney general four years ago drew fewer than 3,500 voters. But this year, with strong television advertising and a strong voter registration drive by both campaigns, along with interest in the fiercely competitive Democratic gubernatorial primary no one seems certain what will occur.
"It's an important primary to both campaigns, and both campaigns have a lot of money to identify who the Independence voters are," said Jerry Skurnik, a partner in Prime New York, a political consulting firm. 
"But the fact is, it's uncharted water and no one quite knows what will happen."

HEADLINE: Side Effect of Welfare Law: The No-Parent Family 

BYLINE:  By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
When studies last year showed that the share of the nation's children living in single-parent households had declined in the late 1990's, many welcomed the results as signs that the 1996 welfare overhaul was working.
 But new research underscores a smaller, unwelcome trend: a rising share of children, particularly black children in cities, are turning up in no-parent households, left with relatives, friends or foster families without either their mother or their father. 
 Researchers say they cannot pinpoint the forces driving parents and children apart. But among them, they said, may be the stresses of the new welfare world -- loss of benefits, low-wage jobs at irregular hours and pressure from a new partner needed to pay the rent.
The findings are helping reopen the debate on what shifting welfare rules are doing to families. They are contributing to second thoughts among some of the most optimistic analysts, even as the White House and some lawmakers are pushing to make the welfare law's work requirements even stricter. The law now requires 50 percent of welfare recipients to work up to 30 hours a week, with some exceptions for hardship. 
One important study of census data in each state, recently presented to an audience of welfare experts at Harvard, concluded that among those most affected by the welfare changes -- black children in central cities -- the share living without their parents had more than doubled on average, to 16.1 percent from 7.5 percent, when researchers controlled for other factors.
"What we're seeing is the complex relationship between this thing we call welfare reform and the impact on families," said Wade F. Horn, the Bush administration official who oversees the welfare program. "In some cases we see positive effects on family structures, and in other cases we see more children living in no-parent families." 
Mr. Horn said new welfare demands might expose an unfit parent whose children are better off in foster care. On the other hand, he added, a West Virginia mother told to seek work in Ohio may feel obliged to leave a child behind to finish school.
"What it tells us," he said, "is that we need to do an even better job on understanding the complexities of these programs on real people."
In a support group in the Bronx, grandparents raising grandchildren spoke of the many pressures their families faced. Linda Woods, for example, finds it easy to understand how a decline in households with single mothers and a rise in children living apart from both parents could be two sides of a coin.
Ms. Woods's daughter, a sickly high school dropout who once worked in sales, supported her own daughter, China, on welfare after the girl's father abandoned them. Unable to work in exchange for benefits, she eventually qualified for Social Security disability payments and found a boyfriend with a job.
"She got married to him too quick," Ms. Woods recalled. "I tried to tell her, 'You're making a big mistake.' " Two years ago, she added, China, then 7, telephoned from her mother's home in Queens, begging to be rescued from conflicts with her stepfather.
Now Ms. Woods, 53 and retired because of ill health, is struggling to care for China without any public aid. China's mother, with a second child to support, has separated from her husband. 
Last year, analysts at the nonpartisan Urban Institute reported that the share of children in the United States living in households without their parents rose to 3.5 percent, or 2.3 million children, in 1999, from nearly 3.1 percent, or 1.8 million children, in 1997, a significant increase. 
Recently Greg Acs, an author of an upbeat Urban Institute report last year on the rise in two-adult households, titled "Honey, I'm Home," took a second look at his study's unreported results and found that among low-income children, a population more likely to be affected by welfare changes, the share living with neither parent had risen to 5.7 percent in 1999, from 4.7 percent in 1997, double the overall increase.
"If the first story is the decline in kids in single-parent households, then the next story is, where are they going?" Mr. Acs said. 
Many, if not most, he said, are living with two parents or a mother and boyfriend. But, he added, "vulnerable children in vulnerable families are increasingly likely to be in no-parent households." 
The author of another report on the increase in children in two-adult families, Wendell Primus, now says he has a more nuanced view of his findings. His optimistic take had been particularly influential because he resigned in 1996 as deputy assistant secretary of Health and Human Services to protest what he feared would be the severe impact of the welfare overhaul on children.
"An individual child is sometimes better off living with grandmother, but as a societal matter, more kids living with neither parent can't be viewed as a good thing," Mr. Primus said. 
Children who do not live with their parents do significantly worse on average than those in single-parent homes, child welfare experts say, with higher rates of school failure, mental health problems and delinquency.
Some researchers, however, are not persuaded that the upturn in such children is tied to welfare changes. The share of children living without their own parents has fluctuated in the past, with peaks linked to the crack epidemic, AIDS and recessions.
But the economists at the University of California and the Rand Corporation who analyzed the impact of welfare changes on children's living arrangements found a very strong link. Comparing Census Bureau surveys before and after different welfare changes in all 50 states throughout the 1990's, and controlling for other economic factors, they found that on average the share of black children living in cities without their parents more than doubled after the changes even as the share with an unmarried mother dropped to an average of 51 percent from 64 percent. 
The effects, researchers calculated, translate into about 200,000 more black, urban children living without a parent.
In contrast, weaker results for Hispanics more consistently fulfilled the intentions of legislators, said Hilary Hoynes, an economist and an author of the study: Hispanic mothers were more likely to be married after welfare changes, and Hispanic children somewhat less likely to live in a single-parent home but no more likely to live without their own parents.
Other researchers suggested that the contrast could partly reflect changing Hispanic immigration, higher marriage and fertility rates by recent immigrants and different cultural traditions in coping with adversity.
One lesson emerging from other recent research, said Doug Besharov, a scholar at the conservative American Enterprise Institute, is that cumulative figures can mask very different, even contradictory effects for different groups and hide the impact of rules that vary from county to county.
"It's an incomplete puzzle," Mr. Besharov said. 
The life stories shared in the Bronx grandparents' group help resolve some of the seeming contradictions. 
Margaret King, 64, a retired telephone worker with custody of two of her five grandchildren, said that when her daughter lost welfare benefits, the young woman had to depend more on her children's mentally ill, drug-abusing father.
At one point, Ms. King said, after the family was evicted from their Queens apartment and placed in a temporary shelter in the Bronx, the mother became desperate to keep her welfare-to-work job at the city's Human Resources Administration in Lower Manhattan. She left three children with their father at the shelter for lack of a baby sitter, and the youngest, a brain-damaged toddler, cut himself badly on an open can while the father was sleeping off a drinking binge. The mother, who has already turned over her two older children to their grandmother, was charged with neglect and is now at risk of losing the others to foster care.
"She was always a good mother," the grandmother said. "She had no choice, and the system didn't help her."
The King family's experience was echoed in a report last month by Mathematica Policy Research Inc., a nonpartisan research organization. Its study of Iowa's stringent welfare-to-work program found that 7.2 percent of applicants randomly assigned to the program in March 1997 had a child in foster care two years later, compared with only 3.2 percent among those randomly assigned to a control group under the old welfare rules. 
Robert Lerman, a researcher at the Urban Institute known for his work on the benefits of marriage, said there was no consensus on the effects of welfare changes on family structure. He was disappointed recently himself, he said, when he sought confirmation of Mr. Primus's earlier finding that the share of black children living with married parents had jumped to 38.9 percent in 2000 from 34.8 percent in 1995. 
Looking at newly formed black families in the Urban Institute's large, nationally representative sample, Mr. Lerman instead found a drop in the share of children under a year old living with married parents, to only 26 percent in 1999, from an already low 36 percent in 1997.
Over all, Census Bureau surveys indicate that the number of people in female-headed households declined to 27.4 million in 2000, from 29.2 million in 1995, Mr. Primus said.
But, he added, the number mainly seems to reflect "doubling up and coupling up out of economic necessity, the way poor people have historically managed," a pattern that includes leaving children with relatives.
"The number is still truly astonishing," he said, "but I think the implications of this number are not as rosy as just the number would seem."

HEADLINE: Is Economic Double Dip Lurking on the Horizon? 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
Only once in the last half-century, 20 years ago, has the United States suffered two recessions in quick succession. Now, the recent plunge in the stock market and a cooler economy have generated a debate about whether history will soon repeat itself.
 The most recent recession, many economists agree, ended late last year. In the first half of this year, the economy -- including housing, retail spending and industrial production -- recovered nicely. 
 But some economists are increasingly concerned about the prospect of a relapse in 2002, a "double dip" recession. 
Leading the list of fresh worries is the downturn in the stock market, which has fallen by roughly 20 percent in two months. The long slide in portfolio values could hurt consumer spending, which has been the economy's most robust support.
Volatile businesses like high technology and telecommunications, once at the vanguard of economic growth and stock gains, are also struggling.
"Although many companies had decent second-quarter earnings, outlooks came crashing down," wrote Steven M. Milunovich, a Merrill Lynch analyst, of profit reports last week from technology companies.
Dell Computer said its market was likely to remain sluggish. Intel, the leading maker of computer chips, now expects the only improvement in the third quarter to come from typical yearly buying patterns, rather than outright shifts in demand. After WorldCom's flameout, investors are questioning the solvency of some other telecommunications companies as well.
Even companies with good outlooks are having trouble raising money. There has been little more than a trickle of new stock offerings for more than a year, and short-term credit has been scarce except for the most-sound companies. Recently, long-term bond deals have also become harder to sell.
"You start monkeying around with the supply of credit, and things can change pretty quickly," said Stephen D. Slifer, the co-chief United States economist at Lehman Brothers. "It's not only a stock market event anymore, it's starting to spill over into capital markets more generally."
Despite the disappearance of about $7 trillion in portfolio wealth since the stock market peaked, consumers have not cracked.
But they have certainly become more cautious. Sales of existing homes and big-ticket items like washing machines slowed in June, as consumer confidence slid markedly, according to surveys by the University of Michigan. Stories abound of lost business at restaurants and shrinking retirement portfolios.
All this is enough evidence for some economists to conclude that another recession could come soon. But others say the economy is unlikely to sag quickly into recession.
"I look at the stock market on one side and go, 'Boy, this is ugly,' " Mr. Slifer said. "And then I go, 'Wait a minute, there's nothing really happening.' "
A potent mix of low interest rates, lower taxes, high productivity growth and vanishing inflation, Mr. Slifer said, will probably propel the economy into another upswing.
But lately, the disagreement among economic forecasters about what will happen next has widened. 
For example, the team at J. P. Morgan now thinks the economy will grow by 4 percent this year after a strong second half. By contrast, Stephen S. Roach, the chief economist of Morgan Stanley, says it is likely that the economy will fall into another recession by December.
Much of the discrepancy stems from a difference of opinion over whether consumers will rein in their spending. As stocks rose in value during the last two decades, the economy was supercharged by an extra boost in consumption. On the way down, though, consumption has not deteriorated significantly -- at least not yet.
"We definitely think that there's going to be feedback from the stock market weakness back to the real economy," said William C. Dudley, the chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "It's hard to know if that's going to happen quickly or slowly, but it has to happen. We're not expecting a double dip, but we're definitely worried about it."
Mr. Dudley says he expects the economy to grow by about 2.4 percent this year, but he sees more risks of worse than better outcomes.
In the past, some economists estimated that as much as 5 percent of the changes in stock market wealth translated into consumers' spending. So a 20 percent drop in the stock market might generate a dip in consumption of about 1 percent, or $70 billion to $80 billion.
But a senior government economist says he thinks the amount is far smaller. "It's on the order of a few tenths of a percent off growth of G.D.P.," he said, referring to gross domestic product.
Robert J. Gordon, a professor at Northwestern University who serves on the committee monitoring the business cycle at the National Bureau of Economic Research, is also skeptical that the stock market's plunge will knock consumers seriously off their stride. He says he expects lower interest rates to encourage new spending, especially as homeowners continue to lower their monthly mortgage payments by refinancing home loans.
Refinancing gave back about $100 billion to household incomes in 2001 and could add $50 billion this year, said Robert A. Van Order, chief international economist at Freddie Mac, a government-sponsored buyer of mortgages. "Whether people refinance or not, there's been a lot of wealth created by the increase in house prices," Mr. Van Order added.
Professor Gordon, who recently refinanced his home, said that the refinancing activity could offset the negative effect of the stock market. "If you get an $80 billion loss from the stock market, and you get an $80 billion push from refinancing, it's a wash," he said.
Furthermore, much of the nation's stock market wealth is locked up in retirement funds, Professor Gordon said. Because consumers hold those funds for the long term, he reasoned, they might simply assume that stocks would gain back much, if not all, of their value in time for retirement.
It is also worth noting that the "double dip" in the early 1980's was an extraordinary event. The Federal Reserve's crusade to quell the rampant inflation of the 1970's led the economy into recession, beginning in January 1980. In March, President Jimmy Carter asked the Fed to impose emergency credit controls, which panicked consumers so much that the economy fell even more sharply. But as soon as he released the controls that summer, interest rates dropped and the economy started to recover.
Double-digit inflation resumed, and the Fed fought back by sending interest rates higher again. Without low interest rates to stimulate a recovery, the economy fell into recession in July 1981.
So there is much more to the economy than just the stock market. Just ask the men who turn the dials of economic policy in Washington. In two speaking appearances last week, Paul H. O'Neill, the Treasury secretary, emphasized the strength of automobile and home sales, both hovering near record levels for months, and manufacturers' success in trimming inventories. He predicted that the economy would grow by 3 to 3.5 percent this year.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, says he thinks the economy could do even better this year. In testimony before Congress earlier this month, he talked of gains in worker productivity as a sure route to higher corporate profits and rising wages, which would lead to more spending by businesses and consumers.
Professor Gordon, once an outspoken skeptic of predictions of permanently higher productivity growth, now is a believer. "It's pretty hard to pin it down, but it looks like the trend growth of productivity has increased since 1995 from 1.4 percent to somewhere between 2 and 2.5 percent," he said. "Everybody has nudged up their estimate of that trend."
While many economists play down the risk of a double-dip recession this year, some investors still worry that the United States is in for a prolonged period of slow growth of the sort Japan experienced during the last decade.
But that turn of events is unlikely, said Richard B. Berner, the chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley. He noted that the American economy reallocates workers and capital much more quickly than Japan's.
"There are a lot of companies in Japan that are technically bankrupt or insolvent right now that the Japanese won't let go out of business," he said. "Correspondingly, the Japanese have not been willing to write off bad loans."
Though the collapse of stock market wealth will put a dent in the economy, he said, American companies and investors have reacted quickly to reverses. "We don't let things fester over long periods of time," Mr. Berner said.
Lower taxes, bigger federal spending and low interest rates should prevent the United States from lapsing into deflation as Japan did, he says.
Indeed, Mr. Berner said his colleague at Morgan Stanley, Mr. Roach, had still not managed to convince him that a double dip was a certainty, though he now gives it a 40 percent chance. It will be some time until the danger passes, he added.
"You're going to see the residue in this post-bubble environment," he said. "You're not going to feel safe until next year."

HEADLINE: Poughkeepsie Journal; 
Adding Life and Color To a Once-Faded City

BYLINE:  By LISA W. FODERARO

DATELINE: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. 

 BODY:
It seems an unlikely marriage: Peter Max, the psychedelic art phenomenon from the 1960's, and this faded river city.
 But Mr. Max, who is still going strong, has set his sights on a building here to house his creative vision, and city leaders are hoping that he will do for Poughkeepsie what the Andy Warhol Museum did for Pittsburgh. 
 As recently as the 1990's, Poughkeepsie was virtually written off. Its population had dropped by a third since mid-century. Ten people were slain in its four square miles in a single year. And Main Street, with a deserted pedestrian mall, was a listless tableau, marked by empty storefronts with dated signs. 
But within the past year, driven by surging property values across Dutchess County and a focus by the city government on revitalization, Poughkeepsie is showing not only a pulse, but actual promise.
This spring, the Mid-Hudson Children's Museum moved into an empty building on the waterfront next to Waryas Park, where the city has installed a walkway and old-fashioned lighting.
Nearby, the 1918 train station was renovated with new signs, and next to the station the Metro-North Railroad completed an $18 million parking garage, with a design that appears plucked from an Impressionest painting.
"It's the Taj Mahal of parking garages," said Robert Dooley, who is redeveloping a vacant Victorian building by the train station into offices, stores and restaurants. "It's hard to imagine that you want your building to look like a parking garage, but they made a statement there."
Another developer, Joseph A. Bonura, who owns the Poughkeepsie Grand Hotel, is working with the city to transform a 13-acre brownfield, an abandoned industrial site on the river, into a mixed-use complex to include a boutique hotel, restaurants, a catering business, office space and a marina. He said he hoped to build offices, condominiums and a restaurant on an additional 13 acres.
"There's nothing on the waterfront," said Mr. Bonura, who opened a successful restaurant last year across the Hudson River in Newburgh, another moribund city that has recently breathed new life. "Since 9/11, a lot of people are looking for office space up this way."
Clearly the sexiest development on the horizon is taking place a bit inland -- along the stretch of Main Street where the city ripped out the pedestrian mall last fall.
The old Luckey Platt department store, a wedding-cake of a building that once anchored the downtown but that has sat idle for 15 years, a symbol of the city's woes, will soon be in the hands of Mr. Max, who has reached an agreement with the city to take it over for $1.
Mr. Max said he wanted to fashion a small museum and cultural center out of the 150,000-square-foot structure. The museum would feature his own work and that of other modern artists, while the center would offer courses and forums on everything from the creative process to animal protection to the environment.
Plans also call for the building to include artists' lofts on the upper floors and a restaurant on the ground floor. "It's a wonderful structure, a tremendous blank canvas for me," said Mr. Max, whose successful studio in Manhattan employs 105 people. The project would cost in excess of $20 million to develop, he said.
Asked if he was concerned about the vacancies and depressed aura that still color the business district, Mr. Max said: "I think that will change in a minute. I have already heard that there are many people optioning sites all around the building."
Mr. Max, who owns property across the river in Woodstock, said he had been searching for a property in St. Louis to house a museum when he learned of the Luckey Platt property from a friend in Poughkeepsie. Then the mayor, Colette M. Lafuente, showed up at his door.
"The mayor came to see me at my studio," Mr. Max recalled, "and she was very, very excited and showed me a picture of a very large building and she said I could have it."
No single event set Poughkeepsie on a downward spiral. Rather, a number of forces conspired against the city: the carving up of neighborhoods to build highways; the creation of the dreary pedestrian mall; competition to local stores from regional malls; employee cutbacks by I.B.M., a major employer; and the city's decision to level charming neighborhoods and replace them with public housing.
And despite the fledgling renaissance, many problems persist. There is still no supermarket for the 29,000 residents. The median household income is $29,389, compared with $53,086 nationally. The percentage of families living below the poverty line rose to 18 percent in 2000, from 11 percent in 1990.
Still, many in this city credit Mrs. Lafuente, who lost her husband on Sept. 11, for bringing Poughkeepsie back from the brink, in part by embracing the arts.
"Colette has just been a fireball here for the city," said Chris Silva, executive director of the Bardavon 1869 Opera House, a 944-seat theater that has featured such varied artists as Patti Smith and the Moscow Ballet. "She's an incredible optimist, and it's contagious. You need that in a city like this."
The Bardavon, where Mark Twain lectured during its inaugural year, has itself experienced something of a rebirth, drawing 120,000 visitors annually, up from 40,000 in 1994. Its facade has been restored, complete with a glittering new marquis, a replica of one from the 1920's.
Besides focusing on real estate development and the arts, Mayor Lafuente and the city's Common Council have addressed crime. The city has doubled its police budget since Mayor Lafuente took office in 1996 and added 20 officers for a total of 100. There have been two murders so far this year, both drug-related -- nothing to crow about, but still an improvement over recent years.
"That has been key," she said. "People have to feel safe. I have one more year as mayor because I'm term-limited, and I keep hoping for one year without a murder."
There is another encouraging sign. People are moving in, not out: for the first time in a half century, according to the 2000 census, the population actually rose, if ever so slightly. "There's a turnaround," said James A. Marquette, the city administrator. "We have a good way to go, but it's visible. It's not just talk."

Along Main Street, right, a number of buildings are being fixed up. HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
HAMPTON, COLIN CAMPBELL

 BODY:
 HAMPTON-Colin Campbell. Of Amelia Island, Florida, a former Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of UNUM Corporation, parent company of UNUM Life Insurance Company, died on Wednesday, July 24, 2002, in a local hospital. Mr. Hampton died after heart surgery. He was 79. Under Mr. Hampton's chairmanship, UNUM became the first mutual life insurance company of size to "demutualize" officially converting from a mutual company to a publically owned company listed on the New York Stock Exchange. In the process, the company's surplus was distributed to its policy holders in part in cash and in part in stock amounting to a total distribution of roughly $652 million. Mr. Hampton was a true visionary. From the time he became CEO in 1970, until his retirement in 1988, UNUM's assets substantially increased from $270 million to over $7 billion. Profits increased over this time period from $2.5 million to $125 million. The company gained reputation as the leading seller of Long Term Disability Income and the only insurance company with a dominant position in both Group and Individual Disability Income. Mr. Hampton was born in New Haven, Connecticut, the son of the late George Wellington and Jean Stewart Hampton. He graduated from Vanderbilt University, attended New York University Graduate School of Economics; received an M.B.A. from the University of Maine and an honorary Doctor of Science in Business Administration from Thomas College. He served in the U.S. Air Force in World War II as a First Lieutenant, receiving the European Air Medal with Oak Leaf Clusters. 
He married his college sweetheart, Marjorie Alice Brown, of Savannah, Georgia, in June 1951. Mr. Hampton first entered the investment business in 1949 in New York as a security analyst with Bankers Trust. In 1956, he joined Union Mutual Life Insurance Company in Portland, Maine, as a security analyst in the Investment Department. Mr. Hampton quickly moved up in the company, finally becoming Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer in 1970. Mr. Hampton served the state of Maine in numerous ways. He was a Director and Chairman of the Chamber of Commerce in the Greater Portland region, Chairman of the Maine Committee on the Judicial Responsibility and Disability, and Chairman for the Greater Portland United Way Campaign and Cumberland County Chairman for the March of Dimes. He served as co-chairman of the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum's "Campaign to Remember," Maine State Campaign, raising a then record $1.3 million. He was the Maine State Chairman for the U.S. Olympics. Mr. Hampton received the Eleventh Annual Pine Tree Distinguished Citizen Award for his outstanding contribution to the community. Mr. Hampton served as a Director of Colonial Life and Accident Insurance Co., American Council of Life Insurance, Life Office Management Association, Central Maine Power Company, Key Trust Company of Maine, Peoples Heritage Bank, Maine Medical Center, Portland Boys' Club and Associated Industries of Maine. He was a senior member of the Conference Board, a Trustee of the Maine Court Facilities Authority, Westbrook College, New England College Fund, Inc., and MGI Properties, Inc. He was Chairman of the Health Insurance Association of America and for Vanderbilt University for the state of Maine. He was a member of the Portland Country Club, the Cumberland Club, the Newcomen Society, the Torch Club of Western Maine, the Cabinet of Vanderbilt University, the Amelia Island Plantation Ocean Club and St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Amelia Island. He was an avid golfer and proud of his two holes-inone. He is survived by his loving wife Marjorie Brown Hampton, a son, Colin C. Hampton Jr., of Sea Ranch Lakes, Florida, and a daughter, Carolyn Hampton LoRusso, of Medfield, Massachusetts, as well as four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM, July 31, at St. Peter's Episcopal Church. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to College of Arts and Science at Vanderbilt University, West End Avenue, Nashville, Tennessee.

HEADLINE: A Failure of Democracy, Not Capitalism 

BYLINE:  By Benjamin R. Barber; Benjamin R. Barber is a professor of political philosophy at the University of Maryland and the author of "Jihad vs. McWorld."

 BODY:
Congress passed sweeping legislation to reform corporate conduct and governance last week, and President Bush has pledged to sign it. A mere two months ago, the prospects for such broad reform were grim, as Congressional Republicans and the president himself favored a more limited approach.
 The new law -- among other reforms, it creates an independent oversight board for the accounting industry and curbs executive abuses like sweetheart loans -- may appear to be the reassertion of the public will over private interests. But it fails to address the deeper scandal: the real cause of spreading corporate malfeasance in America is a lack of faith in democratic institutions themselves. 
 Politicians on both sides of the aisle long insisted the scandals could be traced to a few rotten apples in an otherwise healthy barrel; a few radicals worry that the barrel itself (the capitalist system) is rotten. But business malfeasance is the consequence neither of systemic capitalist contradictions nor private sin, which are endemic to capitalism and, indeed, to humanity. It arises from a failure of the instruments of democracy, which have been weakened by three decades of market fundamentalism, privatization ideology and resentment of government.
Capitalism is not too strong; democracy is too weak. We have not grown too hubristic as producers and consumers; we have grown too timid as citizens, acquiescing to deregulation and privatization (airlines, accounting firms, banks, media conglomerates, you name it) and a growing tyranny of money over politics.
The corrosive effects of this trend are visible not only on Wall Street. The Bush administration, which favors energy production over energy conservation, has engineered a reversal of a generation of progress on environmentalism that threatens to leave the Superfund program underfunded, air-quality standards compromised and global warming unchecked. These policies can be traced directly to that proud disdain for the public realm that is common to all market fundamentalists, Republican and Democratic alike. Such attitudes represent a penchant for a go-it-alone economics that undermines the social contract and turns corporate sins into virtues of the bottom line.
Even in foreign policy, where unilateralism and the repudiation of partnerships might suggest a muscular governmental policy, there is a tendency to treat the international sector as a Hobbesian "state of nature," anarchic and disorderly, where "force and fraud are cardinal virtues" and the life of men is "nasty, brutish and short."
The United States fails to see that the international treaties it won't sign, the criminal court it will not acknowledge and the United Nations system it does not adequately support are all efforts, however compromised, at developing a new global contract to contain the chaos. The American belittlement of these efforts betrays a strategy that enhances global anarchy in the name of preserving national sovereignty. Thus the new global disorder is as incapable of constraining global crime as the deregulated domestic market is incapable of containing corporate crime.
Market fundamentalism, which defined the era of Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher, encourages a myth of omnipotent markets. But this is as foolish and wrong-headed as the myth of omnipotent states, which reigned from the New Deal to the Great Society. It tricks people into believing their own common power represents some bureaucrat's hegemony over them, and that buying power is the same as voting power. But consumers are not citizens, and markets cannot exercise democratic sovereignty.
The ascendant market ideology claims to free us, but it actually robs us of the civic freedom by which we control the social consequences of our private choices. We are unlikely to achieve a genuinely public and democratic plan for the World Trade Center site, for example, by polling the myriad private interests with a stake in the development of the site. Democracy is more than consumer polling. It demands the consideration not only of what individuals want (private choosing) but also of what society needs (public choosing).
The truth is that runaway capitalists, environmental know-nothings, irresponsible accountants, amoral drug runners and antimodern terrorists all flourish because we have diminished the power of the public sphere. By privatizing government functions and refusing to help create democratic institutions of global governance, America has relinquished its authority to control these forces. Within the United States, we foolishly think we possess a private liberty that allows us to work and prosper individually, not together or in conformity with a social contract. In the international realm, we seem to believe that our claim to national sovereignty allows us to operate unilaterally -- America first and foremost, not together or in conformity with a global contract.
On Sept. 11, no one looked to Bill Gates or Michael Eisner, let alone Kenneth Lay or Martha Stewart, for national leadership. On that day Americans remembered the true meaning of words like citizen and public servant and relied upon firefighters, mayors, Congress and the president. Why then today do we expect corporate executives or "market professionals" to cure the disorders of anarchic market capitalism -- which, as Theodore Roosevelt understood, responds only to democratic oversight? And how do we expect a go-it-alone superpower to depose terrorists who exploit the global interdependence America is reluctant to recognize?
These ends are public, the res publica that constitutes us as a common people. To secure them is the common task of every citizen -- as well as the principal responsibility of the president and Congress, whose problem is not that they may have once been complicit in the vices of capitalism, but that they are today insufficiently complicit in the virtues of democracy.

Bertelsmann's Chief Out After Clash Over Strategy
Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, said its chief executive, Thomas Middelhoff, had left after clashing with the controlling family over strategy. The company, whose assets include Random House and Britney Spears' record company, named Gunter Thielen, who heads Bertelsmann's media services division Arvato, as Mr. Middelhoff's successor.
 His departure comes as media companies struggle to make their acquisitions work. Robert W. Pittman, the chief operating officer at AOL Time Warner left last week and Jean-Marie Messier, the chief executive of Vivendi Universal, was ousted earlier. Section A. 

Patent Claim Strikes a Nerve
A small Texas videoconferencing company is shaking up the consumer electronics and computer industries with claims that it has a patent that covers parts of the JPEG data-compression standard. The standard is used widely in digital cameras, printers, scanners, personal computers and on the Internet. C4.

Triumph of the Producing Class
The 1994 class of the University of Southern California's Peter Stark producing program, a brash group of young players who are surging toward positions of power, appear to embody the soul of a new corporate Hollywood, with its emphasis on commerce over art. The group owes much to Stark's director, Lawrence Turman, above, who chose the '94 class with an eye on entrepreneurial zeal. C7.

IVillage, a network of Web sites for women, says it is heeding the complaints of its readers and plans to eliminate most pop-up advertising by Sept. 30 on all its sites. C4.

Ziff Davis Media has been telling advertisers that it will be forced to enter bankruptcy by the end of the week, a major advertiser said. Company executives had no comment on a possible bankruptcy filing, but acknowledged there would be a restructuring. Advertising. C8.

Smitten and Pining Away for Himself
Few of the executives accused of fraud may have set out to break the law. What's more likely is that they became lost in a narcissistic fog in which they imagined that the rules no longer applied to them. Sam Vaknin, left, who has written a book on narcissism, says a narcissist regards himself as "a gift to his company." New Economy: Tim Race. C4.

Martha Stewart's Paycheck
Even in its worst year as a public company, Martha Stewart's empire has been good to her. The proxy statement shows that Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia paid her about $2.7 million. She is also the sole owner of 30 million Class B shares, giving her great control. The question is what will happen to the other shareholders -- the ones who didn't bolt as the share price fell to $7.25. Market Place. C8.

Diageo plans to have one distributor in each state, the company's first major move since announcing the sale of Burger King in an effort to concentrate on alcoholic beverages. C6.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bodyguards Buy Time for Afghan Leader 

BYLINE:  By CARLOTTA GALL 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 28 

 BODY:
American security guards in T-shirts and jeans, carrying large assault rifles, were prowling the president's office here this weekend. The first half dozen members of an American security force were in place to guard President Hamid Karzai, working alongside their Afghan counterparts.
 Mr. Karzai's decision last week to accept protection by American Special Forces has caused conflict. It has upset his Afghan security detail and their superiors in the Defense Ministry and brought warnings that it will resonate badly among the fiercely independent Afghan people. 
 But it has made foreign diplomats and military leaders, who are concerned about Mr. Karzai's survival, breathe more easily. It has stirred hopes among members of his administration that it signals a new assertiveness on his part to extend the writ of the central government and address the country's most pressing problems.
"There is a need for speed and decisiveness," said Hedayat Amin Arsala, a close adviser to Mr. Karzai and one of his four vice presidents. "It is important to consider all the implications, but once we take a decision, it is important we move fast and with decisiveness. I think President Karzai is doing this now." 
Mr. Karzai is at a crossroads, many here say. A month after a grand council, or loya jirga, of 1,600 representatives voted to give him a two-year term as head of state, the pressure is on him to perform.
The loya jirga, while a huge success in itself, ended with a sense of disappointment as Mr. Karzai appeared to opt for accommodation rather than confrontation with the regional strongmen and the powerful Tajik faction who had already dominated his cabinet and in fact control the Defense Ministry. 
Delegates, and particularly his own ethnic group, the Pashtuns -- the country's largest ethnic group -- left dissatisfied. They contended that Mr. Karzai had allowed the former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, to be sidelined and had not taken advantage of his popular mandate to bring balance into the government.
Seven months after the fall of the Taliban, Afghanistan's problems remain enormous, and the public's expectations are only becoming more pressing. Mr. Karzai's supporters say he must deliver on security and disarmament and resurrect the economy to provide jobs and reconstruction, or risk losing support.
"He got a big mandate in the loya jirga and now people are expecting him to do what would have been very difficult to do before," Mr. Arsala said.
But Mr. Karzai, determined to avoid more bloodshed, has moved slowly, even timidly. That has left at least one warlord in eastern Afghanistan openly flouting Mr. Karzai's authority, and it has led to accusations that the president himself is controlled by the powerful Tajik defense minister, Gen. Muhammad Fahim.
There are palace mutterings that the Tajik faction, and specifically General Fahim, was behind the assassination of Vice President Hajji Abdul Qadir earlier this month. The Tajiks run not only the Defense Ministry, but also the powerful intelligence service and the office of the administration.
Mr. Karzai's decision to accept the American offer security guards was in part an apparent move to break from the control, or the perceived control, of the Tajiks. "It is a clear indication of what he feels about the people around him and what they can do," said one foreign diplomat. 
The protection of American bodyguards will give the president a few months to act more firmly against those who stand in his way, in particular those who run the security and defense ministries and the warlords who still dominate the regions, an Afghan official said. 
Mr. Karzai has formed a national security council that serves as an inner cabinet and that meets daily, accelerating the decision-making process, Javier Solana, the European Union's high representative for common foreign and security policy, said during a visit to Kabul today. 
"Deep down there are more things in motion now," Mr. Solana said. "Now he is taking control," he said of the president.
Other ethnically balanced commissions are being formed to oversee crucial changes in the country's military and national security procedures and disarmament. Mr. Karzai has also dispatched ministerial delegations on fact-finding missions, one to the north of the country to investigate reports of violence against the Pashtun minority there, and four more to try to solve security problems on the main roads. 
When reports of fighting around the old Soviet air base in Shindand, in western Afghanistan, came in last Monday, Mr. Karzai halted a cabinet meeting and sent four top officials to investigate and quell the fighting. His actions have been welcomed by the United Nations Assistance Mission for Afghanistan, which has repeatedly complained about the security problems caused by armed factions. 
"For months we have waited for the government, through the presidential administration, to act," said one United Nations official. "This is the beginning of a possible new relationship between the center and the periphery." 
The official praised the strong positions taken by the commission investigating violence in the north and the cabinet's decision to act on the commission's report, in particular its call to arrest six commanders thought to be responsible for recent unrest. The new activity by the central government has been popular in the affected regions, and even the famously independent-minded governor of Herat, Ismail Khan, welcomed the attention from Kabul, a presidential spokesman said.
Yet so far the evidence of any real changes is thin, and praise of Mr. Karzai's newly exercised power may be premature. The six commanders in northern Afghanistan remain at large, and if some fighting has been quelled, the underlying power struggles involving regional warlords remain unresolved. Disarmament is going to remain extremely difficult while one faction, the Tajiks, hold sway over the defense minister, a presidential adviser said.
International supporters do not appear to be willing to provide more resources to strengthen Mr. Karzai beyond providing him with bodyguards. There is no support for extending the international security force beyond Kabul, Mr. Solana said, and the Afghan national army will take years to build.
Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz admitted on a recent visit to Afghanistan that he had "no doctrine or blueprint" for tackling the problem. The American commander of coalition forces, Lt. Gen. Dan K. McNeill, has been making regular visits to regional strongmen to urge them to cooperate with the government and with the national army.
"I give them the same message, that it is in their best interest to support what is presently a legitimate government," General McNeill said last week at his headquarters in Bagram air base outside Kabul. "It is important to support Mr. Karzai, because he is the head of that legitimate government."
Members of Mr. Karzai's own administration say that in the end he will have to get tough. "He's going slowly because he doesn't want bloodshed," said a presidential spokesman, Fazel Akbar. "We want to solve the problems through negotiation. But maybe we need a little bit of dictatorship."

HEADLINE: Budgeting Now for Tomorrow 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael Bloomberg's recent announcement that he might cut the city's work force to balance next year's budget offers a reminder that he is not running for office this year. Gov. George Pataki and the New York State legislators, who are facing the voters, have created a state budget that is built on such financial whimsy that they will almost certainly have to return to Albany after the election to face hard realities. Congress, which is heading for midterm elections, shows no signs of dealing seriously enough with Washington's big new budget deficit and the next stage of tax cuts that will only add to the federal shortfall. 
 In contrast, Mayor Bloomberg has wisely decided he wants the city to start facing the bad news now. The budget gap next year is estimated at $3.7 billion to $6 billion, and every dollar saved this summer lowers next year's bill. His first step has been to ask all of his commissioners -- including police, fire and schools -- to propose cuts of 7.5 percent. This is a large whack at what has already been advertised as an ultra-lean budget. The mayor is hoping that commissioners who now have a few months' seasoning might better recognize places to economize or positions to leave vacant. By threatening layoffs, which can be so disruptive in the city, the mayor also hopes to tame unions facing new contract talks and sustain the pressure on Albany and Washington for more financial aid. 
 Mr. Bloomberg has to take care, however, that the city doesn't slide back to its old days, with more homeless on the sidewalks, more schools without decent equipment, crime levels inching upward, litter sweeping the streets. A city that now depends so much on tourists can't afford to slow down basic services despite a frail economy and the daily fibrillations on Wall Street.
The mayor has hinted that cutting services or even workers might not be enough to balance the budget as required by law. That can only mean new revenues -- that is, tax increases -- which clearly make the most sense in this climate, if done judiciously. The commuter tax, or some similar levy on the many nonresidents who work in the city, needs to be high on his list. Property taxes or an income tax surcharge targeted for schools could follow. The mayor may be moving too slowly in the right direction, but at least he's starting early.

HEADLINE: Saying No to Free 9/11 Aid, Many Families Hire Lawyers 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
When the federal government promised last fall to compensate the relatives of victims who were killed or injured on Sept. 11, the Association of Trial Lawyers of America urged its members to join an altruistic and patriotic endeavor without precedent: offering free legal advice to the thousands of bereaved families who would be in line for billions of dollars in awards.
 "If ever there were a time when lawyers could pursue their calling for a noble purpose; if ever there were a cause that demanded our most magnificent effort as lawyers, as human beings, as Americans -- this is it," read a brochure for Trial Lawyers Care, the pro bono Sept. 11 organization set up by the national association. 
 If only doing something for free were quite so simple.
First, families of victims became frustrated by delays in assignments of the free lawyers, as the trial lawyers association encountered a shortage of local volunteers. Then, other lawyers, unpersuaded by the noble calling, began signing up families as formal clients. Now at least 500 families -- or more than a quarter of all the families who have sought legal advice -- have hired paid lawyers who could collect fees of up to 25 percent of the awards paid by the federal Victim Compensation Fund. 
On top of that, nine of New York City's biggest white-shoe firms have formed their own pro bono initiative, arguing to families that neither the free lawyers provided by the trial lawyers association nor the paid professionals are good enough. Only they, their argument goes, can be truly effective in navigating the government fund that has proven to be far more complicated than anyone had anticipated.
Not even the patriotic calls to action made months ago by the trial lawyers group have escaped barbs or backhanded compliments.
"It's very noble and beautiful of the trial lawyers association to do this, and bless their little hearts," said Guillermo A. Gleizer, a lawyer in Manhattan whose firm represents more than 100 injured victims and is charging fees of up to 25 percent. "But we represent a client in every single problem related to the Sept. 11 tragedy -- hospitalization, credit cards, mortgages -- and we want to make money. Guy works, guy gets paid. That is the American way."
And so if the idealistic impulse of Trial Lawyers Care was to cushion families from worrying about the maneuvering and motivations of lawyers, the realistic reckoning now, nearly 11 months after the attack, is that the legal landscape may be as confusing as ever -- complicated by competing lawyers and contradictory stories about who is good, who is not good or who might simply be up to no good.
For their part, officials with Trial Lawyers Care, known as T.L.C., say their bumpy beginnings are over. They have a Web site -- www.911lawhelp.org -- and they are immensely proud of how they have put together a national network of 1,200 lawyers dedicated to the largest pro bono effort in American history. But they are frustrated, too, by the cynical perception that a free lawyer is not as good as a paid one.
And do not get a T.L.C. lawyer started on the morals of colleagues who are collecting money from victims.
"It's infuriating, and frankly, I don't have much regard for them," said William L. Mauk, the former director of litigation support for T.L.C. "I think they are taking advantage of a national tragedy."
To date, only 620 families have applied to the fund, which is expected to pay each family an average of $1.5 million. But with the first awards set to be announced by Kenneth R. Feinberg, the special master responsible for administering the fund, the hundreds of families who have not even chosen a lawyer may feel compelled to do so soon.
From the outset, the trial lawyers' association has praised the fund as an expeditious no-fault alternative to civil litigation by offering families awards that are guaranteed, though smaller than possible jury verdicts. And despite suspicions that the lawyers were mainly trying to polish their image, T.L.C. forged ahead, led by many lawyers who said they were motivated because of personal connections to Sept. 11.
Indeed, many families, touched by the dedication of T.L.C. lawyers, say that they would be lost without them.
"Sometimes I'm just like, thank you, thank you, thank you, because I don't know what else to say," said Leonor Ramos-Santoro, whose husband, Mario, was an emergency medical technician. Her T.L.C. lawyer is Paul A. Scrudato. "They're taking care of things that I wouldn't have a clue about. It really brings me to tears."
But T.L.C., which is expected to cost more than $1 million, has also experienced growing pains.
Recruiting enough volunteers experienced in personal injury or wrongful death cases has been hard, especially from the local area. Today, about one-fourth of all T.L.C. lawyers are from outside the New York region. 
The application process has been far more difficult than anyone expected, and subject to frequent clarifications from Mr. Feinberg. Lawyers say that a typical case requires not just a couple of hours of fill-in-the-blanks paperwork, but sometimes more than 100 hours of tricky legal work.
David Salvo, whose father, Sam, died, said that he waited several months before he even got so much as a phone call from T.L.C. Disheartened, he ultimately switched to a law firm in Chicago, Nolan Law Group, which specializes in lawsuits against airlines. It is charging its two dozen or so Sept. 11 clients a 10 percent cut of the final fund award, and up to 25 percent of any litigation award.
"It took forever, and I was getting frustrated because I wanted some help," said Mr. Salvo, who has not yet decided whether to apply to the fund or to file a lawsuit. "So I contacted Nolan, and they gave us the pros and cons of everything. They were great."
As T.L.C. struggled, some lawyers -- particularly those with aviation disaster firms -- began touting their services to the bereaved families. Many of these lawyers questioned the fund's methodology and its intentions as part of an airline industry bailout. "The dream of every defendant is that the other side doesn't have lawyers," Mr. Gleizer said. "The second best is, O.K., go to some free lawyers."
Some firms insisted that if the families chose the fund, they would be able to win bigger awards than their pro bono counterparts. In return, they said, they would collect a commission, usually 10 percent of a family's award.
The pitch is resonating. More than 200 families have turned to Kreindler & Kreindler, an aviation-disaster firm in Manhattan. About 60 have signed up with the law firm of Michel F. Baumeister. The list goes on.
"Not that T.L.C. is doing anything wrong; I applaud what they're doing," said Kenneth P. Nolan, a partner at Speiser, Krause, Nolan & Granito, which represents more than 50 families, including a few for free. "But some people don't trust the system, and they want someone who's used to fighting the system."
Some firms are also reaching out to families desperate for intangibles like familiarity or shared geography.
John D'Amato, a partner at Russo Scammardella and D'Amato in Staten Island, said he thought T.L.C. was a wonderful concept. Shortly after Sept. 11, he offered free legal help to families on estate matters. But then families began beseeching his firm, which includes Guy V. Molinari, the former Staten Island borough president, to help with the federal fund.
"There's a comfort level," he said. "I know them. I see them at the Y. I see them at Staten Island Yankee games."
But to represent all 30 or so of his clients for free would be impossible "because I would go out of business," Mr. D'Amato said. So his firm is now charging families 5 percent for the first $1 million from the federal fund, and 10 percent of any money over $1 million.
The question of whether to represent a Sept. 11 family for free, or for a fee, has produced some passionate rhetoric, not all of it nice.
Some fee-charging lawyers, for instance, say that families who choose a free lawyer get what they pay for. T.L.C., in turn, says that anyone who chooses to pay, say, 10 percent for something they can get for free is being hoodwinked. T.L.C. officials also grumble that they are doing the bulk of the trailblazing legal work in testing the boundaries of the fund.
"We're defining how the program works," Mr. Mauk said. "They're sitting on the sidelines, and they're going to piggyback on our cases."
Stepping gingerly into the middle of these two opposing forces are some prominent law firms that are helping specific groups, using different approaches.
One notable pro bono initiative, launched by the New York Lawyers for the Public Interest, features nine prominent firms, including Shearman & Sterling; Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft; Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton; and Debevoise & Plimpton. Together, they are providing a wide array of services -- in areas like immigration, financial planning and family law, in addition to help with the federal fund -- to about 70 poor union families, many of whom are illegal immigrants. Cadwalader has also produced a Sept. 11 handbook that is available at its Web site, www.cadwalader.com.
Unlike T.L.C. or the paid professionals, this group is not even seeking reimbursement for their expenses, which can run into the tens of thousands of dollars.
"This is pro bono in the truest sense of the word," said Bryan Pu-Folkes, the coalition's coordinator. 'I don't think it's possible for any law firm to provide legal services that are superior than this project because it's comprehensive and holistic."
On the other end of the economic scale, Cantor Fitzgerald, which lost 658 employees, has persuaded a coterie of high-powered law firms to assist their families for a nominal fee of about one percent of any money received from the federal fund. That way, officials say, Cantor families will have legal experts in their corner who are familiar with the company's compensation history and projections.
Whether all of this legal jockeying makes any difference remains to be seen. In an interview, Mr. Feinberg, the special master, said that his position was one "of studied neutrality." But so far, he says, there has been "no appreciable difference" between the quality of the lawyers' work, paid or not paid.
Through it all, many families say that they are not sure where to turn, who to trust. Even Kristen Breitweiser, a widow who used to practice law, finds the process daunting. That is why she feels lucky that a friend who works at a major New York firm is handling her case, for free.
"It's very nerve-wracking for everyone," said Mrs. Breitweiser, whose husband, Ronald, worked at Fiduciary Trust International. "You worry about the widow with two kids who's not functioning properly, and all of a sudden she wakes up out of her fog five years later, and she's like, 'Oh my God, what did I do?' These are big, big decisions, and you just hope that they're thinking clearly and they have proper representation."

HEADLINE: Corporate Abuses Cause Bipartisan Indignation 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: ONTARIO, Calif., July 26 

 BODY:
Myra Clay went to the bank here this week and moved her retirement savings from the stock market into a fixed annuity. An unemployed quality assurance inspector, she says she worries about her future and the nation's. She is infuriated at Wall Street corporate executives and the politicians she says have protected them.
 In short, Ms. Clay is precisely the kind of voter Democratic leaders say could deliver the party control of Congress in November and the White House in 2004. 
 Except for one thing. As angry as Ms. Clay is -- she says the profiteering on Wall Street will be the first thing on her mind when she votes this November -- she says she does not think Democrats will be any tougher than Republicans in confronting corporate abuses. Ms. Clay, a Democrat, said that although Republicans might be more inclined to hoist the corporate banner, both parties were too financially indebted to Wall Street to do much about it, no matter what Democrats in Washington are saying these days. 
"I don't think either one of them is better," Ms. Clay said on the steps of the public library here in the foothills of the San Bernardino Mountains. "And the corporate contributions have a heck of a lot to do with it."
Ms. Clay is hardly alone. In a series of interviews over two days in this sprawling community of 160,000 people about 30 miles east of the Los Angeles County line -- the kind of growing, middle-class and blue-collar exurb that often decides elections these days -- voter after voter expressed distress at what was taking place a nation away on Wall Street.
But voter after voter said that when it came to curbing abuses in corporate boardrooms, it made no difference which party was in power.
The resignation and exasperation they voiced suggested how difficult a task the Democrats face as they seek to turn the fall elections into a referendum on one dominant issue.
"It has nothing to do with party lines, it has to do with the almighty dollar," said Sue Bonetti, a retired teacher whose husband is four years away from what suddenly looks as if it could be an uneasy retirement. "What are they going to do -- cut the belt that feeds them?"
Ruby Stewart, 41, a corrections officer who was with her four daughters at the Ontario Mills mall here today, laughed when asked if it mattered which party controlled the White House and Congress.
"With who they have running?" Ms. Stewart said. "I think it would be wet and wet, to tell you the truth: no difference, no difference whatsoever. Wet and wet. You don't have anybody up there who is going to look out for the interests of the public. They are only interested in themselves."
Remarks like hers suggest that the activity on Wall Street and the frenzy in Washington to respond to it have reinforced the cynicism about politicians that Ross Perot tapped when he ran for president in 1992.
The anger and indignation were palpable and personal. More than a few people said they had watched their retirement accounts tumble with the stock market. But many added that this issue would not prompt them to vote for one party over the other. In fact, they said, they might not vote at all.
Bruce Lee, 52, a writer who voted for Ralph Nader in 2000, said it was "completely irrelevant" who was in charge. "The overwhelming majority of both political parties sold out 20 years ago," Mr. Lee said. "There may be some question as to who bought them, but they have been bought."
Bob Ferguson, 75, a retired plastering contractor, echoed that point with a comment made only partly in jest. "When you buy a Republican, he stays bought," Mr. Ferguson said. "That's the difference between the two parties."
Beyond that, the interviews here reflected the conflicting opinions Americans have of their president today. Voters from both parties expressed concern about President Bush's close identification with corporate interests, and his handling of the economy. Yet almost without exception, they applauded his handling of the war on terrorism, conveying admiration for the president during this difficult time.
"When can you think of a time that a guy has been beset with more problems?" Mr. Ferguson said. "All you can do is play the hand that's dealt you, and I think he's done a good job playing a bad hand."
Mr. Ferguson, a Republican, voted for Mr. Bush in 2000, but even Charlotte Smith, 45, a Democrat who voted against him, seemed open to the idea of voting for him in 2004. "He's actually doing better than I thought he would," Ms. Smith said.
Conversely, the views offered about Al Gore, who handily defeated Mr. Bush in this state four years ago and must do so again in 2004 if he hopes to win the White House, were hardly favorable, even among Democrats. Several people expressed annoyance that Mr. Gore had kept such a low profile for so long after the Sept. 11 attacks, and some said he had relinquished any claim to be the head of the opposition or his party's leading candidate for 2004.
"I used to think Gore but I'm not sure now," said William Lopez, 50, a Democrat and an elementary school teacher, who was wearing a Bruce Springsteen T-shirt. "Maybe because after the election, he stood away -- he kept away. He kept away too long. I know he was trying to be a gracious loser, but at the same time, maybe he could have took a stronger stand on everything."
Ms. Clay, the quality assurance inspector, said she had voted for Mr. Gore in 2000 but would be inclined to vote for Mr. Bush in a rematch. "Gore gave up on me," she said. "When he lost the election, he just kind of faded in the bushes. He's weak." 
The responses on the subject of Wall Street were noteworthy because they came as the Democratic Party was maneuvering to hold the Republican Party responsible for corporate abuses. Democratic strategists who just weeks ago were gloomy about their November prospects say the corporate issue is a way to nationalize the election, in effect, giving dozens of Democratic congressional candidates a single issue to use against the Republicans.
There was, in fact, a sentiment voiced by the people interviewed that Republicans in general -- and the president in particular -- had deep ties with corporate interests, evidenced by financial contributions to the party and the number of former corporate executives in the Bush administration. "He's too associated with corporate America, oil companies," said Jerome Rinkus, a Russian language teacher. "His vice president as well."
Yet many voters suggested that business ties were not necessarily a bad thing. Many also said such connections were counterbalanced by what the Democrats have been doing in Washington. "Both are involved in taking corporate monies," said Tom Alpert, a pilot for Northwest Airlines. "And I think that if you look at the House and the Senate in either party, you're going to find that neither party is totally pure."
But in a changing political climate affected so much by international turmoil, no one was prepared to say that what was happening today would matter much in November -- much less two years from now.
"Today it's very important," said John Eubank, 65, a retired network computer engineer. "Something else might come forward in the next two years. And who will remember?"
