HEADLINE: A CONVERSATION WITH/Janos Marton; 
A Protected Space, Where Art Comes Calling

BYLINE:  By ERICA GOODE

 BODY:
If Dr. Janos Marton ran the world, there would be protected spaces everywhere for people with mental illness to create paintings and sculptures, drawings and lithographs, installations, murals and collages, poetry and novels, songs and symphonies.
 The abandoned buildings on the grounds of old state hospitals would be turned into sheltered workshops. 
 Warehouses in urban centers, where the mentally ill pace the streets and scrounge meals from garbage cans, would become safe harbors, working studios filled with color and form.
Delusion and hallucination, pain and sorrow, fear and manic exuberance would find their outlet in something quite simple, the creation of works of art. 
Dr. Marton's vision is hardly an idle one. At the Living Museum, housed in Building 75 of the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens, the state hospital's former main kitchen and dining areas, he is the director of just such an "art asylum," a refuge where in the 19 years since the museum opened more than 800 men and women have shed their identities as psychiatric patients and bloomed instead as artists.
Their work has been widely exhibited, most recently at the Queens Museum. Several artists have attained prominence in the world of outsider art. 
"Artists at the Living Museum don't really care about the diagnoses: they ignore labels," Dr. Marton wrote in the catalog for the Queens Museum show. "What counts is their behavior, the outcome of their labor. It's not therapy. It's art that matters."
Dr. Marton, a psychologist, was born in Hungary in 1949, the son of a dissident economist who was taken off to prison for six years on the day of his son's birth.
His generation, Dr. Marton said, grew up with the shadow of communism and the legacy of the Holocaust. "We were the children of Marx and Coca Cola, and rejecting both." 
In Vienna, where his parents moved in the 60's, he absorbed the Freudian atmosphere of that city, and in high school, he became familiar with the art work of the psychiatric patients at the Landers Clinic, a state hospital in a nearby hamlet, Maria Gugging.
The art program there occupied its own building, known as the House of Artists, and the painter Jean Dubuffet included the work of several Gugging patients in his collection of outsider art or "art brut."
After studying psychology at the University of Vienna, Dr. Marton completed a doctorate in psychology and a master's in fine arts at Columbia University and went to work as a psychologist at Creedmoor.
In 1983, Dr. Marton invited Bolek Greczynski, a Polish artist known for his work in political art and experimental theater, to join the hospital staff. Together, the two guided the transformation of an abandoned building into a place of extraordinary beauty.
Mr. Greczynski was the museum's first director. Dr. Marton took over the post in 1995, shortly after Mr. Greczynski died. Today, 70 or so artists work at the museum regularly.
In a recent interview, Dr. Marton discussed the museum's goals and the relationship between art and mental illness.

Q. A longstanding argument in psychology is about whether creative genius is in some way tied to mental illness. Do you find that there is a link?

A. There is this question of, Would van Gogh have been a great artist if he would not have been mentally ill? I think that mental illness is an asset in art. You don't have to be mentally ill to be a great artist, but you definitely have to work very hard to get to a spot where mentally ill people are automatically.
Mental illness is one of the most horrifying conditions that a person can experience. But what I'm trying to do is to see the good and the positive aspects and to build on those. If you have delusions, for example, I see it as fertile ground for great art work.
The point is that art is not going to take away your mental illness. But it builds on the symptoms of mental illness. Great art really occurs in the domain where schizophrenic processes often occur.
In the regular hospital setting, that is something they'd want to get rid of, because that's what makes you crazy, what defines you as a mental patient, what gives you the diagnosis.
But I celebrate those aspects.

Q. A psychiatrist at Gugging once said the number of truly gifted artists among the mentally ill was about the same as among other people, that is, very, very small. Do you agree?

A. I think that the idea of talent is overrated. The traditional definition of art and what is good art and what is valuable art went out of the window with Marcel Duchamp. I am a fan of Gugging, but they are much more conservative. We pay homage to Andy Warhol's Factory, to Duchamp. We are much more applied modern art, conceptual art.

Q.You have said that the Living Museum is about art and not about therapy. And you don't do traditional art therapy here, where the paintings or drawings are interpreted and talked about in terms of the patient's life. But at the same time, the experience of working here has a tremendous impact. Could you talk about the transformation that takes place for many patients?

A. The self-definition of the mental patient is an incredibly self-destructive one, because of the societal scorn and because you are stripped of every other aspect of your humanity. You cease to be a tailor or a journalist or a mother or a soccer player, and whatever identity you have is all reduced to that of a mental patient. You become "the other."
And that has self-esteem issues, and this internalized self-concept is more destructive than even societal discrimination.
But then suddenly you think of yourself as a painter, as a poet. You can, realistically, too, because the Living Museum provides you with a realistic framework to do that. You exhibit. People come to see your work. Suddenly, the disadvantage of your existence, which is time and boredom and waiting -- that's the reality of mental illness, endless waiting, endless emptiness, endless void -- suddenly turns into an asset: "Oh my God, I have time to paint!"

Q. Are there any rules for patients who come to work at the museum?

A. The dialectic of rules is, of course, that the more rules you have the more controlling you have to be. So in a way, we have no rules here, because this demand for no rules creates no need for rules.
Most mentally ill people are oversocialized by the time I get my hands on them. They have been told over and over again to do this, to do that, not to do this, not to do that. So in a way, pointing out rules doesn't help. 
And second, which is that the rules are really self-imposed rules. If you own the place, when it's yours, if you set your own rules, you work along internalized rules. And it has worked fantastically. Nothing negative ever happened here.

Q. How is the Living Museum organized?

A. You have a collective going here that is based on need, and not on democracy or equity. It is more like a family structure, that people get what they need and not what they deserve.
An example is that if you are needy and more in a psychotic state, then I give you more attention. I help you more with your materials. I give you more space. You get better treatment. You get maybe an extra amount of nice herbal tea and you get a sweeter spot, even though you misbehave, because you are not doing well. And if you are doing well and on top of the day, you get neglected more.

Q. Doesn't rewarding illness with greater attention encourage people to stay sick?

A. People don't get sick because of lack of attention. That's one of the big problems, that mentally ill people are often treated like bad children. They are approached in a moralistic way, and it doesn't work. People don't misbehave in a mentally ill way because they are bad. It's a brain disease. Their problem comes from above. They're not responsible. There is such a thing that the illness takes over.
In the mental health system, people are often scolded for having what's called "poor activities of daily living," that you're messy, you stink, you neglect your hygiene. But in reality, it is connected more to your lack of medication than to your behavior. Once the medication stabilizes you, then your hygiene improves.

Q. You have talked about the need for more art centers or "asylums" like the Living Museum. How would this work?

A. Right now there is a lot of real estate being taken away from the mentally ill. For example, state hospitals are closing down, and these are gigantic real estate complexes that are being sold off or given away and basically being taken away from the mentally ill people of the state. And so there is a lot of real estate to be had that could be used for art asylums.
These are not art therapy programs. The practical distinction would be that instead of therapists you would need artists to run these places.
The idea of an asylum goes back to the idea of integration versus segregation. The old asylums were in the context of segregation. Creedmoor was built far away from urban centers. It was difficult to get to. And the idea was to separate people.
It was ultimately, of course, a discriminatory idea. However, once you were there, it was a different matter. The mental patients were running the place. They were working. So you had better food, because Creedmoor has fantastic soil. You could grow things.
You were among similar people, so you did not have this constant fear of being rejected and measuring yourself against others. You felt comfortable among your own, which had many positive aspects for people. It is similar to all-girl schools. They are not determined so much by the male energy.

Q. How does the concept of asylum relate to art?

A. Great art is created in asylums. An asylum per se means protection. And protection is needed for the mentally ill. The pressure of the outside world is tremendous. We still don't have a cure for mental illness.
If you look at the situation of people with mental illness, in general in the world and specifically in New York, it is in need of reform, to put it mildly. It is in a crisis. Ask yourself the question, "Would I want my mentally ill child to be in any of the situations that are available for him or her currently where you live such as adult homes or the street?"
Creedmoor is a five-star hotel compared to what is going on mostly.
Art asylums would create a kind of social gentrification like what happens in urban gentrification. Artists move into dilapidated areas like SoHo or TriBeCa, and over a period of a decade that area gets gentrified.
Only artists will put up with a lack of water, a lack of heat, a lack of elevators.
I'm thinking of using artists to gentrify the social sphere. These places can be a cultural center for the whole society. And only artists have the discipline to put in that much energy and work hours to create something like you have at the Living Museum.
And people with mental illness have a special role in my mind. If you've heard voices, there is a certain experience that emerges, a certain truth, and the art can be the vehicle to communicate this to the world.

SECTION: Section E; Column 5; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 1

HEADLINE: ARTS ABROAD; 
In Argentina, Struggling To Survive A Depression

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, July 23 

 BODY:
"The Marriage of Figaro" has been performed many times at the venerable Teatro Colon, but the premiere of the latest production last month came with a twist that reflected the hard times here. Because the collapse of the Argentine economy in December has meant periodic shortages of paper, no program was available for the opera's opening night.
 "Neither you nor the artists nor I deserve this," Emilio Basaldua, the Colon's artistic director, told the crowd that evening. Audiences at later performances have been getting a program, but one whose production cost is one-quarter that of the past; it is made of coarser paper, with six photos of performers to the page, rather than two. 
 As Argentina struggles to survive a four-year economic calamity that in statistical terms is now the equivalent of the Great Depression in the United States, the impact on the nation's cultural life is felt in every way and at every level. Cultural producers are not only scrambling to try to do more with less, they are being forced to rethink the role, function and nature of culture in Argentine society. 
The easiest way to measure the crisis in the arts is in terms of opportunities lost and events canceled. Popular music artists ranging from Rod Stewart to the jazz guitarist Mike Stern have called off shows here, for example, and the sparkling new Buenos Aires Museum of Latin American Art has had to cancel a pair of major exhibitions, one featuring works by Roy Lichtenstein and the other Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo.
"Those shows were extremely expensive and had to be suspended because they were beyond our operating and financial capacity," said Marcelo Pacheco, who became director of the museum in June after his predecessor resigned. "I'm not averse to high-impact shows, but not if they consume two or three years' worth of my budget."
But the situation here is even more complicated. In the words of Marcos Aguinis, a prominent author and a former culture minister, "the paradox of Argentina today is that in spite of the crisis, culture continues to resist, and that even without money you continue to have expositions, conferences and other activities."
So while bookstores are closing, sales at the recent Buenos Aires book fair were up by 25 percent over last year. Corporate sponsors for arts events have dried up, but the employees of an abandoned plastics factory have turned it into a cultural center offering plays and tango shows. And though 20 percent of the nation's 155 cultural magazines have ceased publication, traditional folk music forms like murgas and candombe are reviving. "In times of extreme crisis such as this, people have a greater inclination to participate and to do things that establish an identity," argued Jorge Telerman, the culture secretary for the city of Buenos Aires. There is a feeling here, he added, that since "our culture is the only thing left to us, we can't afford to lose it."
Since its opening nearly a century ago, the Teatro Colon has been Argentina's symbol of culture. But to keep the theater's programs running since Mr. Basaldua took over as artistic director last October, "one month before the country exploded," as he put it, he has had to confront situations that would be unimaginable to directors of similar institutions in other countries.
In late April the Bertolt Brecht-Kurt Weill opera "The Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny" was being presented, precisely because "Buenos Aires was the city in the real world that most resembled Mahagonny at that time," Mr. Basaldua said. But the government had just ordered all banks closed indefinitely, no money was available anywhere, and the Colon ended up simply throwing its doors open to the public and offering the last performance free.
A month earlier, demonstrators had broken into the theater and disrupted a show, responding to rumors that President Eduardo Duhalde and an elite group of the rich and the powerful decked out in jewels and furs were in attendance. In reality the theater was offering a concert at discount prices intended to attract middle-class patrons who might otherwise no longer be able to afford tickets.
The Colon's plans for the rest of this season remain unchanged, including a production of Alban Berg's "Wozzeck" at an abandoned factory. With the value of the peso having dropped from parity with the dollar to as low as four to the dollar, Mr. Basaldua said his problem is not this year's program but next year's.
"How can you possibly negotiate contracts when you don't know how much a peso is really worth?" he asked. "We are working from day to day."
At the moment Mr. Telerman is confronting a similar problem for the same reason. He received $10 million just before the collapse for the expansion of the Museum of Modern Art, but now finds that construction companies refuse to make bids on the project because they do not know when or how they will be paid.
Buenos Aires remains one of the few Latin American cities close to fulfilling Unesco's recommendation that 5 percent of government budgets be directed to culture. But that spending is now way down in dollar terms as a result of the devaluation: from $145 million to $34 million for the city, Mr. Telerman said, and $45 million to $10 million at the Colon.
The "immense distance between the reality of the crisis and the image of Buenos Aires as a city under siege," hasn't helped either, Mr. Pacheco said. Museums abroad have become more cautious about lending works following Sept. 11, and street disturbances earlier this year, which have largely ended, made Argentina appear dangerous and drove insurance rates beyond the country's ability to pay.
With it difficult to attract or afford foreign artists, some of the gap has been made up by Argentine artists living abroad who want to help. Daniel Barenboim, for instance, agreed to perform the complete cycle of Beethoven's sonatas at the Teatro Colon from July 27 to Aug. 10 for "a fee that is symbolic, a fraction of what he could be earning elsewhere," as Mr. Basaldua put it.
"The money is not the important factor for me in this case," Mr. Barenboim said in a telephone interview from Germany. "This has to do with the fact that I was born there, that both my parents were born there, that I still have relatives and friends there, that I went to the Colon often as a child and that my first musical memories are there."
Hoping to increase revenues, the Colon has stepped up efforts to rent out its opera sets, and has recently done so to companies in Brazil and Spain. It has also opened its doors to popular music artists like the Argentine rock star Gustavo Cerati, who performed recently with the National Philharmonic Orchestra in a show that dismayed some traditionalists but drew widespread critical praise. The Colon's management has also taken advantage of the crisis to revise generous labor contracts negotiated in 1978. The Colon remains "an island of artistic perfection in a country in ruins," said Pablo Batalla, the theater's financial director, who also argues that political stability and artistic quality are not directly related. "The best of Greek classical theater was performed when the gates of Athens were about to burn," he said. The crisis also appears to have had the beneficial effect of forcing a new realism on Argentina's intellectuals and cultural elite. Many illusions have had to be discarded, the most pernicious of which may have been that Argentina had more in common culturally and politically with Italy or Spain than with neighboring countries.
"Argentina, and Buenos Aires in particular, has always felt it was expelled from Europe and obliged to be anchored in Latin America," Mr. Pacheco said. "But that fiction, and the image we constructed of a country that wanted to be what it was not, cannot be sustained any more. Now, for better or worse, we are forced to be interested in the place that we are really a part of."

HEADLINE: Implacable Force for Family Planning 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE

 BODY:
What a moment for an American to take over the world's largest family planning organization.
 "We're completely at odds with Bush policy," said Dr. Steven W. Sinding, who becomes director general of the International Planned Parenthood Federation in London this month. 
 Because the federation's agenda includes access to abortion, it receives no American money for any of its programs in more than 180 countries. Yet this is a time when millions of people in the third world are clamoring for more contraceptives and health workers are short of condoms to fight the spread of AIDS. 
On July 22, the administration also ended American support for the United Nations Populations Fund, citing its activities in China, where birth control has been coercive. On that issue, the White House overrode the State Department, which had sent experts to China to look at the fund's programs and found no evidence that American money had been funneled to such programs. 
"At a moment when in some ways the priority is shifting from birth control to disease control," Dr. Sinding said, "it's devastating that the resources are not available to these organizations that are the primary channels of service to women in the developing world." 
In Africa, and possibly Asia, more women than men are being infected with the virus that causes AIDS. 
Dr. Sinding, 58, has many credentials, including posts as former head of the population office of the United States Agency for International Development, senior population adviser to the World Bank, director of population sciences at the Rockefeller Fund and, most recently, professor at Columbia University's Mailman School of Public Health. He learned the basics at the grass roots in Pakistan, the Philippines and Kenya.
He is ready for a fight, after seeing population programs under renewed assault from Washington. He sees a chance to make noise at the international federation, which works in concert with voluntary national organizations like the Planned Parenthood Association of the United States. Dr. Sinding wants to rekindle the fire of the federation's founders in 1952, among them family-planning pioneers like Margaret Sanger.
"I'm determined to move I.P.P.F. back to that brave and angry posture on issues that are today's most difficult and controversial, because I think that to some extent it's lost its pioneering spirit," Dr. Sinding said in an interview in his apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan as his wife, Monica Knorr, a geriatric-care expert, packed to move. "Since I.P.P.F. doesn't receive any money from the United States, there's no penalty associated with speaking out on those issues that the United States is being so recalcitrant on." 
In the United States, Dr. Sinding said, reproductive health and choice have become entangled in a culture war irrelevant to global realities. The Reagan-era ban on money to any organization that even counsels abortion was continued through the first Bush administration, then lifted by President Bill Clinton, only to be reinstated as the second Bush administration took office. The issue has become a partisan battleground. 
"The saddest thing is that this domestic political debate has such a profound impact around the world," Dr. Sinding said. "Women suffer deeply." 
Pregnancy is the leading cause of death among girls ages 15 to 19 in poor countries, many of them child brides forced into arranged marriages or children trafficked in the sex trade. 
"There will always be unwanted pregnancies, especially among women in poverty, and women so young that their pelvises are not yet formed to the point where they can safely deliver a child," he said.
About girls 14, 15 or 16 forced into sex, he said, "to condemn them to bear a child that may very well cause them to die is just morally indefensible."
Administration officials say the $34 million that Congress allocated for the United Nations will not be wasted but will be put to good use through A.I.D.
"We program more than $400 million in family-planning right now in more than 64 countries," Dr. Anne Peterson, assistant administrator of the Bureau of Global Health, said. "The $34 million is a significant amount of money, and it could go in a number of different countries and be programmed fairly easily."
Dr. Peterson said it would not be hard to find nongovernmental organizations willing to accept American restrictions on any involvement with abortion or abortion rights. 
"In many of these countries," she said, "that's where their own country and culture is on the abortion issue. And so they're very comfortable that we also have our funding that has that restriction on it."
Before heading to London, Dr. Sinding had collected a few wounds from service on the front line of the culture war. In 1984, when the Reagan administration suddenly announced at a United Nations conference in Mexico City that it was ending family-planning aid to countries and organizations that were involved in abortions, Dr. Sinding was running population policy for A.I.D.
"The Mexico City policy came out of the blue," he said. "It caught the State Department totally unawares. The senior population person at State resigned over this issue. The White House basically took control, which was most unusual."
State Department and aid officials were stunned by the severity of the policy.
"It basically said two things," Dr. Sinding said. "We categorically oppose abortion and we're going to defund any foreign nongovernmental organization that does it, even with its own money. And we don't think as a government that population is all that big a problem.
"Until Reagan, there was a bipartisan consensus. If anything, there was more Republican support than Democratic support for population funds. It was based on a belief that there was both a national security and an international development rationale for dealing with population. That consensus was broken in the 1980's. Population became a highly partisan issue -- and has remained so ever since."

HEADLINE: British Judge Splits Ruling On Suit by Cantor Fitzgerald 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, July 29 

 BODY:
A British High Court judge handed down a split ruling today in a bitter dispute of the rival bond brokerage firms Cantor Fitzgerald and Icap, backing Cantor's accusations that Icap unlawfully poached one broker after the firm lost 658 employees in the attack on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11.
 But the judge, Richard McCombe, dismissed complaints by Cantor that Icap, which is based in London, illicitly lured two other brokers from Cantor's London offices. Mr. McCombe also cast doubt on suggestions that Icap's activities represented part of a deliberate attempt to weaken its rival after Sept. 11, as Cantor had initially argued. All three of the traders hired away from Cantor by Icap were London interest rates swaps traders. 
 While the attack on the World Trade Center "provided the backdrop to what happened," the judge said, "the events of Sept. 11 did not have an immediate or direct effect upon the business of the department of Cantor with which I am concerned." Indeed, the ruling seemed to support accusations by two former Cantor brokers, Ed Bird and Spencer Gill, that they were "constructively dismissed," a legal term meaning that Cantor forced them to quit by bullying and what Icap called "inappropriate behavior at the hands of Cantor's management."
Mr. Bird, for example, said a senior manager once wiped spittle on his face.
Only in the case of the broker Luigi Boucher did Judge McCombe rule that Icap had offered an "unlawful inducement" to persuade Mr. Boucher to breach his contract with Cantor. The judge granted an injunction preventing Boucher from starting work at Icap for several months. A Cantor spokesman called the ruling a victory.
The case offered a mirror-image of a lawsuit in 1999, when Cantor was found guilty of poaching about 20 employees from Intercapital Debt Trading, now part of Icap. At that time Cantor was ordered by a London court to pay damages then worth about $1.7 million.
Judge McCombe said damages against Icap in the latest case may be awarded in September. The High Court will also determine costs and consider any appeal by Icap, he said.
The case has been closely followed here because of Cantor's attempt to link the charges to Sept. 11. When the case opened in June, Andrew Hillier, a lawyer for Cantor, said Icap had "embarked on a systematic and carefully planned attempt to poach" leading brokers from Cantor's interest rates division. Cantor had been suing both Icap and the three brokers, who all claimed constructive dismissal.
The two companies compete as intermediaries executing bond, currency and other trades for investment banks.
The London case also raised eyebrows with an inside look into what was depicted as a decadent lifestyle among brokers and traders in the City -- London's equivalent of Wall Street -- with frequent visit to lap-dance and strip clubs.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Untangling Muddy Waters and His Blues

BYLINE:  By JON PARELES

 BODY:
CAN'T BE SATISFIED
The Life and Times of Muddy Waters
By Robert Gordon
Illustrated. 408 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $22.95.
 The story of Muddy Waters is the archetypal path of the blues. McKinley Morganfield was born in Mississippi in 1913 and picked cotton on a Mississippi Delta plantation, where he was nicknamed after the river itself. He sang at fish fries and juke joints and was recorded on the plantation for the Library of Congress. He moved north to Chicago, where he plugged in his guitar and led a band that transformed the sound of the deep rural blues for urban audiences, making music full of pain and pride, menace and lust. 
 He became the "Hoochie-Coochie Man," the "Mannish Boy"; he boasted "Got My Mojo Working." Waters was discovered in turn by homesick Southerners, by radio listeners, by well-meaning folkies and by rock musicians who would blast his songs to a worldwide audience. He was exploited, misused, revived and eventually revered before his death in 1983.
Robert Gordon, a writer and filmmaker who has devoted himself to music from Memphis and points south, seeks out the details behind the archetype in "Can't Be Satisfied." Working through the tangles of a largely oral history, Mr. Gordon has retraced itineraries, sorted through conflicting memories and given credit to undervalued figures like John Work III, the musicologist who helped the folklorist Alan Lomax find Waters on the Stovall Plantation and record him in 1941. 
Waters had already been working his way around the Delta as a musician. He resettled in Chicago in 1943, and in 1947 he began recording for Chess Records, which would be his label until 1975. Though Waters's band was driving club audiences wild, Chess waited years to record Waters with that band rather than other, more old-fashioned lineups. Waters had hits in the early 1950's, but his blues was pushed off the charts by rock 'n' roll. Mr. Gordon, with obvious exasperation, shows how Chess kept trying to remake Waters to fit perceived trends: as a "folk singer," with "The Muddy Waters Twist," with horn sections, amid a psychedelic hubbub, and, more sensibly, with younger English and American blues-rockers. 
The label's accounting practices were hazy at best. While blues-rock bands were playing his songs in arenas, the illiterate Waters was persuaded to sign over the copyrights to Arc Music, Chess's publishing company. Eventually Waters and his manager retrieved them after a lawsuit, and Waters left Chess to revitalize his music and career by restoring his unvarnished Delta attack.
Mr. Gordon's extensive research is tucked into endnotes that give alternate versions of incidents and add some irresistible anecdotes. The biography itself moves briskly, pausing every so often to explain the economics of cotton or to reclaim the startling power of Waters's music when it was made.
A version of "Rollin' and Tumblin' " from 1950 "is little more than a harmonica, a bass drum in overdrive, an occasionally ferocious slide guitar and the orgiastic humming of several grown men," Mr. Gordon writes. "The sounds are pugilistic and sexual. Someone yelps. Someone else responds. The randomness of the interjections is frightening, the rapid-fire drumming disorienting. Muddy's slide rings like loose spokes on an iron wheel, haywire. The harp is hypnotic. Chant and hum, chant and hum. Violence hangs everywhere, the sex heated and raw." 
The music, as Mr. Gordon calmly documents, came from a milieu straight out of gangsta rap: guns, booze, knife fights, fast women and sleazy deals. Waters was a lifelong womanizer who met his last wife, Marva Jean Brooks, when she was 19 and he was over 60. He had at least six children, most illegitimate; mistresses and a daughter were lost to drugs. One former band member was sentenced to life in prison for murder. The pianist Otis Spann, a vital part of Mr. Waters's groundbreaking 1950's band, drank hard and was dead at 39.
Waters's indomitable voice, the lyrics to songs like "Rollin' Stone" (which named a band), and the slash and quiver of his guitar playing hinted at all he had seen. But he revealed little of himself offstage, even in interviews. Mr. Gordon faces an enigmatic and inconsistent character he can track but not quite animate. 
Waters could be as stubborn as the unchanging Delta core of his music, but he could also be disappointingly complaisant, as he was through his years at Chess. Mr. Gordon concludes that Waters carried with him not just the sounds of the Delta cotton fields, but the mentality of the sharecropper who was perpetually indebted to the plantation owner for the "furnish," the supplies and necessities to get through the season that were charged against his share. In an interview that Mr. Gordon cites, Waters said, "It was just, 'I belongs to the Chess family.' " 
That passivity has little connection to Waters's music. His songs are grounded in pride and fierce virility. Mr. Gordon's sharp and comprehensive biography can only accept the paradoxes, recognizing Waters's failings while giving full respect to his mojo.

HEADLINE: Festivals, Festivals Everywhere; 
Summer Arts Events Multiply, Testing Limits of Growth

BYLINE:  By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
They began innocently enough, as high-minded diversions on warm summer nights shared with mosquitoes and lake breezes. But this summer the number of arts festivals nationwide has reached an all-time high of about 3,000, drawing an audience estimated at up to 130 million and accounting, by industry estimates, for close to $2 billion in spending. 
 With the number of arts festivals nearly doubling, by some accounts, since the mid-90's, the festivals have changed the ways Americans consume culture. 
 "Culture has become a destination," said Kate Maguire, executive director of the Berkshire Theater Festival, whose alumni include Eva Le Gallienne, Buster Keaton and Katharine Hepburn. 
Increasingly, she said, people are planning their summers around arts calendars and becoming more discerning, making greater demands on festivals like hers. "It's no longer, 'Let's put on a play in two weeks,' " she said. "A lot of avant-garde work is being done." 
This year more than ever, from the culture-gridlocked Berkshires to Lincoln Center, Charleston, Santa Fe and points in between and beyond, summer festivals of music, theater, dance, film and the visual arts are springing up with particular abandon. 
In some places, the festivals are crowding each other to the point that some arts managers feel they are competing for audiences and artists. But by and large, the managers say that the multitude of offerings provides a critical mass for an explosion of cultural tourism. 
"It's the mall effect," said Paul Kellogg, director of the New York City Opera and of the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., one of the leading opera festivals, founded in 1975. "The summer population will go to an area where there are three evening performances rather than one."
Arts festivals alone account for close to $2 billion a year in spending, not counting art purchases and lodging revenue, according to Jim Shanklin, founder of RSL Interactive, a Seattle marketing services company focused on the arts and a developer of festival Web sites. That does not include about 2,000 more folkish arts and crafts festivals and another 20,000 novelty and other festivals not related to art.
From the Lake Chelan Bach festival in Lake Chelan, Wash., to the New York City Tap Dance Festival on 42nd Street to innumerable Shakespeare festivals, the proliferation has been in all directions. But opera, in particular, seems to breed opera.
"People who like it tend to go to a lot of it," said William Florescu, general director of the Lake George Opera, who shares his audiences with Glimmerglass, the Berkshire Opera in Great Barrington, Mass., and the Saratoga Performing Arts Festival. 
When pressed, some arts directors acknowledge feeling the squeeze of summer competition for audiences and artists. The Opera Theater of St. Louis, which recently completed its 27th season of staging innovative works in an annual May-to-June festival, suffered a dip in single-ticket sales it attributed to a free Shakespeare festival that started last year.
The field is definitely growing more crowded, said Charles MacKay, the general director. 
"When we go to engage singers, we have overlapping dates with Glimmerglass or Santa Fe," he said. Artists juggle offers from the Utah Festival Opera, the Opera Festival of New Jersey, the Des Moines Metropolitan Opera, the Lake George Opera, the Cincinnati Opera and others.
So, Mr. MacKay said, St. Louis has sought to mix traditional crowd pleasers with unusual works that offer opera fans the chance "to put another notch in their belts." The season's four offerings included the world premiere of Cary John Franklin's "Loss of Eden," about the Lindberghs and the Hauptmanns, and a rare staging of Ambroise Thomas's 1868 romantic "Hamlet," and they drew ticket buyers from 42 states and five foreign countries. 
The recently concluded Lincoln Center Festival, now in its seventh season, adopted a similar offbeat and avant-gardish approach, presenting the American premiere of "Ta'ziyeh," an Iranian musical epic based on the battle between the prophet Muhammad's grandson, Imam Hussein, and Caliph Yazid on the Kerbala desert in A.D. 680.
"I get calls all the time" from advice seekers wanting to put on festivals, said Nigel Redden, director of the Lincoln Center Festival and another of the nation's more prestigious arts festivals, the Spoleto festival in Charleston, S.C. "Send out your five-year plan. Then they see it's so overwhelming many never call back."
The Virginia Arts Festival adopted another tactic to differentiate itself when it pitched its tents in eight Southeast waterfront communities six years ago. It set its season from the end of April to the end of May, before other festivals get going. That, said the artistic director, Robert W. Cross, put it at an initial disadvantage because traveling artists tended to wrap up their tours before the Easter lull and stayed home until the summer season. 
But capitalizing on the tourism lure of Colonial Williamsburg, Virginia Beach and Norfolk, the festival gained a quick foothold, this year drawing about 70,000 visitors to performances by the Dance Theater of Harlem, Mark Morris, a collaborative "Romeo and Juliet" with Shakespeare & Company in the Berkshires and the Buffalo Philharmonic, and a giant tattoo of military bands and drill teams. Almost one in four visitors came from out of the area, double the percentage when the festival began. 
Summer arts festivals have been around for ages, most prominently in Europe, where Bayreuth, the Salzburg Festival, the Casals Festival, Documenta and many others have long been fixtures. 
In the United States, the Ravinia Festival in Highland Park, Ill., originating as an amusement park in 1904 to boost ridership on the railroad, became one of the nation's first outdoor classical music meccas and has been the summer home of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra since 1936. The Tanglewood Music Festival just outside Stockbridge, Mass., has been the summer home of the Boston Symphony since 1937 and now attracts some 250,000 patrons a season. Jacob's Pillow, the pre-eminent summer dance festival, in Becket, Mass., was founded by Ted Shawn in 1933, and the Berkshire Theater Festival, now in its 74th season in Stockbridge, began life in a playhouse converted from a casino built by Stanford White in 1888.
The postwar years brought a proliferation of festivals, including the Newport Jazz Festival in 1954, but according to Mr. Shanklin of RSL Interactive the field began really booming as a commercial sector in the mid-1980's.
The International Festivals and Events Association, founded in 1957 and based in Boise, Idaho, counts some 3,300 members -- almost triple the number in 1995 -- from the Kentucky Derby Festival and the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade to the Barbecue Goat Cook-Off in Brady, Tex. Since the University of Illinois at Urbana created the first curriculum in special events management and marketing in 1990, seven other universities have followed suit with undergraduate and advanced programs. There are also annual prizes for creativity in festival organizing, called the Pinnacle Awards. 
The vast majority of festivals have little to do with the arts, but the arts sector has also been growing rapidly, the group's records suggest.
Although comparative data is hard to come by, one veteran manager, Joseph Lillis, executive director of the 50-year-old Sausalito Arts Festival in California, said he believed that the number of arts festivals might have doubled in the past 10 years. An industry Web site, www.Festivals.com, which opened in 1995 listing three events -- Thanksgiving parades in New York, Philadelphia and Detroit -- now tracks 40,000 festivals of all kinds, and the number has been growing by about 1,000 a month. The list includes almost 5,000 arts festivals in the United States, broken down by category: arts and crafts, 2,074; dance, 369; film, 817; fine arts, 511; literature, 679; and theater 505. Another Web site, www.festivalfinder.com, lists hundreds of music festivals by date, location and type of music, from a starlight concert series in Kennesaw, Ga., to an international accordion celebration in Leavenworth, Wash., to a guitar festival in Buffalo to countless easy-to-mount chamber music festivals. 
The lure for communities is not hard to fathom. Even free festivals nourish the local economy. Mr. Lillis in Sausalito said his 60,000 patrons spend an average of $17 each, bringing in more than $1 million, plus gate receipts of $600,000. Thanks to that kind of success, the festival recently built a park and gave it to the city.
For a microcosm of the arts festival world, perhaps nothing can match the Berkshires, with some 65 nonprofit arts groups. "We've done Shakespeare & Company, Jacob's Pillow and now this," said Katie Daily, lunching with two friends from Manhattan on a blanket at Tanglewood one recent Sunday during a chamber music recital.
The night before, Garrison Keillor and his "Prairie Home Companion" held forth on the same manicured lawns. "I live in Minnesota," a bleary-eyed Mr. Keillor said the next day. "We're not a festive people. We're a cautious people. We have small festivals, 20, 25 people in our backyard." 
At the Berkshire Theater Festival, meanwhile, Guy Pellegrinelli of Pittsfield, Mass., turned out with his wife, Mary, for the Kander and Ebb musical "Zorba," in the main theater. "There's a certain element of friendliness that comes with the warm weather," Mr. Pellegrinelli said.
Ms. Maguire, who usually greets guests from the stage before performances, said the mix was carefully thought out. In addition to "Zorba" that weekend, there was a swing-era adaptation of "The Magic Flute" for a younger audience at the Berkshire Museum in Pittsfield and a performance of "Dimetos" by Athol Fugard in the more experimental Unicorn Theater.
"There's no competition; the community wants it all -- dance, theater, music," she said.

(Photographs by Alan E. Solomon for The New York Times)(pg. E1); Keith Phares as Lindbergh in "Loss of Eden," staged in St. Louis. (Ken Howard)(pg. E5)

HEADLINE: Stoking a Stock Market 'Revolution' 

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 29 

 BODY:
Raymundo Magliano, the chairman of the Bovespa, Latin America's mightiest stock market, heaved a sigh as he checked the monitor perched on his elegant antique desk one afternoon early this month and summed up the state of Brazil's markets by spelling out a Portuguese word: C-A-O-S.
 Ten floors below, on the exchange's trading floor, chaos indeed reigned as the Bovespa index registered yet another day of losses. 
 Even before global markets were plunged into their current turmoil, many Brazilian blue-chip companies had listed their shares in New York; because a tax in Brazil made trading in New York much cheaper, much of Bovespa's trading volume went with them. Many local investors, meanwhile, have stayed away from the Bovespa because years of high interest rates to keep inflation under control and defend the Brazilian currency have made a simple bank deposit a safer and often more lucrative bet. The recent accounting scandals involving some of America's top corporate names also have not helped. 
So it may seem a strange time to be making a pitch to spread "people's capitalism" through share ownership across Brazil and push for fresh policies to reverse nearly five years of capital flight to New York markets, but that is just what Mr. Magliano is doing.
"What we want to do is transform the Bovespa into a market for all," he said. Mr. Magliano, 60, an exuberant former broker, took over as Bovespa chairman in January 2001.
"We are revolutionaries, and we are going to spark a cultural revolution."
Given the current economic climate -- and with only about 2 percent of Brazilians owning stocks, compared with roughly half of American adults -- he is going to need a lot of revolutionary fervor.
While Brazilian stocks climbed slightly today, the Bovespa index is down 31 percent so far this year. The currency, the real, is slumping, today sinking to its lowest level since it was introduced in 1994, to 3.2 for for every United States dollar. The country's benchmark C-bond has also taken a hammering. The only thing that seems to be rising is Brazil's country risk -- the premium the country must pay over United States Treasuries to raise cash on capital markets. 
The latest market crisis in Brazil, Latin America's largest economy, was set off by fallout from Argentina's collapse. It is built on fears that Brazil may have to reschedule or even default on its own hefty $250 billion public debt, and on growing concern on Wall Street that Luiz Inacio da Silva, the presidential candidate of the left-wing Workers' Party, could triumph in the elections on Oct. 6.
So far, by doggedly lobbying the government, staging headline-grabbing events including a one-day bourse strike to protest a crippling 0.38 percent tax on financial transactions and hiring actors to stage shows on how to invest in the market at union-sponsored Brazilian Labor Day celebrations this spring, Mr. Magliano has managed to chalk up some victories.
Starting this month, stock transactions are exempt from a tax that is levied on everything from cash withdrawals to checks, known as the C.P.M.F. tax, which had made Bovespa's transaction costs as much as 165 percent higher than that of the New York Stock Exchange. Congress has passed a new corporate law strengthening minority shareholders' rights. And the Bovespa recently started a bourse called the Novo Mercado, modeled on the Neuer Markt in Germany, to increase liquidity and provide smaller Brazilian companies with an alternative source of money.
There is much debate, however, about whether these moves are enough to stop what even Mr. Magliano acknowledges is serious decay.
In 1997, Bovespa's daily average trading volume was around $1 billion, about the same as Toronto's exchange. Today, it has an average volume of $200 million, less than one-sixth of Toronto's. About 40 percent of investors have migrated to American depository receipts of blue-chip Brazilian companies. In the last year, 13 Sao Paulo brokerage firms have closed.
"The major companies no longer participate" in significant volume "on the local market, and the smaller companies that do are left with a bourse that has no liquidity," said Eduardo da Rocha Azevedo, the Bovespa president for two stints in the 1980's, who now runs the Sao Paulo brokerage firm Convencao. "This is the Brazilian model, and it's all wrong."
Mr. Azevedo blames the center-right government of the president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, which is generally seen as market-friendly. A combination of the C.P.M.F. tax and the failure to promote popular capitalism during Brazil's huge privatization program sapped Brazilian capital markets, Mr. Azevedo said.
A base interest rate stuck at 18 percent to defend the real and keep a lid on inflation has also driven investors away from stocks and toward fixed-rate investments, further draining Bovespa's liquidity and discouraging smaller companies from coming to the market to raise capital. So far, only two companies have listed on the Novo Mercado since it opened in February.
"Today, it's better to sell your assets, put the money in the bank and stay at home watching TV," Mr. Azevedo said.
As the Bovespa has slid, an increasing number of market players have demonized the New York Stock Exchange, accusing it of stealing away Brazilian listings. Last year, the appearance of the finance minister, Pedro Malan, at the exchange for a ceremony promoting listed Brazilian companies spurred the Bovespa traders' strike and the push for the C.P.M.F. tax exemption.
But Roberto Castello Branco, head of investor relations at the Brazilian mining giant Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, which lists on both the Bovespa and the New York Stock Exchange, said that since listing in New York raised the profile of Brazilian companies, it should also raise investor interest in Bovespa.
"It's not a zero-sum game," Mr. Castello Branco said. Besides, he said, "a company that is a global player like ours has an obligation to list in New York or London." 
While most analysts say that Mr. Magliano's campaign is headed in the right direction, they also say that a more concerted effort will be needed from the next government to revive Bovespa.
The changes thus far "are necessary and welcome," said Fernando Exel, president of the financial consultant Economatica in Sao Paulo, "but they're not going to generate business overnight."
Mr. Magliano says the recent oversubscription of a local offering of shares of Companhia Vale do Rio Doce held by the Brazilian government is proof that his efforts to get ordinary Brazilians to invest in stocks will pay off, if investors are given the right incentives.
The government allowed workers to use some of their social security deposits, and some 800,000 workers signed up, nearly three-times oversubscribing a 1 billion reais ($334 million) offering.
Under a similar plan, some 370,000 workers subscribed to an offering of the state oil giant Petroleo Brasileiro S.A., or Petrobras. Mr. Magliano predicts strong interest for the coming sale of shares in Banco do Brasil.

HEADLINE: Easing Palestine's Humanitarian Crisis 

BYLINE:  By Peter Hansen; Peter Hansen is commissioner general of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency.

DATELINE: GAZA CITY, Gaza 

 BODY:
A consensus has emerged in the Middle East, among people of otherwise widely divergent views, on one point: something must be done for ordinary families in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. They face a crisis of such dimensions that it threatens everyone in the region.
 On July 16, Ariel Sharon, Israel's prime minister, telephoned Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, to ask for an international effort to help the Palestinian people. Last Wednesday Daniel Kurtzer, the American ambassador in Israel, calling the situation in the territories "a humanitarian disaster," urged Israel to lift travel restrictions on Palestinians. And on Friday the New York Times reported on an ongoing study by the United States Agency for International Development that has found dramatically increased malnutrition and anemia among Palestinian children. By Sunday, Prime Minister Sharon had announced an easing of travel and other restrictions and had named Foreign Minister Shimon Peres to coordinate relief of Palestinians.The United Nations hopes these decisions will be swiftly implemented in such a way that they make a substantive difference to ordinary Palestinians. 
 Mr. Sharon's phone call came on a day when Mr. Annan was meeting in New York with his colleagues in the Quartet -- Secretary of State Colin Powell, Russia's foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, and Javier Solana, the European Union's high representative. They agreed that full humanitarian access would be the fastest way to begin improving the Palestinians' plight, and that the United Nations should lead the humanitarian effort.
The United Nations already has the largest humanitarian operation on the ground in the Middle East, with 10,500 staff in the West Bank and Gaza alone: the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees. Since 1950, UNRWA has catered to the basic health, education and welfare needs of refugees from the 1948 Arab-Israeli War and their descendants -- some of whom still live in so-called refugee camps, which are townships of two- and three-story buildings, while many others are scattered across the region.
Since September 2000, the agency has also been trying to lessen the humanitarian impact of violence, curfews and closures on the refugees in the West Bank and Gaza. It has massively increased its provision of food aid: whereas before the strife such aid went to 11,000 refugee families, it is now targeting almost 220,000 families. As the Palestinian economy has stagnated, the demands on agency resources have soared.
Israel has long understood that the relief agency's work is an important factor in the stability of the large Palestinian population on its doorstep. In 1967, when it took control of the West Bank and Gaza, Israel asked the agency to continue its work there -- a responsibility that, without the agency, would have fallen on Israel's shoulders. More recently, in November 2001, the Israeli delegate to the United Nations General Assembly expressed Israel's "appreciation for the efforts of UNRWA in providing important services, especially in the fields of health care and education."
Despite such statements, there have been attacks on the agency by some commentators in Israel and America alleging, wrongly, that the relief agency is not part of the solution to the violence in the region, but is part of the problem.
The agency faces many difficulties in serving such a highly politicized population, even though it does not police or administer the refugee camps (where one third of refugees live). The agency is committed to ensuring that its installations remain free of militant activity and demands that its 22,000 staff members -- 99 per cent of whom are Palestinian refugees -- do not allow their political beliefs to interfere with their duties. These efforts have brought attacks from Arab commentators (and some in the agency's staff union) claiming that the agency suppresses freedom of speech.
However, in an environment as polarized as the Middle East, the agency would soon loseall credibility if it allowed its commitment to the norms of justice to be diluted by a fear of criticism, regardless of where it might come from.
The agency is working with its donors to tackle some of the difficulties created by the political landscape. For several years it has produced school materials promoting tolerance, nonviolent conflict resolution and human rights. The agency plans to expand this program with further financial support from the United States, which has long been the most generous funder of Palestinian refugee relief. Such support and understanding from the international community is vital if the relief and works agency is to continue to operate apolitically in a politically polarized region -- and to relieve the desperate situation of Palestinian refugees.

HEADLINE: ON THE GROUND: In Seattle; 
Old Economy Still Vital In High-Technology City

BYLINE:  By LYNN ELSEY 

 BODY:
High technology, with Microsoft at the helm, has put Seattle on the map. Still, lumber and agriculture formed the city's industrial backbone, and the old economy continues to play an important role in the Puget Sound area. The retailers Nordstrom and Costco are here, as are the insurance giant Safeco (which has acquired naming rights to the home of the Seattle Mariners, Safeco Field) and, of course, Starbucks and its ubiquitous coffee houses.
 The wobbly American economy has not spared Seattle. The jobless rate, which hovered around 3.3 percent in the late 1990's, has doubled since then, and the once robust housing market has weakened. Boeing's decision to move its world headquarters to Chicago last year cost the area 13,800 jobs, to say nothing of a measure of Seattle's pride. On the other hand, Amazon recently reported quarterly results that were slightly better than expected. 

HOTELS
The Renaissance style FOUR SEASONS OLYMPIC (206-621-1700, from $295) provides all the expected five-star amenities, including high-speed Internet access, a health club that will lend you running shoes and transportation in the hotel's Mercedes S Class house car. The hotel's stately lobby is popular for informal business meetings.
With its arty atmosphere, the ALEXIS HOTEL (206-624-4844, from $295) reflects the hotel's proximity to Seattle's creative-arts district, although guests are as likely to be corporate lawyers as advertising types.
For those on a tight budget, the MAYFLOWER PARK HOTEL (206-623-8700, from $135) is small enough to be personal but large enough to offer 24-hour concierge service and a small exercise room. It is centrally located and an easy walk to the Washington State Convention and Trade Center.
The BELLEVUE CLUB HOTEL (425-454-4424, from $230) is a brief cab ride to Microsoft headquarters as well as the offices of dozens of smaller companies in Seattle's high-technology sphere. Laptops seem de rigueur in the lobby, and the hotel offers free broadband access, cordless phones in all rooms and a technical-support hot line.

DINING OUT
Chuck Stonecipher, president of Advanced Digital Information, says he can't remember the last time anybody at his company went out for a traditional business lunch. "When our suppliers or customers visit, we work over sandwiches that are brought in," he said, adding, "On the rare occasion that we do something more formal, we tend to go to restaurants with good local seafood," like RAY'S BOATHOUSE (206-789-3770, $135 for dinner for two with wine and tip) or the THIRD FLOOR FISH CAFE (425-822-3553, $146) in Kirkland.
Downtown, fish gets a serious steakhouse treatment at the OCEANAIRE SEAFOOD ROOM (206-267-2277, $145). The menu features huge portions of seafood favorites like Alaskan halibut cheeks along with old-fashioned comforts like relish trays, creamed corn and asparagus with Hollandaise sauce; diehard steakophiles can always order the filet mignon.
At ANDALUCA (206-382-6999, $100), the "great glass plates, interesting food and a reasonably priced Spanish wine list" get a thumbs up from Karen Johnson, senior vice president for corporate development at Metro One Telecommunications in Portland.
Recent renovations have toned down its brocaded stiffness, but the GEORGIAN ROOM ($130) in the Four Seasons Olympic retains an air of hushed formality and is considered one of Seattle's most impressive dining experiences. The menu is light, offering reasonably priced contemporary Northwest cuisine.
Jayne Lipe, president of JLipe Consulting, says her favorite place to take clients is BIS ON MAIN (425-455-2033, $95) in Bellevue. "The food and wine are absolutely delicious, service is excellent, and the atmosphere is quiet enough for a good discussion," she said.

NIGHT LIFE
The METROPOLITAN GRILL (206-624-3287), a traditional brass and green-leather place, is a popular spot for business travelers as well as local entrepreneurs; its walls are lined with photos of athletes and well-known business executives who have enjoyed the high-octane Martini and cigar-enhanced atmosphere.
Wine aficionados head to CASCADIA (206-448-8884) for the wine list and live piano music or to BRASA'S bar (206-728-4220) for Mediterranean warmth and celebrity sighting. But the city's best entertainment is found on the field at the Mariner's new ball park, within walking distance of downtown.

ON YOUR OWN
Washington State is the country's second-largest producer of premium wines after California, and several wineries on the dry eastern side of the Cascade Range, including CHATEAU ST. MICHELLE (425-415-3633) in Woodinville and HEDGES CELLARS (425-391-6056) in Issaquah offer tours and wine tastings daily.
SEATTLE SEAPLANES (206-329-9638) offers 20-minute flights with views of the city and its landmarks, including the Space Needle, the Elliott Bay waterfront and the homes of the rich and famous along Lake Washington.
If you visit the Seattle Center (home of the Space Needle), be sure to mosey over to the Experience Music Project, Paul Allen's interactive ode to rock 'n' roll. Opened in 2000 with as much fanfare for the building's unusual architecture and vividly colored stainless steel and aluminum walls as the opportunity for the general public to partake in high-end karaoke, it is often rented by corporations for parties and other events.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Sprite tries to increase sales with a campaign about thirsts.

BYLINE:  By Allison Fass 

 BODY:
IN an attempt to re-engage young consumers, Sprite, the lemon-lime soft drink sold by the Coca-Cola Company, is taking another new turn in a campaign that emphasizes individual passions -- or thirsts -- through the stories of real young people.
 The campaign, which began last night, is tied to several promotions and is the latest attempt by Sprite to turnaround sales and market share that declined in 2001 for the second consecutive year. Sprite spent more than $75 million on advertising last year, according to CMR, a unit of Taylor Nelson Sofres. 
 This is the first effort for Sprite from its new agency, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group. The campaign, titled "Portraits in Thirst," replaces the "Voices" campaign created by the longtime Sprite agency, Lowe & Partners Worldwide in New York. That campaign showed teenagers using rap or rhyme to express their interpretations of attributes that Sprite suggested, like "crisp," "not too sweet" and "absolutely clear." 
Though it sticks with the "Obey your thirst" theme that was used in "Voices" and that dates to 1994, the new campaign invites a different response by asking a question: "What's your thirst?"
Last year, Coca-Cola shifted the Sprite assignment to Ogilvy after more than 15 years of working with Lowe, part of the Partnership unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, and predecessor agencies. Before the "Voices" campaign, previous Sprite advertising from Lowe had relied on light humor through parodies of marketing efforts.
The recent campaign did not stem declines in sales volume and market share, according to John D. Sicher, editor and publisher of Beverage Digest in Bedford Hills, N.Y. Last year, Sprite sales were down 1.8 percent, and market share declined one-tenth of a percentage point. That came after a slow 2000, in which Sprite sales were down 2 percent, and market share declined two-tenths of a percentage point.
"Sprite was one of the three top carbonated soft-drink growth brands during most of the 1990's," Mr. Sicher said. "It has run into some growth problems in recent years."
He cited three factors. "One is, as a light, clear beverage it's being affected by the dramatic growth in bottled water," Mr. Sicher said. "Second, it has needed some aggressive promotion and new advertising for some time. Third, it has not had any product innovation such as Mountain Dew, Coke and Pepsi have."
To address the disappointing statistics, the new ads go beyond previous efforts to relate to young people, ages 12 to 24, by offering unusual but trendy tales. In the spots, Mike Lopez, a low-rider bicycle builder, and Rikkia Mills, a female drag-race-car driver, who were found through interviews with teenagers and executives in industries like music publishing, are shown in urban settings with hip background music from Jurassic 5 and the Donnas, respectively. They explain their own thirsts: Mike's is "style," which he expresses through building low-rider bicycles. Rikkia's is "speed," which she shows through her drag-race car driving.
"There's been a fundamental shift in the consumer landscape," said Darryl Cobbin, vice president and brand director for Sprite in Atlanta. "We think young people had a bit more cynicism two or three years ago."
"This campaign is a bit more optimistic, broader in range and it also begins to take us into different passion points for young people," he added.
The concept is rooted in the television commercials, which will include appearances on BET, Fox, MTV, TBS and WB, but will extend to promotional events where young people can explore and develop their own.
"What Ogilvy has been able to bring to us is this notion of integrated marketing with a capital 'M,' " Mr. Cobbin said. "When we talk with them about a new campaign, they do not approach us with a series of executions exclusively. They come back to us with ideas that will go across different mediums that will accomplish our different communications objectives."
One promotion will be the Liquid Mix Tour, a 15-city concert festival beginning in mid-August that will include music, street sports, artistic demonstrations and fashion. The line-up includes the rapper Jay-Z and the alternative rock group 311. 
Another element will be a contest in conjunction with Def Jam Recordings in which young people can win a Sprite cap or a three-day clinic to learn about the hip-hop music business from executives at Def Jam Recordings.
Consumers can have further "experiences" with the pursuit of their own thirsts at the Sprite Web site, Sprite.com. In addition to viewing more vignettes about Mike and Rikkia, they will be able to create their own portraits based on their specific interests.
"The role of television is obviously in its mass reaches very important, but if you look at the life of the audience we're trying to reach, they don't spend their days in front of the television," said Scott Flood, senior partner and worldwide managing director on the Coca-Cola business at Ogilvy. "They're spending an increasing amount of time, as we all know, online. They're interested in and are engaging in events."

HEADLINE: A Grim Choice In Westchester: Harsh Cutbacks Or Higher Taxes 

BYLINE:  By WINNIE HU 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, July 29 

 BODY:
The Westchester County budget director, Kathleen M. Carrano, recently laid out some of the options for county officials trying to close a $102-million budget gap in the coming year. 
 Lay off 402 employees and cut 58 vacancies. 
 Eliminate 914 day care slots for low-income families.
Close seven parks and four pools. 
Raise bus fares by $2 a ticket, and golf fees by $3 a round.
By the end of the exercise, those cutbacks and others accounted for only $65 million in county expenses -- leaving another $37 million to go. "We've been through these times before," she said. "They're painful, and they're difficult, and we always come through. But it will be a very different government than before."
This summer, it seems that just about everyone has been afflicted by budget woes, from the family next door to the lawmakers in Washington. Even prosperous counties like Westchester are finding themselves running short of money, though for the most part, financial analysts say they are still in better shape than Nassau County and other places with chronic fiscal problems. 
Last week, the Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, warned that the county might be forced to cut programs and services drastically, or raise the property tax levy by 29 percent or higher. Alternatively, he has called for a 1 percent increase in the sales tax that would collect an extra $100 million a year, of which $75 million would pay for increased costs for Medicaid and other state-mandated programs. 
"I'm not very happy about it," Mr. Spano said. "If this was something we caused, I would take responsibility and say, 'I did a bad job.' But that is not the case at all."
Across the New York region, local governments say they are being squeezed on one side by the escalating costs of Medicaid and other mandated programs, and on the other, by declining revenues and investment returns. In particular, the tremendous growth in sales tax revenues in recent years has slowed as consumers shop more frugally.
"Counties are at a crisis point," said Robert R. Gregory, executive director of the New York State Association of Counties, which has unsuccessfully lobbied state legislators to limit the counties' expenses for Medicaid as a way to relieve some of the financial pressure. "They can no longer absorb the cost of the Medicaid program locally." 
State officials said they had already provided millions of dollars in additional state money to county governments, and taken other steps to help them pay for state-mandated programs. "As we move forward, we will continue our efforts to assist county governments, keeping in mind that the state faces its own unprecedented fiscal challenges as a result of 9/11 and the national economic downtown," said Kevin Quinn, a spokesman for the New York State Division of the Budget. 
Faced with these realities, a growing number of counties are seeking to plug their budget holes by raising sales and property taxes. Since January, a half-dozen counties have received approval from the State Legislature for a sales tax increase. Rockland County leaders, for instance, raised the sales tax by 0.62 percent to 7.87 percent in March to collect an additional $14 million for this year's budget. 
In Westchester, officials depleted $36 million this year from a $40 million reserve fund that was started in 1999. They had hoped to replace the money with new revenue from a 1 percent increase in the sales tax, but so far, Mr. Spano and other county officials have been unable to win support for the proposed increase from state legislators. 
Westchester currently has a 6.75 percent sales tax, one of the lowest in the state. Exceptions are the citties of Mount Vernon, New Rochelle, White Plains and Yonkers, whose combination of local, state, and county taxes range from 7.75 to 8.25 percent.
Since state legislators ended their session earlier this month, any approval for a sales tax increase would be unlikely before the Westchester budget process begins in November. So Mr. Spano, a Democrat who once pledged to reduce property taxes, said that he had to consider other options, including a 29-percent increase in the property tax levy -- one of the largest in county history.
Next year, the county's budget is expected to grow by $79.9 million to $1.37 billion, a 6.2 percent increase. More than two thirds of that increase, $54.9 million, would be used for Medicaid and an educational program for handicapped children. The rest would cover rising costs for the state pension system, public transit, the county jail, and other services, Ms. Carrano said. 
Meanwhile, the county's revenues from sales tax revenue, investments and the tobacco settlement are declining. Based on midyear figures, county officials have lowered this year's sales tax projection to $257 million, $2.1 million less than the previous year.
Westchester's budget crisis has already prompted county legislators to crunch numbers months earlier than usual, and citizens groups to mobilize against tax increases of any kind. County leaders raised the property tax levy this year by 3.8 percent, the first increase since Mr. Spano took office in 1998.
County Legislator Clinton I. Young Jr., the Democratic majority leader, said he would not support any proposal for a "double-digit" property tax increase. "No one wants to see services cut or jobs lost, but what alternatives are there?" he asked. "It is unconscionable to raise property taxes by 29 percent."
Kelly Jones, president of the Taxpayers' Alliance of New York, a Westchester citizens group, said that county officials should take this opportunity to evaluate "what is essential, what is not so essential, and what is just nice to have" and make broad cuts. "The county overspends because it's addicted to taxes," he said. "If they are saying things are that bad, then where are the drastic solutions?"
