HEADLINE: These Colors Don't Run, But They Droop; 
Bodegas and Their Awnings Are Both Looking Tired

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
The streets of a city all have a signature of their own, a one-of-a-kind mark fashioned by front stoops and storefronts and the sights, shapes and smells of each wave of immigrants who come to chase after their dreams. 
 In vast swaths of New York, the street signatures have accent marks -- the red-and-yellow metal awnings that hang like droopy eyelids over thousands of Latino-owned grocery stores, called bodegas. The origins of the red-and-yellow bodega awnings and their near-universal application are something of an urban mystery. But it is no secret that the awnings are now disappearing from the city's streetscape, victims of tough times and changing tastes. 
 Red-and-yellow awnings were once a potent symbol of the raw economic and cultural potential of Hispanics -- now the largest minority group in the city -- who arrived in New York with their own language and their own brash, noisy vision of how city life is supposed to be lived. 
The awnings were the height of modernity in the 1970's, the next step after the 19th-century canvas awnings that greengrocers hand-cranked to shield their vegetables from the sun. At a time homeowners across America were turning to siding as a protective miracle, that the awnings were aluminum and plastic was a mark of modernism. Overnight, or so it seemed, the red-and-yellow awnings were everywhere in Latino neighborhoods. 
Thousands of red-and-yellow awnings still hang over the bodega entrances, but most are dingy and bent, lost in a sea of brighter, bolder, bigger signs for the barbershops, fried chicken places, nail salons and electronics stores all around them. 
Today's bodega owners say they would like to join the other businesses and install the newer-style awnings that would make them look modern and successful. But how can they rationalize the expense, they say, when bodegas, even with their long hours, have tortilla-thin profit margins? 
"As a business right now, bodegas have become very competitive and it is difficult for owners to make it," said Francisco L. Rivera-Batiz, director of the Program of Economic Policy Management at Columbia University. Korean delis continue to spring up around them, and supermarkets all over the city now offer Latin foods at cheaper prices. 
Bodega owners say that if they stand for anything, the old awnings have come to represent a struggle to survive that the bodegueros, often originally from the Dominican Republic, seem to be losing.
"Bodegas mean only one thing," said Jose William Garcia, a 39-year-old Dominican who has owned the Colmado Lopez, a grocery at Broadway and 161st Street, for 18 years, "mucho trabajo y poco dinero": much work and little money. 
Some bodega operators even suspect that the awnings may have played some part in limiting their economic potential. 
"The universal way the same red and yellow were applied all over New York really shows a lack of creativity on our part," said Teodoro Ventura, 58, an associate owner of a bodega at St. Nicholas Avenue and 191st Street in Washington Heights. 
Mr. Ventura, who worked for the Dominican government as a regional director of agricultural development before coming to the United States more than 10 years ago, said the uniform awnings made the bodegas seem as if they belonged to a chain run by and for Dominicans. 
"That meant we were exclusive -- just for Dominicans -- when we should have tried to be inclusive, open to everyone," Mr. Ventura said. "What we have done is keep ourselves on the margins of society." 
Hispanic immigrants longed for a taste of home almost from the moment they arrived in the United States. They quickly found their way to bodegas, because they once were the only places to buy plantains, yucca or cassava bread. More than that, they served as informal meeting rooms, places to chat in Spanish, trade gossip from home and, when money was tight, to buy milk and coffee on credit. 
Nearly every bodega is owned individually, for independence is what drives men like Mr. Garcia, the bodega owner on Broadway, to spend nearly half their lives behind the counter. 
Attempts to create a strong federation of bodega owners in New York have stumbled many times. Yet the stores all seem to be of one mind when it comes to the shape, size and colors of their awnings. 
They are so uniform that James E. Rauch, an economist at the University of California at San Diego, who studied minority entrepreneurship in New York, said non-Hispanic businessmen look with admiration -- even jealousy -- at what seems to be a huge cooperative effort by the bodega owners. 
Pamela Fairclough, financial controller of the Community Food Resource Center, an organization in New York that studies food and hunger, said the awnings are the byproduct of the long-standing competition between a few large non-Latin grocery wholesalers, including Krasdale Foods and White Rose Food, that supply most of New York's groceries and supermarkets. 
"It might have looked like a variety of different players were involved, but there weren't," Ms. Fairclough said. The bodegas all bought supplies from either of the two major wholesalers. The wholesalers in turn helped them break into the bodega business, which traditionally required little in the way of capital or experience. 
Krasdale officials say they provided financial assistance to help bodega owners start out, but they never actually provided the awnings. Rather, they said they simply recommended that bodegas have awnings, and provided the names of suppliers who could install them. (An official with White Rose confirmed that the company did some business with bodegas, but said that no one there could remember the origin of the awnings.)
The first bodega to hang a corrugated red metal awning with a yellow plastic skirt and black lettering is lost to history. But the idea quickly spread by word of mouth. With one or two bodegas crammed into nearly every street in Hispanic neighborhoods, envious owners saw the new signs go up and wanted the same thing.
Then other awning suppliers tried to cash in on the growing popularity of the style, ordering materials in bulk, which allowed them to reduce prices and sell the style to even more businesses. 
"It's the same if you walk into any Korean market or nail salon today," said Tama Starr, president of the ArtKraft Strauss Sign Corporation. "Each one is slightly different but they all have the same design consciousness and they all carry the same brands. And if someone comes up with a new technique, they all have to have it within a short time."
And the red-and-yellow color scheme? Valentin Pena Hernandez, who works at El Gigante Supermarket at Broadway and 161st Street, was confident that he knew what the colors meant. "They signify the Dominican flag," said Mr. Pena Hernandez, who is Mexican. But as is evident in almost every bodega, including El Gigante, the Dominican flag is predominantly red, white and blue.
Interviews with more than two dozen bodega owners and workers, as well as with sign company executives and academics, suggest that the colors were selected not for patriotic or symbolic reasons, but simply because they are striking, something advertisers have exploited for years. C-Town supermarkets, Cafe Bustelo, McDonald's and other companies use red and yellow. 
Carlos de Jesus, manager of the Elvis Grocery at St. Nicholas Avenue and 189th Street, recently installed a new yellow skirt on the old awning when the name of the store was changed from Katy to Elvis. "They didn't even ask us what colors we wanted," he said of the sign company. 
"No bodega owner would think to say 'Give me different colors,' " Mr. DeJesus said. "He just wouldn't. Maybe the sign companies bought all the same yellow material and now they give a better price if you use it. Who knows?"
Modifying the Elvis bodega awning cost $250. Elvis Rodriguez, the store's namesake, said he had thought about buying the new generation of awning, made of canvas or plastic stretched over a frame of aluminum tubing like the barbershop next door. But that would have cost $1,500, and he was no closer to being able to afford that than he was to hire the Goodyear blimp to advertise his business. 
"This has worked till now," he said, referring to the corrugated metal awning that is no longer manufactured, but can be repaired by itinerant sign makers. "It calls attention to the store, and at night we put the lights on underneath so someone down the block can see that we're still open. It's always been like that."
Most of the original bodega owners were Puerto Ricans or Cubans. Some were quite successful. They sold their businesses to newcomers from the Dominican Republic, who after a few years sold the businesses to relatives or employees. 
Today it is Mexicans, who are installing awnings painted in their own red, white and green color scheme, inspired by the Mexican flag. Other bodega owners are letting Pepsi or Coca-Cola provide new awnings, in exchange for putting their own logos on them.
Someday perhaps, all the red-and-yellow awnings will be gone. But their colors will remain in the collective memory of Hispanics and in works of art like the paintings of Stephen Beveridge, an immigrant artist from Scotland who has lived on upper Broadway for 15 years. 
For him, the shapes and spirit of the bodega awnings came to stand for the city. "I see the awnings as a symbol of hope and home in what can be an impersonal, challenging environment," Mr. Beveridge said. He has incorporated the awnings in his paintings, since they are part of the signature of his street. 
"On my way home," he said, "I can recognize which block I am on by the bodega on the corner."

HEADLINE: As Career Wanes, Armey's Fund-Raising Waxes 

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 29 

 BODY:
Dick Armey may be retiring from Congress, but he is not retiring from Republican fund-raising.
 Mr. Armey, the House majority leader, is spending much of what will be his final summer in Congress raising money that will go both to individual Republican Congressional candidates and to his political action committee, the Majority Leader's Fund. 
 Just last week, an invitation circulated on Capitol Hill that invited donors to hear Mr. Armey speak at a $500-a-plate luncheon on Aug. 9 at the Union League Club in Manhattan, with all the proceeds directed to the Majority Leader's Fund. Among the sponsors of the event are Lawrence Kudlow, the economist and television commentator, and Roger Hertog, the financier who is a founder of The New York Sun. 
According to the fund, Mr. Armey traveled to 24 states in the first six months of the year and raised more than $2 million for Republican candidates and state parties. In March, he was the host of a fund-raising dinner -- the Retain Our Majority Program, or ROMP -- that collected $850,000 for eight Republican candidates.
The pace of his fund-raising suggests that the Texas Republican intends to remain influential in the party long after he has left Congress, and that the Majority Leader's Fund may be converted into an all-purpose political fund for Mr. Armey to draw on in his next career, whatever that is.
Mr. Armey, a former college economics professor, is mum on questions about what he will do next, and what will become of the fund. His aides say they have no idea about his post-Congress plans, despite news reports suggesting that he may consider a career as a Washington lobbyist, or may want to return to academia.
"I know that he is looking forward to spending time with his family and his wife, but I also know that he is committed to fulfill his obligations to the party, and he is having a great time on the road this year," said Jaylene Farry, the executive director of the Majority Leader's Fund. 
She said that "he remains in very high demand -- I think he just connects with voters out there."
According to its most recent filing with the Federal Election Commission, the fund raised $1.3 million from January through June and had $196,000 on hand. Of its $1.2 million in expenditures during the six-month period, about $272,000 went to Congressional candidates, most of it in the form of $5,000 donations to individual House and Senate campaigns.
The Majority Leader's Fund is separate from Mr. Armey's re-election fund, which was effectively shut down after his announcement last December that he would not seek another term in the House. Mr. Armey had hoped to turn his House seat over to his son, Scott, a county judge in Texas. But the younger Mr. Armey was beaten in a runoff election for the Republican nomination.
Fred Wertheimer of Democracy 21, a group that favors limits on political fund-raising, said there was "nothing aberrational" in Mr. Armey's decision to raise so much money in the final months of his Congressional career.
"It's the way of Washington," Mr. Wertheimer said. "He's continuing to raise huge sums of money to, no doubt, help his colleagues."
Mr. Wertheimer said that while Mr. Armey was barred from converting money from his re-election fund to personal use, there were many fewer limitations on his use of the money in the Majority Leader's Fund.
Mr. Kudlow says he organized the New York fund-raising lunch next month at Mr. Armey's request.
"Dick asked me to help organize something," he said. "It will be small. If we can raise 10 grand or 12 grand, we'll be pleased. I've known Dick very well for many years, and I'm a big fan." 
Mr. Kudlow said he was not surprised by Mr. Armey's busy fund-raising schedule in the months before his retirement. "It's obviously going to be a tough fight to keep the House," Mr. Kudlow said, "and so he's trying as hard as he can to help."
Even as he continues to raise money on behalf of Republican candidates, some of Mr. Armey's friends and supporters are raising money for him -- not for a re-election campaign this time, but for his official retirement portrait.
The National Journal reported last week that a group of Mr. Armey's former aides, including Ed Gillespie, a Republican political operative, and Kerry Knott, a top Microsoft lobbyist, were seeking checks to help raise the $100,000 needed for the painting, which is to hang in the Capitol.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 16, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on July 30 about political fund-raising by Dick Armey, the House majority leader, referred imprecisely to his son Scott, who sought the Republican nomination to succeed his father in Congress. Scott Armey had been a county judge while he was seeking election, but then resigned to take a job with the federal government.

PERSON: Abraham M. Lackman 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
A Young Troublemaker, Now Mature and Moderate

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

DATELINE: ALBANY 

 BODY:
SOME people say it was the governor who tried to have Abraham M. Lackman, then a graduate student in economics at the State University at Albany, expelled. 
 It was the summer of 1975. The city was in a fiscal crisis. But the state was viewed as immune from money troubles. Mr. Lackman had a summer internship with the Democratic-led state Assembly. Long before "off-balance sheet" was uttered by anyone not wearing a green eyeshade, he researched and wrote a report on the hidden debt loads of various state authorities. 
 No one paid much attention, except his professors, who asked to send the report to The Municipal Bond Buyer, a trade publication. It published the entire thing, on the front page.
The state's debt rating was downgraded. Certain telephone calls were made. 
"I was supposed to go to the university and make charges against this kid and get him out," remembered Robert S. Herman, then special assistant to Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut. "I said, 'Stanley, if he goes I go.' "
The episode established Mr. Lackman as troublemaker and budget prodigy. Official forgiveness came when Gov. Hugh L. Carey offered him a job. But, he said: "I don't see it as creating mischief for the sake of mischief. I see it as stirring the pot for the greater good."
Mr. Lackman soon went to work for the Senate finance committee, where he found a way to sidestep lawmakers' mistrust of Mayor David N. Dinkins's request for an income-tax surcharge to pay for the "safe streets, safe city" plan. He took the mayor's statement from a news release -- that the surcharge would put at least 31,000 officers on the streets -- and wrote it into the law.
For a year, in 1994, Mr. Lackman became Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's first budget director, until he grew tired of being separated from his wife and two sons, now 27 and 23. 
It was his protege, Marc V. Shaw, now deputy to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who who floated his name for the job. Mr. Lackman presided over difficult budget cuts and encouraged a hard line in labor negotiations.
"We were known as these two short Jews with beards," Mr. Shaw said. "The difference is he's a real Republican and I'm not."
But Mr. Lackman, who has been the secretary of the Senate finance committee for eight years, credits himself with tugging his current boss, Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, toward the center. 
He is given to moderate pronouncements like: "Labor has a constituency. They represent their constituency, and they're actually trying to do the right thing." Or: "Across-the-board tax cuts are very expensive. And it's not at all clear how successful they've been."
Slight and smiling, Mr. Lackman pads about the Capitol with a looseness that belies his bottom-line concerns. He is, perhaps, a poet among apparatchiks, one who can discuss in detail the making of amarone, a strong Italian wine (let the grapes rot in the sun first). Although he says, "I never thought of myself as, like, golf," he picked up the sport after seeing a red fox cross a green. 
At a party with Gov. George E. Pataki, the two agreed that Big Pink, the storied house near Woodstock where Bob Dylan recorded, should be included in the governor's proposal for a state heritage trail, Mr. Lackman recalled.
Mr. Lackman has friends on both sides of the aisle. He recently visited Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Democrat, at his weekend house in the Catskills, and he is on call when the three Albany leaders, Mr. Pataki, Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno, just cannot agree. Again. 
"If people criticize me," he said, "it's because I'm willing to compromise, to understand the argument of the other side. I don't automatically assume the other side is wrong. It's easy to be a Reagan Republican or a McGovern liberal if you don't want results."
AT the same time, he defends the widely ridiculed process of making laws in Albany. "The level of grappling with thoughts at the leaders' meetings is fairly high," he says.
The child of two Holocaust survivors, Mr. Lackman, 54, was born in Belgium. His parents moved to New York and became garment workers, then owners of a raincoat factory, and their son became a left-wing radical at New York University. After college, he managed the Eighth Street Bookshop in Greenwich Village, visited by Abbie Hoffman and Allen Ginsberg. He became interested in economics when in the gasoline crisis in the early 70's he made money on investments in alternative-fuel stocks. 
He acquired a more conservative outlook. "I was very disillusioned with the whole culture, particularly 'if it feels good, it's O.K.,' " he said.
Like any poet, Mr. Lackman has a trove of old ideas that floundered -- building a bridge from Oyster Bay to Connecticut to energize Long Island's economy and lifting rent regulations but requiring landlords to give some of the proceeds to a fund for cheaper housing.
More often, he says, he is on the mark. He will leave in November to be president of the Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities, where he will lobby for private institutions. The trend, he says, is toward economic development like the deal to attract Sematech, the microchip maker, to Albany, in which universities will have a large role. "If you have the right idea at the right time," he said, "you can make a change."

HEADLINE: Our Banana Republics 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
New Jersey has always been a good state for scandals, and last week provided two. One, the case of Web-snooping by a Princeton admissions officer, which involved a total of 11 applicants to Yale, was the subject of front-page stories across the nation. (Disclosure: I'm a Princeton professor.)
 The other -- further revelations about the way dishonest budgeting by former Gov. Christie Whitman crippled the state's finances -- has dire implications for all of the state's eight million people, who face the prospect of higher taxes on their houses, more potholes in their roads, fewer teachers in their children's classrooms and worse medical care for their parents. This story received no national coverage at all. 
 Experts already knew that the Whitman administration had used creative accounting to justify a series of tax cuts. Last year New Jersey Policy Perspective, a local think tank, released a study of fiscal policies in the 1990's titled "Take the Money and Run." Among other things, the state stopped contributing to its pension funds. This made the budget look a lot better, but created a financial hole. In an attempt to fill that hole Governor Whitman violated the basic principles of pension funds by having them engage in stock arbitrage, borrowing money to speculate on the market. 
Now the state's taxpayers must make up for an investment loss of $22 billion, most of a year's tax receipts. But don't cry for New Jersey; Mrs. Whitman wasn't alone in her misbehavior.
For one thing, many corporations with pension plans used a similar trick to inflate their bottom lines. As the current issue of Business Week explains, the pension time bomb involves large numbers; I'd say it's the equivalent of at least 50 WorldComs. 
Furthermore, Mrs. Whitman's policies were by no means the worst among the states. That honor may fall to Tennessee, though Alabama, where a cash crunch stopped all jury trials for awhile, may run a close second. 
The fact is that in recent years many states have been run like banana republics. Responsibility gave way to political opportunism, and in some cases to mob rule. When Tennessee considered a tax increase last year, legislators were intimidated by a riot stirred up by radio talk-show hosts. Only when lack of cash forced the governor to lay off half the work force did the state, which has the second-lowest per capita taxes in the country, face up to reality.
The only reason Tennessee doesn't look like Argentina right now is that it isn't a sovereign nation; since the federal budget was in good shape until recently, there's a safety net. And the federal budget was in pretty good shape because the Clinton administration, unlike state governments, behaved responsibly. Budget projections were honest -- if anything, too cautious -- and boom-year surpluses were used to reduce debt. 
But the responsibility era is over. Even as state governments face up to the consequences of cooked books in the 1990's, the Bush administration is following in their footsteps.
The latest antics of the White House Office of Management and Budget have even the most hardened cynics shaking their heads. It's not just that projections for fiscal 2002 have gone from a $150 billion surplus to a $165 billion deficit in the space of a few months; it's not just that the O.M.B. projects a much smaller deficit next year, when everyone else -- including the Republican staff of the Senate Budget Committee -- says the deficit will increase. It's also the fact that O.M.B officials simply lie about what their own report says.
"The recession erased two-thirds of the projected 10-year surplus. . . . The tax cut, which economists credit for helping the economy recover, generated less than 15% of the change." So reads the agency's press release. Yet as the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities points out, the actual report attributes 40 percent of the budget deterioration to tax cuts, only 10 percent to recession. Maybe dishonesty in the defense of tax cuts is no vice.
State governments turned into banana republics in part because voters didn't realize that a charming, personable chief executive can also be an irresponsible opportunist, seeking political advantage through policies that ensure a fiscal crisis on someone else's watch. Now the same governing style has moved to Washington. And this time there's no safety net.

Nicholas D. Kristof is on vacation.

HEADLINE: Charities Find Donors Scarce As Market Losses Compound 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Ashoka, a nonprofit organization that helps develop social service agencies around the globe, sent an S.O.S. last month to potential contributors. "Three of our top seven donors lost 90 percent of their wealth last year," the letter said, explaining Ashoka's straits.
 Many other businesses that usually contribute heavily to charity have suffered financial setbacks too, said Bill Drayton, the former McKinsey & Company consultant who founded Ashoka and is its chief executive. "We don't know the exact numbers, but they're selling things that make one believe they're in some difficulty," Mr. Drayton said. 
 So charities keep adding holes to the belts they had tightened as the economy soured and then cinched again after Sept. 11. Measures being taken include postponing new programs and increasing solicitations.
"Charities everywhere are struggling even more than they were at the end of last year," said Trent Stamp, the executive director of Charity Navigator, an online charity watchdog organization. "Everyone knows foundation endowments are down, and donors are getting hit by the stock market."
Ashoka, the charity of choice for many entrepreneurs, described the solicitation as "an unusual appeal for help," but such appeals are all too familiar to donors these days.
"We're getting all sorts of earnest pleas from organizations saying collections are down and programs are threatened," said Daniel J. Rose, the real estate developer whose family is among New York's most philanthropic. "This has been a year of great stringency for charities."
Mr. Rose has an unusual perspective. He also founded the Harlem Educational Activities Fund, or HEAF, a small nonprofit organization that provides enrichment programs to urban students with the goal of getting them into New York's elite public high schools.
Contributions to the fund have dropped significantly over the last year, so its staff has been making what Mr. Rose called herculean efforts to attract new donors and re-enlist dormant donors. But HEAF is also making contingency plans.
"I think every charity today is hoping life will get better but uncomfortably preparing to adjust if it doesn't," Mr. Rose said, "which means eating into reserves, deferring programs you wanted to start and retrenching."
Mr. Stamp, whose Charity Navigator service analyzes tax returns of some 1,200 charities and rates them, said many have stopped hiring and reduced or eliminated programs. 
But the pain has not been equally spread among organizations, Mr. Stamp said. The charities he said would weather the donor drought best were service providers like food banks and homeless shelters, whose effectiveness can be measured easily, and community trusts, which have expertise in giving. 
"Dollars are scarce, so donors are even more concerned that their giving is not wasted," he said.
The breaking of a major pledge in the New York area last became public in the late 1980's, when Ivan F. Boesky, the arbitrageur who was convicted of insider trading, failed to make good on commitments to Princeton University and the Jewish Theological Seminary.
But rumors about major donors reneging on pledges now abound. Cultural institutions have spread whispers about various Wall Street figures who are in arrears, but no officials will make those charges on the record, because embarrassing donors is taboo in the charity world.
To maintain commitments while dealing with the realities of the economy, several major donors have said they are extending the time over which they will be paying off pledges. Ted Turner told The Wall Street Journal his stake in AOL Time Warner Inc. had lost so much value he planned to stretch a five-year, $250 million pledge to the Nuclear Threat Initiative, which works to abolish nuclear weapons, over seven years.
At Ashoka, Vinette Brown, the associate director of development (charity's word for fund-raising), said she has seen some donors who were unable to pay off pledges. For instance, Ashoka has received $2 million of a five-year, $5 million pledge but does not expect to receive the remaining $3 million, Ms. Brown said. A $1 million oral pledge has evaporated, she said.
"It's not the person's fault," Ms. Brown said. "His stock is at 1 percent of its peak level."
Luckily for Ashoka, only 10 percent of its endowment is exposed to the fluctuations of stocks, so it has not suffered as badly as many charities, including the David and Lucile Packard Foundation, whose endowment is down more than 50 percent; the Lilly Endowment, which is down more than 40 percent; and the Ford Foundation, down 30 percent.
Ashoka has made up some of the contribution deficit by finding new donors, like the American Indian Association, which gave $500,000, and the Hilti Corporation, which is underwriting a program in Egypt. Still, it has cut $3 million from its budget, and Mr. Drayton was not optimistic.
When the impact of the oil crisis struck foundations in 1975, their giving dropped 28 percent and did not recover for 10 years, according to The Chronicle of Philanthropy.
"This looks worse than it did then," Mr. Drayton said last week when the stock market was dropping. "This bubble is worse than anything we've ever seen in the entire financial history of the United States, and that is not encouraging." 

CORRECTION-DATE: August 1, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about the finances of charities affected by the decline in the stock market misidentified a donor found by one nonprofit organization, Ashoka, to make up part of its deficit. The donor is the American India Foundation, not the American Indian Association.

HEADLINE: Labor to Press for Changes In CorporateGovernance 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Organized labor will announce plans today to throw its considerable weight -- in lobbying and in shareholder fights -- behind efforts to reform stock options, severance pay and pensions.
 At a labor rally on Wall Street, John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., plans to announce the labor movement's support of several proposals, among them recording stock options as expenses and prohibiting top corporate officials from selling company stock while in office. 
 Noting that scandals at Enron, WorldCom and Arthur Andersen had cost 28,500 workers their jobs, Mr. Sweeney will call on the Securities and Exchange Commission and the three main stock exchanges to agree to a single higher standard for publicly traded corporations. 
"When corporate criminals invade our workplaces and our markets to steal our jobs and our savings, we must react every bit as decisively as when thieves enter our homes and try to bring harm to our loved ones," Mr. Sweeney will tell union members, according to the prepared text of his speech.
Labor unions have already played a role in moving accounting reforms through Congress and in several successive shareholder battles that have brought about changes, among them persuading the Walt Disney Company to stop using the same firm to audit its books and to do consulting work for it. In his speech today, Mr. Sweeney says that labor will step up these efforts -- in meetings with executives and in shareholder fights, demonstrations, lobbying and e-mail campaigns.
He promises that the A.F.L.-C.I.O., a federation of 66 unions representing 13 million workers, will work for reforms, company by company, starting with the Standard & Poor's 100. He says unions will use more than $5 trillion in union pension funds to pressure corporate managers to be more responsive and responsible.
He will also call for changes to give pension funds more power to choose directors who do not rubber-stamp the decisions of company executives. He also raises the possibility of banning stock options altogether, and he wants workers to be able to choose representatives on the boards of their 401(k) plans.
Although unions represent only a fraction of the workers at companies hit by corporate scandal, labor leaders say this is an opportune time to rein in executive compensation and to align the interests of executives more closely with those of investors and workers.
"Nearly 100 years ago, robber barons hijacked our country and our wealth by taking advantage of the legal and regulatory voids created by our change from an agricultural to an industrial economy," Mr. Sweeney's speech says. "Now we're faced with 21st century corporate pirates who took advantage of our transition from an industrial to an information economy to kidnap working families and take us back to the past."
Citing the efforts of the Stanley Works to reincorporate in Bermuda, Mr. Sweeney will call for outlawing the use of offshore tax havens, which he says make it easier for companies to evade taxes and accountability. He will also call for revising bankruptcy laws so that workers who lose their jobs because of corporate scandals will not receive a mere fraction of the severance pay due them.
When Enron employees found themselves without jobs and with their 401(k) plans largely wiped out, the federation led a fight in bankruptcy court to obtain more severance pay for 4,200 laid-off workers. Enron said it could pay only a fraction of the severance pay they were owed, but the workers won a $34 million settlement promising up to $13,500 each.
Today, Mr. Sweeney will announce the federation's plans to file a similar lawsuit on behalf of 17,000 laid-off WorldCom workers. 
Charles M. Elson, director of the Center for Corporate Governance at the University of Delaware, said: "A lot of folks in the governance area have been calling for a lot of these things for a long time. I think stock options should be expensed, and I don't think C.E.O.'s should be selling their stock when they're still working, except under extraordinary circumstances."
Mr. Elson said the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s pledge to play a larger role should give a big lift to the corporate overhaul movement.
"Labor has been a very active voice in the governance area and a very successful voice," he said.
Mr. Sweeney joined a labor demonstration yesterday at the Stanley Works in New Britain, Conn., to protest its plan to reincorporate in Bermuda. On Wednesday, he plans to lead a labor rally at the headquarters of Fidelity Investments in Boston, the world's largest large mutual fund company, to protest its policy of not disclosing how it votes in shareholder battles.
After his speech today, Mr. Sweeney plans to meet with Richard A. Grasso, the president of the New York Stock Exchange, and Henry M. Paulson Jr., the chief executive of the Goldman Sachs Group, to discuss his ideas for corporate overhaul.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. chief, John J. Sweeney, speaking at a rally yesterday outside the Stanley Works factory in New Britain, Conn. The union federation is fighting Stanley's efforts to reincorporate in Bermuda. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Officials Seek More Designers For Downtown 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Responding to criticism of the plans to rebuild Lower Manhattan, officials overseeing the development said yesterday that they wanted to open up the design effort to more architects and planners.
 The proposal, which originated with directors of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation after six initial plans were released two weeks ago, would broaden the process to include smaller design firms and foreign teams. 
 Many such groups were excluded from consideration for the first design contract because of their relative lack of experience working on big projects in New York. For instance, the firms were required to have 10 years of urban planning experience and to have worked on at least three $100 million projects. 
Officials involved in the rebuilding effort, including two directors of the development corporation who favor opening up the design process and who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said they believed some effort to expand the number and type of firms submitting ideas for the World Trade Center site would come to fruition over the next few weeks. They noted that the criticism of the first site plans had apparently persuaded several city and state officials to overhaul the design effort to win public support for the process and the plans for the site. 
Last week, Gov. George E. Pataki said that planners should consider broadening their site designs, possibly moving commercial space previously on the trade center site to nearby areas, leaving more potential space for a memorial and cultural development on the site. And Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has also criticized the initial plans, saying that he intends to submit some of his own ideas, including putting housing on or near the site.
One development corporation official said the new effort would not begin with an entirely clean slate.
"This would be very different from creating a full-blown new master plan," one director of the development corporation said. "It would take the things that people responded to in a very positive way. Then it would try to have new groups of architects look at those possibilities in different ways, to open up the ideas and discussions."
Development corporation officials are still negotiating with officials from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the owner of the site and the development corporation's partner in the rebuilding, over the terms of a new process. 
While the Port Authority's approval is not required for the development corporation to hire new design consultants to come up with ideas, the two agencies have made an effort to work together. 
Earlier this year, the development corporation issued its own request for proposals from architecture firms to create the plans for the trade center without consulting the Port Authority. When the Port Authority objected, the request was quickly withdrawn and a new request was issued with the inclusion of the Port Authority.
Spokesmen for the two agencies would not confirm or deny that a new design process was in the works. A spokesman for the Port Authority, Michael Petralia, said the agency "is getting public input on a number of ideas on how to move forward in order to ensure a successful effort."
He added, "It's premature to comment on any particular idea except to say our focus should be on ideas that help us move forward in an open, well-thought-out manner."
Matthew Higgins, a spokesman for the development corporation, said, "We're considering a range of ideas on how best to incorporate public input, but at this stage many of them are just ideas."
A spokesman for Mr. Pataki, Michael McKeon, said the governor was "open to ideas that continue to improve the process. If the directors decide to pursue something like that, we'll take a look at it."
The six site plans released two weeks ago were designed by a team of planners and architects headed by Beyer Blinder Belle, a New York firm. They were widely criticized as uninspired and uninteresting, with critics responding unfavorably to the dense array of commercial buildings that surrounded a central site, which was reserved for a memorial to victims of the attack on Sept. 11. 
Beyer Blinder Belle officials did not return two telephone calls seeking comment.
The process in which Beyer Blinder Belle was selected also was criticized for limiting the field of potential designers by requiring extensive experience in urban planning and involvement in major projects.
The new call for designers and architects would have less onerous requirements for experience, officials said. Smaller firms with some design credentials and less formal experience would be eligible. Foreign firms also would be encouraged to apply.
New York New Visions, a coalition of civic, architecture and design groups that has contributed ideas related to the rebuilding effort, called on the development corporation and the Port Authority yesterday to expand the planning effort and to "rethink its goals, priorities and process."
"What we have before us are not master plans that provide a range of choices to the public and decision makers," said Marcie Kesner, the co-chairwoman of a New York New Visions task force that analyzed the initial six designs. "Before dealing with the details of site plan or design, our elected and appointed officials must define a compelling vision for this public site and for Lower Manhattan. This has not yet happened."

HEADLINE: Staff Members of Wall St. Journal Returning to Offices Near Ground Zero 

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
Amid the irritating minutiae that attend any move, the first large contingent of Wall Street Journal reporters and editors returned yesterday to their offices in 1 World Financial Center next to ground zero, where everything was familiar and nothing was familiar.
 The blue-black carpets were so new that they bristled. The state-of-the-art telephones worked, or failed, with the normal whimsy of state-of-the-art technology. Snippets of office talk mixed journalistic commonplaces ("I still don't have a good anecdote that would tie this all up.") and musings about old neighbors ("The fruit vendor, the one with the beard who worked on Liberty Street, I wonder where he is?"). 
 The Journal was far from the first business to move its employees back to the neighborhood. Construction delays, environmental testing and staff concerns ensured that they returned well after other World Financial Center tenants like Deloitte & Touche and the Battery Park City Authority.
But Sept. 11 is such a part of the newspaper's institutional history -- the comprehensive coverage its scattered staff produced for Sept. 12 won a Pulitzer Prize -- that the permanent return of the first 80 or so workers to the place they fled and later feared was both a personal and a semipublic event.
"I was struck by the fact they frosted the windows in the lobby," said the economics editor, Constance Mitchell Ford. "When I left that morning, that's where I looked. The first tower had just fallen. People were running and screaming and debris was falling." She added, "I'm so relieved my office window doesn't look that way."
A handful of editors like Ms. Ford, two assistant managing editors, and the managing editor, Paul E. Steiger, were on hand to greet returning journalists. Steven V. Goldstein, vice president for communications at Dow Jones & Company, The Journal's parent, shuttled television crews and non-Journal reporters through the construction workers and boxes. No corporate officers were on hand.
The newly appointed publisher, Karen Elliott House, was on a vacation that could not be postponed, Mr. Goldstein said. Her husband, Dow Jones's chief executive, Peter R. Kann, was with her. 
"The reporters did notice that there was a lack of senior people here to welcome us back," said Tom Lauricella, a Journal mutual funds reporter and newsroom director for the Independent Association of Publishers' Employees, part of the Communications Workers of America. 
A survey taken in the late spring by employees affiliated with neither the union nor the management found that 72 percent of the 175 people asked wanted to relocate elsewhere. The finding of asbestos residue in an air vent earlier this year, after the Dow Jones offices were given a clean bill of health, heightened employees' worries. After its removal, studies by both union and management contractors found the site to be clean.
Mr. Goldstein said three of the seven floors leased by Dow Jones would be reoccupied by 400 Journal and Dow Jones employees. About 250 others, including Journal copy editors and art designers, have been relocated to South Brunswick, N.J. Others, like the employees of the Web site wsj.com, will now move from New Jersey to Dow Jones's offices in SoHo.
About 800 employees of The Journal and its sister publication, Barron's, had worked at 1 World Financial Center last year. Dow Jones is now due to resume payments to its landlord, Brookfield Financial Properties.
"It's weird to be back," Mr. Lauricella said. "I think we all expected it to be an odd experience. We're in the same office building, on the same floor, but everything is completely different."
Some journalists had gone on earlier company tours of the site, and editors like Mr. Steiger had made their own inspection trips earlier. The impact of the return, Mr. Steiger said, "is not going to sink in until I'm actually in my office and at my desk and walking around." But even now, he said: "When you kind of go by where the towers were, so-called ground zero, it kind of aches at you. That will happen for people for a while."

HEADLINE: 9/11 Memories Cast Shadow On Primary 

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
Even as the Democratic candidates for governor ratchet up campaigning in the final weeks before the primary, their advisers are anticipating a period when they will have to soften the tone, shift the emphasis to leadership and at least evoke a mood of reconciliation.
 Usually such transformations occur the day after a primary, when the loser espouses a message of unity and healing, for the good of the party. This year, though, the day after is Sept. 11, and political advisers said the first anniversary of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon would loom large in campaigns, particularly in New York. 
 Eleven states -- including New York -- and the District of Columbia have primaries scheduled for Sept. 10. Analysts predict the closeness to the anniversary will influence everything from the candidates' advertising to the tenor of stump speeches. 
Any negative campaigning, a tactic often employed at the end by trailing candidates, is not likely to play well with voters in a somber mood, the analysts predict. More mundane tactics, like get-out-the-vote calls a day or so before the primary, are likely to be altered, shifting perhaps to reminders of the patriotic duty of voting.
For New York, the timing has the potential to throw a major complication into what is expected to be a hard-fought race.
Several political analysts say the anniversary is likely to change the tactics of the two Democrats, Andrew M. Cuomo, the former federal housing secretary, and H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, including how they spend their money and the content of their advertisements.
It will also deprive the winner of a much-desired boost the day after the primary: even as their Republican opponent, Gov. George E. Pataki, is sure to be prominent at public events, neither Mr. Cuomo nor Mr. McCall expects to campaign on Sept. 11.
"There is definitely an unclosed wound in the New York voter's psyche," said Norman Adler, a longtime political consultant not affiliated with either campaign, "and people have to be very careful that they are not rubbing dirt into it." 
Stuart Rothenberg, who publishes a nonpartisan political newsletter, said that although the anniversary was most significant in New York, many consultants in the array of congressional, gubernatorial and local primaries in other states were also weighing how to handle campaigning leading up to Sept. 11.
"Some consultants say it will be a 24-hour event, but I am doubtful of that," Mr. Rothenberg said. "I just think there is going to be enough national media coverage leading up to the anniversary of the tragedy that it is going to create a certain feeling, and that will make it difficult to run a traditional campaign with attacks and the usual political rhetoric."
Last year, the Democratic mayoral primary fell on Sept. 11, but voting was halted after the attacks and rescheduled on Sept. 25. The candidates mounted largely subdued campaigns under the blanket of attack coverage.
As it is, the September political calendar presents severe complications.
Campaigns normally pull out of the August doldrums after Labor Day, which is Sept. 2. This year the candidates must also consider Rosh Hashana, which begins a few days later at sundown Sept. 6 and normally brings a lull in campaigning, particularly aimed at Jewish voters. The holiday ends Sept. 8, just a couple of days before the primary. 
Political analysts predict that the campaigns will end up with a more solemn tone, with fewer negative attacks and with campaign stops that emphasize the candidates' leadership qualities. News coverage is likely to be focused elsewhere, so the candidates may be forced to use more commercials, giving a potential advantage to the candidate with more money. Mr. Cuomo has raised more money than Mr. McCall. 
The need for more delicate, softer steps on the campaign trail could place the trailing candidate at a severe disadvantage. Normally, candidates in that position would consider negative advertisements and attacks on the stump to get attention and tarnish their opponent's image.
"The playbook calls for going after one opponent or another," said David Axelrod, a political consultant who has advised both Mr. McCall and Dennis Mehiel, a candidate for lieutenant governor. "But whether people will tolerate that, I don't know. Just the word 'attack' is repugnant around that time."
"I think it is going to be a tough period if you are out there savaging one another at a time when people are in a reflective, somber mood," he added.
Another consultant, Richard Schrader, who ran Mark Green's campaign for mayor last year during a primary delayed by the Sept. 11 attacks, agreed.
"I don't there there will be attack ads," he said. "The public will not be in a mood for politicians attacking one another. It will look self-serving."
Since Sept. 11 is expected to be high in voters' minds, the candidates must find a way of addressing the issue without looking as if they are capitalizing on it.
Already, Mr. Cuomo suffered a setback when he criticized the leadership of Mr. Pataki in contrast to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, saying he merely "held the leader's coat." Mr. Cuomo's standings in public polls dropped afterward.
When asked about campaigning near the anniversary, the candidates and their strategists, while not revealing details, did indeed say that, even more than usual, they would seek to portray the candidates as effective, stable leaders. That is partly to contradict Mr. Pataki, who many strategists believe has benefited from his prominence in Sept. 11 coverage.
"One of the lessons of 9/11 was the need for real leadership in these new times, and I believe the campaign will highlight that," said Josh Isay, campaign manager for Mr. Cuomo.
Voters, said Mr. McCall, "are going to say, 'Wait a minute, who is going to be in charge? Who are they? What have they done?' And particularly they know we have an incredible challenge ahead not just because of Sept. 11 but the economic challenge."
A top campaign aide to Mr. Pataki said, "I think for the public, post-9/11, the issue of leadership and where we stand on security are much more important."
There is disagreement over whether the attention paid to the anniversary will diminish voter turnout during the primary. Some believe it will be hard to mobilize voters paying more attention to the anniversary, while others look to recent history as a better guide.
Despite predictions that the terrorist attacks would leave voters less inclined to go to the polls, turnout in the mayoral primary last year was the highest since 1989, 26 percent. 
Either way, consultants believe the standard get-out-the-vote pitch will not do. A nightmare scenario is calling voters just as they are watching a tear-filled tribute to a fallen firefighter or police officer.
Mr. Adler said a campaign caller might instead emphasize the importance of voting, suggesting a script that might say, "Tuesday is Election Day. These terrible events were done by people who wanted to destroy democracy . . ."
Of course, the anniversary events will come to an end and regular campaigning will resume. It is worth noting that last year's mayoral runoff on Oct. 11 ended with the Democratic candidates, Mark Green and Fernando Ferrer, accusing one another of negative, divisive attacks.
Aides to both Mr. McCall and Mr. Cuomo said they planned to resume campaigning within a day or so of the anniversary, depending on the atmosphere.
Then they will have to assess the degree to which the anniversary coverage affected Mr. Pataki, who is far ahead of either Mr. Cuomo or Mr. McCall in the polls and has resisted the Democrats' attempts to engage him.
David Garth, who was Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's political strategist in last year's campaign, said the candidate who can most identify himself with his predecessor, Mr. Giuliani, or even get an endorsement from him, would gain the most. At this point, he said, "Pataki is associated with Giuliani."

HEADLINE: 8 Years After Invasion, Haiti Squalor Worsens 

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti 

 BODY:
Sonia Jean-Pierre's life is one of apocalyptic misery. With hardly any food or work, her only refuge is a concrete cell. The searing sun is blotted out by cardboard pasted over the windows. On the wall by her bed, she has scrawled, "Jesus Christ is coming soon," like a promise of salvation to greet her every morning. 
 Ms. Jean-Pierre and hundreds of neighbors live as squatters inside the old Fort Dimanche Prison, once the brutally efficient killing chamber of the Duvalier dictatorships. A prison no longer, it has been renamed, hopefully, Village Democratie. 
 The poor cram themselves into the dingy cells and even inside the old sentry towers that look out over the surrounding shanties, where 2,000 more souls live without water, schools or electricity. Some are so desperate they eat pancakelike disks of bouillon-flavored clay. Poverty is the only jailer. 
"We are free prisoners," said Ms. Jean-Pierre, who rested one recent afternoon on the cool concrete floor. "We are still living like prisoners." 
Nearly eight years after the United States led an invasion of Haiti to oust a military junta and restore President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to power, Village Democratie is just one measure of this country's despairing slide. 
Increasingly exasperated with Mr. Aristide's government, which has yet to resolve a two-year-old deadlock with its opposition, the United States and European countries have blocked some $500 million in aid, hoping to encourage greater democracy. Critics say the decision has merely eroded the hopes and deepened the poverty of this country's seven million or so people.
For a nation as poor as Haiti, withholding the money has become both carrot and stick. Haiti still lingers near the bottom of the United Nations' annual survey of living conditions. Life expectancy is less than 53 years. Preventable diseases go untreated. The yearly income of the average family is less than is needed to sustain a single person. 
Mr. Aristide calls the withholding of the aid an "embargo." His American supporters, including the Congressional Black Caucus and well-paid lobbyists, say it is immoral to withhold the aid and punish the Haitian people, as government agencies go without budgets, plans or projects to provide water, health care and schools. Some $150 million from the United States, they note, might not only improve roads, water and health but also create jobs. 
Still, diplomats and aid officials say, Mr. Aristide's use of the term "embargo" reflects calculated rhetoric more than reality. Trade and travel continue, and relief, including contributions from the United States, flows into Haiti through nongovernmental groups. 
Solving Haiti's problems, they argue, will take more than just an infusion of aid. Most important, they say, Mr. Aristide has yet to prove that his government has escaped the corruption and destructive self-interest of governments past.
Meanwhile, the political stalemate, which arose over a disputed election, and the international response to it, have stalled what little functioning government democracy might have brought.
"The situation is getting worse for the majority of the people," said the Rev. Jan Hanssens, a Roman Catholic priest who sits on the Justice and Peace Commission of the Bishops' Conference. "There is certainly no hope unless there is a drastic reassessment of Haitian society itself. If things simply go on as now, there is no chance." 
Along the streets of Village Democratie, faith in politicians is as elusive as a decent job. Faded posters of Mr. Aristide, wearing the presidential sash and with his arms outstretched, are his only presence.
Laughing young men crouched at the entrance to the former prison and gambled a few wrinkled gourde notes, the country's currency. Inside, past corridors whose crumbled walls reveal a weed-choked courtyard, people walked home after church clutching hymnals titled "Songs of Hope." 
Inside tiny rooms with cardboard walls, slim shafts of sunlight cut through the haze of charcoal smoke from braziers where pots of rice boiled. There are no sewers or running water anywhere in the neighborhood, and when the rains come, they leave fetid puddles where malaria-carrying mosquitoes breed.
"Aristide said here is the room of the people," said Dorlis Ephesans. "But he has never showed his face here." 
Some of the residents had tried to leave Haiti during the 1991 coup that ousted Mr. Aristide. Some made it to Miami, some died and others, like Israel Arince, were caught at sea and returned.
The same America that sent him back to Haiti and restored Mr. Aristide to power in 1994, Mr. Arince said, now makes life impossible.
"They have blocked the country from getting aid," he said. "We are human beings and we do not like to live like this. Only animals should live here."
In La Saline slum, down a busy road near the prison that is often choked with carts and traffic, pigs waded through streams of human waste and poked their snouts into mountains of garbage in a drainage canal. Young women dropped plastic buckets into a sewer and hauled out a gray water they would use to wash their floors. Potable water is too expensive.
"There is no way to be healthy here," said Elisena Nicolas, who spends a third of her income on water. "But you have to keep the children clean."
As hard as it is to conceive, people come to La Saline to escape rural misery. In the Central Plateau town of Cange, doctors with the Zanmi Lasante clinic said children commonly died from malaria or diarrhea, while tuberculosis and AIDS killed their parents. Even polio, once thought to have been eradicated, has resurfaced recently.
Although the clinic receives no international aid, doctors said they worked with many Haitian government clinics in nearby villages where the frozen aid has left them unable to cope. In recent years, their volunteer clinic's patient load has tripled to 120,000, with patients sometimes walking five hours for free care.
Dr. Paul Farmer, an American who helped found the clinic in the 1980's, said he could not prove that the blocked aid resulted in more suffering, but the deteriorating conditions were evident. International aid, provided on an emergency basis to charitable groups, was no substitute for a working government, he said. 
"One of the world's most powerful countries is taking on one of the most impoverished," he said of the United States decision to withhold aid. "I object to that on moral grounds. Anybody who presides over this blockade needs to know the impact here already."
But Haiti's record of official corruption and mismanagement, regardless of who was in power, has given pause to many international aid officials. A recent study by the World Bank concluded that 15 years of aid through 2001 had had no discernible impact in reducing poverty, since projects were carried out haphazardly and government officials did not sustain improvements. 
Today, for instance, a maze of rat-infested pipes is all that is left of a potable water project after funds ran out before the pipes could be connected to the water main.
At the same time, political opponents and diplomats said, the government has money to provide cars for legislators or pay off neighborhood groups that are its foot soldiers and that, the opposition charges, have been used to intimidate government opponents. 
As a result, diplomats and aid officials said Mr. Aristide must not only resolve his political crisis, he must also show that he will allow economic and administrative reforms to guarantee that any forthcoming aid will be honestly spent. 
"We are saying we want to help you," said a European diplomat, who noted that the European Union was ready to provide $350 million. "But you must help us help you. You comply, I'll comply."
Absent any aid or a political pact, people scrape by as they have for years, sharing what little they have or sacrificing themselves for their children. In the neighborhood of Fort Sinclaire, a dilapidated maze of shacks, indigent teenagers with tuberculosis sleep on sheets spread out on hard concrete porches. 
A soft carpet of soggy wood chips blankets the entrance to the neighborhood, as men carve wooden bowls to sell to tourists who have yet to return to Haiti. Lionel Agustain, a woodworker, sometimes earns two dollars a day, not enough to prevent him from losing his home a few years ago.
A friend lets him sleep on a rickety cot inside a gym where the weights are improvised from gears and other car parts. The walls are tauntingly decorated with wrinkled posters of bodybuilders with bulging chests and biceps. Mr. Agustain is thin, and he sometimes eats only a bowl of rice. 
"We don't know when they are going to fix things," he said. "We suffer. And when you suffer enough, you die."

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Asia: Japan: Industrial Output Declines 

BYLINE:  By Ken Belson (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Output at Japan's factories fell for the first time in five months but was expected to rise the rest of the summer. 
Industrial production declined a larger-than-expected 0.7 percent in June from the previous month, partly a reaction to an unusually large gain in May. The government also expects output to rise 1.6 percent in July and another 1.8 percent in August. Exports of electronics and automobiles to the United States have largely been behind the gains. Ken Belson (NYT)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
From Almost No More To More Than Enough

BYLINE:  By JERE LONGMAN

 BODY:
The Minnesota Twins are not supposed to be alive, much less in first place. Their owner wanted them eliminated last winter, canceled like a bad check. They were destined to become ghosts, shadow remnants of baseball's financial nightmare. Contraction, Commissioner Bud Selig called it, a tidy euphemism, as if he wanted to omit a few letters from a word instead of an entire team with a rich history and two World Series titles.
 A court fight saved the Twins, but only with a guarantee through next season. Resilient on the field, the Twins (64-42) have built an apparently unassailable 14-game lead in the American League Central and may be ready to challenge the Yankees in the playoffs. If there are any playoffs. Given baseball's self-destructive state, the Twins face the real possibility of winning the division and losing any chance of reaching another World Series because of a work stoppage. 
 Celebration of the team's success here has been tempered by disillusionment, anxiety and uncertainty. Attendance has been indifferent this season. The issue of a new stadium remains unresolved. The Twins want out of the dreary Metrodome, into a ballpark with a retractable roof, but ownership recently rebuffed a dalliance from St. Paul, citing the uncertainty of relocation costs. 
The Twins are for sale, but it seems very unlikely that anyone would want to buy them until baseball's labor strife and the stadium issue are settled. Public sentiment seems to be grudgingly in favor of a new stadium, if public spending is held to a reasonable amount, but the future of the team and its location have become wearying in the Twin Cities. 
"This thing keeps rising up like Jason from 'Halloween,' " said Kathy Lantry, a city councilwoman from St. Paul, who opposes spending public money on a baseball stadium. "You think you've killed it and it comes back. You're constantly fighting it."
In the Twins' clubhouse, the mood is one of relief and determination that comes with a second chance, optimism of the nearly condemned. The team endured eight consecutive losing seasons through 2000, then faded from first place after the All-Star Game break in 2001. Many of the players have come up together, agonized through defeat together and now want to succeed together. Few have ever participated in the playoffs, have ever received playoff recognition and playoff money.
All are aware that the franchise might sustain permanent damage from a strike, pointing to the dispiriting example of Montreal, which led the National League East in 1994, missed the postseason because of a work stoppage and nearly became a discarded brother in contraction last winter.
"Montreal was in the same position and never recovered," catcher A. J. Pierzynski said. "We don't want to have to go through that."
Starter Rick Reed, who arrived last summer in a trade with the Mets, added, "It would tear some hearts out of some people's chests in here."
Of course the Twins would join the other 29 major league teams in the event of a strike, said Denny Hocking, the team's player representative. A union has to do what it has to do. But Hocking appears to have no stomach for a walkout. He knows the public is sickened by what it considers as bickering between millionaire players and billionaire owners. The recent encouraging talk from negotiators buoys him.
"It's like working as a postal worker -- you work from Jan. 1 to Dec. 23, and you're going to get your Christmas bonus on Christmas Day and you walk out," Hocking said. "That doesn't make a lot of sense."

Team Is for Real
In more certain times, this is a team that a city could grow to love. They are pleasant, hard-playing guys, and they have gained baseball's biggest division lead despite having one of baseball's smallest payrolls ($41.5 million). Ron Gardenhire, the first-year manager, has kept his players looking ahead toward the postseason, not behind toward teams trying to catch up. The starting pitching has excelled, the bullpen has been dependable, the bats have been pounding and the ability to come from behind has been remarkable. Some players seem to have taken the threat of contraction as a personal affront to their abilities.
"Sooner or later, someone is going to have to say this team is for real and start to recognize that," Hocking said. 
Torii Hunter, the brilliant center fielder, added: "Look at what we went through. We were almost no more."
For years, fans could be counted on for dutiful support. The Twins won the World Series in 1987 and, a season later, became the first American League team to draw three million fans. Another title followed in 1991, and attendance in 1992 reached 2.5 million. This year, winning has actually attracted smaller crowds, at least until 40,300 fans showed up on July 27 and 30,500 on July 28. 
Last Friday, the Minneapolis and St. Paul newspapers both ran front-page stories about the Twins' mediocre attendance. Until this latest homestand, the Twins were averaging a meager 21,668 fans at home -- 23 percent below the major league average of 28,114, and 45 percent below the average of 39,068 drawn to the parks of baseball's other division leaders. Even with a weekend boost, the current average attendance of 22,251 is slightly lower than last season's average. A number of reasons might account for the drop: a downturn in the economy, a pennant race that lacks suspense, an imbalanced schedule, the reluctance of fans to sit indoors during the short summers in Minnesota, constant bad-mouthing of the Metrodome by Twins officials.
"We've been telling the legislature and the public it's a lousy place," Jerry Bell, president of the Twins, said in an interview. "Some people believe it."
Perhaps no other metropolitan area is more sophisticated about the financial realities of modern sports than the Twin Cities. The Minneapolis Lakers of long ago left for Los Angeles, the Minnesota North Stars went to Dallas, the Timberwolves nearly skipped town to New Orleans, the Twins threatened to ship out to North Carolina. The National Basketball Association's $120 million contract was also born here in the paycheck of Timberwolves forward Kevin Garnett.
It is hardly surprising that fans here are dubious about contraction of the Twins, especially given reports that Carl Pohlad, the team owner, stood to receive $150 million, more than his team is reportedly worth in the Metrodome. And public trust was not engendered by the revelation that Selig had once received an undisclosed and, perhaps improper, loan of $3 million for his Milwaukee Brewers from Pohlad in 1995. Local suspicion holds that the Brewers stood to benefit from contraction of the Twins by siphoning its television market and fan base.
Lingering resentment from the threat of past and future contraction was given as a reason for low attendance by a number of fans interviewed July 26 at the Metrodome. "When people say, 'I'm going to pull your team from you,' and it's possible you'll be without a team after next year, do you really want to watch that team play?" said Daran Gaudineer, 37, who drove three hours from Des Moines.

Winning Draws Fans
Neither Pohlad, an octogenarian banker, nor Selig are popular figures here. A Pohlad joke making the rounds: "Did you hear that Carl Pohlad just got a pacemaker? No, I didn't know he had a heart." Local fans seem gleeful that Selig's Brewers have cratered in the National League Central. And Milwaukee has provided yet another example of how a new stadium does not remedy attendance ills if the team is not competitive.
"How will a stadium stave off contraction in the future?" said Sarah Steinhilber of Blaine, Minn. "We could be left paying for an empty stadium."
But, Steinhilber added, she would most likely give reluctant support to a new stadium if it meant keeping the Twins in Minnesota. Many fans seemed to feel that way, with a kind of Norwegian reasonableness, that the Twins are a civic asset and worth keeping, as long as the public did not have to pay an outrageous amount of money.
"The threat of contraction, whether it was real or not, was a wake-up call," said Jay Weiner, a St. Paul journalist and the author of "Stadium Games: Fifty Years of Big League Greed and Bush League Boondoggles (2000, University of Minnesota Press).
Still, several fans, including season-ticket holders, said they would not return if there was a strike and a canceled postseason, as in 1994. "I'd spend my money somewhere else," said John Santoro of Woodbury, Minn. "They'll end up killing themselves."
That is the exact fear voiced by Dave St. Peter, the Twins' senior vice president for business affairs. "I'd have grave concerns about this franchise's ability to continue," he said. "It scares the hell out of me. I can't put it any other way."

Home-Field Advantage
A strike-ruined postseason would provide a great irony along with bitter feelings. As much as the 20-year-old Metrodome is maligned, it provides a tremendous home-field advantage. The Twins are 11-1 in the postseason there. They won all four home games in both the 1987 and the 1991 World Series, taking each in the seventh game. The American League is also scheduled to play four home games in this year's Series.
"The cards are all set up just right," Bell, the Twins' president, said of the Metrodome. "It's a lousy place for the visiting team. They should hate it."
Even if a strike is averted, or resolved before the playoffs, the future of the Twins remains murky. The Metropolitan Sports Facilities Commission, which operates the Metrodome, sued to keep the team in Minnesota, and Major League Baseball settled by agreeing to sustain the team through the 2003 season. Without a new stadium and income from luxury boxes and parking that now goes to the Minnesota Vikings, the Twins have said they cannot survive.
The stadium issue appears headed back to the state legislature in January. A proposed referendum on a bar and restaurant tax to pay for a $330 million ballpark in St. Paul was scuttled two weeks ago. The Twins said they could not make a long-term commitment to St. Paul because the team's share of the stadium bill -- $120 million -- might rise by tens of millions of dollars in still undetermined costs for land acquisition and infrastructure.
A site being discussed now is a warehouse district in downtown Minneapolis. But there is no guarantee for the Twins. The Vikings will also be asking for a new stadium in January. Meanwhile, the state faces a budget deficit, a new governor will be in office and up to a third of the legislators will be freshmen.
"I think, in the long run, we'll probably get a stadium here," said Marshall Tanick, a Minneapolis sports lawyer who has followed the issue closely. "But hazarding a prediction now is like predicting the stock market. The situation is so volatile. Whatever happens, it will go into extra innings."
